column2: Shawn Johnson leads the all-around in the U.S. Women’s Gymnastics Nationals. She’s a favorite to win the all-around at the Beijing Olympics.

Senator Robert C. Byrd, left, Democrat of West Virginia, was released from the hospital after being treated for a mild infection. Mr. Byrd, 90, was admitted Monday night after he began feeling ill at home. He had cast a vote on the Senate floor that day and started running a fever and feeling lethargic. “Senator Byrd will complete the course of his antibiotic treatment as prescribed by his doctors at his home and is expected to return to his official Senate duties upon his doctors’ approval,” said a spokesman, Jesse Jacobs. Mr. Byrd, the longest-serving senator in history, was hospitalized twice earlier this year.
Jason Giambi connected for a two-run homer with two outs in the bottom of the ninth inning, giving the Yankees a 9-8 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays on Thursday.

The military intercepted a ballistic missile in the first such sea-based test since a Navy cruiser shot down an errant satellite this year. The military fired the target, a Scud-like missile with a range of a few hundred miles, from a decommissioned amphibious assault ship near Kauai. The guided-missile cruiser Lake Erie, based at Pearl Harbor, fired two interceptor missiles that shot down the target in its final seconds of flight about 12 miles above the Pacific Ocean. The test showed Navy ships are capable of shooting down short-range targets in their last phase of flight using modified missiles on hand, the military said.

A wildfire that started on a wildlife refuge in eastern North Carolina and burned into privately owned rural land doubled in size as it sent smoke and ash as far away as the Outer Banks and neighboring Virginia. The fire consumed just over 32 square miles of forest and fields at Pocosin Lakes National Wildlife Refuge. About half the fire was burning on the refuge and about half was on private land in Hyde, Tyrrell and Washington Counties, officials said. No injuries were reported and no structures had burned, said Brian Haines, spokesman for the North Carolina Forest Service. The fire started from lightning on Sunday. Evacuation orders were issued for homes in parts of Tyrrell County and for Hyde County. The authorities had asked 39 homeowners around Lake Phelps to leave on Wednesday.

The sportsmanship committee of the Wisconsin Interscholastic Athletic Association recommended banning fans with bare or painted chests from indoor games last month. The proposal will take effect if a committee of state athletic directors approves it next week and the association’s Board of Control approves it on June 19. The proposal does not include outdoor sports, where the weather and social conventions might make it more acceptable, association officials said. Todd Clark, coordinator of the association’s sportsmanship committee, said the idea of banning bare chests had been tossed around for years because some people found such exposure offensive.

The United States marathon record-holder Deena Kastor will compete in the New York Mini 10K road race Saturday to help prepare for the marathon at the Beijing Olympics. Kastor won the bronze medal in the marathon at the 2004 Athens Olympics. On Saturday, she will be joined by her Olympic marathon teammates Magdalena Lewy-Boulet and Blake Russell as favorites in the 37th running of the women’s 6.2-mile race.

Combining his usual strong ball-striking with efficient putting, Boo Weekley shot a five-under-par 65 to take the first-round lead in the Stanford St. Jude Championship in Memphis. He closed with a birdie on No. 18 to move a stroke ahead of Tommy Armour III.

Evander Holyfield’s desire to keep fighting at age 45 may be fueled by financial problems. Holyfield’s $10 million estate in suburban Atlanta is under foreclosure, the mother of one of his children is suing for unpaid child support, and a Utah consulting company has gone to court claiming he failed to pay back more than a half-million dollars for landscaping.

A former grocery clerk must serve six months in federal prison for making bogus Internet postings warning of terrorist attacks against N.F.L. stadiums, a judge ruled Thursday. Jake Brahm must also serve six months under house arrest and repay $26,750 incurred in extra security costs at two of the stadiums. United States District Judge Jose L. Linares said Brahm, 22, conducted a “sick” hoax. Brahm, of Wauwatosa, Wis., entered a guilty plea in February.

The sportsmanship committee of the Wisconsin Interscholastic Athletic Association last month recommended banning fans with bare or painted chests from indoor games. The proposal would take effect if a committee of state athletic directors approves it next week and the association’s Board of Control approves it June 19. “People say, ‘Hey, we are attempting to take the fun out of high school sports.’ That isn’t the intention at all,” said Tom Shafranski, assistant director of the association. Students cannot bare their chests in class, so there is no reason for them to do it at indoor sporting events, he said.

The former N.F.L. linebacker Steve Foley was charged with a felony after his pit bulls bit a woman and killed her puppy in Richmond, Tex. He surrendered at the Fort Bend County Jail on Wednesday and was released on $10,000 bond, a sheriff’s spokeswoman said. Two pit bulls belonging to Foley attacked a neighbor, causing serious injury when they bit her, according to court documents. Foley, 32, played with Cincinnati, Houston and San Diego. His career ended after he was shot by an off-duty police officer in San Diego in 2006. He pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge of drunken driving and was sentenced to five years’ probation.

PERLS--Klaus G. A scholar and a friend, whose wisdom, eye, and integrity guided our work together on the Chaim Soutine catalogue raisonne. As Klaus would invariably toast Soutine: ''To Chaim, L' Chaim.'' To Klaus, we toast the same. Esti Dunow and Maurice Tuchman PERLS--Klaus. The members of the Art Dealers Association of America mourn the loss of one of its founding members and past presidents. A scholar, a collector whose donations made him a public benefactor, a collegial colleague, a strong advocate for the artists whose works he sold, he was a great and respected art dealer. Our sympathy and condolences to his daughter, Katherine. Roland Augustine, Pres. Gilbert S. Edelson, Admin. VP Linda Blumberg, Exec. Dir.

'DRAWING ON FILM' Direct films, which are made by drawing on or scratching into film stock, are an intriguing subset of art cinema. You might think of them as animation, structuralist film or a variant of cameraless photography. A new exhibition at the Drawing Center, a gallery normally given over to works on paper, suggests that direct films are really drawings that speed by at 24 frames a second. In the oldest film in the exhibition, ''A Colour Box'' (1935) by Len Lye, wavy lines sway to a percussive Cuban soundtrack. Grids and checkerboards expand and contract in ''Early Abstractions No. 3: Interwoven'' (1947-49), by the midcentury mystic and folk archivist Harry Smith.

Services will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 1:15 pm, Friday, June 6, 2008.

Bicyclists in New York are known to possess an evangelical fervor. Now another fervor-driven environmentally friendly transportation group is growing up behind them: the scooter obsessives. A surge in gas prices has turned people toward gas-sipping scooters across the country -- even in New York City. The riders were out in force last weekend for a New York Scooter Club block party at the Brass Monkey bar in Manhattan's meatpacking district, with scooters daintily lined up on Little West 12th Street.
Tin Parachutes On Thursday, a Delaware judge unsealed documents related to a shareholder class-action lawsuit filed against Yahoo's board.

BOOTH AND PAT The classic showbiz tale generally has a star getting laryngitis and an understudy getting a big break. For Booth Daniels and Patrick Frankfort, it was more like this: Somebody blew off a gig, so, well, we can't let that empty stage go to waste, can we? Last fall Mr. Frankfort, above left, a singer-songwriter with a comic side, was booked for a solo engagement at the Mean Fiddler on West 47th Street and asked Mr. Daniels, above right, a longtime friend from when both studied musical theater at the Boston Conservatory, to provide some backup vocals. When another act on the bill didn't show up, Mr. Frankfort, 31, and Mr. Daniels, 34, began winging it to fill the time, and the audience seemed to get a kick out of their easy, goofy rapport.

MELAMID--Zev, son of Zippora and Meshulam Melamid, was born in Sadki, Poland on August 21, 1930. He grew up in Israel where he served in the Irgun (Etzel) combat unit and the Israeli army. He earned a BA in Business Administration from NYU. He and his wife of 48 years, Estelle, nee Resnick, established Tower Travel, a tour operator. He was founding President of Tower Air, President of Air America, and in later years worked in international business combining Europe and Asia. Since 1996 he was a member of the Institute for Retired Professionals at the New School. Survived by his wife Estelle, son Elan Melamid, daughter Diana Henderson, son-in-law Stephen B. Henderson, daughter-in-law Amy Berfield and granddaughter Caroline Kati Henderson. Services at ''The Riverside'' at 76th and Amsterdam, at 11:15am on Sunday, June 8th. Donations may be sent to Doctors Without Borders.

WHEN Catherine Chalmers was preparing to film her video ''Safari,'' which documents the journey of a cockroach through a mini-tropical landscape, she turned to animal breeders to buy her exotic cast of creatures, which included a poison dart frog and a pygmy chameleon. Even the cockroach came from a lab. But there was something missing, she felt -- she wanted more bright color. Then she remembered the red-spotted newts that emerged in vivid orange abundance each spring in the woods near her second home in Rensselaerville, N.Y., about 30 miles southwest of Albany. That May, she carried 15 of them in a terrarium on Amtrak into Manhattan for their film debut.

We extend our heartfelt condolences to Carol and Robert, to their son Samuel, and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

It had been almost 30 years since Ana Mojica last saw her half brother, Ruben, on Fordham Road. In the intervening decades, she moved to Reading, Pa., started a family and eventually her own housecleaning business. Comfortable and far away from the Bronx, she still prayed to find her brother. She did not want to be the last of the Mojicas.

'BALLET MÉCANIQUE' The American avant-garde composer George Antheil (above in 1927), the self-proclaimed ''bad boy of music'' who died in 1959, would doubtlessly be thrilled by Saturday's performance of his ''Ballet Mécanique'' by a 25-piece automated orchestra created by the League of Electronic Musical Urban Robots. The score will be played, as originally intended, during a showing of the Dadaist film of the same name. Antheil was living in Paris (where his friends and supporters included Stravinsky, James Joyce, Satie, Dalí and Picasso) when he wrote the score to accompany the film, made by the Cubist painter Fernand Léger. It was written for 16 player pianos, xylophones, percussion and airplane propellers; the composer wrote that it was ''the first piece of music that has been composed out of and for machines, on earth.''

ATLANTIC AVENUE ARTWALK From Harlem to Clinton Hill, the chance to peer into artists' studios is a staple of the New York neighborhood spring calendar. They're do-it-yourself affairs: grab a map, stop where you please, talk to the artist or don't. It's your world now; the artists just work here. And they're fine with that. Or at least Mac Premo is. A 35-year-old collagist and animator (his ''Nature v. Neuron,'' from 2007, is above) who has had gallery shows in Chelsea and Los Angeles, Mr. Premo is among more than 100 artists taking part in this weekend's Atlantic Avenue ArtWalk in Brooklyn, one of the last of the season. (Bushwick Open Studios is the same weekend; see artsinbushwick.org.) This will be his fifth time throwing open the studio he shares with a jewelry maker and a painter, and the idea of hundreds of people tramping through his personal workspace isn't the headache it sounds like. ''For emerging artists, it helps every time you get your art in front of people,'' he said.

EPSTEIN--Michael, a native of Mineola, NY, died June 2 in Zurich, Switzerland, after a lengthy illness. Michael, 50, was a veritable Renaissance man. A professional tennis player in his younger years, he qualified for the US Open and played Davis Cup matches for Switzerland. He was fluent in four languages, was an equally gifted chess player, photographer, music aficionado and gourmet cook. After earning a law degree at the University of Zurich, he was employed by Swissair before moving to the Zurich District Attorney's office, and then establishing a private practice in Zurich. Michael never lost his affinity for his native New York and remained a lifelong fan of the New York Mets. He traveled to the East Coast often to rejuvenate his love for New York, the Mets, and a good kosher deli. He is survived by his wife Simone Fasler Epstein, and a son, Gene Liam Epstein. He was loved by all who knew him.

The American ambassador to Iraq dismissed any suggestion that the Bush administration was maneuvering to set up permanent military bases in Iraq. ''I'm very comfortable saying to you, to the Iraqis, to anyone who asks, that, no indeed, we are not seeking permanent bases, either explicitly or implicitly,'' the ambassador, Ryan C. Crocker, said at a State Department news briefing. He described as ''flatly untrue'' a report in The Independent of London of a secret plan involving 50 permanent American bases in Iraq, American control of Iraqi airspace and legal immunity for American troops and contractors.

'ARCHAEOLOGY ZONE: DISCOVERING TREASURES FROM PLAYGROUNDS TO PALACES' A certain blockbuster movie franchise may have given children a distorted idea of archaeologists' pursuits. ''Archaeology Zone,'' for ages 3 to 10, has no toy bullwhips, crystal skulls or hints of El Dorado. But as a display at the Jewish Museum, it does have artifacts relating to God's covenant (if not the lost ark) and enough intriguing secrets to delight young Indiana Joneses. It even includes -- the staff couldn't resist -- a rakish straw fedora. ''We're really focusing on after the dig,'' said Rachel Katz, who organized the show. ''How do archaeologists analyze artifacts, and what are the objects' stories?''

'THE FRENCH COLLECTION' The French contemporary dance scene is surprisingly different from the American one -- all penury and bare-bones experiment over here; all state financing, props and wild theatricality over there. Or is that just a stereotype? It's hard to know, since only the best-known companies from each country bridge the divide, so three cheers for this cutely titled minifestival, which opens Tuesday. Three companies will each spend a week at the Joyce Theater, beginning with Compagnie Heddy Maalem (above), well known in France and never seen here. Mr. Maalem is French-Algerian, and he has long been interested in Africa as a source of personal identity and creative inspiration. He brings his version of ''The Rite of Spring'' (apparently every choreographer has to have one), inspired by time spent in Lagos, Nigeria, and his dancers come from all over Africa -- all of which speaks to the diverse influences that have percolated into French dance over the last decade.

This 850-square-foot farmhouse, built in the late 1930s, is used as a cottage. The 1.5-acre property, lined with picket fencing, spans two sides of a road. FLEISIG--Sheila, loved and adored by all who knew her as a wife, proud mother and grandma, editor, writer, and educator, athlete and world traveler died Wednesday June 4th, at the age of 75. Graduate of Lincoln High School, and Hunter College, she prided herself working for EDL, as a creator of educational stories for children using a system of ''controlled readers vocabulary'', which eventually were produced and shown on TV as tools to educate children in the proper use of the English language. Her claim to fame was that there was never a crossword puzzle she could not complete, miss a Jeopardy or other Quiz Program, where she was quicker and more proficient with responses than the contestants. She lived to her fullest and enjoyed the closeness of her family and all her dearest friends. We will all miss her sharp mind and humor, her smile and gentle being. God rest her soul. The funeral will be at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY 11979 at noon on Friday, June 6, 2008. (516)921-5757.

(Sundance) OLD JOY (2006) Two slackers in their 40s, the free-spirited Kurt (Will Oldham) and the soon-to-be-a-father Mark (Daniel London, above top, with Mr. Oldham), go camping in the mountains of Oregon to try to recapture their friendship, whose disintegration has filled them each with sorrow -- or, as Kurt says, ''nothing but worn-out joy.'' Kelly Reichardt directed this film about memory and loss based on a short story by Jonathan Raymond, who wrote the screenplay with Ms. Reichardt. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis called the movie ''a triumph of modesty and of seriousness that also happens to be one of the finest American films of the year.'' 8 P.M. HYDE--Arthur Dwight, Jr., of Desert Mountain, Arizona died on May 15 at age 78 from Leukemia. The son of Arthur Dwight Hyde and Josephine Maclay Hyde, he was graduated from Blake School, Hopkins, MN where he was the senior class President and Williams Trophy winner. He was graduated from Harvard University, where he was a 1951 class Marshall and Francis H. Burr Award winner, and from Harvard Business School. He began his career at White, Weld & Co. in New York City in 1956 and ended it as the Global Chief Investment Officer for Citibank NA in 1999. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, Carrol Thomas Hyde, a daughter, Dr. Josephine A., of Chicago, IL, three sons, Arthur Dwight III and Jacob M. R. of Bronxville, NY, and Thomas L. of Darien, CT, as well as 11 grandchildren. He is also survived by a brother, Maclay R., of Minneapolis, and a sister, Roxbury M. Crystal of Longmont, CO.

It looks as if every horse in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday is a descendant of Native Dancer. The "Gray Ghost of Sagamore," who won every race he ever ran in except the 1953 Kentucky Derby -- a race he lost by a narrowing head -- was bred and owned by my father, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt Jr. If it proves to be true, this will be the first time that any thoroughbred has had his bloodline in every horse that ran in every race of the Triple Crown series. Only the Godolphin Arabian, Darly Arabian and Byerley Turk, the foundation sires of the breed, are said to have done the same.

Horses don't like heat. They evolved in cool, even sub-arctic climates and are generally poorly-suited to deal with hot, humid weather. Heat makes horses sweat. Horses dissipate 75 percent of excess heat by sweating. The remainder of the heat is blown off by respiration. High humidity reduces the horse's ability to dissipate heat by sweating, making it more difficult to keep the body temperature normal.

Saturday will undoubtedly be the biggest betting day of the year in New York racing. There will, it seems, be no rematch for Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Oscar De La Hoya. Mayweather retired Friday, saying in a statement that “these past few years have been extremely difficult for me to find the desire and joy to continue in the sport.” Mayweather (39-0), the W.B.C. welterweight champion, said he had talked about retiring over the last two years, but subsequently rekindled his passion to compete. Now, “after many sleepless nights and intense soul-searching, I realized I could no longer base my decision on anything but my own personal happiness, which I no longer could find.”.

Miriam Makeba, below, has canceled two American concerts this month because of a fall she sustained last week. The dates included the Detroit Festival of the Arts on Sunday and Celebrate Brooklyn on June 14. Ms. Makeba will be replaced at the Brooklyn show by Sibongile Khumalo, another South African singer. ... Playwrights Horizons has announced two new plays for its 2008-9 season. “The Savannah Disputation” by Evan Smith, to be directed by Walter Bobbie (“Chicago”), will feature Dana Ivey; and “Inked Baby” by Christina Anderson is a world premiere for the play and an Off Broadway debut for the writer. The theater company also announced that Michael Mayer (“Spring Awakening”) will direct the previously announced Theresa Rebeck satire “Our House”; Maura Tierney (“ER”) will star in Nicky Silver’s play “Three Changes”; and Jonathan Groff will join “Prayer for My Enemy.”.

The Australian police have dropped their investigation into the work of Bill Henson, whose photographs of naked children caused controversy after the authorities shut down an exhibition in Sydney last month, Bloomberg News reported. The New South Wales state police said in a statement on Friday that “there is no reasonable prospect for a successful conviction.” Mr. Henson’s images captured headlines after officers shut down the exhibition, saying they had received complaints. Australia’s prime minister, Kevin Rudd, called the photos “absolutely revolting,” while more than 40 prominent people in the arts, including the actress Cate Blanchett, signed an open letter in support of Mr. Henson. The artist said in a statement that it had been “profoundly humbling to witness the depth of support” for his work in the last few weeks. “It is reassuring to see existing laws, having been rigorously tested, still provide a framework in which debate and expression of ideas can occur,” he added.

The 26th Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music will open on Sept. 30 with the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, as part of a season packed with dance, the academy announced. The troupe, above in rehearsal with Mr. Jones, will perform the New York premiere of “A Quarreling Pair,” based on a puppet play by Jane Bowles. Other dance presentations include La La La Human Steps, from Montreal; the French nouveau cirque group Compagnie 111; and return engagements from two Brooklyn Academy regulars, Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker and Pina Bausch. The Vesturport Theater of Iceland will offer a new production of Georg Büchner’s “Woyzeck” with music by Nick Cave and Warren Ellis, and Ivo van Hove brings his Toneelgroep Amsterdam for a stage adaptation of John Cassavetes’s 1977 film “Opening Night.” Music bookings include “Red Hot + Rio 2,” a two-night Brazilian concert with Bebel Gilberto, José González, Céu and others; the avant-garde string quartet Ethel; “Arjuna’s Dilemma,” a chamber opera based on the Bhagavad-Gita by the New York composer Douglas J. Cuomo; and a multimedia interpretation of Emily Dickinson’s poems by the Bang on a Can composer Michael Gordon, with the Ridge Theater and the filmmaker Bill Morrison. Information and tickets: (718) 636-4100, bam.org.

Adam Sandler’s production company, Happy Madison, is branching into thrillers with a new division called Scary Madison, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The division’s first picture is “Shortcut,” about two brothers who find a neglected — and presumably frightening — route in their town. Not counting Happy Madison’s latest movie, “You Don’t Mess With the Zohan,” which stars Mr. Sandler and opened on Friday, the company has produced 18 films that have grossed more than $1.1 billion in ticket sales, according to Baseline, an entertainment database. ... Columbia Pictures and CBS Films will make a new version of “My Fair Lady,” the classic Lerner and Loewe musical, the companies announced on Friday. It will be produced by Duncan Kenworthy (“Four Weddings and a Funeral”) and Cameron Mackintosh (“Cats,” “Les Misérables”), who said in a statement that they would use the songs from the original Broadway show and shoot part of the film on location in London. Variety reported that the studios were in discussions with Keira Knightley to play Eliza Doolittle, but a Columbia spokesman declined to comment on casting.

Vladimir Voronin, the president of Moldova, made a wonderful announcement on Friday, saying that two paintings stolen from the State Hermitage Museum in Russia had been found in Moldova and would soon be returned, The Associated Press reported. There’s just one problem: He did not say what the works were, and the Hermitage’s press office said it had no idea what paintings he was talking about. In Russia for talks with President Dmitri A. Medvedev, Mr. Voronin said the paintings had been recovered three days earlier after a long police investigation. The Interior Ministry of Moldova said that the investigation was under way and that details would not be revealed until Tuesday, but the Russian news service Itar-Tass, citing an unidentified law enforcement source in Moldova, said the paintings were believed to be by the 19th-century landscape artist Vasily Polenov and the Soviet-era social realist Boris Ioganson. The Hermitage, in St. Petersburg, said in July 2006 that 221 items had been stolen, but did not report any missing paintings.

The debut of the CBS drama “Swingtown” attracted moderate interest on Thursday, delivering an audience of 8.6 million viewers at 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. The new series, set among suburban libertines in the 1970s, has drawn scrutiny for its depictions of sex and drug use. Among adults 18 to 49, it was far from the night’s highest-rated show, but “Swingtown” did improve on CBS’s performance in that demographic earlier in the night. In the 8 and 9 p.m. time slots, the network broadcast two repeats of “CSI,” which, despite low ratings among the 18-to-49 set, fared well in total viewers, with 8.2 million and 9.4 million respectively. CBS ranked third for the night over all, just behind Fox and its two-hour installment of “So You Think You Can Dance” from 8 to 10 (9.1 million). ABC led over all with live coverage of the first game of the N.B.A. finals, which averaged approximately 10 million viewers from 9 to 11.

SPERLING--Irving Leslie, M.D. , died June 4th, 2008 at age 93. Rheumatologist and WWII veteran, survived by wife Lillian, siblings Sandra and Seymour, children and grandchildren. Memorial service at Winchester Gardens, 333 Elmwood Ave., Maplewood, NJ, June 8, 11:30am.

7 P.M. (TCM) PRIVATE SCREENINGS: LESLIE CARON (1999) Turner Classic Movies heralds the ''funny face'' -- and terrific legs -- of Ms. Caron, starting with this hourlong special in which she discusses her career with Robert Osborne. A four-film tribute follows, starting with ''Fanny'' (1961), a romance about a sailor (Horst Buchholz) who reunites with his lover (Ms. Caron) and the son he has never met. Maurice Chevalier plays Panisse, the older suitor who has married Fanny to save her reputation but is now dying. In ''Father Goose'' (1964), at 10:30, Cary Grant (with Ms. Caron above) plays a World War II beach bum in the South Pacific who finds himself protecting a beautiful French teacher (Ms. Caron) and her charges on the run from the Japanese. ''The L-Shaped Room'' (1962), at 12:30 a.m., finds Ms. Caron portraying a pregnant and unwed Frenchwoman trying to build a new life in a low-rent London boarding house. And in ''An American in Paris'' (1951), she trips the light fantastic alongside the man who discovered her: Gene Kelly. 8 P.M. (CBS) SYBIL (2008) Tammy Blanchard stars as the woman with 16 personalities whose name became synonymous with dissociative identity disorder in this adaptation of the book by Flora Rheta Schreiber. Jessica Lange is Dr. Cornelia Wilbur, the psychiatrist who begins to treat Sybil after she attempts suicide. And JoBeth Williams is Hattie, the mentally disturbed mother whose physical, emotional and sexual abuse caused Sybil to develop separate personalities, each distinct in age and appearance, to cope with the cruelty she endured as a child.

ELALOUF--Simy . Beloved wife of the late Salomon. Beloved mother of Huguette (Larry), Liliane (Ruben), Laurette (Richard) and Sion (Diane). Grandmother of ten, great-grandmother of twenty-two. Passed away Friday June 6, 2008 at the age of 94. She will be remembered for her beauty, strength and love for her family's Judaism. She will be in our hearts forever. Services are Sunday 9am at ''Guttermans Funeral Home'' 98-60 Queens Blvd. (Parkside building) Forest Hills, NY corner of 66th Ave.

BECKHARDT--Clare , died peacefully on June 5, 2008 after a long illness at the age of 77. Beloved wife of Fred, sister of George and Nancy, loving mother of Seth and Meredith and Laurence and Aimee, adoring grandmother of Molly, Deanna, Layla and Joshua. A dedicated environmentalist and builder of parks in NYC. As Regional Director of the NYS Office of Parks and Recreation, she was responsible for the creation of Riverbank State Park in Manhattan, Empire-Fulton Ferry State Park in Brooklyn, and the Clay Pit State Park and Nature Preserve on Staten Island. She was an outgoing person who will be missed by all. Contributions in her memory may be made to the NYC Council on the Environment or High School of Environmental Studies. Service Sunday 2:15pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel on West 76th St. and Amsterdam.

MALBIN--Dorothy . Prede ceased by her loving husband of 51 years Ernest Mabin; dedicated mother to three daughters; Karen, Joanne and Linda; and devoted grandmother to seven grandchildren. Appreciated by many for her gracious hospitality, commitment to Judaism, and as a source of strength for many in need. Dorothy sustained a large but close knit group of true friends and family. Services will be held on Sunday at 10am at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY 516-487-9600

Survived by his wife Jane, brother Joel, children David, Brad, Lauren Primoff, Ellen Blasi and four grandchildren.
RAPTOPOULOS--Kit . Loving sister of Bette. Her forty day memorial will be held on Sunday, June 8, 2008 at 10am at St. Spyridon Greek Orthodox Church, 179th Street and Wadsworth Avenue, NYC.

LETTERI--Dr. Joseph Michael , on June 1, 2008 of Sands Point, NY. Loving husband of Mary. Dear father of Jeffrey J., and Marisa McCusker. Devoted grandfather of John, Austin and Meagan. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Mahassett, NY, Saturday and Sunday 3-5 and 79pm. Funeral Mass Monday 10am, St. Peter of Alcantara R.C. Church. For much of baseball, an important factor in the draft is a player's willingness to sign. Of course, the Yankees do not operate like most of their peers, generally ignoring the bonus recommendations of the commissioner's office. So when a highly regarded high school right-hander, Gerrit Cole, fell to them with the 28th overall pick Thursday, the Yankees pounced. Their vision of Cole's 98-mile-an-hour fastball outweighed any dread of negotiating with the agent Scott Boras.

STREULI--Christian Daniel , passed away on Sunday, June 1, following a traumatic injury suffered earlier in the weekend. Chris was born June 5, 1961 in Zurich, Switzerland and raised in Bronxville, NY. Beloved husband of Therese for 16 years; devoted father of Allison, Christian, Jr. and Caroline; dear son of Huguette F. and the late Fritz H. Streuli; brother of Nicolas (Dianne) and Michel (Elsa); uncle of Chad, Elaine, Julia and Andreas. Interment Bronswood Cemetery, Oak Brook, IL. In lieu of flowers, memorials will be appreciated for the Streuli Children Education Fund, World Vision and Doctors Without Borders. Info. www.ahlgrim.com or 630-834-3515.

ZWAIK--Anne Lehman , died June 5 at 89 years old. Adored wife of Stanley N. Zwaik (deceased). Anne was a loving mother, grandmother, sisterin-law and aunt. Her greatest joy was to be surrounded by her beloved daughters, Judith (David) Tarlo and Stephanie (Dan Powers) Greenberg and grandchildren Howard (Toni) and Joseph (Maggie Williams), Andrew (Danielle) and Dori. A graduate of Hunter College, Anne was accomplished in her work for the U.S. Department of the Navy and as an elementary school teacher. Her happiest times were when she stepped aside so those she loved could shine brightly. She left us with dignity and eternal love. Since December 2006, Anne lived at the Hebrew Home in Riverdale where she was surrounded by love and caring hands for which her family will be forever grateful. Funeral services will be held 11:30am Sunday June 8 at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Donations in Anne's name may be sent to The Hebrew Home, Development Office, 5901 Palisade Ave., Riverdale, NY 10471 1/3

RAFEL--Ellen . Surrounded by family and friends, Ellen Rafel, 63, passed away on June 5, 2008. Serving children of NYC's Public Schools for over three decades, she was chosen by her peers ''Guidance Counselor of the Year'' three times. Paraphrasing Ted Kennedy, to Ellen love meant having a social conscience and battling the wrongs which needed our attention. Each time we act to improve the life of others, or strike out against injustice, we send forth a tiny ripple of hope. Ellen sent out lots of ripples. She was a good and decent woman, who saw wrong and tried to right it, saw suffering and tried to heal it. She will be remembered by her husband, Erwin Rafel-Frankel; sons, Gideon and Saul; sister, Judy Englander; nieces, Freya and Emily; grandnephew and niece, Nathan and Ruby and dear family and friends. Funeral services will take place Sunday, June 8, 10am at Temple Anshe Chesed, West End Avenue and 100th Street. May her memory, like her life be for a blessing.

COGUT--Edgar W. , in his 95th year. Beloved husband of the late Peppy and the late Betty; devoted companion of Iris Rothstein; loving father of Nancy and Michael Cardozo and Casey and Ellen Cogut; cherished grandfather of Hedy and Michael, Sheryl, Pamela and Rachel; adored Big Pa of Lucy and Joshua; loyal brother of Justin; dear friend of many. He will be missed by all who knew him. Services June 8 at 11am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Parker Jewish Institute for Health Care, the American Jewish Committee or a charity of your choice.

Readers who responded to my column lampooning the University of Colorado's plan to raise $9 million for a chair in conservative thought aggressively reopened a question I took up in several columns written in 2006. The question, provoked by the fact that according to a survey only 2 or 3 percent of the C.U. faculty identifies as Republican, is, what is the relationship between the political affiliations of a faculty member and his or her classroom performance? And the answer I gave, and would still give, is none, necessarily.I would never deny that there are some college and university teachers who mistake the classroom lectern for a political platform and thereby substitute indoctrination for instruction. But, I argue, this need not happen -- it is not an inevitable consequence either of our fallible natures or of certain subject matters -- and when it does happen, it should be labeled as wrong and regarded as a reason for discipline by the school's administration.

Nice day for a car show if you brought along a change of clothes, but a perfect day for a drive, preferably with the top down. The New England Patriots said that Nick Kaczur, an offensive lineman charged with drug possession, would remain on the team. But the Patriots had no comment on disciplinary action it might take. Kaczur was arrested April 27 after the police said a small amount of OxyContin was found in his truck after a traffic stop. Kaczur helped the federal authorities catch the man he said was supplying him with the drug, 35-year-old Daniel Ekasala, who is free on bail after pleading not guilty.

Tim Clark broke a logjam at the Stanford St. Jude Championship in Memphis and grabbed the lead for himself. He leads by two strokes as he looks for his first PGA Tour victory.

An article on April 20, adapted from the book “The Big Squeeze: Tough Times for the American Worker,” referred imprecisely to the Internal Revenue Service’s treatment of FedEx Ground, the delivery business, over the way it classifies truck operators. The I.R.S. preliminarily assessed FedEx $319 million in taxes and penalties, plus interest, for 2002 over its classification of truck operators as independent contractors rather than employees; the I.R.S. did not order it to pay $319 million. As the article noted, the I.R.S. told FedEx that it could face similar charges for subsequent years.

As someone who got nastily zinged by Emily Gould on Gawker (for my “oversharing” in the pages of The New York Times, no less), I particularly appreciated — and enjoyed — her brave personal essay (May 25). Above all, it was helpful to gain insight into some of the motivations behind the increasingly vicious blog world, courtesy of one of its former mean girls. Gould’s was just the kind of confessional piece she might have had a field day eviscerating in her days as a Gawker editor. It’s nice to see that she’s at least somewhat reformed, even if she lost some of her smugness only as a result of painful karmic retribution, apparently turned around at an accelerated rate on the Internet.

For families who would like to explore the 18th-century history of the United States while on vacation — and not go broke in the process — there is the Summer Saver package at the official Colonial Williamsburg hotel, the Woodlands Hotel and Suites (www.colonialwilliamsburg.com). For families of four (two adults and two children under 18) who stay through Aug. 28, the package costs $600 (plus tax) and includes four nights of accommodations with daily breakfast; unlimited access to the historic area, including all exhibit sites; a new street theater production, “Revolutionary City,” above; and indoor museums like the DeWitt Wallace Decorative Arts Museum and the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Folk Art Museum. Participants will also receive free parking, a 50 percent discount on Colonial Evening Program tickets and a $200 resort credit, which can be applied toward meals in 10 restaurants or taverns, golf at the Golden Horseshoe Golf Club or services at the spa. Participants must check in on Sunday or Monday. The number for reservations is (800) 447-8679. The package is based on availability.

Politicos concerned about carbon emissions will have the opportunity to make a statement — and get some exercise — during the Democratic and Republican conventions held in Denver this August and in Minneapolis-St. Paul this September. Freewheelin, a bike-sharing program based in Louisville with about 2,500 registered users, recently started an initiative to provide about 1,000 bicycles for free use at both conventions. The brainchild of Humana, a health benefits company, and Bikes Belong, a cycling advocacy organization, Freewheelin is currently in discussions to expand the program to other cities, and plans to leave behind about 70 bicycles in both Denver and Minneapolis-St. Paul for public use after the conventions.

To the Editor: Your “36 Hours: Liverpool” (May 11) column suggests that to reach Liverpool, “it is easier to fly into Heathrow Airport in London” and then make two rail connections. Travelers seeking a simpler route and wishing to avoid the horrors of Heathrow might prefer to fly into Manchester, less than 30 miles from Liverpool. Daily nonstop flights on several airlines link this major Midlands city with Atlanta, Chicago, New York and Newark.

STREULI--Christian Daniel, passed away on Sunday, June 1, following a traumatic injury suffered earlier in the weekend. Chris was born June 5, 1961 in Zurich, Switzerland and raised in Bronxville, NY. Beloved husband of Therese for 16 years; devoted father of Allison, Christian, Jr. and Caroline; dear son of Huguette F. and the late Fritz H. Streuli; brother of Nicolas (Dianne) and Michel (Elsa); uncle of Chad, Elaine, Julia and Andreas. Interment Bronswood Cemetery, Oak Brook, IL. In lieu of flowers, memorials will be appreciated for the Streuli Children Education Fund, World Vision and Doctors Without Borders. Info. www.ahlgrim.com or 630-834-3515.

In the movie ''An American Crime,'' presented on Showtime, terrible things are done to the young actress Ellen Page, and as unlikely as it seems, Catherine Keener plays her tormentor. Ms. Keener portrays Gertrude Baniszewski, the laundress at the center of a true-crime story of child abuse and murder in 1960s Indiana, and she presents Gertrude as someone who sees her sadism as a right, a sword against her litany of misfortunes. The complexity of Ms. Keener's performance is in a fragility that avoids any invitation to sympathy. She plays to the power of her character's self-delusion, making it, in the end, as perverse as anything Gertrude has done.
RIDING Anne Kursinski

LAST week, when the principal pro-Israel lobby, the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, met in Washington, two of the many speakers were the presumptive nominees for president -- John McCain, Republican, on Tuesday; Barack Obama, Democrat, on Wednesday. While their approaches to the Middle East differ substantially, their comments before this forum observed something of a common ritual -- touching a series of points, intended to reassure Israel and its American supporters that their unshakable commitment was in no doubt, though their opponents' steadfastness or judgment might be. Here are excerpts from that election year ritual.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended May 24, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount and department stores; and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. It is a blasphemous game to home in on any single performance on ''The Wire'' and herald it as superior to some other, but Isiah Whitlock Jr.'s portrayal of Clay Davis during the show's final season got to the core of some of the series's most trenchant observations: specifically the near impossibility of battling urban corruption in the face of the flash and showmanship that keep its engines going. Testifying to a jury on charges of financial impropriety, Davis, a Maryland state senator, offers a mock-Capraesque speech about his politics of the soul, one that, heck, can't always easily accommodate traditional ideas about ethics. As he explains it, he's not pocketing anything, he's just taking from the haves so that he can give to the have-nots. Mr. Whitlock makes the speech swell with a mesmerizing, vaudevillian phoniness. Had he done nothing else of any merit in the show's previous seasons, he would have earned his Emmy then.
Because of an editing error, the Evening Hours column last Sunday misstated the amount raised by the Jazz at Lincoln Center concert and dinner on May 28. It was $1.4 million, not $4 million.

As Doris Duke's butler, fellow masochist and confidante in the HBO film ''Bernard and Doris,'' Ralph Fiennes sings ''I Love the Way You're Breaking My Heart'' Peggy Lee style: as if he had lived every word. The film, directed by Bob Balaban, imagines the specifics of the relationship between the tobacco heiress (portrayed by Susan Sarandon) and a man named Bernard Lafferty, the Irish alcoholic she hired to oversee the polishing of the silver and serve as a paid friend after the previous gentleman who had held the position made the career-ending mistake of serving her cantaloupe too cold. Mr. Fiennes plays a repressed gay man, as awed by his good fortune as he is a slave to his debilitating habit, someone inclined to recede but desperate to assume his place. And Mr. Fiennes makes the suffering and shame apparent in every tilt of his character's head.

In HBO's drama about a psychotherapist, played by Gabriel Byrne, several addictive story lines were offered -- each half hour was devoted to a different patient -- but who was more addictive than Sophie? Mia Wasikowska, an unknown 18-year-old actress playing a gymnast sabotaging her efforts to reach the Olympics, brought to her character an exquisite balance of rage and reason. She delivered the consummate woman-child: vulnerable, primal, audacious. And she made Sophie's growth as real as her compelling sense of denial. Her chemistry with Mr. Byrne wavered not a nanosecond in its intensity, and her scenes with Peter Horton (playing her slacker father in an episode) were sublime.
GYMNASTICS David Durante

Jean Smart has aged well. She doesn't just look good; as an actress she's gotten better and funnier. Nearly every time she has appeared on television in the past few years, you have wanted her to sit tight and stay. As Martha Logan, wife of the weasely, Nixonian commander in chief during the fifth season of ''24'' (and his ex, briefly and brilliantly this past season), she gave us torment and grievance and righteous fury. As Regina Newly, mother to Christina Applegate's recovering amnesiac on the ABC comedy, ''Samantha Who?,'' she makes narcissism seem like parental entitlement and disdain a joy for whoever is looking. Regina has little use for her daughter's search for selfhood -- she regarded the coma that had caused her forgetfulness as an opportunity to pitch the family's woeful fortunes to a home-makeover show -- and Ms. Smart brings a restrained relish to every second of the insanity.

While you're browsing the aisles of your local bookstore, someone is reading you. Bookstore clerks are the quiet gatekeepers of literature -- they know what you like, and they hear how you ask for it. The illustrator Leanne Shapton recently went behind the counters of some of her favorite independent bookshops in New York to ask a few questions: Have you ever kicked anyone out? Do you correct customers' pronunciation? What's the strangest thing anyone has left behind? ''I hear people talking on their cellphones. They call and say, 'Hey, I'm in Housing Works Bookstore. You free for a drink?' It seems to be a place people want to call from to show that they're cool.''
Television Mike Hale

THE writing crew of the CBS sitcom ''How I Met Your Mother'' once had a light saber battle in the dark. There haven't been many other accessories in their room, except for a massage chair that was originally in the ''Friends'' writing room, said Craig Thomas, a creator and executive producer of the series. ''We like to stay as focused as we can,'' he said. ''We all have personal lives that we like.'' Not that there has been much time for goofing off. Mr. Thomas likens the post-writers'-strike intensity required to crank out 9 episodes in 10 weeks to the Discovery Channel crab-fishing series ''Deadliest Catch'': ''It feels like a writers' room. It's these guys stuck in this nasty boat, and they have to do the job.''

JUNE 1988: Twenty years ago this week, Gabriel García Márquez, Tom Wolfe, Elmore Leonard and Michael Chabon had books on the hardcover fiction list. The nonfiction side had memoirs by two Reagan administration veterans (the former chief of staff Donald T. Regan and the former White House spokesman Larry Speakes) as well as a forward-looking volume by Richard Nixon. The book at No. 3 on the nonfiction list, Michael Jackson's ''Moonwalk,'' was written about here by Ken Tucker, whose review began this way: '''What can one say about Michael Jackson,' asks his editor, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, in her introduction to this autobiography by the world's most famous living pop star. Since Mrs. Onassis' introduction takes up all of one short paragraph, the implied answer would seem to be 'Not much,' and indeed the same question seems to have stumped the book's author, who fills pages with drab show-biz clichés and aimless anecdotes.'' Here are all of the fiction and nonfiction best sellers for June 5, 1988:

She was young and she was beautiful and she was 18 years old. Her name was Elinor Moses and she was the daughter of a Los Angeles business tycoon. Her long-ago scrapbook -- titled ''Stunt Book'' -- is a marvel: visually eclectic, at once somber and goofy, an extraordinary time capsule.

''Dexter,'' the Showtime series based on the novels of Jeff Lindsay, rose to the ranks of greatness during its second season, largely by deploying the flexible muscles of Michael C. Hall. Playing the show's title hero -- a serial killer who only gets rid of the whack jobs who are more depraved than he is -- Mr. Hall took us down every byway of Dexter's accidental leap into self-actualization, embracing the character as though he loved him like some crazy, ingenious, fanatical blood relative. Confronted with the possibility of getting caught, Dexter reckons with his avocation, deciding in the end that civic serial killing really is for him. Mr. Hall made Dexter believable both as a moralist and a newfound hedonist, bringing to his attendant sexual awakening the sudden virility of a libidinous teenager. Yet still he never let us forget what a repressed guy Dexter was, while keeping his character's arsonist girlfriend always wanting more.

Brett Myers, the Phillies' closer in 2007, might have completed the conversion back to productive starter. In his last two outings, he struck out 11 Marlins in a victory over Florida, and took a no-hitter into the seventh against the Reds. But Myers, right, will be challenged this week when he makes two starts on the road, where he has a 7.15 earned run average. He has yet to win this season away from Citizens Bank Park. The Tigers' bullpen, which has the second worst E.R.A. in the American League, may have some relief on the horizon. Joel Zumaya and Fernando Rodney have begun rehabilitation stints. Zumaya's fastball hit 100 miles an hour on the radar gun last week in a Class A game. Rodney hit 94, and his changeup was impressive at Class AAA. Both could return to Detroit this month.

BECKER--Robert O., M.D., May 14, 2008. Among the world's great research scientists. Inspirational colleague, mentor, clinician, gentleman, environmentalist. Dr. Becker defined the science of bioelectricity, laying the groundwork for discoveries in stem cells, genetics, cloning, silver ion therapy, oncology, immunology, wound healing, bone fusion, and limb regeneration. He blew the whistle on the health/environmental effects of man-made electromagnetic fields, challenged the status quo, paid dearly, but remained undiminished. His moral compass was true, his vision clear, his work of incalculable value. A once-in-acentury visionary. Andrew Marino, Ph.D., J.D., Louisiana State U. Medical Center Joseph A. Spadaro Ph.D., Upstate Medical U. (S.U.N.Y.) Bruce R. McLeod, Ph.D. Montana State U. Arthur Bartholomew Flick, M.D. University of Georgia A.R. Liboff, Ph.D., Florida Altantic U. Reba Goodman, Ph.D., Columbia U. Stephen D. Smith, Ph.D, University of Kentucky B. Blake Levitt, Author

Let us now praise the malevolent side of Ted Danson, suppressed for far too long beneath all that jovial affability. As Arthur Frobisher, a venal executive on the FX legal thriller, he hung up Sam Malone's jacket along with the sense that the worst characteristic we might attribute to him would be rampant womanizing. In ''Damages'' Mr. Danson summoned a whole universe of inequity, showing us that he could disregard the little people just as callously as those evildoers at Enron. He has always been a master of the smug smile and entitled gesture, but here he made his every movement predatory. In Frobisher's encounters with working people he bilked, Mr. Danson perfected a cruel style of patronizing that passes itself off as earnest ingratiation. His comportment alone -- the mere way he carried himself in a pair of jeans -- could ignite 100 class wars.

LINDSAY--Nancy Dalley, on June 7th after a long and courageous battle with a pituitary tumor. Beloved wife for 58 years of Robert V. Lindsay, mother of Cameron Lindsay of Denver, Colorado, Tinker Lindsay of Hollywood, California and Robert D. and daughter-in-law Teresa Lindsay of Locust Valley, New York. Grandmother of Thomas and Dorothy Beatty, Jonathan and Andrew Warkentin, and Robert T., James, Alexander and Duncan Lindsay. Mrs. Lindsay was born in New York City and attended the Lenox School, Greenwood School and Vassar College. A noted breeder and judge of dogs, she filled judging assignments on three continents, including judge of Best in Show at the Westminster Kennel Club show. Mrs. Lindsay was a founding trustee of the American Kennel Club Museum of the Dog in Saint Louis, Missouri. She also is a past trustee of the Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge Foundation and served on the boards of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, the Cooper Union, the Animal Medical Center, the ASPCA, the Westminster Kennel Foundation, the East Woods School and the Dutchess Day School. She served as chairman of the Women's Committee of the American Museum of Natural History, and in 1976 as Vice-Chairman in London of the U.S. Bicentennial Committee which brought together collections of American Indian art and artifacts from world-wide sources for a London exposition in honor of the Bicentennial. A memorial service will be held Friday, June 13 at 11am, at St. Peter's Church on Deep Hollow Road in Millbrook NY. (Lithgow). In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Hospice, Inc. Dutchess County, 374 Violet Avenue, Poughkeepsie NY, 12601.

MEYERSON--Monroe R., born August 23, 1930, to Harry and Beatrice Meyerson in Brooklyn, NY, died June 6, 2008, in Boca Raton, FL. He leaves behind his beloved wife of 53 Years, Leila Mann Meyerson, his children, Cindie (Dr. Donald) Kastenbaum, David Meyerson, and Stuart (Lisa) Meyerson, and five wonderful grandchildren: Julie, Harry, Jessica, Samuel and Benjamin. He attended Poly Prep Day School where he achieved a football scholarship to the University of NC/Chapel Hill. He graduated from New York University with a degree in engineering and economics and later obtained an MBA from the Trinity School at NYU. As a graduate of ROTC, he became a pilot in the Air Force and was honorably discharged in 1955. He began his career as project manager at Centrig Industries, a small familyoperated construction company in NYC in 1956, and during his 35 year tenure as its Chairman and CEO, grew the company into an internationally recognized leader in heavy industrial construction and a world leader in the installation of newspaper presses, including The New York Times, Chicago Tribune, Miami Herald, San Fransisco Chronicle, Charlotte Observer, and the Washingon Post. As a result of having been a dialysis patient in 1992, Mr. Meyerson founded the Dialysis Centers of America (DCA) in 1995 with a strong commitment to improving the quality of care, treatment and outcomes for dialysis patients. Within three years, DCA grew from a single location to the largest kidney dialysis treatment in the Midwest. DCA'a greatest accomplishment was in the development of renal care informatics which became the ''golden rule'' adopted by the dialysis industry. In 1998, Mr. Meyerson founded the Radiology Corporation of America (RCOA), an innovator and early adopter of Positron Emission Tomography (PET), a new molecular imaging technology that improved the diagnosis and treatment of many diseases, including the early detection of cancer and Alzheimer's Disease. Mr. Meyerson was also instrumental in founding the Institute of Molecular Technology, a trade association which educated the medical community about the benefits of PET technology which led to the acceptance of reimbursement protocols under Medicare. As a result of his daughter's juvenile diabetes in 1967, Mr. Meyerson was a co-founder and the inspiration for the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation (JDF), both the New York chapter and the national organization, where he served as a Board member for many years. In addition, Mr. Meyerson was aformer Director of Gatekeeper Solutions, the Whitney Art Museum, Dance Theater of Harlem, Boca Rio Country Club, and a member of Chief Executives Organization, World Presidents' Organization and Young Presidents' Organization. He was a renaissance man involved in Arts and Theatre and his philanthropic endeavors included support of Technion University, Kravis Center for the Performing Arts, Broward Center for the Performing Arts, University of Minnesota, American Parkinson's Disease Foundation, among many others. Mr. Meyerson was an avid art collector of photorealism and supported many young artists. He generously donated art to both the St. Louis Art Museum and the Whitney Museum Of Art. Services will be held Tuesday, June 10th, 2008, 11:45am at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made to M.D. Anderson Cancer Research Center, Houston, TX, and the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation.

IN contrast to the writers' rooms of other series, the one for Showtime's ''Weeds'' is almost Spartan. ''We have eliminated most of the distractions from the room,'' said Craig Zisk, an executive producer. All the better, in a strike-shortened season, to focus on the work of reinventing this series, about a widowed suburban mother (Mary-Louise Parker) who sells marijuana. (She has just burned down her neighborhood.) Computers, P.D.A.'s and cellphones had to go. ''We were spending too much time text-messaging each other in the room about what everyone else was saying,'' he said. And at the beginning of the season, after Mr. Zisk and one of the writers lost weight by cutting out sugar, the staff of nine voted to institute a no-sugar policy in the writers' room. The sweets were replaced with fruit plates, dried fruit, nuts and energy drinks. ''We're a very focused group,'' Mr. Zisk said.
Classical By Anthony Tommasini

NO standard dry-erase boards for the three writers of HBO's ''Flight of the Conchords'': James Bobin, who is an executive producer and director as well as writer, said they prefer colored index cards, hundreds of them. ''I'm worried I'll erase something and forget about it,'' Mr. Bobin said. On the 20-foot wall in the writers' room, he said, is ''every idea we've ever had in the last six months.'' Plot outlines, character arcs, notes about old music videos the writers like and have looked up online. The comedy series, starring Mr. Bobin's fellow writers Bret McKenzie and Jemaine Clement as the real-life New Zealand folk parody duo for whom the show is named, ''would be impossible to make without YouTube,'' Mr. Bobin said. ''We spend our entire time iTunes D.J.-ing each other's lists, doing a 'Name That Tune' sort of quiz.''

RAFEL--Ellen Frankel. We are very sad; we send love to Erwin, Gideon and Saul. Judy and Philip Parkas RAFEL--Ellen. Surrounded by family and friends, Ellen Rafel, 63, passed away on June 5, 2008. Serving children of NYC's Public Schools for over three decades, she was chosen by her peers ''Guidance Counselor of the Year'' three times. Paraphrasing Ted Kennedy, to Ellen love meant having a social conscience and battling the wrongs which needed our attention. Each time we act to improve the life of others, or strike out against injustice, we send forth a tiny ripple of hope. Ellen sent out lots of ripples. She was a good and decent woman, who saw wrong and tried to right it, saw suffering and tried to heal it. She will be remembered by her husband, Erwin Rafel-Frankel; sons, Gideon and Saul; sister, Judy Englander; nieces, Freya and Emily; grandnephew and niece, Nathan and Ruby and dear family and friends. Funeral services will take place Sunday, June 8, 10am at Temple Anshe Chesed, West End Avenue and 100th Street. May her memory, like her life be for a blessing. RAFEL--Ellen. Farewell friend from all of the Ellens, Judys and Lauras who will remember you always with love.

Despite reports of a looming rice shortage, large sacks of that grain fill one of the two front windows of Cosmos International in West Hartford. Alongside various brands of basmati are similarly oversize containers of durum flour and, in an adjacent aisle, bags of lentils and other legumes. Though not a huge establishment, Cosmos is a horn of plenty that extends well beyond starchy staples. It carries an abundance of teas, from Twinings to Zarrin to Ahmad of London ($2.99 to $7.99), specialty oils like walnut and hazelnut, as well as olive ($5.49 to $23.99, depending on size), boxed falafel mixes ($2.89 to $3.89), even four types of Turkish delight ($4.59 per pound).

SIODMAK--Manfred, formerly of New York and Larchmont, died on June 2, 2008 in Laguna Woods, CA. He would have been 100 years old this month. Born in Dresden, Germany, Manfred came to the U.S. when he was 18, where he learned the fur trade. He married Sybil Haber, and they had two daughters: Judy (Victor) Ratner, and Midge Sanford (Peter Broderick); grandchildren, Kate and Jonathan Sanford, and Deborah and the late Elizabeth Ratner; and two great-grandsons Will and Ben Lockhart. Too old to enlist during World War II, Manfred drove ambulances at night to fill in for the drivers who were at war. He was a skier, a violinist, a bridge player, and a tennis player with a terrific backhand. He loved music, particularly Brahms, and his family. Happily married for many decades, Manfred and Sybil celebrated their 71st wedding anniversary last summer. There will be a small private service at the home later in the month. Contributions to The Jewish Guild for the Blind, 15 West 65th St., New York, NY 10023.

JAMES--Joan Headley, 77, was born in New York City on July 9, 1930. She died June 3, 2008 after a long illness. She is survived by her husband, Tommie; two sons, Vincent and Eric; and a host of other relatives and friends. Joan and Tommie were married on February 26, 1955. Throughout her life, she was always a devoted wife and mother, and as the family moved to Georgia then Mississippi, she continued to make new friends and renew old friendships. She will always be remembered for her warm smile, generous nature and her resilience.

As Peggy Olson, the secretary turned junior copywriter at Sterling Cooper, the fictional 1960s Madison Avenue ad agency at the heart of ''Mad Men'' on AMC, Elisabeth Moss brings a full steno pad of subtleties to a young woman whose ambitions seem essentially futuristic. With her tentative movements, scrappy bangs and hard expressions, she gives us both striver and naïf, a woman blind to how much she yearns for until she lands in a Manhattan of fur-trimmed coats. Peggy embodies the show's mood of gritty postwar aspiration even more than her boss, Don Draper (Jon Hamm), who has climbed so high and so fast that he is suffering from his own kind of altitude sickness. What he ends up wanting, no Diners Club card can purchase. Watching Ms. Moss, feeling her fastidiously counting the miles between the Brooklyn of Peggy's upbringing and the Manhattan of Bonwit Teller, liberal sex and reinvention, you almost hurt. She does something close to somatizing Peggy's class anxieties, and the viewer can't help reaching for the aspirin.

My husband's mother and stepfather live in Hawaii, and while this arrangement is the envy of many of our friends who dream of tropical vacations, it is, in my opinion, an inconvenient one. When they visit, we seem to fall into rituals, keeping to certain haunts, as if to suggest that not much time has passed since we saw them last. One such place was a Greek restaurant in the West Village that served revani, an ambrosial dessert traditional to Macedonia, Greece's largest region. The moment my in-laws would bite into this tender semolina cake, the stress of their long flight east would fall away, and calm would settle over the table. When the restaurant sadly closed, I decided to try to recreate it for them at home. An ancient crossroads between Europe and the East, Macedonia developed a vibrant cuisine. The Egnatian Way, stretching from the Adriatic to Constantinople, helped pave the way for a gastronomic exchange that still influences Mediterranean food today. Over the years, Macedonia's port-side capital, Thessaloniki, became a safe haven for everyone from Christian pilgrims to Jews fleeing the Spanish Inquisition to refugees from Asia Minor. Given its traumatized citizenry, it's no wonder that the Thessalonikans took so passionately to the comfort of sweets, going so far as to nickname their city Glykomana, ''sweet mother.''

THE NEWS American and British diplomats investigating political violence in Zimbabwe were stopped by the police, threatened and detained for five hours. BEHIND THE NEWS The episode underscored the increasingly repressive atmosphere in Zimbabwe in advance of the June 27 presidential election. The government also ordered aid groups to suspend their operations. Earlier in the week, Morgan Tsvangirai, the opposition leader who placed first in the March elections and now faces a runoff with President Robert Mugabe, was detained by the police and charged with drawing a big crowd. Amnesty International condemned his detention as part of a ''sharp and dangerous crackdown.''

He touched and helped the lives of countless people.

The exhibition ''Sprawl'' at the Jersey City Museum does not set out to prove that parts of the New Jersey landscape are ugly. But it is hard to escape that conclusion after seeing the show. Still, the exhibition, curated by Rocio Aranda-Alvarado, the museum's curator of contemporary art, is both pertinent and engrossing. It gathers together artworks by 41 artists, mostly young, all living and working in the state.

9 P.M. (History) ICE ROAD TRUCKERS Yellowknife is so last season. This time around the drivers will try to haul equipment and supplies to natural gas exploration sites more than 200 miles north of the Arctic Circle, where temperatures routinely sink to minus 60 degrees. And the ice road? It's an even more treacherous path running over the frozen Arctic Ocean and the Mackenzie River into the far corners of the Northwest Territories. Unlike Season 1's makeshift highway, this one is all ice, all the time, with no narrow land bridges on which truckers can escape. 5 P.M. (21) TIMELESS: A NATIONAL PARKS ODYSSEY David Fortney captures the natural beauty of 18 North American parks: Arches, Banff, Bryce, Canyonlands, Death Valley, Denali, Glacier, Grand Teton, Jasper, Joshua Tree, Olympic, Point Lobos, Redwood, Salt Point, Yellowstone, Yosemite, Zion and Grand Canyon.

Riding a cable car, Jan. 7, 2008 Florian Wahl, a college student from Kempten, Bavaria. ''I wanted to improve my English and get away from home. My university in Ulm had partner schools in England and America, but England seemed too close to Germany. Plus, I had always wanted to go to the U.S. I ended up in Flint, Mich. When the semester ended at Christmastime, I went to New York to see a few friends and then, together with my girlfriend and another couple, flew to Las Vegas for New Year's. After that the four of us got a big rental car and drove from Las Vegas to San Francisco by way of Death Valley -- a proper road trip. But we dropped the car off when we arrived in San Francisco. There were three things we definitely wanted to see there: the Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz and cable cars. I knew the cable cars from TV shows and movies and definitely wanted to ride on them. We bought unlimited daylong tickets. It was a beautiful day, and it was great just to ride around the streets, hanging on, looking at the city.'' As told to Tim Mohr

Rather than follow the ideas of the formal fashion world, some young people in New York have created their own fashion uniform, the vest. It is almost always worn with jeans or leggings, seldom with skirts. Young men are wearing vests without jackets, to both the office and evening events. Women's vests tend to be abbreviated and form-fitting; some have exposed backs instead of silk.

ONE freakishly stormy night several years ago in San Diego, my car stalled at a flooded intersection. As I pushed the car out of the intersection, lightning was going off all around like flash bulbs. Recently, the State of California sent me my tax refund, and curiously, $328 had been deducted from it. After quite a bit of research, I found the missing amount was courtesy of a traffic court in San Diego, which asserted that I had an unpaid ticket from years earlier. I said I was never notified of it and unaware of committing a violation. But it apparently stemmed from that freak thunderstorm. To condense a longer story: one of those flashes apparently was the flash from a red-light camera.

THERE is a rule in the ''House'' writing room: No eating on the pool table. It's left free for the show's creator, David Shore, who can be found playing a game with a colleague there nearly every afternoon. The rule is important because the table is a tempting surface in a room that is more a daily lunch spot than the site of writing sessions, for a staff of more than a dozen. Mr. Shore -- who is also an executive producer of this Fox series, starring Hugh Laurie as the cantankerous Dr. Gregory House -- said the ''basic gumshoe-type work'' of researching the obscure maladies that form the core of each episode is done by individuals outside the room, as is much of the script writing.

WHAT a difference six months make. At the Detroit auto show in January, General Motors was selling its idea of a greener, cleaner Hummer. On Tuesday, Rick Wagoner, G.M.'s chief executive, announced that the company was shutting down four truck plants and thinking about unloading Hummer by or before 2010.

SPRIGGS--Dillard Pynor, born February 6, 1926, died peacefully May 29, 2008, in New York City following a long illness. As one of the first Wall Street analysts to focus on oil companies, he pioneered analysis of international oil issues. He joined Baker, Weeks in 1958 and eventually served as executive Vice President. In 1974, Mr. Spriggs testified before the Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee on Multinational Corporations, on the importance of developing domestic oil production to counter the global energy crisis. In 1978, Mr. Spriggs founded International Petroleum Finance, which he sold to Petroleum Intelligence Weekly in 1994, although he continued to write for IPF until his retirement in 1997. He is survived by his wife Nancy, daughter Julie (Glenn Stevens), step-daughter Barbara Gates (Patrick O'Donnell), two granddaughters, Chloe and Caitlin, and his sister Dorothy. In lieu of flowers, donations would be appreciated to a fund to be announced at his memorial service in September.
Film Manohla Dargis

GILMAN--Harold, died peacefully on June 3, 2008 at the age of 81. Born in the Bronx in 1927, he graduated from Townsend Harris High School, and, at just 18 years of age, from City College of New York. After serving in the Navy he completed graduate work in chemical engineering at Polytechnic University. For most of his career he was employed by Scientific Design/Halcon International, where he developed new chemical technology and worked on process design. He held numerous patents. More than a scientist, he was a great lover of the arts, particularly opera, and New York's Metropolitan Opera was his home away from home. A man of profound intellect whose storehouse of knowledge --and recall of baseball statistics --never ceased to amaze, Harold was perhaps most loved by those who knew him for his utter lack of pretention and his liberal broad-mindedness. He was his family's Answer Man and without him the world will be a far more confusing place. Survivors include his wife of 54 years, Mildred, daughters Margot Gilman and Nora Blum, sons-in-law Stephen Tympanick and Jeffrey Blum, grandchildren Thea, Lily, Heather, Amanda and Jacob, brother Sheldon and cousin Herbert. A memorial service will be held in the fall.

Special aunt and friend. Her greatest joy was to be surrounded by her family and eating one piece of ''dark chocolate'' every day. She will be remembered for her love for her family, strength, beauty, and her total alertness until the very end.

WILLIAMSON--Peter. The Board of Trustees of Skidmore College and the campus community deeply mourn the death of Peter D. Williamson, husband of alumna and trustee Susan Kettering Williamson '59, benefactor, and friend. A world-renowned neurologist and epilepsy expert, Peter spent 20 years as director of the Yale Epilepsy Program at Yale University, returning to his alma mater (Dartmouth) in 1991 to establish the Dartmouth - Hitchcock Compre hensive Epilepsy Center and to serve as a professor of medicine in neurology at Dartmouth Medical School. He and Susan, his wife of 50 years, are known for their transformative philanthropy in medicine and education. Their leadership and many contributions to Skidmore, including several scholarship programs, have made it possible for hundreds of students to attend the College. As a couple, Peter and Susan hosted Skidmore events, warmly welcoming alumni, parents, and friends into their home. A dedicated collector of exotic automobiles, Peter once permitted the College to display several cars from his worldclass collection of Bugattis, to the delight of alumni and friends. A generous and dedicated supporter and passionate advocate of the College and its mission, Peter will be deeply missed. We send our deepest condolences to his wife, Susan; to his children, Kyle, Karen, Doug, and Debbie; to his many grandchildren; and to the entire Williamson family. Suzanne Corbet Thomas '62 Chair, Board of Trustees Philip A. Glotzbach President, Skidmore College

THE diversions in the writers' room of the FX series ''Damages'' are countless: there's a football, a dartboard, a futon, a television and a golf putter that inspired a scene. But none are louder than Uncle Ralph, the schnoodle rescued from the streets of Brooklyn that belongs to Todd A. Kessler, one of three creators and executive producers. Uncle Ralph barks at the printer, Mr. Kessler said, which the team members at first took as ''a quality-control thing,'' until they realized that he barked at every page that came out. ''Either we only write bad pages, or it's in his DNA,'' Mr. Kessler said. ''He just doesn't like the show.'' Given that the scheming lawyer Patty Hewes, played by Glenn Close, killed a dog in the first season, maybe it's with good reason.
An article on May 11, about American members of the French Legion of Honor, included an extra rank within the society. There is no grand commandeur.

ZWAIK--Anne Lehman, died June 5 at 89 years old. Adored wife of Stanley N. Zwaik (deceased). Anne was a loving mother, grandmother, sisterin-law and aunt. Her greatest joy was to be surrounded by her beloved daughters, Judith (David) Tarlo and Stephanie (Dan Powers) Greenberg and grandchildren Howard (Toni) and Joseph (Maggie Williams), Andrew (Danielle) and Dori. A graduate of Hunter College, Anne was accomplished in her work for the U.S. Department of the Navy and as an elementary school teacher. Her happiest times were when she stepped aside so those she loved could shine brightly. She left us with dignity and eternal love. Since December 2006, Anne lived at the Hebrew Home in Riverdale where she was surrounded by love and caring hands for which her family will be forever grateful. Funeral services will be held 11:30am Sunday June 8 at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Donations in Anne's name may be sent to The Hebrew Home, Development Office, 5901 Palisade Ave., Riverdale, NY 10471.

LIBOVE--Charles, 1926-2008. The great American violinist Charles Libove was a student at the Curtis Institute of Music with Lea Luboshutz and later with Ivan Galamian. His principle teacher was Demetrius Dounis. Few violinists could boast of a more wonderful technique and with Mr. Libove's passing the great golden age of violin playing comes practically to a close. Winner of the first International Enesco violin competition, the first International Naumberg Chamber music contest, he was also a member of the Marlboro trio, the Philharmonia trio, and the Paganini quartet for many years. Charles Libove is survived by his wife, the outstanding Ukrainian-American pianist and for many years his chamber music partner Nina Lugovoy.

YARD--Mary Howell, died at home in Manchester, Connecticut on the second of June. She was ninety-two years old. Born in Bucks County, Pennsylvania, she resided in New Jersey for most of her life. She was the daughter of Mary Abigail Johnson and Gershom Mott Howell, the granddaughter of William Gillingham Howell, a prominent New Jersey financier, and a descendant of Edward Howell, the leader of the colonists who founded Southampton, Long Island in 1640. A graduate of Miss Fine's School in Princeton, New Jersey, and of Smith College in Northampton, Massachusetts, class of 1937, she was a proponent of the importance of knowledge and a liberal arts education. Mary Emma married Edward Madison Yard on July 27, 1940. They met as children while horseback riding at Ely's in New Hope, PA. She taught English literature at Miss Fine's School prior to the birth of her three children. Mary Emma was a member of the Colonial Dames of New Jersey, the Junior League of Greater Princeton, the General Mercer Chapter DAR and the Princeton Present Day Club. She was also a deacon of the First Presbyterian Church. For thirty-five years she was on the Board of Trustees of the Old Barracks Museum in Trenton, New Jersey, serving as its president several times. She led the second restoration in 1979 and was the recipient of the first Beulah Oliphant award in 1991 for her contribution to the preservation of historic buildings. In her association with the Old Barracks she was carrying on a tradition of the Yard family. Several of her husband's ancestors played important roles in its history, including Joseph Yard who served as the first Barracks Master and Josephine Yard Breese, Edward's grandmother, who was one of the women who raised the money to save the Old Barracks and served as its first president. A supporter of civil rights, for many years in the 1940s she was the director of the Committee for Unity, whose purpose was to further the rights of black individuals. She continued this work in other ways during the 1950s, and was a recipient of an award in the 1960s for her efforts to advance the rights of blacks. Her life long love of travel, ocean liners and art were instilled by her mother with whom she traveled extensively in Europe, attending a school in Paris on one occasion. Following Mrs. Howell's death in 1932, Mary Emma's beloved Aunt, Thirza A. Howell, assumed the role of a mother. Mary Emma and her family summered in Ogunquit, Maine with Aunt Thirza for many years. She was predeceased by her husband and is survived by three daughters, Barbara Anne Yard of Manchester, CT, Marcia Louise Yard and her husband Dean R. DePietro of Manchester, CT, Sally Elizabeth Yard of La Jolla, California, and one granddaughter, Alexandra Yard Davies, also of La Jolla. Funeral services were by M. William Murphy Funeral Directors, 935 Parkway Avenue, Ewing, New Jersey.
