With his Mets trailing the Padres by a run in the ninth inning Friday night, Manager Willie Randolph wanted a left-handed hitter to bat for Fernando Tatis. He sent up Carlos Delgado, but only because Ryan Church, his first choice, told him that he ''didn't feel right.'' Church said Saturday that he felt ''a heartbeat in my head'' and had learned from mistakes he made last month, when he pinch-hit four times while still dealing with the effects of his second concussion in less than three months.

AT&T restructured its deal with Apple, said Ralph de la Vega, the chief executive of AT&T Mobility, in order to overcome resistance from mass consumers to the high $399 price of the iPhone. Now, instead of paying Apple a portion of their monthly fees, carriers like AT&T will make a large payment to Apple every time an iPhone is sold and attached to their network.

To hear AT&T executives tell it, the company expects the iPhone to strike at the heart of the BlackBerry, taking aim at business customers who have been devoted fans of the so-called "CrackBerry" for years.

27 Days to L'Étape.Today's training: A day off after two long, hilly rides north of the city on Saturday (75 miles) and Sunday (52 miles). Rode early Saturday morning with a small group of experienced riders, roughly along this route, getting a lot of invaluable advice and a chance to practice some basic bike skills, like riding in a paceline. Best tip: while riding up the 7.1% gradient of Alpine Hill in New Jersey, a 47-year-old photographer, who once rode professionally in France, told me as we discussed how long this section of the road was (a mile or a mile and a half, depending on where you start), that once you pass 40, it's best to describe the distances you ride in kilometers and your weight in kilos.

Debate about the soundness of racehorses might be hotter now than ever before, but the hand-wringing over the fragility of the thoroughbred has been around just about as long as the breed itself. Around the 1900s, French breeders started to out-cross thoroughbreds with sturdier stock to build a better steeplechaser. By the end of the century, these cross-breds were routinely beating thoroughbreds over the big fences at Auteuil, and a new breed was born: the AQPS, or "autre que pur sang" -- "other than thoroughbred."

Robert Kubica grabbed his first Formula One victory and the series points lead after Lewis Hamilton’s mistake took him and the world champion Kimi Raikkonen out of the Canadian Grand Prix in Montreal. Hamilton, the defending champion and pole-sitter, slammed his Mercedes McLaren into the rear of Raikkonen’s Ferrari in the pits early in the race, taking out both and giving the 23-year-old Kubica a clear road to victory in his 29th Formula One start.

Horst Skoff, a former Austrian tennis player who won four ATP Tour titles, died during a business trip to Germany. He was 39. Austria’s tennis federation said Skoff died Saturday of a heart attack. Puckhofer told the Austrian news agency APA that the police were investigating why Skoff had injuries to his face.

DIAMOND--Nathan, of Delray Beach, passed May 31, 2008. An indomitable spirit with unbounded love for his darling wife Faye, loving sons Andy (Geri), Jeff (Regina), sister Florence (Julian Kumock) and all of his sweet and wonderful relatives and friends. Nat loved New York University Law School and was recently celebrated as its oldest living alumni. He was a member of the N.Y.U. Society of the Torch. He touched and helped the lives of countless people.

NEWBLATT-FIUR--Irene, on June 4, 2008 at the age of 100. Beloved wife of Sol Fiur. Mother of Robert (Marilyn) Newblatt and Jane Melamed. Grandmother of Paul (Cathy) Melamed, Brett (Colby) Newblatt, Lindsay (Jon) Reitzes and great-grandmother of Ian and Sascha Melamed. Stepmother of Ellen Fiur. Services Sunday, June 8, 11:30am, Boulevard Riverside, Hewlett, NY. NEWBLATT-FIUR--Irene. A superb woman with courage and insight always to help others. She touched our lives with her devotion to family and her vibrance. Our love and condolences to Sol, Robert, Paul and their families. Joan and Blaine Land

LEBOWITZ--Ruth. We'll miss you, your show tunes, humor, and your kind heart like your beloved father. Hard to believe you've left us. Maybe harder for your cyber-celebrity kitties, Ditzy, Milo, Alison, and Otie. Love and peace now. Susan Grant

LINDSAY--Nancy Dalley, on June 7th after a long and courageous battle with a pituitary tumor. Beloved wife for 58 years of Robert V. Lindsay, mother of Cameron Lindsay of Denver, Colorado, Tinker Lindsay of Hollywood, California and Robert D. and daughter-in-law Teresa Lindsay of Locust Valley, New York. Grandmother of Thomas and Dorothy Beatty, Jonathan and Andrew Warkentin, and Robert T., James, Alexander and Duncan Lindsay. Mrs. Lindsay was born in New York City and attended the Lenox School, Greenwood School and Vassar College. A noted breeder and judge of dogs, she filled judging assignments on three continents, including judge of Best in Show at the Westminster Kennel Club show. Mrs. Lindsay was a founding trustee of the American Kennel Club Museum of the Dog in Saint Louis, Missouri. She also is a past trustee of the Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge Foundation and served on the boards of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, the Cooper Union, the Animal Medical Center, the ASPCA, the Westminster Kennel Foundation, the East Woods School and the Dutchess Day School. She served as chairman of the Women's Committee of the American Museum of Natural History, and in 1976 as Vice-Chairman in London of the U.S. Bicentennial Committee which brought together collections of American Indian art and artifacts from world-wide sources for a London exposition in honor of the Bicentennial. A memorial service will be held Friday, June 13 at 11am, at St. Peter's Church on Deep Hollow Road in Millbrook NY. (Lithgow). In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Hospice, Inc. Dutchess County, 374 Violet Avenue, Poughkeepsie NY, 12601.

SLAVIN--Jack, June 2nd, 2008. Born July 4th, 1928, Jack was husband and best friend to Norma; the beloved father to Rina, Jim, Amy, Gary, David and Pat; and grandfather to Ethan, Nichole, Jessica, Hannah, Emma, Gary Jr. and Elizabeth. Jack was a pioneer and innovator in special education. He was also an avid fisherman and conservationist. He will be sorely missed by all.

POLISH--Jack Bruce, died peacefully at home on June 3 after a long illness. Devoted husband of the late Muriel Wallick Polish, exceedingly proud father of Beth and Nathaniel, loving father-inlaw of Philip Friedman and Ellen Schorr, delighted and doting grandfather of Anna Rose, Isadora, William and Charles. A tenacious and brilliant negotiator, a peacemaker, fiercely loyal to his many and diverse friends, an optimist to the last. No cause was ever hopeless. Funeral at Plaza, 91st St. and Amsterdam, Thursday 11am. Donations to New Yorkers Against Gun Violence, www.nyagv.org.
KONIGSBERG--Natalie. We miss your warmth, wit, style and kindness. Lovingly remembered by your family.

Allocca--Philip, of Milford, CT and White Plains, NY died June 1, 2008 after a short illness. Born December 14, 1938 in Brooklyn, NY to Daniel and Conchita (Vela) Allocca, he's survived by a son David and grandchildren Dustin and Amber of Easton PA; sisters Barbara Bongo of Mount Arlington, NJ and Dorothy Brennan of Madison, NJ and brother Richard of Chester, NJ; and many nieces and nephews. A graduate of Bloomfield (NJ) High School, William Patterson and Seaton Hall University , Phil spent his entire career in education and retired as a principal from the Burgen County, NJ school system in 1994 and was fulfilling his dream to ''teach in a small New England college'' at Albertus Magnus College in New Haven, CT. Services were private.

FOGARTY--Kevin C. Sr., on June 6, 2008. Beloved son of Michael and Gretta. Beloved husband of Joan A. O'Berg. Devoted father of Kevin Jr. and Molly, Maria and Sameer Tandon and Diane. Loving grandfather of Aidan and Conor. Dear brother of Michael, John, Peter, Robert and Barbara Augustine. Judge Fogarty graduated from St. John's University (B.A. and L.L.B.) and NYU School of Law (L.L.M.). Served in the U.S. Army (Korean War), Chief Clerk of King's County Surrogate Court, Judge NYC Family Court, Professor of Law (St.John's University School of Law) and Chairman of the Board of Trustees of St. Francis College Emeritus. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach. Funeral Mass at St.Francis deSales Church, Monday at 11am. Visiting Sunday 2-5 and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Ozanam Hall Nursing Home, Bayside, NY.
TYSON--Dr. Margaret Gould, leader in nursing education, dies at age 87. Services 2pm July 5th at Church of Our Savior, New Lebanon, New York. Direct all inquiries to charrison2010@aol.com

SIODMAK--Manfred, formerly of New York and Larchmont, died on June 2, 2008 in Laguna Woods, CA. He would have been 100 years old this month. Born in Dresden, Germany, Manfred came to the U.S. when he was 18, where he learned the fur trade. He married Sybil Haber, and they had two daughters: Judy (Victor) Ratner, and Midge Sanford (Peter Broderick); grandchildren, Kate and Jonathan Sanford, and Deborah and the late Elizabeth Ratner; and two great-grandsons Will and Ben Lockhart. Too old to enlist during World War II, Manfred drove ambulances at night to fill in for the drivers who were at war. He was a skier, a violinist, a bridge player, and a tennis player with a terrific backhand. He loved music, particularly Brahms, and his family. Happily married for many decades, Manfred and Sybil celebrated their 71st wedding anniversary last summer. There will be a small private service at the home later in the month. Contributions to The Jewish Guild for the Blind, 15 West 65th St., New York, NY 10023.

JAMES--Joan Headley, 77, was born in New York City on July 9, 1930. She died June 3, 2008 after a long illness. She is survived by her husband, Tommie; two sons, Vincent and Eric; and a host of other relatives and friends. Joan and Tommie were married on February 26, 1955. Throughout her life, she was always a devoted wife and mother, and as the family moved to Georgia then Mississippi, she continued to make new friends and renew old friendships. She will always be remembered for her warm smile, generous nature and her resilience.

STECKLER--Nettie, June 1, 2008. Very special wife, mother, grandmother, great grandmother, sister, aunt, great-aunt, cousin. Retired Reference Librarian, Queensboro Public Library. Forever in our hearts.

GILMAN--Harold, died peacefully on June 3, 2008 at the age of 81. Born in the Bronx in 1927, he graduated from Townsend Harris High School, and, at just 18 years of age, from City College of New York. After serving in the Navy he completed graduate work in chemical engineering at Polytechnic University. For most of his career he was employed by Scientific Design/Halcon International, where he developed new chemical technology and worked on process design. He held numerous patents. More than a scientist, he was a great lover of the arts, particularly opera, and New York's Metropolitan Opera was his home away from home. A man of profound intellect whose storehouse of knowledge --and recall of baseball statistics --never ceased to amaze, Harold was perhaps most loved by those who knew him for his utter lack of pretention and his liberal broad-mindedness. He was his family's Answer Man and without him the world will be a far more confusing place. Survivors include his wife of 54 years, Mildred, daughters Margot Gilman and Nora Blum, sons-in-law Stephen Tympanick and Jeffrey Blum, grandchildren Thea, Lily, Heather, Amanda and Jacob, brother Sheldon and cousin Herbert. A memorial service will be held in the fall.
MILSTOC--Dr. Mayer. Missing you for 8 years, but with me always. Love, Gilda

SERENI--Elizabeth, died peacefully at her home on June 6, 2008. Loving wife of the late George Sereni. Dear sister and sister-in-law of John and Ann Wasilik. WILLIAMSON--Peter. The Board of Trustees of Skidmore College and the campus community deeply mourn the death of Peter D. Williamson, husband of alumna and trustee Susan Kettering Williamson '59, benefactor, and friend. A world-renowned neurologist and epilepsy expert, Peter spent 20 years as director of the Yale Epilepsy Program at Yale University, returning to his alma mater (Dartmouth) in 1991 to establish the Dartmouth - Hitchcock Compre hensive Epilepsy Center and to serve as a professor of medicine in neurology at Dartmouth Medical School. He and Susan, his wife of 50 years, are known for their transformative philanthropy in medicine and education. Their leadership and many contributions to Skidmore, including several scholarship programs, have made it possible for hundreds of students to attend the College. As a couple, Peter and Susan hosted Skidmore events, warmly welcoming alumni, parents, and friends into their home. A dedicated collector of exotic automobiles, Peter once permitted the College to display several cars from his worldclass collection of Bugattis, to the delight of alumni and friends. A generous and dedicated supporter and passionate advocate of the College and its mission, Peter will be deeply missed. We send our deepest condolences to his wife, Susan; to his children, Kyle, Karen, Doug, and Debbie; to his many grandchildren; and to the entire Williamson family. Suzanne Corbet Thomas '62 Chair, Board of Trustees Philip A. Glotzbach President, Skidmore College

BECKHARDT--Clare, died peacefully on June 5, 2008 after a long illness at the age of 77. Beloved wife of Fred, sister of George and Nancy, loving mother of Seth and Meredith and Laurence and Aimee, adoring grandmother of Molly, Deanna, Layla and Joshua. A dedicated environmentalist and builder of parks in NYC. As Regional Director of the NYS Office of Parks and Recreation, she was responsible for the creation of Riverbank State Park in Manhattan, Empire-Fulton Ferry State Park in Brooklyn, and the Clay Pit State Park and Nature Preserve on Staten Island. She was an outgoing person who will be missed by all. Contributions in her memory may be made to the NYC Council on the Environment or High School of Environmental Studies. Service Sunday 2:15pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel on West 76th St. and Amsterdam. BECKHARDT--Clare. The Board of the New York League of Conservation Voters mourns the passing of a founding Member, champion of parks and friend.

YANKER--Gary D., 60, of New York and Tucson died May 15 from cancer. He grew up in New Jersey, graduated from Georgetown in 1969 and earned a Law Degree and MBA from Columbia. He practiced law at Milbank Tweed and subsequently wrote numerous books promoting walking. He later practiced law. He was predeceased by his first wife, Virginia Rice and is survived by his second wife Diane Van Arsdel, his sons Andrew and Wyatt, his mother Lisl, his sister Kristin and brother Peter. A service will be held at St. Josephs Church, 404 E. 87th St. at 10am on June 20th.

MEYERSON--Monroe. Our friend Monroe was a remarkable man. He had great courage and an indomitable spirit. He was loved, admired and respected by all his friends and family. Our love and deepest sympathy to Leila and all their family. Carol and Mel MEYERSON--Monroe, above all you were the most giving, caring and bravest of all men. We will miss you forever our sympathies to Leila, David, Cindie, Donald, Stuart and Lisa and the grandchildren. Meryle, Irving, Donald, Faye, Gary, Lester and Andrea MEYERSON--Monroe. The Membership and Board of Governors of the Boca Rio Golf Club, Boca Raton, FL, announces with deep regret and sorrow the passing of our dear friend, esteemed member and former governor, Monroe Meyerson on June 6, 2008, and extends our sincerest condolences to his wife Leila and their family. Robert M. Merson, President Boca Rio Golf Club MEYERSON--Monroe R., born August 23, 1930, to Harry and Beatrice Meyerson in Brooklyn, NY, died June 6, 2008, in Boca Raton, FL. He leaves behind his beloved wife of 53 Years, Leila Mann Meyerson, his children, Cindie (Dr. Donald) Kastenbaum, David Meyerson, and Stuart (Lisa) Meyerson, and five wonderful grandchildren: Julie, Harry, Jessica, Samuel and Benjamin. He attended Poly Prep Day School where he achieved a football scholarship to the University of NC/Chapel Hill. He graduated from New York University with a degree in engineering and economics and later obtained an MBA from the Trinity School at NYU. As a graduate of ROTC, he became a pilot in the Air Force and was honorably discharged in 1955. He began his career as project manager at Centrig Industries, a small familyoperated construction company in NYC in 1956, and during his 35 year tenure as its Chairman and CEO, grew the company into an internationally recognized leader in heavy industrial construction and a world leader in the installation of newspaper presses, including The New York Times, Chicago Tribune, Miami Herald, San Fransisco Chronicle, Charlotte Observer, and the Washingon Post. As a result of having been a dialysis patient in 1992, Mr. Meyerson founded the Dialysis Centers of America (DCA) in 1995 with a strong commitment to improving the quality of care, treatment and outcomes for dialysis patients. Within three years, DCA grew from a single location to the largest kidney dialysis treatment in the Midwest. DCA'a greatest accomplishment was in the development of renal care informatics which became the ''golden rule'' adopted by the dialysis industry. In 1998, Mr. Meyerson founded the Radiology Corporation of America (RCOA), an innovator and early adopter of Positron Emission Tomography (PET), a new molecular imaging technology that improved the diagnosis and treatment of many diseases, including the early detection of cancer and Alzheimer's Disease. Mr. Meyerson was also instrumental in founding the Institute of Molecular Technology, a trade association which educated the medical community about the benefits of PET technology which led to the acceptance of reimbursement protocols under Medicare. As a result of his daughter's juvenile diabetes in 1967, Mr. Meyerson was a co-founder and the inspiration for the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation (JDF), both the New York chapter and the national organization, where he served as a Board member for many years. In addition, Mr. Meyerson was aformer Director of Gatekeeper Solutions, the Whitney Art Museum, Dance Theater of Harlem, Boca Rio Country Club, and a member of Chief Executives Organization, World Presidents' Organization and Young Presidents' Organization. He was a renaissance man involved in Arts and Theatre and his philanthropic endeavors included support of Technion University, Kravis Center for the Performing Arts, Broward Center for the Performing Arts, University of Minnesota, American Parkinson's Disease Foundation, among many others. Mr. Meyerson was an avid art collector of photorealism and supported many young artists. He generously donated art to both the St. Louis Art Museum and the Whitney Museum Of Art. Services will be held Tuesday, June 10th, 2008, 11:45am at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made to M.D. Anderson Cancer Research Center, Houston, TX, and the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation.

YARD--Mary Howell, died at home in Manchester, Connecticut on the second of June. She was ninety-two years old. Born in Bucks County, Pennsylvania, she resided in New Jersey for most of her life. She was the daughter of Mary Abigail Johnson and Gershom Mott Howell, the granddaughter of William Gillingham Howell, a prominent New Jersey financier, and a descendant of Edward Howell, the leader of the colonists who founded Southampton, Long Island in 1640. A graduate of Miss Fine's School in Princeton, New Jersey, and of Smith College in Northampton, Massachusetts, class of 1937, she was a proponent of the importance of knowledge and a liberal arts education. Mary Emma married Edward Madison Yard on July 27, 1940. They met as children while horseback riding at Ely's in New Hope, PA. She taught English literature at Miss Fine's School prior to the birth of her three children. Mary Emma was a member of the Colonial Dames of New Jersey, the Junior League of Greater Princeton, the General Mercer Chapter DAR and the Princeton Present Day Club. She was also a deacon of the First Presbyterian Church. For thirty-five years she was on the Board of Trustees of the Old Barracks Museum in Trenton, New Jersey, serving as its president several times. She led the second restoration in 1979 and was the recipient of the first Beulah Oliphant award in 1991 for her contribution to the preservation of historic buildings. In her association with the Old Barracks she was carrying on a tradition of the Yard family. Several of her husband's ancestors played important roles in its history, including Joseph Yard who served as the first Barracks Master and Josephine Yard Breese, Edward's grandmother, who was one of the women who raised the money to save the Old Barracks and served as its first president. A supporter of civil rights, for many years in the 1940s she was the director of the Committee for Unity, whose purpose was to further the rights of black individuals. She continued this work in other ways during the 1950s, and was a recipient of an award in the 1960s for her efforts to advance the rights of blacks. Her life long love of travel, ocean liners and art were instilled by her mother with whom she traveled extensively in Europe, attending a school in Paris on one occasion. Following Mrs. Howell's death in 1932, Mary Emma's beloved Aunt, Thirza A. Howell, assumed the role of a mother. Mary Emma and her family summered in Ogunquit, Maine with Aunt Thirza for many years. She was predeceased by her husband and is survived by three daughters, Barbara Anne Yard of Manchester, CT, Marcia Louise Yard and her husband Dean R. DePietro of Manchester, CT, Sally Elizabeth Yard of La Jolla, California, and one granddaughter, Alexandra Yard Davies, also of La Jolla. Funeral services were by M. William Murphy Funeral Directors, 935 Parkway Avenue, Ewing, New Jersey.

ANONYMOUS SOURCES In The Times

9 P.M. (HBO) ROMAN POLANSKI: WANTED AND DESIRED (2008) In 1977 Mr. Polanski, above, the director of ''Rosemary's Baby'' and ''Chinatown,'' pleaded guilty to unlawful sexual intercourse with a 13-year-old girl and then, faced with a possible 50-year prison sentence, fled to Paris. He continues to live in France and remains a fugitive from justice in this country. This documentary, directed by Marina Zenovich, explores the myths that surround the case and the circumstances that led to the conviction and flight of Mr. Polanski, now 74, who in 2003 won the best-director Oscar for ''The Pianist.'' Among those interviewed are Samantha Geimer, the victim; Roger Gunson, a former assistant district attorney; Douglas Dalton, Mr. Polanski's lawyer; and the actress Mia Farrow, in archival footage. 8 P.M. (ABC) THE BACHELORETTE DeAnna Pappas makes the men sing for her affection, with the most vocally talented getting to escort her to a performance by Natasha Bedingfield. Then six of the bachelors race stock cars at the California Motor Speedway, with the fastest guy winning time alone with Ms. Pappas. After which someone gets a rose.

CASSANDRA WILSON ''Loverly'' (Blue Note) When Cassandra Wilson made the all-standards album ''Blue Skies'' in 1988, such jazz tunes were a little more sacred than they are now. There was an innovation-versus-tradition argument in progress. Ms. Wilson was then an impossibly hip young singer making her name with a radical fringe that merged jazz improvisation with complicated funk (imagine that!). For her to record songs like ''I'm Old Fashioned'' and ''Polka Dots and Moonbeams'' -- with a straight-ahead rhythm section, treating the songs with due respect and scat singing -- amounted to decent frisson. It was a lovely record, too.

GORDON--George. Hineni expresses sympathy to Eileen Gordon on the passing of her beloved husband George, to their children Tara, Michael and Lin. We will always remember George's voice even when he no longer had a voice.

EMMYLOU HARRIS ''All I Intended to Be'' (Nonesuch) Emmylou Harris has always embraced the urge to excavate. She has a folk singer's air of resourceful humility and no compunctions about approaching other people's songs. Shaping her own music, she can be graceful and evocative. But like the best of her fellow inductees in the Country Music Hall of Fame -- she joined their ranks just a couple of months ago -- she doesn't bestow strict privilege on originality.

HOTAREK--Rudolph T., of Port Washington, age 91 on June 7, 2008 after a prolonged illness. Beloved husband of the late Regina Jamison for 60 years. Devoted father of Gail Dwyer (Edward), Brian (Christine), Regina, Robert (Joan), and Christine Shepherd (Scott). Loving grandfather of 11 and proud greatgrandfather of six. Highly decorated veteran of WWII, having received two Purple Hearts for wounds sustained in combat, and the Bronze Star for valor. One of the few decorated war veterans of both the European and Asian campaigns. For 30 years he has run his own incentive marketing firm where he worked until retirement, at age 80. Co-founder and former president of Port Youth Activities. He was an instrumental force in St. Ignatius Retreat Program for over 20 years and was also an active member of St. Peter of Alcantara Church since 1953. LIBOVE--Charles, 1926-2008. The great American violinist Charles Libove was a student at the Curtis Institute of Music with Lea Luboshutz and later with Ivan Galamian. His principle teacher was Demetrius Dounis. Few violinists could boast of a more wonderful technique and with Mr. Libove's passing the great golden age of violin playing comes practically to a close. Winner of the first International Enesco violin competition, the first International Naumberg Chamber music contest, he was also a member of the Marlboro trio, the Philharmonia trio, and the Paganini quartet for many years. Charles Libove is survived by his wife, the outstanding Ukrainian-American pianist and for many years his chamber music partner Nina Lugovoy.

LINDSAY--Nancy Dalley, on June 7th after a long and courageous battle with a pituitary tumor. Beloved wife for 58 years of Robert V. Lindsay, mother of Cameron Lindsay of Denver, Colorado, Tinker Lindsay of Hollywood, California and Robert D. and daughter-in-law Teresa Lindsay of Locust Valley, New York. Grandmother of Thomas and Dorothy Beatty, Jonathan and Andrew Warkentin, and Robert T., James, Alexander and Duncan Lindsay. Mrs. Lindsay was born in New York City and attended the Lenox School, Greenwood School and Vassar College. A noted breeder and judge of dogs, she filled judging assignments on three continents, including judge of Best in Show at the Westminster Kennel Club show. Mrs. Lindsay was a founding trustee of the American Kennel Club Museum of the Dog in Saint Louis, Missouri. She also is a past trustee of the Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge Foundation and served on the boards of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, the Cooper Union, the Animal Medical Center, the ASPCA, the Westminster Kennel Foundation, the East Woods School and the Dutchess Day School. She served as chairman of the Women's Committee of the American Museum of Natural History, and in 1976 as Vice-Chairman in London of the U.S. Bicentennial Committee which brought together collections of American Indian art and artifacts from world-wide sources for a London exposition in honor of the Bicentennial. A memorial service will be held Friday, June 13 at 11am, at St. Peter's Church on Deep Hollow Road in Millbrook NY. (Lithgow). In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Hospice, Inc. N.E.R.D. ''Seeing Sounds'' (Star Trak/Interscope) There are no drums better than the Neptunes' drums. Crisp, authoritative and crackling, they have laid the bedrock for many of the most electrifying rap songs of the last decade. And even though it's been a few years since the duo -- Pharrell Williams and Chad Hugo -- has had a stranglehold on urban radio, those who have followed the pair have failed to improve on its foundation.

The TV Sports column on Tuesday, about the first live network prime-time broadcast of a mixed martial arts show, misstated the number of known deaths in the sport's history. It is two, not zero. (One of them occurred in an unsanctioned bout.)

SPRIGGS--Dillard Pynor, born February 6, 1926, died peacefully May 29, 2008, in New York City following a long illness. As one of the first Wall Street analysts to focus on oil companies, he pioneered analysis of international oil issues. He joined Baker, Weeks in 1958 and eventually served as executive Vice President. In 1974, Mr. Spriggs testified before the Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee on Multinational Corporations, on the importance of developing domestic oil production to counter the global energy crisis. In 1978, Mr. Spriggs founded International Petroleum Finance, which he sold to Petroleum Intelligence Weekly in 1994, although he continued to write for IPF until his retirement in 1997. He is survived by his wife Nancy, daughter Julie (Glenn Stevens), step-daughter Barbara Gates (Patrick O'Donnell), two granddaughters, Chloe and Caitlin, and his sister Dorothy. In lieu of flowers, donations would be appreciated to a fund to be announced at his memorial service in September.

BECKER--Robert O., M.D., May 14, 2008. Among the world's great research scientists. Inspirational colleague, mentor, clinician, gentleman, environmentalist. He blew the whistle on the health/environmental effects of man-made electromagnetic fields, challenged the status quo, paid dearly, but remained undiminished. He leaves behind his beloved wife of 53 Years, Leila Mann Meyerson, his children, Cindie (Dr. Donald) Kastenbaum, David Meyerson, and Stuart (Lisa) Meyerson, and five wonderful grandchildren: Julie, Harry, Jessica, Samuel and Benjamin. He attended Poly Prep Day School where he achieved a football scholarship to the University of NC/Chapel Hill. He graduated from New York University with a degree in engineering and economics and later obtained an MBA from the Trinity School at NYU. As a graduate of ROTC, he became a pilot in the Air Force and was honorably discharged in 1955. He began his career as project manager at Centrig Industries, a small familyoperated construction company in NYC in 1956, and during his 35 year tenure as its Chairman and CEO, grew the company into an internationally recognized leader in heavy industrial construction and a world leader in the installation of newspaper presses, including The New York Times, Chicago Tribune, Miami Herald, San Fransisco Chronicle, Charlotte Observer, and the Washingon Post. As a result of having been a dialysis patient in 1992, Mr. Meyerson founded the Dialysis Centers of America (DCA) in 1995 with a strong commitment to improving the quality of care, treatment and outcomes for dialysis patients. Within three years, DCA grew from a single location to the largest kidney dialysis treatment in the Midwest. DCA'a greatest accomplishment was in the development of renal care informatics which became the ''golden rule'' adopted by the dialysis industry. In 1998, Mr. Meyerson founded the Radiology Corporation of America (RCOA), an innovator and early adopter of Positron Emission Tomography (PET), a new molecular imaging technology that improved the diagnosis and treatment of many diseases, including the early detection of cancer and Alzheimer's Disease. Mr. Meyerson was also instrumental in founding the Institute of Molecular Technology, a trade association which educated the medical community about the benefits of PET technology which led to the acceptance of reimbursement protocols under Medicare. As a result of his daughter's juvenile diabetes in 1967, Mr. Meyerson was a co-founder and the inspiration for the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation (JDF), both the New York chapter and the national organization, where he served as a Board member for many years. In addition, Mr. Meyerson was aformer Director of Gatekeeper Solutions, the Whitney Art Museum, Dance Theater of Harlem, Boca Rio Country Club, and a member of Chief Executives Organization, World Presidents' Organization and Young Presidents' Organization. He was a renaissance man involved in Arts and Theatre and his philanthropic endeavors included support of Technion University, Kravis Center for the Performing Arts, Broward Center for the Performing Arts, University of Minnesota, American Parkinson's Disease Foundation, among many others. Mr. Meyerson was an avid art collector of photorealism and supported many young artists. He generously donated art to both the St. Louis Art Museum and the Whitney Museum Of Art. Services will be held Tuesday, June 10th, 2008, 11:45am at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made to M.D. Anderson Cancer Research Center, Houston, TX, and the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation.

RAFEL--Ellen Frankel. We are very sad; we send love to Erwin, Gideon and Saul. Judy and Philip Parkas RAFEL--Ellen. Surrounded by family and friends, Ellen Rafel, 63, passed away on June 5, 2008. Serving children of NYC's Public Schools for over three decades, she was chosen by her peers ''Guidance Counselor of the Year'' three times. Paraphrasing Ted Kennedy, to Ellen love meant having a social conscience and battling the wrongs which needed our attention. Each time we act to improve the life of others, or strike out against injustice, we send forth a tiny ripple of hope. Ellen sent out lots of ripples. She was a good and decent woman, who saw wrong and tried to right it, saw suffering and tried to heal it. She will be remembered by her husband, Erwin Rafel-Frankel; sons, Gideon and Saul; sister, Judy Englander; nieces, Freya and Emily; grandnephew and niece, Nathan and Ruby and dear family and friends. Funeral services will take place Sunday, June 8, 10am at Temple Anshe Chesed, West End Avenue and 100th Street. May her memory, like her life be for a blessing. RAFEL--Ellen. Farewell friend from all of the Ellens, Judys and Lauras who will remember you always with love.

Health work in poor countries looks easy -- vaccinate the kids, treat malaria, prevent mother-to-child transmission of AIDS -- and yet in fact it's extraordinarily difficult and has often failed. Because of AIDS, life expectancy has fallen. A quarter more women die in childbirth now in Africa than in 1990. As for malaria, we don't even have a good sense of the scale of the challenge. We roll out multi-billion dollar anti-retroviral programs for AIDS, but we don't even deworm kids or iodize salt -- two simple interventions that would raise school attendance, reduce malnutrition and anemia, and prevent cognitive impairment and even cretinism.

Dominik Hasek, the goaltender known as the Dominator, retired Monday because he said he lacked the motivation for a 17th season. His announcement came five days after Detroit won the Stanley Cup in six games over Pittsburgh. Hasek, a six-time Vezina Trophy winner as the N.H.L.’s top goaltender and a two-time Hart Trophy winner as the league’s most valuable player, leaves on a mixed note. Hasek, 43, the only goalie to win the M.V.P. award twice, lost his job during Detroit’s run to the Cup. He was benched in favor of Chris Osgood.
Madison Square Garden, which last hosted an N.C.A.A. tournament game in 1961, is hoping its $500 million renovation will help it land the East Regional championship as early as 2012.
A 6-year-old girl was killed after she was struck by a hit-and-run driver and possibly by a second vehicle in the Bronx, the police said.
The Libertarian Party selected Susan Overeem as the nominee for the Congressional seat being vacated by Representative Vito J. Fossella of Staten Island.
Nearly two weeks after Ian Kennedy was put on the disabled list, the Yankees’ rotation may no longer have a place for him.
Two months into the season, Omar Minaya, the general manager of the Mets, did not expect the $138 million Mets to be so skittish.

A preliminary examination by the Dallas County Medical Examiner’s Office has determined that the woman found dead last week with David Jacobs, a convicted steroids dealer who tied several N.F.L. players to performance-enhancing drugs, was a homicide victim, the police said. The woman, Amanda Jo Earhart-Savell, and Jacobs were found dead on Thursday at Jacobs’s home in Plano, Tex. Last week, a preliminary examination by the medical examiner’s office found that Jacobs had shot himself. The police have said that the deaths are consistent with a murder-suicide.

The Chicago Bears released running back Cedric Benson after his second alcohol-related arrest in a month. General Manager Jerry Angelo said in a statement that Benson “displayed a pattern of behavior we will not tolerate.” Three ineffective and injury-plagued years by Benson left management looking for another running back, and that was before his recent brushes with the law.

Michael Curry, with one year of experience as an assistant, will be the Detroit Pistons’ coach next season, the team’s president, Joe Dumars, said. Curry was an assistant last season in Detroit under Flip Saunders, who was fired last week. Curry agreed to a three-year deal.

Dominik Hasek, the goaltender known as the Dominator, retired Monday because he said he lacked the motivation for a 17th season. His announcement came five days after Detroit won the Stanley Cup in six games over Pittsburgh. Hasek, a six-time Vezina Trophy winner as the N.H.L.’s top goaltender and a two-time Hart Trophy winner as the league’s most valuable player, leaves on a mixed note. Hasek, 43, the only goalie to win the M.V.P. award twice, lost his job during Detroit’s run to the Cup. He was benched in favor of Chris Osgood.
A retired police officer pleaded guilty to killing a retired Port Authority officer as part of an agreement that will send him to prison for 21 years, according to prosecutors.

A “Notes” entry in some editions on Monday with an article about the scoreless soccer draw between the United States and Argentina referred incorrectly to an accomplishment by Landon Donovan, who played in his 100th international match. He became the 11th American man to reach that milestone, not the 11th American. (The feat has also been accomplished by 19 American women, according to U.S. Soccer.).
INTERNATIONAL.

A museum review on Monday about the new Contemporary Jewish Museum in San Francisco referred imprecisely to the landmark power plant on the site that was incorporated into the museum’s design. While the plant was indeed first built there in the 19th century, the landmark status derives from a rebuilding of it in the early 20th century, not the 19th.

An article on Monday about a temporary agreement by Hamburg, Germany, to incinerate the trash of Naples, Italy, referred incorrectly to Hamburg’s political leadership. It is a coalition of the conservative Christian Democratic Union and the environmentally conscious German Green Party; it is not governed solely by the Green Party. (The Greens do control Hamburg’s environmental waste policy.).

Schedule information on Monday with a music review of a concert at the 3LD Art & Technology Center that featured “Ballet Mécanique,” by George Antheil, and that was presented in conjunction with “Frequency Hopping,” a play about Antheil and Hedy Lamarr, misstated the center’s address. It is 80 Greenwich Street in Lower Manhattan (at Rector Street), not 80 Rector Street.

An obituary on Thursday about William E. Odom, a director of the National Security Agency in the Reagan administration, misstated his position under President Jimmy Carter. He worked for the National Security Council, not the National Security Agency.

An article on Thursday about the election of the Rev. Miguel d’Escoto Brockmann of Nicaragua as president of the United Nations General Assembly misstated the year he was appointed Nicaragua’s foreign minister under the Sandinista government. It was 1979, not 1989.

An art review on Friday about “Framing a Century: Master Photographers, 1840-1940,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, misstated the surname of the curator who organized the exhibition. He is Malcolm Daniel, not Daniels.
The early-season swelter in New York created an array of problems, from power failures to delays on several subway lines.

GORMAN--Bernadette, 59, former Executive Director of the Association of Independent Music Publishers in NY, died peacefully in her home on June 6 in NYC. Gorman worked at Shelter Records in the 1970's after leaving her home town of Chicago, and she subsequently worked in video production in London, England. For many years thereafter, Gorman was a music publisher in NYC, including stints as a paralegal for the Law Office of Michael Sukin, General Manager of the Arc Music Group, and most recently as Publishing Administrator for Denise Rich Music. Steeped in the international music business, she leaves friends and colleagues around the world in mourning. A wake and funeral will take place among her family in Chicago on Friday June 13 and Saturday June 14. Caroline Bienstock, Executive Director Association of Independent Music Publishers

HALSEY--Anthony P., 78, died June 6. Graduated from Hotchkiss 1949, Yale 1956, served in Korea earning the Bronze Star. Tony worked for 30 years at Chemical Bank retiring in 1985 as SVP. He moved to Mystic, CT, founded Bank of Mystic, Stonington Country Club, and was Mystic Art Center's three-time president, MIYC past commodore, Mystic Seaport trustee, Lawrence and Memorial trustee, treasurer; Elm Grove Cemetery president. Survived by Sandy, wife of 51 years; children, Wendy, Linda Bonadies, Toby, Bill, their spouses and his seven grandchildren. A passionate sailor, NYYC, CCA and Scandinavia's N.A. Station member plus several yacht clubs. Memorial Service: June 12, 1pm, Mystic Congregational Church, 43 East Main Street, Mystic, CT.
INTERNATIONAL IRAN'S LEADER TELLS IRAQ

SALIT--Rose, passed away on June 8, 2008 at the age of 97. Beloved wife of Henry, mother of Al and Charles, sister of Alan Kurtz, Mollie Goldin and Ray Schwartz, grandmother of Jordan, Lisa and Clayton, and great-grandmother of Samantha. Her warm smile, opinions and sense of humor will be missed.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy was released from a North Carolina medical center, one week after undergoing surgery for a malignant brain tumor. He told reporters it was ''good to be home, good to be here'' upon arriving at his home in Hyannis Port. Doctors who performed the surgery on June 2 at Duke University Medical Center said they were pleased with Mr. Kennedy's progress after the operation, which was intended to reduce the size of what was described as an aggressive tumor known as a malignant glioma. He will continue to recuperate at home, his office said, and will soon begin radiation and chemotherapy treatment at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, where the brain tumor was diagnosed.

BERKMAN--Stuart M., 82 of Peru, VT, and formerly of New York City, died Saturday June 7th at his daughter's home in Williamstown, MA, surrounded by his family. Born in Manhattan, Mr. Berkman was a graduate of Poly Prep, Pace University and Fordham Law School. He was an Army Air Corps veteran of World War II. He was a partner and attorney for Nathan Berkman & Co., and later president and CEO of Wichita River Industries, until his retirement in 1987. His wife, the former Anne Halpern, died in 1987. They were married in 1948. Survived by two daughters--Amy Griffin M.D., and her husband Michael of Williamstown, MA and Lisa Berkman Ph.D. of Cambridge, MA; and three grandchildren--Tia Hobbs, Andrei Pogany, and Alex Pogany; and one sister--Rene Nelson of Greenwich, CT and NY; and by his longtime companion, Natalee Everett of Peru, VT. Services are at Peru Cemetery in Peru, VT on Saturday June 14, at 2pm.

CHASIS--Barbara (also known as Dr. Barbara Parker): Devoted to her family and patients, she was an inspiration to all. She will be remembered for her caring and generous spirit, her optimism and curiosity, her fortitude and her commitment to making the world an enlightened, kinder place. There will be a small private service. Donations to the Caring Community, 20 Washington Square North, NY, NY 10011 or The Stein Senior Center, 340 E. 24th St, NY, NY 10010 would be deeply appreciated.

BIERMAN--Gladys (nee Foster), 89, passed away quietly on Sunday, June 9, surrounded by her loving family. Her valiant fight with lung cancer, her optimism and spirited personality were an inspiration for all lucky enough to know her. Loving wife, beloved mother to Gail Bierman, Lynn Beer and Bruce Bierman; mother-in-law to Alan Beer and William Secord; cherished grandmother to Sheryl, Beth, Allison, David and Jonathan. Adoring greatgrandmother to Sarah, Rachel, Sigal, Jack, Ty and Liana. Survived by her siblings Julia Groman and Marvin Foster. In loving memory of Gladys Bierman, donations may be made to New York Presbyterian Hospital, Intensive Care Unit. Funeral services at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street, NYC, June 10, 12:45pm. Our hearts are broken...

WOMEN MOVE TO SMARTPHONES About a third of the people buying Apple's new iPhone are women, who have become eager buyers of other smartphones like BlackBerrys, Treos and other models for both business and family reasons. Apple will sell a speedier version of iPhone for $199 beginning in July, hoping to sell 10 million iPhones in 2008. [C4.]

DOWNEY--Theresa M. passed away peacefully on June 7, 2008 at the age of 83 on Cape Cod, MA. Beloved mother of 10, grandmother of seven and great-grandmother of two. Reposing Wednesday and Thursday, 2-4 and 79pm at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave., Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial, Friday 10am at St. Eugene's Church, Yonkers. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Donations to National Alliance for Mentally Ill (NAMI) would be greatly appreciated.

A memorial service for Nuala O'Faolain, the Irish writer, is scheduled for Tuesday, June 24, at 7 p.m., in the Celeste Bartos Forum at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street. Ms. O'Faolain, who died in Dublin on May 9 at age 68, was best known as the author of ''Are You Somebody?,'' a memoir of childhood poverty and suffering. Among those expected to pay tribute to Ms. O'Faolain are the writers Frank McCourt, Sheridan Hay, Polly Devlin and Paul Muldoon; the literary critic Fintan O'Toole; and the book editor Julie Grau.

MEYERSON--Monroe. Above all you were the most giving, caring, and bravest of all men. We will miss you forever. Our sympathies to Leila, David, Cindie, Donald, Stuart, and Lisa, and the grandchildren. Meryle, Irving, Donald, Faye, Gary, Lester, and Andrea MEYERSON--Monroe. In laws but dear friends. We will miss you. We grieve deeply with all of you. The Kastenbaum Family MEYERSON--Monroe. We will miss you so much, our dear, cherished friend of over 50 years. Your stories, your wisdom, and your kind heart will live on forever. Our hearts go out to your darling Leila, your children Cindie, Stuart and David, and your grandchildren. With profound love, Jan & Larry Ruben

WALSH--Mary S.U. (formerly Sister Mary Kieran) on June 7, 2008, in Kingston. Born in NYC August 27, 1927, Mary Theresa Walsh daughter of the late Anna and James Walsh. Sr. Mary entered the Society of Saint Ursula on August15, 1945. She received a BS and MA from Fordham University. Sr. Mary taught at Academy of St. Ursula, St. Joseph's School both in Kingston, NY, Notre Dame School in NYC, J.A. Coleman HS in Hurley, NY and Arlington Catholic HS in Arlington, MA. Sr. Mary was campus minister at Seton College in Yonkers, at UNC, Chapel Hill, and St. Ann University Parish in Boston. She was an adjunct professor at St. John's University. She was currently working at the Linwood Spiritual Center. Mass June 11, 10am at Linwood, Rhinebeck. Memorials to the Society of St. Ursula or the Linwood Spiritual Center, Rhinebeck, NY. For information visit www.gormleyfuneralhome .com

DEGENSTEIN--Lee, died Sunday June 8th, 2008 in his home in New York City at age 52. Beloved father of David and Michael, son of the late Lester and Lila Degenstein, former husband of Dr. Joan Kent. Degenstein retired from SmithBarney, Senior Vice President for Communication. Raised in Manhattan, he graduated from St. Bernard's School; Hun School of Princeton; and attended Utica College. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, June 10, 9:30am, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home 81st and Madison Avenue. TREES--James, F. age 69, died June 2 in Tiburon, California. Jim Trees was a true renaissance man, a successful financier, rancher and conservationist. Jim received his Ph.D. from Harvard in International Finance and soon after founded and became Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Fischer, Francis, Trees & Watts, Inc., a New York investment management firm. Jim served on the faculty of Harvard Business School, and was a member of the Harvard Faculty research team on the Central American Common Market. At age 40, Jim left New York to pursue his passion for conservationism and the outdoors. In 1981 he built Trees Ranch, and Springdale Fruit Company, the first organic apple orchard in Utah. In June, 1992, he formed, and was CEO of BrianHead Resort, Inc. which owns and operates the largest ski and summer resort in southern Utah. In 1985 Jim founded and chaired the Grand Canyon Trust, an organization devoted to the restoration and protection of the Colorado Plateau and Grand Canyon. In 1997 he moved with his two young children from his ranch in Utah to San Francisco. His totality as a visionary, creator, outdoorsman, businessman and devoted father made Jim bigger than life to his countless friends across the country. Jim is survived by his two daughters, Willow and Sierra, a brother, Jack and sister Joanne Davis both of Lake Forest, Illinois. Services will be held July 23, 2008 at Jim's beach home in Sagaponack, NY. Donations may be made to the Grand Canyon Trust.

DERESIEWICZ--Herbert, 82, loving and beloved father and grandfather, died June 8, 2008. Born in Czechoslovakia, came to the U.S. 1939, served in the U.S. Army. Was Professor Emeritus of Mechanical Engineering at Columbia University, where he served more than 40 years. Brilliant theoretician; esteemed colleague; mentor and friend to a generation of students; generous supporter of Jewish campus education; valued member of Congregation Ahavath Torah, Englewood, NJ. Predeceased by his wife of 47 years, Evelyn (nee Altman), he is survived by his daughter, Ellen Schwartz, two sons, Bob and Bill Deresiewicz, and four grandchildren. Funeral services will be held 11am at Wien & Wien Memorial Chapels, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ.

I have to be careful writing about jockeys and riding as I still do veterinary regulatory racetrack work from time to time representing the horses and jockeys safety and welfare on race day. I try to stay out of debates involving riding strategy, so as not to have jockeys lose confidence in me should I happen to perform regulatory work at their track in the future. In order to effectively carry out regulatory duties, veterinarians have to maintain trusting working relationships with the jockeys. On the other hand, proper horsemanship is essential for horse racing safety, and regulatory veterinarians are certainly responsible for that.

Monaco, the richest 0.76 square miles on the Mediterranean, is not exactly the Frugal Traveler's kingdom. This independent principality is synonymous with money - big, untaxed money - and ways of spending it: fast cars, luxury goods, gourmet meals and high-stakes gambling. That was apparent even on the five-hour train ride from Montpellier (41.60 euros, or about $67 at $1.61 to the euro; www.voyages-sncf.com) along thegorgeous French Riviera. Instead of backpacks and sandals, my well-tanned fellow passengers were armed with Louis Vuitton handbags and Gucci sunglasses.

Daniel W. Drezner, a political economist at Tufts University and a veteran blogger, has posted a provocative essay about public intellectuals on his site. Drezner goes on to list a battalion of contemporary public intellectuals to prove his point, everyone from Barbara Ehrenreich to Tom Wolfe to Samuel Huntington.

BRIEFS From this morning's USA Today, two items that demonstrate the impressive willpower of today's young people. One survey found that virginity pledges are working for some teenagers, and another declared that cookies and candy were losing out to fruit as the most popular treats for children under 6.

BRIEFS As his struggle against President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe continues, Morgan Tsvangirai, the opposition leader, has begun to embrace a old term most often associated of late with Myanmar's reclusive government: "This country is effectively now run by a military junta," he said. Whether this rhetorical shift helps matters on the ground remains to be seen, though South Africa's leader, a key player in the region, voiced "serious concern" on the violent situation there hours later.
Aurora Lopez Mejia's Amulet ring and her 18k gold Eternity handcuffs (Shuli Hallak).
We've been discussing the presidential candidates' positions on medical marijuana. Here are a couple of other interesting reports on the subject:
I promised one of our most loyal readers and posters, Dan from South Baltimore, that I'd give a shout out to his new T-shirt and hat business. It's good stuff for horse enthusiasts. Check it out.

Although critics like to portray President Bush as unyielding, his steadfast opposition to the view held by many Americans that the Iraq war a mistake is not without caveats. There were mistakes made -- or at least one that he acknowledged during his last swing through Europe as president.
The collapsed business class airline Silverjet plans to be back in the skies within weeks after its administrators accepted a buyout offer from a Swiss investment firm.
"It is the most important work of American art of the 19th century," Sara Cedar Miller said.
The part of the brain that stores memory appears to shrink in people with sleep apnea, adding further evidence that the sleep and breathing disorder is a serious health threat.

Over the last few months several people whose opinions I respect have told me about positive experiences at dell'Anima, an Italian restaurant in Greenwich Village that hadn't impressed me so much right after it opened late last year. In a prior blog post I described a meal I had there in its early days.

Senator Barack Obama, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, has pulled even among white voters in New York State with Senator John McCain, the presumptive Republican nominee, and now has a commanding overall lead over Mr. McCain, 50 percent to 36 percent, according to a Quinnipiac University poll released on Wednesday. The survey suggests that New York remains a securely blue state, notwithstanding disappointment over the defeat of its home state senator, Hillary Rodham Clinton, by Mr. Obama in the Democratic nominating contests.

The private equity implosion has cast dubious light on the optionality inherent in private equity agreements. Many commentators, including myself, thought that the repeated invocation of these provisions by private equity firms last fall and in the new year would lead targets to demand firmer, less optional agreements from their private equity acquirers.
The Loew's Jersey Theater in Jersey City was once threatened with demolition but has been brought back to life through renovation.
William Gibson's most recent novel is "Spook Country."

Perhaps none of the folks being considered for the Democrats' No. 2 slot is as intriguing as Jim Webb, the former Reagan Navy secretary turned Virginia senator. Now a few in the blogosphere are trying to derail that train before it leaves the station. David Mark of the Politico feels Webb has a problematic sense of nostalgia:
It's hot! (We tell you, as if you haven't noticed yourself.) But a small measure of relief may be in sight.
In the world of broadcasting, PBS shuns commercials. On the Internet, things are different.

Of all the research reports written about the debut of Apple's new $199 iPhone this week, one written by Craig Moffett of Sanford C. Bernstein was particularly notable: He warned that the cheaper iPhone is really a step back, not a step forward, for open networks.

The Webby Awards were handed out last night in downtown Manhattan. Some of the comedy winners have been featured here before, like these two (others can't be featured here, ever). First, The Onion reporting on just what paranoid schizophrenics need -- help from the government ...

The speculation over who the two presumptive nominees will tap as their running mate is heating up as the media and the opposing campaign place more scrutiny, not only on the field of potential vice presidential contenders, but also on the campaign operatives who are combing through their resumes.
Pointless post: this story made me think of the example Stephen Pinker gives of a grammatical but incomprehensible sentence:
With average gasoline prices hitting a record $4 a gallon, drivers are increasingly looking for ways to cut fuel costs.
Dean Baker is upset at a news report suggesting that John McCain -- unlike Barack Obama! -- is concerned with job creation.
A closer look at our coverage on Iraq.
Yahoo's war of words with Carl Icahn keeps heating up.

Big news from the opera world: The soprano Deborah Voigt's returning to the London production she was fired from in 2004 because the director considered her too heavy to wear a sleek black cocktail dress. The ensuing uproar is now famous, and revenge is sweet, as she pokes fun in this video:
Citigroup's chief executive, Vikram Pandit, on Tuesday called for a "vigorous" debate on regulatory oversight as the crisis in the financial services industry continues, Dow Jones Newswires reported.
European Union regulators said Wednesday that they would investigate whether Italy's rescue loan to ailing national airline Alitalia is illegal, The Associated Press reported.
Staples, the office goods supplier, won approval from Corporate Express on Wednesday to take over the Dutch firm with a sweetened 1.7 billion euro ($2.65 billion) bid.
Last week the Times alerted you to the science of sarcasm. Now we find this insightful Wikipedia entry called "Sarcasm is really helpful":

The chief executive of Chrysler, Robert Nardelli, said on Tuesday that the private equity buyers of auto maker Chrysler weren't second guessing their decision to buy Chrysler, and that the business was ahead of target.
With its latest $6 billion capital-raising plan, Lehman Brothers seemed to have staved off a panic along the lines of the one that forced Bear Stearns into an emergency sale.

Merrill Lynch's chief executive, John Thain, on Tuesday said he would like to see broker-dealer access to the Federal Reserve discount window continue longer term, though any increase of regulation in exchange must be appropriate for securities firms.
