Investors withdrew a net amount of nearly $6 billion from hedge funds in April, according to a report from TrimTabs Investment Research and BarclayHedge. It was the first time in more than two years that outflows outpaced inflows, according to Financial News; Reuters said it was the largest outflow in six and a half years. Either way, it suggested investors were not happy with the returns they were seeing.
The latest Big Apple trophy being coveted by oil-rich sovereign wealth funds is the landmark Chrysler Building, according to The New York Post.
Seven months after the $6.6 billion leveraged buyout of United Rentals by Cerberus Capital Management was scuttled, the tool rental company is planning what amounts to its own leveraged buyout.

The heirs of Laurence Tisch, who died in 2003, and his brother, Preston Robert Tisch, who died in 2005, controlled an estimated 23 percent of Loews stock before the spinoff of its Lorillard tobacco company on Tuesday.

A director in single stocks equity derivatives trading at Merrill Lynch in London has quit and is thought to be joining a hedge fund, amid a trend in which investment bank staff are leaving to join alternative investors or brokers in the hope of greater rewards.
Kirk Kerkorian wasn't at loss for options Tuesday, as Ford Motor investors rushed to tender their shares after the financier offered to buy 20 million shares of the automaker for $8.50 a piece.
An activist investor is accusing Syms Corporation, an off-price clothing retailer whose motto is "an educated consumer is our best customer," of not being too forthright about its real estate assets.
HSBC said on Wednesday it might consider pulling out of a $6.3 billion deal to buy Korea Exchange Bank , a move analysts say would heap more pressure on South Korean regulators.

The Commodities Futures Trading Commission said Tuesday that it is establishing a task force to study the role of speculators and index traders in commodities that will include representatives of the Federal Reserve, the Securities Exchange Commission and other agencies.

The Middle East is getting another home-grown private equity fund, as the new $500 million Islamic Buyout Fund has received commitments from Global Investment House and Dubai Islamic Bank, according to The Deal.com.

Medical supply management company CCS Medical Holdings has canceled its proposed initial public offering of 10 million shares because difficult market conditions, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing on Monday.

Peplin, a development-stage pharmaceutical company, has canceled its proposed U.S. initial public offering, citing "unfavorable market conditions," according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday.

Lawyers in a class action suit against UnitedHealth Group say freshly unsealed documents show that the company's current chief executive, Stephen Hemsley, was more involved in granting backdated options than previously thought, The Wall Street Journal reported.

The affectionate fist bump between Senator Barack Obama and his wife, Michelle, before his victory speech last week in St. Paul became an instant source of fascination among commentators in the news media, who for days have tried to decipher the meaning behind this supposedly odd gesture.
Perimeter eSecurity, a provider of network security services, said on Tuesday it has acquired security vendor Edgeos for an undisclosed amount to boost the capabilities in its products.

Brazilian mining giant Vale said Tuesday it was preparing a share offering worth up to $15 billion to help finance organic growth and potential acquisitions, but denied it was in talks on an acquisition.

Precision Drilling Trust, Canada's largest oil services company, is launching a hostile $1.6 billion bid for U.S. driller Grey Wolf Inc. as it joins the move to tap the booming - and more stable - American energy market.
Clues in the Fifth Avenue apartment of the Klinsky-Sherry family embedded by their architectural designer led them on a scavenger hunt through their home.

Soaring commodity prices have triggered an avalanche of coal miners looking to go public in Canada, including a Pennsylvania producer considering a listing that could value the company at about 1 billion Canadian dollars ($981 million), according to The Globe and Mail.

A founder of Peloton Partners, the Britain-based hedge fund group that folded earlier this year, is marketing a new fund to investors, The Financial Times reported, calling it "the latest example of how quickly investors can forgive managers of failed funds."

Constellation Brands' Columbia Winery has been sold along with sister winery Covey Run as part of an eight-winery, $209 million deal with Ascentia Wine Estates, a newly formed private company based in California.
Japanese drug maker Daiichi Sankyo moved to take majority control of India's biggest drug maker Ranbaxy Laboratories in a friendly deal worth up to $4.6 billion.
Madrona Venture Group has raised a $250 million venture fund, the largest in the 13-year history of the Seattle venture capital firm.

Foster + Partners, Will Alsop and Rogers Stirk Harbour + Partners are among the big name U.K. architects turning their talents to jelly. Specifically, they are participating in the Architectural Jelly Design Competition, which seeks to "raise awareness of the relationship between food and architecture," as part of the London Festival of Architecture 2008, June 20 to July 20.
Molly, a three-legged Shetland pony, survived Hurricane Katrina and a pit bull attack. Now, she's helping human amputees cope and is advancing the cause of equine medicine.
HBO’s film about the 1960 U.S. Open is really three minibiographies on golf legends with father-son issues.

To be young and hip in Beijing means knowing where the scene is. The scene, however, is a moving target, a rough beast that always seems to have slouched on just as I get there. When I was young and Jiang Zemin was President, the place to party was the bar area blossoming in the Sanlitun embassy district. It's still there, though many of the old haunts have been replaced by office towers.
Location: Orlando, Fla.
Kent Desormeaux initially thought he was off the hook this time.

Stuart Elliott's verdict on the upfront market of TV advertising sales: "It appears, from discussions with network executives and industry analysts, that the broadcasters may have matched the $9.1 billion to $9.2 billion they took in last spring before the start of the 2007-8 season."
Arsenio Hall, best known for his eponymous 1990s late-night talk show, "has been named host of MyNetworkTV's new comedic clip show, 'Funniest Moments,'" according to The Hollywood Reporter.

Fourteen research teams studying the impacts of warming on the Arctic Ocean have issued independent projections of how the sea ice will behave this summer, and 11 of them foresee an ice retreat at least as extraordinary as last year's or even more dramatic. The other three groups that issued a numerical estimate see the ice extent heading back toward, but not equaling, the average minimum for summers since satellites began tracking the comings and goings of Arctic sea ice in 1979. Five other groups chose not to issue a numerical estimate.
Few filmmakers make the end of days seem as hauntingly beautiful as Werner Herzog does in “Encounters at the End of the World.”
The wine panel tasted 25 bottles of malbec from Argentina that cost no more than $25 each.
From 1928 to 2003, there were only six winners of the U.S. Open who were not American. But Australia’s Geoff Ogilvy, the 2006 winner, could be in the middle of a new trend.
The new St. John’s Bread and Life center in Bedford-Stuyvesant has an innovative new element for feeding the poor.
At Jim McKay’s funeral Tuesday, there were stories about his on-air work, writing skills and modesty. But more than anything, the tales pointed toward home and family.
After several tries, a robotic arm finally succeeded in placing clumps of extraterrestrial soil into the vehicle for analysis.
The campaigns battled over John McCain’s comments about when he expected troops to return from Iraq.
Gen. Peter Pace, who was denied a second term as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff a year ago because of the war in Iraq, is one of the recipients.
Chien-Ming Wang won for the first time in seven starts and Mariano Rivera registered his 17th save of the season.
On a long, rain-delayed evening at Shea Stadium, the Mets squandered a four-run lead and allowed four home runs as they lost their fifth consecutive game.
Nothing ever looked easy for the Lakers Tuesday night, but they at last made their mark, three games into the series, with Kobe Bryant leading the way with 36 points.

Vinny Del Negro has accepted his first head-coaching job, agreeing to take over a Chicago Bulls team that went from 49 wins to 49 losses in a season and missed the playoffs after making the second round in 2007.
The Mets had an entertaining rain delay Tuesday night at Shea Stadium after the sixth inning of their game against the Diamondbacks.
A man died on Monday after being shocked twice with an officer’s Taser stun gun while trying to swallow a bag of drugs.

OAO Norilsk Nickel, the world’s biggest producer of nickel and palladium, reported an unexpected decline in profit for 2007 after cutting almost $2 billion off the value of mining and power companies it bought last year.
German wholesale prices jumped 8.1 percent in May compared with a year ago, the biggest increase in 26 years, the Federal Statistics Office said.
Trevor O’Hoy, the chief executive of the Australian brewer Foster’s Group, resigned as the company cut its profit forecast and began a review of its wine business.

Washington Wizards guard Gilbert Arenas opted out of his contract, giving up a $12.8 million deal to become a free agent on July 1. Arenas, a three-time All-Star, has had two operations on his left knee in the past 14 months and missed most of last season. He has said he will seek a rich long-term deal but will take less money to stay in Washington so that the Wizards can have more money to re-sign forward Antawn Jamison. Arenas has averaged 22.8 points in his seven-year career, but managed 19.4 a game in 13 games last season.

The American George Hincapie won the second stage of the Dauphiné Libéré race in a sprint finish in Vienne, France. He finished the 114.3-mile stage in 4 hours 32 minutes 38 seconds. Sébastien Chavanel was second and Sébastian Lang was third. Thor Hushovd was fifth and retained the overall lead. The third stage of the Dauphiné Libéré, a warm-up for the Tour de France, will be a 19.3-mile time trial on Wednesday.

USA Basketball has changed its plan and will select the 12 players headed to Beijing before they report to Las Vegas for a training camp later this month. The original idea called for the team to have up to 16 players in camp and cut down to 12 on June 30. Jerry Colangelo, the managing director of USA Basketball, said the team would most likely be announced after the completion of the N.B.A. finals.
French industrial production rebounded in April from a decline in the previous month, led by output of cars, electrical equipment and chemicals.
Brazil’s economy grew 5.8 percent in the first quarter, powered by higher consumer spending that is stoking inflation and forcing the central bank to raise interest rates.

Fires that ignited along Interstate 5 in Stockton swept through a neighborhood and torched at least 30 homes, said a city spokeswoman, Connie Cochran. Two firefighters suffered minor injuries, she said, but returned to the fire lines. Paramedics treated residents for smoke inhalation, but no one was taken to a hospital. Officials did not cite an immediate cause for the four separate fires, which started about 11 a.m. in grass and brush along the interstate. High wind spread the embers quickly, officials said, while thick smoke slowed freeway traffic. Stockton is about 50 miles south of Sacramento.
Architects and engineers are fighting Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s effort to downgrade the qualification requirements for the city’s buildings commissioner.

The herb St. John’s wort does not improve children’s symptoms of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, according to researchers who tested it as a possible alternative to stimulant drugs used to treat this common condition. A study published in The Journal of the American Medical Association involving 54 children with the disorder ages 6 to 17 found that those given St. John’s wort did no better than those getting a placebo. Millions of children with the disorder are treated with stimulant medications like Ritalin and Adderall.
Representative Ron Paul is planning a daylong rally in Minnesota during the Republican National Convention there that could draw attention from the presumed nominee, Senator John McCain.
Hanley Ramírez led off the game with one of Florida’s three home runs against Philadelphia starter Brett Myers, and the host Marlins went on to defeat the N.L. East-leading Phillies.
A sidewalk plaque in Lower Manhattan commemorates the Giants’ historic win over the heavily favored New England Patriots in Super Bowl XLII.
Aubrey Huff matched his career high with four hits, including a tying two-run single, and the Baltimore Orioles came from behind twice to hand the Boston Red Sox a rare home loss.
For a second consecutive day Tuesday, the 96-degree heat and electricity use set records as residents cranked up their air conditioners to get through the unusual four-day June heat wave.
A jury acquitted two carpentry union officials of charges that they had taken a bribe.
The illness of the 19-year-old Austrian woman helped expose the secret of a 73-year-old man accused of locking several family members in a cellar for up to 24 years.
The opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai dismissed speculation that he was negotiating with President Robert Mugabe to form a unity government and cancel the presidential runoff on June 27.
A Kenyan cabinet minister and an assistant minister were killed when their small plane crashed near the Masai Mara game reserve.
A senior Vatican official said that the West had become “obsessed by Islam,” to the detriment of other religions involved in interfaith dialogue.
A plan to help Mexico fight drug trafficking emerged from a House-Senate conference in Washington with controversial human rights conditions intact.

Marc Crawford was fired as coach of the Los Angeles Kings on Tuesday after his team finished with the fewest points in the Western Conference. He spent two seasons with the team and had a year left on his contract. Dean Lombardi, the team’s president and general manager, said that he and the Kings’ owners had decided to rebuild rather than try to create an immediate Stanley Cup contender, and Crawford was not the coach for such a team. Crawford coached the Kings to a 59-84-21 record in his two seasons. Last season, the Kings had 71 points, tied with Tampa Bay for the fewest in the league.

After losing more than $30 million, the International Fight League has canceled a card scheduled for August and is seeking help to stay afloat. The show was to have been held Aug. 15 at the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J. The I.F.L. said it might seek protection from creditors via the courts if it did not come up with a solution, like a new partner or investor.

More people are hurt while snowboarding than during any other outdoor activity, accounting for a quarter of emergency room visits, according to the first national study to estimate recreational injuries. Trailing snowboarding were sledding and hiking, researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported in the journal Wilderness and Environmental Medicine. The most common problems were broken bones and sprains, accounting for half of all cases. About 7 percent of emergency room visits were for concussions or other brain injuries.

Ron Wilson was introduced as the coach of the Toronto Maple Leafs, less than a month after he was fired by the San Jose Sharks. Wilson, 53, signed a four-year deal. He was fired May 12 by San Jose after the Sharks lost to the Dallas Stars in the second round of the playoffs. He succeeds Paul Maurice, who was fired last month after missing the playoffs in consecutive seasons.

USA Basketball has changed its plan and will select the 12 players headed to Beijing before they report to Las Vegas for a training camp later this month. The original idea called for the team to have potentially 16 players in camp and cut down to 12 on June 30. Jerry Colangelo, the managing director of USA Basketball, said the team would most likely be announced after the completion of the N.B.A. finals.
The economy has Senators John McCain and Barack Obama echoing their party lines.
N.B.A. executives and referees are accused of broad misconduct and outright manipulation of game results in the latest court filing by the lawyer for the former referee Tim Donaghy.
Jason Giambi’s recent surge has made it clear his career is not finished. But no matter how his season had been going, Giambi said, he would have wanted to keep playing.
Hillary Rodham Clinton’s aides have kept close track of the past allies and beneficiaries of the Clintons who supported Barack Obama’s campaign.
Shoe soles incorporating rice husks will be worn by elite marathon runners in the Beijing Olympics.
The bell will ring at Torrey Pines on Thursday at 8:06 a.m., when Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson, along with Adam Scott, who is No. 3 in the world, tee off on the first hole.
An East Village figure from the world of countercultural politics has been arrested on charges of money laundering in Mattoon, Ill., about 170 miles south of Chicago.
Congress is shifting quickly to a general election footing, with lawmakers of both parties intensifying efforts to exploit public alarm about gasoline prices and the economy.
As the winner of the Masters, Trevor Immelman is the only golfer eligible to win the 2008 Grand Slam. Asked Tuesday if he had considered that possibility, Immelman quickly answered: “No.”
A large number of classic characters for children are being freshened up to try to cater to parents’ nostalgia and children’s YouTube-era sensibilities.
The police unit will be changed in an effort to ensure that governors do not exert improper influence over troopers.
Bank of America is selling its prime brokerage operation to BNP Paribas for around $300 million after a six-month bidding process, according to people briefed on the deal.
The agreement with the owner, Anne Z. Whitman, leaves only two property owners who have not settled with Columbia University, which is embarking on a $7 billion expansion.
James S. Tisch, has said that politics had nothing to do with the company’s decision to spin off Lorillard.
Senator Barack Obama’s choice of a Washington insider to run his vice-presidential selection committee has brought criticism from Republicans.
The case of a schizophrenic man accused of killing an Upper East Side psychotherapist underscores the difficulties of bringing a mentally ill person before the court.
The encouraging news for the Mets Tuesday was that Moises Alou was back on the roster after another trip to the disabled list. But replacing him on the D.L. was Ryan Church.
U.S. News & World Report will publish every other week, while continuing to expand the consumer reporting and product rankings it has bet its future on.
INTERNATIONAL.
Already planning ahead for Big Brown’s next race, members of his team said that they planned to stick with jockey Kent Desormeaux and resume the colt’s treatments of Winstrol.
Space Adventures plans to buy a Soyuz flight in 2011, with the option of buying more. One of the passengers will likely be Google’s co-founder, Sergey Brin.
The Colorado Rockies returned some pop to their lineup Tuesday as the All-Star outfielder Matt Holliday was activated off the disabled list.
More than 100 people have been arrested in New York City this month as part of a continuing effort to crack down on buildings with outstanding fire code violations.
Mr. Asinof’s journalistic re-creation of a 1919 Black Sox scandal, “Eight Men Out,” became a classic of baseball literature and narrative nonfiction.
New York City is just beginning to get serious about making construction safety a priority. It must do more to fix a broken system.
The government should be rushing to improve the oversight and care in its sprawling detention system to protect all detainees.
To win the right to host the Games, China promised to improve its human-rights record. It keeps moving mostly in the opposite direction.
No one ever said that dealing with climate change would be easy or cost-free. But we expected better from the Senate.
Congress is pressing Bush administration officials on a still-unanswered question: How did the United States come to embrace harsh interrogation methods it had always shunned?
Federal agents have raided the offices of an influential lobbying firm in Albany as part of the latest investigation connected to the Jack Abramoff lobbying scandal in Washington.
The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California issued a water alert on Tuesday, asking communities to modernize and toughen their water conservation rules.
It appears that broadcasters may have matched the $9.1 billion to $9.2 billion they took in last spring before the start of the 2007-8 season.
The study said that the most recent census data show that 180,000 children — 15.7 percent of the state total — were living in poverty in Colorado in 2006, a 73 percent increase since 2000.
The two heavyweights in Group A of the European Championship, the Czech Republic and Portugal, both looked good, rather than great, as they won their opening games.
Police had to use video to determine who caught the 600th home run hit by Ken Griffey Jr. on Monday night in Miami.
The rising price of fuel and commodities have been especially painful for India and threaten to undermine the rapid growth of its economy.
The universe of potential candidates in Barak Obama’s vice-presidential search process shrank by one name and grew by another on Tuesday.
The trade deficit increased to the highest level in 13 months in April as America’s bill for foreign crude oil soared to a record high.
A fire on the PATH train tracks near the Ninth Street station in Greenwich Village knocked out service between West 33rd Street in Manhattan and New Jersey on Tuesday.
Federal health officials said that they hoped to announce soon the source of a salmonella outbreak associated with raw tomatoes that has sickened at least 167 people in 17 states.
The Giants will head into next season with the goal of getting better, not necessarily winning another Super Bowl, quarterback Eli Manning said Tuesday.
Japan’s salarymen have borne the brunt of its economic decline, enduring lower wages, job insecurity and long hours of unpaid overtime. Now, a few are fighting back.
A former racing official has sued Nascar, alleging that she was racially and sexually discriminated against in her two years working for the organization.
David Villa scored three times in Spain’s 4-1 victory over Russia on Tuesday in a European Championship game in Innsbruck, Austria.
Ohio must stop using a common combination of three chemicals to execute condemned inmates because they may produce excruciating pain, a state court judge ruled.
A retired Army colonel pleaded guilty to steering a military contract for warehouses in Iraq to a contractor for $4,000 and a vacation to Thailand.

Aubrey Huff matched his career high with four hits, including a tying two-run single, and the Baltimore Orioles came from behind twice to hand the Boston Red Sox a rare home loss, 10-6, on Tuesday night.
The Algerian-born men arrested in Spain are suspected of giving financial and logistical support to a terrorist group in Algeria linked to Al Qaeda.
Urban big-box retailing is no longer a novelty as more shopping centers try to squeeze into densely populated neighborhoods.
The detainees were opposition party members who were detained last month for demanding the release of the Nobel Peace Prize laureate Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.
Few pantry items can inflame an entire island, let alone a region. But not many snack foods have a history and following like that of the Crown Pilot cracker.
As editor of Reader’s Digest Condensed Books in the 1960s, ’70s and ’80s, Mr. Zinsser made nearly 800 carefully crunched versions of popular books available to readers.
The National Transportation Safety Board cited sleepy pilots as a reason that a regional jet slid off a snowy runway in Traverse City, Mich., in April, 2007.
Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates answered questions from Air Force personnel who were uneasy about the status of their service after the ouster last week of the two top Air Force officials.
The Sudan Airways aircraft burst into flames after landing at Khartoum airport.
Is the international system a collection of legal nuts and bolts cobbled together by governments to protect governments, or is it a framework intended to make the world a more humane place?
There are important lessons for U.S.-Egypt relations to be taken away from trying to understand Egyptian culture.
In Germany, as in many parts of Europe, demonstrators no longer protest President Bush’s appearances.
The festival features works by the Limón Dance Company in the centenary year of its founder, the choreographer José Limón.
“Roy Lichtenstein: Girls” at the Gagosian Gallery reveals the artist honing his indelible yet impersonal style.
XTO Energy’s acquisition of Hunt Petroleum, announced Tuesday, adds fuel to the fire of a feud embroiling the Texas dynasty founded by the legendary oilman H. L. Hunt.
A judge has told 50 Cent that he may not dispose of the Long Island property where a $2.4 million house was destroyed by fire two weeks ago, The Associated Press reported.
Last year Live Nation renamed a handful of clubs and small theaters around the country. The Philadelphia club has now reverted to its old name, Theater of the Living Arts.
R. Kelly told the judge in his child-pornography trial on Tuesday that he did not plan to testify in his own defense.
A 23-year-old stuntman died and six others were injured in a fire in Beijing while shooting a historical epic by the director John Woo, The Associated Press reported.
A portrait of the man believed to have inspired the character of Mr. Darcy in “Pride and Prejudice” is going on sale for about $98,000 at an antiques fair in London.
Playboy will publish Denis Johnson’s next novel in four monthly installments of 10,000 words each, to be written on deadline each month through the October issue.
The Fox News Channel will use a rotating series of people for its 5 p.m. hour, beginning next week with the conservative radio host Laura Ingraham.
Reality television proved lackluster in the ratings on Monday as ABC and NBC struggled opposite mostly repeat fare on CBS and Fox.
No one else does or has ever done what Lee Brian Schrager, the charismatic director of the South Beach Wine & Food Festival, does in the food world.
Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson said that the U.S.-China relationship is “growing in a positive direction,” but that he would press for a more open Chinese economy.
A thinner Deborah Voigt returns to “Ariadne auf Naxos” in London: the very production from which she was fired in 2004.
A Polish-language production of “Macbeth” opens next week on a specially constructed, two-story stage in a warehouse on the Brooklyn waterfront.
If you’ve decided to eat less meat, or are considering it for whatever reason, here are some suggestions to ease your path.

Jill and Andrew Pickering live in one of Singapore’s traditional colonial-era homes, with their distinctive black-and-white exteriors and sprawling gardens.

The great German Romantic Heinrich Heine was a “torn poet,” allergic to beauty even as he produced so much of it.
“Don Quixote” was performed on Monday with a good deal of flair and an enlivening sense of fun.

The European Union’s competition commissioner recommended that businesses and governments use software based on open standards.
Many young Muslim women are caught between Europe’s freedoms and the traditions of their parents’ generations.
Kaufman Astoria Studios, one of New York City’s three largest movie studios, is moving ahead with a major expansion plan, nine years after it was announced.
With her new releases, Jenny Scheinman can add vocalist, soloist and composer to her list of accomplishments.
Events, tastings, tours and demonstrations.
There was a sense of déjà vu at this year’s James Beard Foundation’s annual culinary awards, which took place Sunday night.
The British musician Jamie Lidell devolved into sonic shambles, burying himself beneath an assortment of digital manipulations at his show on Monday.
The Broadway belter Martin Vidnovic has charisma, but his voice is too big for the Metropolitan Room, where he performed a tribute to Sergio Franchi on Monday.
Restaurant openings and closings, and chefs on the move.

The affectionate fist bump between Senator Barack Obama and his wife, Michelle, before his victory speech last week in St. Paul became an instant source of fascination among commentators in the news media, who for days have tried to decipher the meaning behind this supposedly odd gesture. But perhaps none went as far afield as E. D. Hill of the Fox News Channel, who, teasing to a segment last Friday on the Obamas' moment, said: ''A fist bump? A pound? A terrorist fist jab? The gesture everyone seems to interpret differently.'' Media Matters, a liberal group, called attention to her comments that day and demanded an apology on Monday.

VAN NES--Andrew , on June 1st, 2008, in his Manhattan apartment of a massive heart attack. Born in 1946, he attended Fieldston School and graduated from Columbia College in 1969. After co-founding a highly successful magazine for students, ''College Monthly'', he went on to a career as an advertising executive at Grey, McCann-Erikson, and Doyle, Dane & Bernbach. He left business early to travel the world pursuing his deep interest in other cultures. Throughout, he maintained the closest ties with his wide network of friends: he was fond, amiable, ferociously smart, but never boastful, always the funniest person in the room, and unfailingly interested and interesting. His passing leaves a vacancy that nobody who knew him will be able to fill. The traveler sets out on this greatest of journeys mourned by his loving siblings Hans Van Nes Esq. of Croton-on-Hudson, NY, Dr. Gordon Van Nes of Chester, CT, Nick Van Nes of West Tisbury, MA, Bretta Lundell of NYC and Heidi Van Nes of New Paltz, NY; and his devoted nieces and nephews Jason Naylor, Erik Lundell, Ali Dolger, Chris Van Nes, Whitney Van Nes, Kate Lundell, Nick Cordella, Max Cordella, Joe Van Nes, Mary Liz Van Nes, Wyatt Naylor and Shane Naylor. Memorial services will be held at All Souls Unitarian Church on Lexington Ave and 80th St, NYC on Friday, June 13th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, please send a contribution in Andrew's name to Kind Heart Rescue of Monmouth-Ocean, 3 Hyacinth Ct, Cream Ridge, NJ 08514, Note: Dachshund Rescue Medical.

MARTIN--William Redmond , of Boca Grande, FL died Friday June 6, 2008. He was born July 2, 1920 in South Orange, NJ. He is survived by his daughter Sabina M. Harvey of Charlottesville, VA; his son William Redmond Martin Jr. of San Francisco; three grandchildren: Sabina M. Milbank, Emmaline H. Milbank and Joseph Hunter Milbank Jr. His service will be private. In lieu of flowers donations to the Boca Grand clinic would be appreciated.

New York State voters support, by a margin of 53 percent to 40 percent, Gov. David A. Paterson’s order to state agencies to recognize same-sex marriages performed outside the state, according to Quinnipiac University poll results released today. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has paid out more than $1.1 billion in claims for personal injury and property damage over the last 12 years, according to a new report [pdf] by State Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli.The claims include $285,046 paid by the Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North Railroad to riders who ripped their pants or other items of clothing on the armrests in the M7 train cars. The armrests are notorious among riders on the two railroads because their design makes them uniquely suited to snag on clothing, especially pants pockets. The two railroads received a total of more than 1,400 claims for torn clothing last year, significantly more than the two previous years, when about 800 claims were filed annually.

When lights and air-conditioners went out in Yorkville and Bensonhurst during this week’s heat wave and thunderstorms, Consolidated Edison customers were able to track the utility’s efforts to restore power in real time online. That is, if they still had power (or a battery-powered laptop or other device).In any case, those who could sign on found a nifty map that Con Edison started on May 30 to show which neighborhoods and how many customers lost power, the cause of the power failure and the estimated time until power would be restored.

What does this week's Science Times section have in common with "The Happening," the new thriller from M. Night Shyamalan? The common element is the ability of non-human nature to unnerve us when it acts out of character. I explored this notion for a half hour on the phone with the writer/director a few days ago, talking about science, nature, scary movies, the Gaia hypothesis, bee die-offs and more. Then I had an advance look at the film, which opens this weekend.

Microsoft and Yahoo have broken up again -- and this time, they say the relationship is over. In a news release Thursday afternoon, Yahoo said it had "concluded" discussions about a "potential transaction" with Microsoft for a full or partial acquisition.

I finally watched "Starting Out in the Evening" the other night, prompted by one rave review after the next, and I came away with a little shrug - entertained but not dazzled, and a bit mystified as to all the huzzah. Mostly I think that's because Lauren Ambrose's character was so despicable from the outset, so nakedly manipulative and self-serving, that I didn't believe a man as cautious and guarded as Frank Langella's character would ever be taken in by her. (Or maybe my expectations were too high. I had the same reaction to the overhyped "Sideways," after all, which I found merely likable enough.)
The talks are dead. Really, this time they are dead.

Architecture |"Paris is miraculous in no small measure because modern architects have not been able to get their hands on it." An essay about Léon Krier, architect-philosopher who believes that architectural modernism is not just ugly but also mistaken about people. -- City Journal

City Room opened the mail recently and discovered three sweatbands -- a headband and two wristbands -- promoting BeFitNYC, a new Parks Department initiative for recreational sports and physical exercise. Normally, we pay little attention to publicity-seeking giveaways. But it's a little unusual for the city to venture into the world of athletic wear (O.K., they did do bike helmets).

There's a new world record holder in the 110-meter hurdles: Dayron Robles of Cuba. Running at a meet in the Czech Republic today, Robles broke the world record set in 2006 by China's Liu Xiang by 1 one-hundredth of a second.
A pair of senior Yahoo executives is leaving the beleaguered Internet company, continuing a steady exodus of executives that began more than two years ago.

Perhaps the ultimate test of a top Wall Street executive is simple: Stay in the game. Of course, one needs to make money, and preferably lots of it, but especially when times grow tough, the hardest task is simply to hold onto one's seat.

The Triple Crown is over. We came very close to seeing a horse sweep the series. Big Brown was much the best in the Derby and the Preakness. The same horse did not show up for the Belmont for whatever reasons.

BRIEFS Previewing a major pornography case over the weekend, The Los Angeles Times noted that Judge Alex Kozinski's "involvement in the case may be a stroke of luck" for the defendant, Ira Isaacs. The paper cited some pornography-friendly rulings, though it didn't mention that he contributed to a Web site that featured sexually explicit materials. Now that the revelation has halted the trial, however, Mr. Isaacs's luck seems to have run out.

When the Yankees placed reliever J.B. Cox on the disabled list Wednesday without specifying a reason, it did not seem to be a good sign. But in talking just now to Mark Newman, the team's senior vice president for baseball operations, it seems to be just a minor problem.

Judging from Sean John's fall lookbook, black is the new black.Ensuring that there is adequate racial representation in fashion, an industry that tends to favor whitewashed ideals of beauty, is a hot-button topic. So it was a welcome surprise to see that Sean John's new fall/winter lookbook features exclusively black models. But then you start to wonder, where are all the Asians? And who's thinking about the poor freckly redheads? What do you think -- is Diddy going in the right direction, or is it all about promoting a good mix?
Qassem H.J. is a newspaper cartoonist working in Iraq. He abbreviates his name to protect his identity.
More campaign-related opinion for Thursday, June 12:

Things have not turned out as planned in Detroit, where the Tigers, buoyed by a major trade in the off-season that landed them the prized young stars Miguel Cabrera and Dontrelle Willis, have scuffled along to a 28-37 record good for second-to-last in the American League Central.
CNBC interviews Charles Plosser, president of the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank about his hawkish position on inflation.

In these volatile times for Wall Street, it's hard for an analyst to know whether to rate a banking stock a buy, neutral or underperform. Guy Moszkowski of Merrill Lynch seems especially torn -- this month alone, he has given all three ratings to Lehman Brothers.

While Gov. Jim Gibbons of Nevada most certainly had textual relations with that woman, none of the 867 mobile text messages between them over six weeks were "love notes," the governor told reporters on Wednesday.
In Chicago, international buyers are playing a key role in the development of two flashy residential tower projects.

It was more than a year ago when City Councilman Charles Barron announced that he would run for Brooklyn borough president in 2009 and that he was abandoning his plans to challenge Representative Edolphus Towns this year for his Congressional seat.

First, thanks to the people at The Rail, especially Melissa, who had the foresight to add actual bloggers, found me and Alan Mann (Left at the Gate), and put up with me. Not every blog is a "blog," but The Rail was one for sure.

"Foreign terrorism suspects held at the Guantánamo Bay naval base in Cuba have constitutional rights to challenge their detention there in United States courts, the Supreme Court ruled, 5 to 4, on Thursday in a historic decision on the balance between personal liberties and national security," reports The Times's David Stout, and again the court finds itself playing politics.

From Ed, a regular Bitten contributor. --MBAs of the first weekend in June there were still no real peas in the farmers' market. By "real" peas, I mean the roundish ones you take out of the pods while listening to music and looking forward to dinner. As opposed to snap peas and snow peas, where you eat the whole thing, pod and all, which I view as the most sinful sort of laziness. Next thing you know, they'll develop a peanut with an edible shell.

The charges by a former N.B.A. referee that the league used its referees to manipulate the outcomes of games has rocked the sport and put the league on the defensive. Do you believe the charges, and if so, how serious a blow is it to the league's credibility. If you don't believe them, why not?
Six of us are interested in traveling to Morocco. What are the best ways to travel among the cities, and are there tour companies that deal with small groups?
A two-hour edition of "So You Think You Can Dance" lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings on Wednesday, with 8.8 million viewers tuning in from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates.

Maybe we missed something, but it seems there's no mention in any of the area papers this morning that either Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist or Devils goalie Martin Brodeur might win the Vezina Trophy as the NHL's top netminder tonight.
Hillary didn't make it, but Stephanie did.
24 Days to L'Étape. Today's training: an hour and half "endurance" ride, which for me means a ride to the park after work, two quick laps of the 6.1 mile circuit, and a ride home.
A selection of articles from many sources on Iraq. For more, see the Baghdad Bureau blog's Google Reader Shared Items.

As the fog of the Triple Crown hangover begins to clear, everyone connected to American horse racing, from fans (those that are left) to hot-walkers, will be wondering what the future holds. Will the legacy of Big Brown and Eight Belles be change for the sport?
If I told you that today's e-column would change your life, would you mind that it's sort of short?
Aired Wednesday night on NBC: For the first time ever, gas across the entire country averaging $4 a gallon. Or as we call that in Los Angeles, the good old days.
Aired Wednesday night on CBS: NASA has announced a plan to take a trip to the sun. So, apparently, the search for bin Laden continues.
The Serbian police arrested one of the four remaining war crimes fugitives wanted by the United Nations tribunal in The Hague.
Cindy McCain, who recently spurned Oscar de la Renta, sporting what appears to be a Chanel watch (AP).
The kidnappers of a prominent businessman have demanded a $46.5 million ransom and have given his family a week to obtain the money and arrange for his release, the Greek media said.
Barclays said it picked up several former Bear Stearns bankers, as the British bank continues to bulk up its presence in the United States.
This is the third set of answers to selected reader questions from Gene Russianoff, staff lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, which advocates for public transit improvements.

Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Well, John McCain just announced he wants to do a series of town hall meetings where he'll meet with the public. That's a good idea, yeah. It's all part of McCain's "Speak Up, I Can't Hear You" tour.
If I take out a cash advance on a credit card to use toward a down payment on a home, is the interest I pay on the credit card deductible on my federal income tax return?

Aired Wednesday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Apparently Barack Obama is e-mail buddies with Scarlett Johansson. This is making me question Barack Obama's judgment, though. If he has Scarlett Johansson's e-mail address, why is he wasting time running for president?
If a tree on my property falls on a neighbor's house during a storm and damages it, whose insurance covers the damage?
Aired Wednesday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: President Bush is in Europe right now, on a tour of Germany, Italy, France, England, and several other countries that hate him.

It's pretty clear that technology can potentially smooth the path toward 9 billion people (more or less) seeking a decent life. The most familiar applications are in realms like energy (cheaper solar cells), transportation (Masdar's smart people movers) and health (water filters or quick tuberculosis tests). But there is growing evidence that another field, human rights, can be aided by gadgets -- in this case eyes in the sky.

Lookybook is a new site where you can browse children's picture books by flipping through every page. There's a bit of a half-baked social-networking angle to it - users can comment on books and build bookshelves of favorites. But mostly it's a try-before-you-buy tool. And maybe the coolest thing (for bloggers) is that you can embed any book on your own site as easily as a YouTube video.

Spaghetti carbonara -- spaghetti tossed with egg, crisp bacon or pancetta and loads of Parmesan -- has become something of a symbol for over-the-top pasta. Made with zucchini, though, the dish becomes a little less fat-laden. And because the backbone of the sauce remains eggs and Parmesan, it is still rich -- and quite delicious.
David Pogue enlightens readers with little-known tips for blocking cellphone spam.
What we're looking at on the Web today...

BRIEFS What to do with all the tomatoes banned from shelves these days? Today's edition of the Newseum's excellent feature on the nation's front pages offered an idea: "You say 'to-may-to' and I say 'to-mah-to.' But however we say it, it's front-page news. Since mid-April, salmonella-tainted tomatoes have sickened more than 150 people in 17 states, putting restaurants and consumers on alert. Today newspapers across the country highlighted the story as health officials, searching for the outbreak's source, struggled to ketchup.
Casual cable viewers could occasionally be forgiven for confusing CNN with The Weather Channel.

With rumors and innuendo flying around the Internet with greater ease -- and nastiness -- then ever before, the Obama campaign has decided to use the same medium to take on the purveyors of what the campaign is calling "dishonest smears."
STRICTLY CONFIDENTIAL
Pop Quiz: Which pitcher would you rather have?
It may be difficult to tell from this stock chart, but Lehman Brothers' stock has actually improved from earlier this morning.

Now that we've seen one Hollywood version of pre-Columbian crystal skulls, could there be another crystal-skull movie with some real archeology in it -- and a very devious French forger? I'm not sure what the box-office potential is, but if any reader can come up with the outline of a clever plot, I'll award a prize: your choice of an Indiana Jones DVD or a one-year subscription to the magazine Archaeology.
You're one of the top-ranked executives at a big-name Wall Street firm. You're in good with the boss (or so you think). And then it happens -- someone else gets your job.
Who says there are no literary feuds these days?

The United States military today confronted the sharpest criticism of an airstrike that left 11 Pakistani paramilitary soldiers dead on Tuesday night by releasing what it says is a video of the incident. (For background, see this article by Carlotta Gall and Eric Schmitt).

In the days since Barack Obama solidified his standing as the presumptive Democratic nominee, "television news executives have begun to set their plans for covering the four-day Democratic convention, which begins on Aug. 25, and its Republican counterpart, which opens in St. Paul on Sept. 1, Labor Day," Jacques Steinberg reports.

Democratic elected officials are clearly trying to make sure that City Councilman Michael E. McMahon has the upper hand in his campaign for the party's nomination for the Congressional seat now held by Vito J. Fossella, a Republican who represents Staten Island and parts of Brooklyn.
"It took four seasons, but a woman finally took the top spot on Bravo's 'Top Chef,'" the Associated Press reports.

Salon's Alex Koppelman, tipped off by a reader, reports that on Fox News yesterday, "during a segment discussing conservative attacks against Michelle Obama, the wife of presumptive Democratic nominee Barack Obama, the network described the former as 'Obama's baby mama.' " (Koppelman has the video clip of the controversial chyron on his blog.)
Video
The rain gods frowned on Switzerland and smiled, ultimately, on the Turkey, who came from a goal down to win in Basel on Wednesday night.

Updated, 4 p.m. | The Police Department said that divers searching the Hudson River on Thursday morning for a car that had become submerged in the water did not, in fact, find a body, contradicting an earlier account from a Fire Department spokesman.

The owner of a Brooklyn construction site where a day laborer died in March when earth and debris collapsed on him was charged with manslaughter. In announcing the indictment, at a time in which construction-related deaths in New York are running far ahead of last year's pace, the authorities said that more construction-related prosecutions may be ahead, Michael Wilson reports.

Lehman Brothers, suffering from a steep stock decline and its first quarterly loss as a public company, said Thursday that it replaced its chief financial officer and chief operating officer, effective immediately.

The resignation of Senator Barack Obama's top vice presidential vetter, James A. Johnson, whose businesses dealings had been called into question by the media and the opposing campaign, poses two sticky problems for the presumptive Democratic nominee.

A bitter battle for control of Anheuser-Busch appears to be looming after the brewer, one of the nation's most prominent family-run companies, formally became the target of a $46.4 billion unsolicited takeover offer from InBev of Belgium on Wednesday.

Invitrogen, which makes chemical kits used to analyze and clone genes, said it agreed to combine with Applied Biosystems Group, a unit of Applera, in a cash and stock deal it valued at $6.7 billion. The deal price of $38 per share is 17 percent above Applied Biosystems' closing stock price on Wednesday.
President Bush may have sworn off golf during wartime, but these patriots didn't. From the humor site 23/6:

The Webby Awards, which honor just about everything on the Internet, try to move things along by requiring that acceptance speeches consist of exactly five words (see above headline). Here are a few five-worders from the ceremony in New York Tuesday night (from the Bits technology blog):

In the end the CSX decision was not a surprise. Judge Lewis A. Kaplan of the Federal District Court in Manhattan had signaled on Monday that he would side with the railroad operator when he held a hearing on possible remedies. (Read his ruling as a PDF here.)

He laughs at the TV so hard he falls off the sofa. A neighbor downstairs thinks he's collapsed and calls the police. The police pepper spray him. Life imitates "Benny Hill." From the Daily Mail of London:
"And what about you and your husband?"
The Digital Ramble explores aesthetic topics through materials found online.

The fight between the CSX Corporation and two hedge funds seeking to win a proxy fight at one of the largest railroad companies in the nation, it seems, may not be over, despite a ruling Wednesday by a federal judge that the two activist funds ad violated securities laws by not disclosing their positions and intentions many months before they did.
Wednesday proved to be another grim day for Lehman Brothers as the investment bank's shares continued their plummet downward.
Another major shareholder advisory firm recommended stockholders reject billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn's slate of nominees to Biogen Idec's board, reducing his odds of success.
The chief executive of Merrill Lynch, John Thain, said that the bank would consider selling its stakes in BlackRock and Bloomberg if it needed more capital.
Merrill Lynch is raising a $6 billion private equity fund, according TheStreet.com, which cited a pitch to an investor earlier this year.

Bertelsmann, the German media group, is seeking $1.2 billion to $1.5 billion for its half share in Sony BMG after opening talks that could result in Sony gaining full control of the world's second-largest music company within weeks, according to The Financial Times.

Zoosk, an online social dating network, said Thursday it raised $4.1 million from a group led by Canaan Partners, its second round of venture funding since it was founded last year. In a press release, Zoosk said it would use the money to build its subscriber base and add new features to its network.

Take-Two Interactive Software is not only fighting a hostile bid from Electronic Arts, but it is also fending off an antitrust investigation from the Federal Trade Commission that was launched as a result of the prospective takeover.
Commerzbank and Allianz's Dresdner Bank are checking each others books in preparation for possible merger talks, Handelsblatt reported.

Tom Connolly, head of Goldman Sachs's U.S. leveraged-finance business, is leaving his post to join the firm's private-equity arm, where he will likely run a new fund investing in debt, according to The Wall Street Journal.
Essar Steel Holdings, an Indian steel maker, plans to raise its bid for U.S. rival Esmark by 12 percent to about $750 million to thwart a bid by Severstal of Russia.

Bullhorn, a Boston-based maker of software that helps companies with staffing and recruiting, said Wednesday that it received $26 million in financing from a consortium led by area venture capital firms Highland Capital Partners and General Catalyst Partners.

Merrimack Pharmaceuticals, which focuses on drug discovery and development of treatments for cancer and autoimmune disease, announced Wednesday that it has raised $60 million in a Series F round of financing.

In a press release early Thursday, Citigroup said it would "restructure" Old Lane, buying the assets of its multi-strategy hedge fund at fair value and integrating some of its other strategies -- convertible equities, credit fixed income and structured credits -- elsewhere at the bank.

The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed new rules on Wednesday intended to stem conflicts of interest, expand disclosure for Wall Street's credit rating industry and flag the ratings of more complex securities.
BHP Billiton on Thursday took its case for a takeover of rival Rio Tinto to well-heeled investors on Thursday, saying a marriage could better capture markets in fast-industrializing Asian economies.

Fans sometimes forget that at each year's NHL awards show, two MVP awards are given out: the Hart Memorial Trophy, voted on by the Professional Hockey Writers Association, and the Lester B. Pearson Award, voted on by the N.H.L. Players Association -- the players themselves.
Anwar J. Ali is an Iraqi employee for The New York Times.
The chief executive of Bank of America, Kenneth D. Lewis, said Wednesday he remains committed to buying Countrywide Financial, the giant money-losing mortgage lender.
Limerick BioPharma, a life sciences start-up in stealth mode, has raised $11 million in venture funding and $4.2 million in debt, according to VentureWire.

Deutsche Bahn's initial public offering may be threatened by possible violations of European Union law, The Financial Times Deutschland reported, citing Juergen Basedow, head of the Bonn-based Monopolies Commission.
Mistras Group, a provider of technology-enabled testing software, on Tuesday filed for an initial pubic offering worth up to $172.5 million.
OGX Petroleo e Gas, the Brazilian oil company controlled by billionaire Eike Batista, raised 5.87 billion reais ($3.58 billion) in what could be the country's biggest initial public offering.

The dispute between the oil giant BP and its partners in the Russian joint venture TNK-BP escalated on Wednesday when the two parties could not even agree to be on talking terms with each other and one threatened legal action.
A prominent Washington lawmaker said Wednesday that he would propose next week to ban large institutional investors, including index funds, from the nation's booming commodity markets.

ATA Airlines is suing the FedEx Corporation over its decision to drop the airline from its military charter team, a move ATA says forced it into bankruptcy protection and left it financially destroyed.

Alcoa stock fell nearly 8 percent Wednesday after a brokerage firm cut its investment rating and profit estimate, expressing doubts that Wall Street would like the new chief executive's strategy for the aluminum company.
Outside investors have poured into Nascar in recent years, buying stakes in race teams eager for an influx of money as the cost of competition rises.

Shareholders of American International Group are reportedly demanding changes to the management and board of the world's largest insurer, which has been struggling with the fallout of the subprime mortgage mess.
More of your "late night" jokes (send via the comment link below):

Haymarket Media has agreed to buy Compliance Week magazine from Financial Media Holdings Group for an undisclosed price. Haymarket's parent company, a privately held group based in the United Kingdom, owns about 100 magazines, including PR Week and Management Today.
Portugal is on the verge of advancing to the quarterfinals after Cristiano Ronaldo's all-around effort produced a decisive victory over the Czech Republic.
Chipper and funny, “Kathy Griffin: My Life on the D-List” exemplifies the way in which celebreality shows have taken over territory formerly occupied by situation comedies.
Donald Trump appeared in Scotland this week to defend his plan to build a massive resort and golf complex on the coastline outside Aberdeen, which was rejected by the local council.
The schedule is the great equalizer for a baseball team. If the Yankees are home a lot one month, chances are they'll be gone a lot the next month. Everything evens out.

Barack Obama is having the first post-primary crisis, a moment in which the only conceivable response is what was he thinking? Talk about unnecessary disasters. It's like having your career ruined because you invited the wrong person to host a party in honor of your nephew's godparents.
Location: Oxford, Miss.

UPDATED, 8:00 a.m.: For the first time since the 1930's, federal biologists confirmed that a leatherback sea turtle has nested on a Texas beach, at the Padre Island National Seashore near Corpus Christi.
Photographs by Julia Gorton of the downtown art rock scene from 1976 to 1980.
The Hunts Point produce market in the South Bronx claims the city balked when it asked the city to help them pay for an expansion that would cost more than $450 million.
The Parliament granted gay and lesbian couples the right to marry and to adopt children on an equal basis with heterosexual couples.
The Canadian government apologized for forcing about 150,000 native children into government-financed residential schools where many suffered physical and sexual abuse.
Thanks to a set of adapters that comes with the new $150 iP99 model of the iHome clock radio, the iPhone as well as various versions of the iPod can be docked.
If I take out a cash advance on a credit card to use toward a down payment on a home, is the interest I pay on the credit card deductible on my federal income tax return?
If a tree on my property falls on a neighbor's house during a storm and damages it, whose insurance covers the damage?

The charges by a former N.B.A. referee that the league used its referees to manipulate the outcomes of games has rocked the sport and put the league on the defensive. Do you believe the charges, and if so, how serious a blow is it to the league’s credibility. If you don’t believe them, why not?.

Bionic ankles dominated the chatter coming from the latest annual meeting of the American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons, especially a study that followed more than 5,000 ankle-surgery patients in California over the course of 10 years, including those who have had complete ankle-joint replacement.

In “The Franchise Babe” (Doubleday, $24.95), our narrator, the sportswriter Jack Brannon, spots a woman on a golf course. She is "MVP toned and shaped...first-team upstairs in a form-fitting, sleeveless, scoop-neck white top" and a "jacked-up mini." Sports fans will recognize this greens report as the work of Dan Jenkins, who since his seminal golf novel, “Dead Solid Perfect” (1974), has explored the relationship between the gentleman’s game, and, well, the gentleman’s game. Brannon makes his approach and unfurls his best pick-up line: "Golf is my life—how about you?".

While our friends across the pond battle it out in the European Championship, the U.S. team faces its own high-stakes international competition this Sunday, playing Barbados in the national team’s first qualification match for the 2010 World Cup in South Africa. And though we can (and often do) talk until we’re blue in the face about soccer’s growth in America, one fact remains: The U.S. attack needs a serious upgrade.

The image of Tiger Woods standing on a podium with an Olympic gold medal around his neck probably inspires heavy breathing among golf officials and some Olympic executives, but the bet here is that we’ll never see it , nor should we. The start of the United States Open today at Torrey Pines, with all the anticipation about Woods’s return from knee surgery and his pairing with Phil Mickelson, is a perfect reminder that major championships provide the most valid and respected measuring sticks in golf, and that the renewed effort to make it an Olympic sport is a fool’s errand.
The A’s ripped Darrell Rasner for seven runs in three and two-thirds innings, and the Yankees’ record stands even for the 23rd time this season.
President Hu Jintao has called on Sudan’s government to take steps toward peace in its Darfur region, state media said Thursday.
Normally, a 13-inning victory that ends a five-game losing streak would be a cause of celebration. But for the Mets, it was more like a consolation prize Wednesday night.
Janel McCarville scored 25 points and had 7 assists to help the Liberty beat Atlanta, 81-77. The Dream (0-8) lost a 12-point lead with 7 minutes 9 seconds to play.
The Yankees might be interested in seeking more public financing to build their new stadium, pending a regulation change by the Internal Revenue Service.
Moises Alou, the veteran left fielder, returned from the disabled list to play Tuesday but felt renewed pain in his left calf and was not in the starting lineup Wednesday night.
Staples agreed to buy Corporate Express for 1.68 billion euros ($2.6 billion) after raising its offer three times, becoming the world’s largest direct distributor of office supplies to companies.
Essar Steel Holdings, an Indian steel maker, plans to raise its bid for Esmark, a steel maker in West Virginia, by 12 percent to about $750 million to thwart a bid by Severstal of Russia.
The collapsed business class airline Silverjet plans to be back in the skies within weeks after its administrators accepted a buyout offer from a Swiss investment firm.
It was not exactly cold out on Wednesday, but New York was cooler than it was on Monday or Tuesday.

About two dozen guest workers from India who said they were victims of human trafficking at an oil rig construction company in Mississippi ended a hunger strike in Washington. The workers said the protest was to pressure the Justice Department to allow them to remain legally in the United States while their case is under investigation. They were brought to this country in 2006 and 2007 under temporary visas to work at Signal International, based in Pascagoula. Twenty workers fasted for varying periods over 29 days; five were hospitalized, said Stephen Boykewich of the New Orleans Workers’ Center for Racial Justice, which organized the protest. After a rally outside the department on Monday, justice officials agreed to meet with workers’ representatives.

A convicted killer, Karl E. Chamberlain, was put to death by lethal injection in Texas, becoming the first prisoner executed in the state since the Supreme Court lifted an unofficial moratorium on the death penalty in April. Texas, the country’s busiest death penalty state, is the fifth state to resume executions since the court rejected a legal challenge to the three-drug cocktail used in most executions for the past 30 years. Mr. Chamberlain, 37, was convicted of the 1991 murder of a 30-year-old Dallas woman who lived in the same apartment complex. Mr. Chamberlain was the 406th inmate executed in Texas since 1982 and the first this year.
After cameos with the Yankees the last two seasons, José Veras is making an impact as a setup man in a bullpen that has lost Joba Chamberlain to the rotation.
A criminal investigation of potential corruption inside the Department of Buildings’ crane inspection operations has widened to focus on several current and former agency employees.
The authorities said that all poultry in Hong Kong’s markets would be killed after signs of avian flu were found among chickens in four markets.
Prince Charles paid off a 17th-century royal debt of about $900, but he steered clear of paying interest of more than $90,000.
The world’s last Hindu king, Gyanendra of Nepal, turned in his scepter and bird-of-paradise plumed crown, and he announced that he would live as a commoner.
The army-backed Bangladeshi government released Sheik Hasina Wazed, the leader of a major political party who had been imprisoned on corruption charges.
Alcoa stock fell nearly 8 percent Wednesday after a brokerage firm cut its investment rating and profit estimate.
A State Supreme Court justice ordered the New York Legislature to give the state’s 1,250 judges their first pay raise in 10 years.

The Kenyan star and former world record holder Paul Tergat has set his eyes on the New York City Marathon in November. Tergat, 39, whose world mark of 2:04.55 in Berlin in 2003 was bettered by his Ethiopian archrival Haile Gebreselassie last year, has not competed since finishing sixth in the 2007 London marathon.

The Chicago Bulls introduced Vinny Del Negro as their head coach, ending a seven-week search in which they tried to lure Mike D’Antoni from the Phoenix Suns and discussed a return with Doug Collins. Instead, they wound up with someone who had never coached. Del Negro was the Suns’ assistant general manager this season.

Thieves broke into an Attleboro, Mass., jewelry company over the weekend and stole up to $2 million in gold, gems and other valuables, including Super Bowl rings made for Giants staff members, authorities said. The players and coaches received their rings last month.

The American teenage striker Jozy Altidore signed a six-year contract with Villarreal and said he was excited about joining the Spanish club. Villarreal agreed to pay a transfer fee reportedly close to $10 million for Altidore, a former Red Bulls player.
Big Brown’s trainer, Rick Dutrow, said Wednesday he intends to be prepared next week when he appears before a Congressional hearing examining safety issues in thoroughbred racing.
The charreada, a type of rodeo popular among a growing number of middle-class Mexican-Americans, is facing criticism over some of its events.
Labor leaders say Jason Furman, Barack Obama’s new economic policy director, focuses too much on corporate America and not enough on workers.
SPORTS.
Some of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s top fund-raisers are reluctant as they prepare to meet Barack Obama’s campaign manager on Thursday.
The unsolicited takeover offer from InBev of Belgium, if accepted, would create the world’s largest brewer.
A cold sense of dread used to descend on the afternoon before the opening day at the United States Open. But this year, there is a different, almost hopeful vibe at Torrey Pines.

The conviction of a former Black Panther in the killing of a prison guard in 1972 should be overturned because his former lawyer should have objected to testimony from witnesses who had died after his original trial, a federal magistrate found. The lawyer’s omission denied a fair second trial for the man, Albert Woodfox, in 1998, the magistrate, Christine Nolan, wrote Tuesday in a recommendation to the federal judge who will rule later. Mr. Woodfox, 61, and Herman Wallace, 66, were convicted in the stabbing death of the guard, Brent Miller, on April 17, 1972. Mr. Wallace has been appealing his conviction based on arguments similar to Mr. Woodfox’s. Mr. Woodfox and Mr. Wallace, with another former Black Panther, became known as the Angola Three because they were held in isolation for about three decades at the Louisiana State Penitentiary in Angola.

The House has voted 251 to 166 to send articles of impeachment against President Bush to the Judiciary Committee, which is not likely to hold hearings before the end of his term. Representative Dennis J. Kucinich, Democrat of Ohio, who ran for president, spent more than four hours on Monday reading his 35 articles of impeachment into the record.
The International Astronomical Union announced the creation of the term “plutoid” for a dwarf planet beyond the orbit of Neptune.

The Census Bureau said that it would fingerprint and conduct background checks on more than a half million temporary workers who will go door to door for the 2010 count, at a cost that could exceed $300 million. The bureau’s director, Steven H. Murdock, told a Congressional committee that the measures were necessary to ensure that the federal government did not send criminals into homes. The bureau received a waiver for the 2000 census from the federal requirement to fingerprint government employees.

The Chicago City Council approved a plan to let the Chicago Children’s Museum build a new home in Grant Park, a downtown park that is protected from development. Much of the museum would be underground. With a 33-to-16 vote, aldermen supported Mayor Richard M. Those political aficionados wondering whether Senator Barack Obama looks better from the right or left, take note: in August visitors to the official Web site of the Democratic National Convention will be able to choose from a menu of camera angles as they tune in live, high-definition video streamed from the party gathering in Denver. Other viewers who prefer to leave the direction and analysis of their convention coverage to the broadcast and cable networks will have plenty of options too. In the days since Mr. Obama solidified his standing as the presumptive Democratic nominee, television news executives have begun to set their plans for covering the four-day Democratic convention, which begins on Aug. 25, and its Republican counterpart, which opens in St. Paul on Sept. 1, Labor Day.

Shelly was born in the Bronx on September 5, 1928, was a longtime resident of Greenwich Village, and lived in Pompano Beach, FL for the past 20 years. He is survived by his loving and dearly loved family; wife, Lee Kane Roen, children and their spouses, Randa and Dan Nachbar of Amherst, MA, Marjorie Roen and Billy Kidd of South Fallsburg, NY and Harris Roen of Burlington, VT, and his adored grandchildren: Jara and Gavin Nachbar, Julianna and Katrina Roen, and Jack Kidd. Shelly was previously married to Selma Pollets Roen. Shelly was a psychologist, an educator, and a businessman. He founded Human Sciences Press, an academic publisher of award-winning technical and scientific books, journals and trade publications. He taught psychology at Columbia University, Harvard University, and the University of New Hampshire. In addition to being a practicing psychologist, he directed the Psychological Consultation Center at Columbia. He was noted professionally as an early architect of and driving force behind the Community Mental Health movement. Upon retirement, Shelly devoted himself to the development and management of an investment program, an extensive study of the sciences, and to writing a book which integrates scientific theory with a discussion of personality characteristics. His love of life and living things also drew him to the pleasure of cultivating a variety of crops in his garden. He will be missed. Graveside services at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY on Friday, June 13 at 1pm.

BROUS--Richard A., born 1915, peacefully passed away June 3rd. Loving husband of 67 years to Muriel (nee Labadorf). A wonderful father to Patricia, Kathy and to John. Proud grandfather of Elizabeth and Katherine. Survived by brother Billy and predeceased by brothers Bernard, Morty and sister Peggy. One could only marvel at his patience and perseverance. A long life filled with joy of family, holes in one, and sunsets at Silverpoint. In his eyes, each day was more meaningful than the one before. ''Love you. Miss you. Wish you were here.''
ROSEN--Helen v. Miss you, Babe, everyday. Michael

Disturbed, a hard-rock band from Chicago, this week scored its third No. 1 on the Billboard album chart with sales of 252,000 copies of ''Indestructible'' (Warner Brothers), below, according to Nielsen SoundScan. In a week busy with new releases, Volume 28 of the pop compilation ''Now That's What I Call Music!,'' with songs by Leona Lewis, Lil Wayne, Jordin Sparks, John Mayer and others, opened at No. 2 with reported sales of 185,000. Weezer's self-titled album on Geffen bowed at No. 4 with 126,000; Journey's ''Revelation'' (Nomota), sold only at Wal-Mart, moved 105,000 to reach No. 5 in its first week. Ashanti's new album, ''The Declaration'' (Universal Motown), is No. 6 with 86,000, and Jewel's country album ''Perfectly Clear'' (Valory) is No. 8 with 48,000. Usher's ''Here I Stand'' (LaFace/Zomba), last week's No. 1, fell two spots to No. 3 with 145,000, a 67 percent decrease.

Loving brother of Ann Weis (Marty) and brother-in-law Sy Bruckner (Audrey). GEWIRTZ--Marian, cher ished wife of the late Gerald Gewirtz, passed away peacefully on June 8, 2008. Loving mother to Amy and Nancy and mother-in-law to Michael and Donald. Beloved ''Nana'' to Michelle, Michael, Emma and Chelsea. Loving sister to Wesley and sister-in-law Carolyn. An independent and courageous woman who inspired all those who knew her. Marian was a trail blazer from her early years in television broadcasting to her most treasured position as a career counselor at Pace University. Marian received her BA from Adelphi University and her Masters in Human Resources from The New School. Services will be held at 9:30am on Thursday June 12, 2008 at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

MARKOWITZ--Harry, died on June 10, 2008 at the age of 96. Beloved husband of 62 years to Patricia Markowitz; father to Susan, Steven and Diane; father-in-law to Richard and Lenore; grandfather to Marisa, Danielle, Liz, Evan, Bradley, Leah and Becky. Harry lost his father at an early age, which necessitated his family going on welfare. This experience caused him to champion governmental assistance to the aged and the needy and made him a vocal, lifelong liberal Democrat. Although he became the family breadwinner, his mother insisted he go to college and law school. A vibrant, passionate man, devoted to Jewish causes, he served as a trustee of Temple Beth-El, Great Neck, chaired the UJA Curtain Drapery division, and donated to the Kravis Center, West Palm Beach, Florida. He sought to advance medical treatment through his contributions to North Shore Hospital, Albert Einstein Medical School, Saint Mary Hospital, West Palm Beach, Florida, and the Cerebral Palsy Foundation. He sponsored the work of two international doctors in their research in the U.S. for fifty years, he ran Max Kahn Curtain Corp., based in New York. Graveside service Friday 11am at Union Fields Cemetery, Ridgewood, NY. MARKOWITZ--Harry. Farewell to a dear friend who was always there for us. Alice Rubinstein

CLARKE--W. Norris, S.J. The administration, trustees, alumni, faculty, staff and students of Fordham University mourn the passing of W. Norris Clarke, S.J., professor emeritus of philosophy, who passed away on June 10 at the age of 93. Father Clarke was ordained into the priesthood in 1945 and joined the Fordham faculty 10 years later. He taught for three decades before becoming an emeritus professor in 1985. In 1961, Father Clarke helped found the International Philosophy Quarterly (IPQ), a journal promoting theological dialogue between Europe and the Americas. He served as editor until his 1985 retirement. The author of eight books and more than 70 articles, Father Clarke was the recipient of numerous awards. He held honorary doctorates from Villanova University and Wheeling Jesuit College. Viewings will be held from 3 to 5pm and from 7 to 9pm on Sunday, June 15 in the Loyola Hall Chapel on Fordham's Rose Hill campus. Services are set for 10:30am on Monday, June 16 in the University Church.

She was predeceased by a son Alan Leegant and two brothers, Sidney and Ben Schindler. A graveside service will be held Thursday, June 12 at 2pm in West Ridgelawn Cemetery, King Solomon Memorial Park Section. The Woodbury Funeral Home of Munson-Lovetere, 2 School St. is in charge of services. Online condolences may be made through: www.munson loveterefuneralhome.com.

COMMODITY PRICES SURGE Corn futures rose above $7 a bushel for the first time, hitting a record after heavy rains in the Midwest prompted the Department of Agriculture to lower its 2008 output estimate. Because of an editing error, an article on May 2, 2005, about the suggestion by Jeff Van Gundy, the coach of the Houston Rockets at the time, that fouls were being called more readily and unfairly on his team's center, Yao Ming, during the N.B.A. playoffs referred incorrectly to the genesis of Van Gundy's concern. He said it was ''an official'' -- not a referee -- who had called him to say that Yao was being singled out in games against the Dallas Mavericks. Van Gundy was fined $100,000 by the league for his comments. The error was repeated in a follow-up article in 2005 and again on Wednesday in an article about Tim Donaghy, a former referee who has pleaded guilty after being charged last year with conspiring with gamblers. In a court filing to seek leniency at sentencing, Donaghy and his lawyer cited the Van Gundy controversy among accusations of misconduct and manipulation of game results by N.B.A. executives and referees. Discussing the Donaghy case on a broadcast on Wednesday night, Van Gundy, now a television analyst, said he had been called by an N.B.A. official in 2005.

She will be remembered as a dear, loyal friend, and an intelligent and quick wit. Funeral services will be held Thursday, June 12th, at 10:30am at St. Ann's Church, 134 Main Street, Lenox, MA. Visiting hours will be held Wednesday, June 11th, at Roche Funeral Home, 120 Main Street, Lenox, MA, from 2pm5pm and 7pm-9pm.

The kidnappers of a prominent businessman have demanded a $46.5 million ransom and have given his family a week to obtain the money and arrange for his release, the Greek media said. Police officials did not confirm the ransom request, but the state-run NET television network said that an anonymous caller had contacted the family of George Mylonas. Mr. Mylonas, chairman of an aluminum conglomerate with operations in Europe, Africa and the Middle East, was ambushed by three hooded men while driving to his home in Thessaloniki late on Monday.

The frisky Swedish quartet Love Is All has more in common with Brooklyn bands like the Yeah Yeah Yeahs than the countrymen who invaded the music scene a few years back.
