ZINSSER--John Sharman, Jr., May 27, 2008. Witty, dear, deep and kind beyond kind, Johnny was a person of indelible charm, subtlety of mind, and effortless elegance, wisdom and generosity. Beloved husband of Anne, father of David and Nina Zinsser, Stephen Wadsworth Zinsser, and Amanda Moffat, and much much more than a stepfather to Peter and Olga von Ziegesar, Lisa Whip, Sondra, Anne and Ward Appleby, and Kate Lamdin. John's delicious humor and inexhaustible welcome brought their families, including 13 grandchildren, and hundreds of friends into his circle of adoring fans. He was a parent of epic patience and compassion. As an editor of Condensed Books at Reader's Digest, and ultimately Editor-in-Chief, he was for many years one of the best loved men (and best luncheon dates) in publishing. A keen editor, he was first liaison between the home office and offices worldwide, then between the Digest and the New York publishing world as Vice President in charge of rights. Before and after retiring he brought all his tact, taste and clarity of mind to many organizations as a volunteer, including the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions, the Connecticut Humanities Council, the Cornwall Library, the Cornwall Energy Task Force, and the Century Club. He was a voracious reader, a writer of warm, vivid letters, a lover of opera, a busy green thumb, and an expert tennis player, but mostly it was people he loved -their stories, their interests, their travails, their triumphs. Johnny, Daddy, you leave us no choice but to delight in what you gave us. Contributions: The Southern Poverty Law Center, www.splcenter.org
INTERNATIONAL U.S.-IRAN CONFRONTATION

VAN NES--Andrew, on June 1st, 2008, in his Manhattan apartment of a massive heart attack. Born in 1946, he attended Fieldston School and graduated from Columbia College in 1969. After co-founding a highly successful magazine for students, ''College Monthly'', he went on to a career as an advertising executive at Grey, McCann-Erikson, and Doyle, Dane & Bernbach. He left business early to travel the world pursuing his deep interest in other cultures. Throughout, he maintained the closest ties with his wide network of friends: he was fond, amiable, ferociously smart, but never boastful, always the funniest person in the room, and unfailingly interested and interesting. His passing leaves a vacancy that nobody who knew him will be able to fill. The traveler sets out on this greatest of journeys mourned by his loving siblings Hans Van Nes Esq. of Croton-on-Hudson, NY, Dr. Gordon Van Nes of Chester, CT, Nick Van Nes of West Tisbury, MA, Bretta Lundell of NYC and Heidi Van Nes of New Paltz, NY; and his devoted nieces and nephews Jason Naylor, Erik Lundell, Ali Dolger, Chris Van Nes, Whitney Van Nes, Kate Lundell, Nick Cordella, Max Cordella, Joe Van Nes, Mary Liz Van Nes, Wyatt Naylor and Shane Naylor. Memorial services will be held at All Souls Unitarian Church on Lexington Ave and 80th St, NYC on Friday, June 13th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, please send a contribution in Andrew's name to Kind Heart Rescue of Monmouth-Ocean, 3 Hyacinth Ct, Cream Ridge, NJ 08514, Note: Dachshund Rescue Medical.

LARKIN--Edith. Devoted wife and mother, and Championship Golfer, Sacramento, CA. Mrs. Edith Lucia Bratti Larkin, age 90, died on June 8th, 2008. Born in Bronx, NY on September 17th, 1917, to immigrant parents, Edith resided in Forest Hills and Garden City, NY, Palm Beach Gardens and Melbourne, FL before moving to Sacramento five years ago. Edith was a teacher, a gardener, a superb athlete and a fantastic cook. In an era when few women went to college, she graduated cum laude with a BA degree from the College of New Rochelle, NY. She was an avid golfer whose natural talents and mental toughness made her a perennial champion at Nassau Country Club, Glen Cove, NY and in various Metropolitan Golf Associations. Playing well in her 70s, Edith routinely attracted a crowd of admiring golfers as she practiced her perfect swing at golf ranges in New York and Florida. Edith did everything with a gusto that was the admiration of her many friends and her large extended family. Her famous frankness was always tempered by her great sense of humor. Her husband, Dr. Vincent Larkin, chief of pediatrics at Wyckoff Heights Hospital in Brooklyn, Booth Memorial Hospital in Queens and Methodist Hospital of Brooklyn, predeceased her in 1985. Her brother Peter Bratti and sisters Hilda Bruschi and Yolanda Walsh also predeceased her. She is survived by her two daughters, Geraldine (William) Brick of Bridgewater, NJ and Adrienne Larkin (Maud Nerman) of Novato, CA; her two sons, Dr. Vincent dePaul Larkin, Jr. (Anne) of Scranton, PA and Eugene (Beverley) Larkin of Cincinnati, OH; her twin sister Enes Mulligan of Sacramento, CA; and 12 grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Monday, June 16th at 9am at Higgins Home for Funerals, 752 Mountain Blvd., Watchung, NJ followed by a Mass of Resurrection at 10am at Blessed Sacrament R.C. Church in Martinsville, NJ. Interment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY. Visitation will be held on Sunday, June 15th, from 3:30pm-7pm at the funeral home. To send condolences please visit www. higginsfuneralhome.com. Memorial donation may be made to: College of New Rochelle, Annual Fund Office, 29 Castle Place, New Rochelle, NY 10805.

VITANZA--Robert D., of Redding, CT died at his home on June 9, 2008 after a short illness. Survived by his wife of 26 years Anne ''Beau'' Vitanza, his mother Joan of Cheshire, CT, and his brothers Scott and Michael. Bob was co-owner of Licari & Vitanza, an executive recruitment firm located in Ridgefield, CT. Born in New York on December 20, 1955. A man of incredible integrity, kindness and humor, Bob had been our friend and neighbor for 10 years. He enjoyed rowing on lake Lillinoa, but above all he treasured his time with family and friends and his darling dog Annabella. Funeral services at the Redding Congregational Church, Saturday, June 14, 2008, at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, donations are requested either to the CJD Foundation or Regional Hospice of Danbury, CT. W. An 800-word handwritten prequel to the ''Harry Potter'' series by J. K. Rowling was sold for nearly $49,000, or just over $61 a word, on Tuesday at an auction for charity in a London bookstore, The Associated Press reported. The story, on both sides of a sheet of A5 paper (about 5 7/8 by 8 1/4 inches), was auctioned at the flagship store of the Waterstone's chain to benefit a dyslexia charity and the English branch of PEN, the writers' association. In addition to Ms. Rowling, right, 12 writers and illustrators contributed short stories on cards, including the novelists Doris Lessing, Nick Hornby and Margaret Atwood and the playwright Tom Stoppard, whose mystery story sold for more than $7,000. Copies of the cards are on display in Waterstone's stores and online at Waterstones.com, and will be collected into a book available in August.

Updated, 8:25 p.m. | Gov. David A. Paterson and the leaders of the Legislature announced on Friday a deal under which New York State would take over the financially unprofitable Off-Track Betting operation from New York City, the biggest change in the governance of the state-regulated gambling entity since its creation of 1970. But Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg — who had moved to shut down the operation, saying that it was not profitable and that it was not in the city’s interests to continue running it — said the deal was unfair to the city and immediately vowed to move forward with a plan to close all 71 O.T.B. outposts this weekend. The political dispute meant that the agency’s future remained uncertain.

Tim Russert, the Washington bureau chief of NBC News, died at age 58 today; The Times’s Caucus blog has a complete report. Years before he entered the world of political journalism, in the mid-1980s, he was intimately involved in the New York political world. From 1977 to 1982, he was the first chief of staff to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a New York Democrat elected in 1976. He was instrumental in Mario M. Cuomo’s election as governor of New York, in 1982, and was counselor to the governor in 1983 and 1984.

The man who founded Macy’s could finally have a street in Manhattan named after him –­ but only for a month. On Thursday night, Community Board 5 unanimously approved the temporary installation of a street sign dubbing the block of 34th Street occupied by the Macy’s flagship store “R. H. Macy Way.” The resolution, which now goes to the City Council for a final decision, calls for the sign to remain up only from Oct. 15 through Nov. 15. (Most honorary street renamings, like Jerry Orbach Way, have been permanent.)

BAGHDAD -- One day is left for submitting questions to our video Q&A with Iraqi teenagers. There is a sleek quality to so much modern technology, and that may make it hard to imagine its polluting potential. But think about it: Many of us in the developed world plug and unplug our cellphones, music players, printers and laptops from wall sockets several times a day. It turns out that these goods are responsible for a significant amount of the electricity that we use in homes and offices.

The 2008 campaign has been a very disillusioning experience for a lot of people. You can make a very good case that Barack Obama was the right person for the Democrats to nominate, and Hillary Clinton the wrong choice. But the way we got there was terrible. The raw sexism, in all too many cases coming from alleged progressives -- see above -- was part of it. So, too, was the inability of many alleged progressives to see that the news media created the narrative of Hillary Clinton as race-baiter in much the same way that, 8 years ago, they created the narrative of Al Gore as congenital liar -- by assembling a montage of quotes taken out of context and willfully misinterpreted.
Seeing Things is a bi-weekly design column by Brooke Hodge, the curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles.

Updated. The economy has dominated the week's campaign news, from Senator Barack Obama's shift into the general cycle with his "Change That Works for You" theme and Senator John McCain's return to town hall meetings where pocketbook issues were on the minds of voters.

Less than three weeks after Macklowe Properties was forced to sell its trophy General Motors Building and three other Midtown Manhattan office towers to pay off its creditors, William S. Macklowe has replaced his father, Harry, as chairman and chief executive of the vastly diminished real estate portfolio, the company announced Thursday.

The bad reviews keep coming in from Donald Trump's appearance in Scotland to defend his plan to build a golf resort near Aberdeen. A Wall Street Journal column tries to explain why Scotland had turned on Trump. "As The Donald is beginning to realize, it's not his plans for a world-class golf course near Aberdeen that have incensed so many Scots -- it's him," according to writer Bill Coles in his entertaining piece, The Donald Dinna Ken the Scots.

Putnam Investments on Thursday named Robert L. Reynolds its chief executive and president, hoping the former Fidelity Investments executive can remake the smaller Boston mutual fund firm into a tougher competitor for its cross-town rival, The Boston Globe reported.
CHICAGO - Senator Barack Obama has not forgotten one of the cardinal rules of politics: never let yourself be photographed wearing nerdy headgear.
Google co-founder Sergey Brin has invested $5 million in Space Adventures, a Virginia outfit that books flights for the well-heeled on Russian Soyuz rockets.
KeyCorp shares fell the most in a quarter-century after the Ohio-based lender said it needs to raise $1.5 billion and slashed its dividend by half because it lost a tax case.
UBS has wrapped up a 16 billion franc ($15.4 billion) rights issue, the Swiss bank's second effort to resuscitate finances that have been ravaged by the global markets crisis.

William Ackman, the billionaire hedge fund manager who is a major stakeholder in Borders Group, says the bookseller should consider approaching online retailer Amazon.com about a possible acquisition.

Refco's former chief executive, Phillip Bennett, deserves a long prison term when he is sentenced for fraud after presiding over "a conspiracy of historic proportions," United States prosecutors argued in court papers made public Thursday.

A manhunt continued on Thursday for Samuel Israel III, a hedge fund manager who disappeared Monday, hours before he was to have reported to prison to serve a 20-year federal sentence for conspiracy and fraud in a scheme to cheat investors out of $450 million.

IMedExchange, which is launching this month with $2.5 million in angel funding, is the latest social networking start-up to target the professional community. Private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management is starting a new fund to invest in assets it thinks have been driven down too low by the credit crisis, the firm's chairman, John Snow, told Reuters.

China Investment Corporation is turning its back on countries that are suspicious of sovereign wealth funds, Gao Xiqing, C.I.C.'s president and chief investment officer, said Friday, Reuters reported.
Exxon Mobil said on Thursday that it was withdrawing from the retail gas business in the United States, citing the "very challenging" business conditions for its service stations.

Lots of people ask me why I left the law and I usually give them a few reasons, including the following: I went to law school mostly to please my parents; the idealism I'd felt as a law student waned when I saw how challenging it was to craft meaningful legal work that paid a living wage; I fell into a specialty that didn't sustain my interest and found it easier to reinvent myself in a new career than within my existing one.

Grey Wolf said Thursday its board has concluded that Precision Drilling Trust's unsolicited bid for the U.S. contract oil driller would not be a better deal for Grey Wolf than its planned merger with Basic Energy Services.

Shareholders of TSX Group have given the nod to change the company's name to TMX Group, reflecting the recent merger of the Toronto and Montreal exchanges to form the country's dominant securities market.

Summer is the time to enjoy the musical bounty of Moscow's tsarist palaces. Although Petersburg is legendary for palaces such as the Catherine Palace at Tsarskoye Selo, Moscow also has its fair share of pre-revolutionary estates. These form the backdrop for concerts of jazz, symphonies, and chamber music throughout the Russian capital's precious warm weather months, which, for the most part have been unseasonably cool so far. But, well, that's another story. Now on to the music.

The chairman of the oil giant BP charged that the company’s Russian partners were “raiding” their joint venture TNK-BP and that the Russian government was doing nothing to stop them. “This is just a return to the corporate raiding activities that were prevalent in Russia in the 1990s,” the chairman, Peter Sutherland, said in an address at a meeting in Stockholm. TNK-BP is jointly controlled by BP and three Russian financiers. One of them, Mikhail Fridman, reacted angrily, saying Mr. Sutherland’s speech “was not constructive and is insulting to Russian authorities, to say the least,” the official Russian news agency RIA Novosti reported. BP and its Russian partners have clashed repeatedly in recent weeks, and the dispute is seen as a test of conditions for foreign investors in the Russian oil sector.
Ireland voted in a referendum on the European Union’s Lisbon Treaty, a painstakingly negotiated pact that would be damaged or destroyed by an Irish rejection.
Arab and Western nations called on Eritrea to withdraw its troops from the border with Djibouti after clashes that killed at least six Djiboutian soldiers and wounded more than 50 others.
The two main parties in Kenya’s coalition government retained their parliamentary balance in a by-election that appeared to have gone peacefully.
A London judge sentenced the wife of one of four men convicted in an abortive plot to bomb London subway trains to 15 years in prison for failing to inform the police of her husband’s plans.

A man accused of planning a massacre at this year’s Super Bowl was convicted Wednesday of federal charges. Kurt Havelock faced six counts of mailing threatening communications in United States District Court in Phoenix. According to court records, Havelock bought an AR-15 semiautomatic rifle and 200 rounds of ammunition from the Scottsdale Gun Club on Jan. 30 to kill people at the Super Bowl in Glendale. However, Havelock had a change of heart. He called his parents, and they persuaded him to turn himself in to the Tempe police.

Bill Curry said he has agreed to a five-year contract to become the first head coach of Georgia State’s program. Curry, 65, who last coached in 1996 at Kentucky, where he was 26-52 in seven years, has most recently worked as an analyst for ESPN. Georgia State plans to sign its first recruiting class in 2009, have its first spring practice later in 2009 and begin play in 2010. The Panthers will compete in the Colonial Athletic Association and will play their home games at the Georgia Dome.

Mitch Frerotte, an offensive lineman who played in three Super Bowls for the Buffalo Bills, has died. He was 43. He died of a heart attack, said his cousin Gus Frerotte, a Minnesota Vikings backup quarterback. Mitch Frerotte played four years, including the Bills’ Super Bowl seasons of 1990-92, mostly as a reserve and on special teams. Frerotte played for Penn State from 1983-87 before going to Buffalo. He sustained a career-ending neck injury after joining the Seattle Seahawks for training camp in 1993.

Cat Whitehill, a defender for the United States women’s national team, will miss the Olympics after tearing a knee ligament. Whitehill tore the anterior cruciate ligament in her left knee Tuesday during practice in Seoul, South Korea and will have surgery in the next few weeks, according to U.S. Soccer. Whitehill, 26, was a strong candidate to make the 18-player roster for the Beijing Games. She played every minute of the 2007 FIFA Women’s World Cup, was part of the 2004 gold medal-winning team and has appeared in 129 games for the United States.

Todd McLellan, an assistant coach for the Stanley Cup champion Detroit Red Wings, was named coach of the San Jose Sharks on Thursday. Wilson was named coach of Toronto on Tuesday.

Dr. Jeffrey Lieberman is the chairman of the psychiatry department at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and director of the college’s Lieber Center for Schizophrenia Research. He was also a principal investigator in a federal study that compared the effectiveness of an older schizophrenia drug with newer, more expensive drugs. The large, multisite study found that the older drug was generally as effective as the newer ones.

RENEGADE CRAFT FAIR Let's face it, hierarchy is passé. Want to watch TV? No need to wait for the networks; just shoot something with your friends and edit the video. How about some music? Go to iTunes and create your own mix. Or a scarf? Pick up some knitting needles, and, well, you get the idea. So it's no surprise that at a time when D.I.Y. is flourishing, people would embrace creating their own accessories, books, prints, home furnishings, you name it. Sue Daly, a jewelry designer, and a friend, Kathleen Habbley, went one step further: They created their own craft fair. ''When I started selling my jewelry, I thought it would be cool to participate in an art fair but didn't find an event that catered to the huge D.I.Y. scene so prevalent online,'' Ms. Daly explained in an e-mail message. So she started the Renegade Craft Fair in Chicago for people who specialize in handmade products and who somehow found the motivation to sell them. The fair's Brooklyn outpost gets under way at McCarren Park Pool, above, this weekend, for the fourth year. And, as the craft movement catches on, so has the fair. More than 200 vendors will set up shop, selling things from clothing to art to food to ceramics. This is more than just an average street fair. As its popularity has grown, it has become more selective, accepting ''less than half the artists who apply,'' Ms. Daly said.

MARK DI SUVERO In this age of sculptures of mindlessly enlarged recognizable objects that are all size but no scale, it is great to be reminded that big can also be abstract, and that abstract at its best requires scale. Case in point is ''Lowell's Ocean'' (2006), right, Mark di Suvero's latest exercise in well-tempered largeness at the Paula Cooper Gallery. Ms. Cooper may not have built her elegantly cavernous ground floor to accommodate Mr. di Suvero -- an artist with whom she has worked on and off for most of her long career -- but sometimes it sure looks that way. His works fare so well in this setting that it has occasionally been hard to tell if the art or the space is doing the heavy lifting. With his latest effort there is no question: ''Lowell's Ocean'' is among the great works of his career. It's an outstanding example of his ability to assemble huge steel elements in ways that are both playful and majestic, intimate and immense. The work consists of an enormous tripodlike structure (though with four legs) made of leaning and crisscrossing steel I-beams (a di Suvero signature). Resting high within its angles is a double spiral that has been cut from one immense sheet of steel and then popped into three dimensions to form two open, scrolling domes that operate in the gap between drawing-in-space and architecture.

'CÉLINE AND JULIE GO BOATING' For a movie so dense with literary and cinematic allusions and perceptual puzzles, Jacques Rivette's 1974 ''Céline and Julie Go Boating'' remains improbably lighthearted. Freewheeling and improvisatory -- the leads, Juliet Berto, above, and Dominque Labourier, share screenwriting credit with Mr. Rivette and three others -- it transports you back to a time when filmmaking seemed full of possibility and Paris was still an enchanted playground for the Nouvelle Vague. A down-the-rabbit-hole tale (''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland'' is one of the its touchstones) about Julie (Ms. Labourier), a librarian, who meets, trails and takes in Céline (Ms. Berto), a free-spirited magician, the film riffs on actors and acting, stories and storytelling, and, of course, movies and moviemaking. Céline and Julie are, as the subtitle calls them, two ''Phantom Ladies Over Paris'' (''Les Vampires,'' Louis Feuillade's silent-film serial, is another touchstone), intrepid explorers who, with the help of magic bonbons, slip into another world, a strange mansion in which a melodramatic story unfolds in jumbled bits and pieces. That story-within-a-story may be darkly foreboding, but Céline and Julie approach it playfully -- those magic bonbons can give a girl a case of the giggles -- and also with purpose. Through trial and error, they learn its rules and, by mastering, alter them, much like, you could say, a director making a movie.

ZINSSER--John Sharman, Jr., May 27, 2008. Witty, dear, deep and kind beyond kind, Johnny was a person of indelible charm, subtlety of mind, and effortless elegance, wisdom and generosity. Beloved husband of Anne, father of David and Nina Zinsser, Stephen Wadsworth Zinsser, and Amanda Moffat, and much much more than a stepfather to Peter and Olga von Ziegesar, Lisa Whip, Sondra, Anne and Ward Appleby, and Kate Lamdin. John's delicious humor and inexhaustible welcome brought their families, including 13 grandchildren, and hundreds of friends into his circle of adoring fans. He was a parent of epic patience and compassion. As an editor of Condensed Books at Reader's Digest, and ultimately Editor-in-Chief, he was for many years one of the best loved men (and best luncheon dates) in publishing. A keen editor, he was first liaison between the home office and offices worldwide, then between the Digest and the New York publishing world as Vice President in charge of rights. Before and after retiring he brought all his tact, taste and clarity of mind to many organizations as a volunteer, including the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions, the Connecticut Humanities Council, the Cornwall Library, the Cornwall Energy Task Force, and the Century Club. He was a voracious reader, a writer of warm, vivid letters, a lover of opera, a busy green thumb, and an expert tennis player, but mostly it was people he loved -their stories, their interests, their travails, their triumphs. Johnny, Daddy, you leave us no choice but to delight in what you gave us. Contributions: The Southern Poverty Law Center, www.splcenter.org

HIP HOP GENERATION NEXT Some New Yorkers like to think that their city wrote the book on the culture of hip-hop and especially on gritty hip-hop art forms like breaking and b-boying. But breaking long ago developed distinct regional and local flavors, and more recently, an international explosion of interest in this competitive, virtuosic form of street dancing started something of a renaissance back where it all started in New York. On Saturday you can see how they do it Windy City style, when the Chicago crew FootworKINGz comes to Coffey Park in Red Hook as part of Hip Hop Generation Next, a free block party run by the excellent public-performance organization Dancing in the Streets. FootworKINGz has danced with Madonna and Missy Elliott but has never been to New York. The troupe's 4:30 p.m. show, which also features the fabulous New York groups Full Circle (with Ana Garcia, known as Rokafella, above) and the House of Ninja, will anchor what promises to be a vibrant afternoon of events. Performances from 2 to 3:30 p.m. include Asase Yaa African-American Dance Theater, Daniel Fetecua-Soto and Illstyle & Peace Productions.

'TAKE ME OUT TO THE BALL GAME: 1864' The games New Yorkers play may be infinite, but at least those on athletic fields are usually identifiable. Even sports fans, however, may scratch their heads over two contests in the Bronx on Saturday. The first involves a ball and bats, but no gloves, no helmets and strictly underhand pitching. The other doesn't use a real ball but rags or yarn wrapped in soft leather. Baseball? Sort of. The first game is the national pastime as it was played in its early days. The other is rounders, one of baseball's precursors. Both will be stars at ''Take Me Out to the Ball Game: 1864,'' on the front lawn of the Bartow-Pell Mansion Museum.

SUMMER SHAKESPEARE The Public Theater's current production of ''Hamlet'' at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park may be the most high-profile Shakespeare play in town, but it is not the only one. Shakespeare's plays have long been a staple of summer theaters in bucolic outdoor settings around the country, and while we might not be known for our greenery here in New York, we still have some ideal locations. New York Classical Theater (above) is offering its own Shakespeare play in Central Park: ''Cymbeline.'' There is no fixed-seat theater, and a bit of audience participation is involved; as the play moves around the park scene by scene, the audience will follow the actors to each new locale. (Through June 22, 103rd Street and Central Park West, 212-252-4531, newyorkclassical.org; free.) The company will also present ''Macbeth,'' Shakespeare's tragedy of prophecy and vaulting ambition, at Castle Clinton in Battery Park from June 26 through July 12.

CLARKE--W. Norris, S.J. The administration, trustees, alumni, faculty, staff and students of Fordham University mourn the passing of W. Norris Clarke, S.J., professor emeritus of philosophy, who passed away on June 10 at the age of 93. Father Clarke was ordained into the priesthood in 1945 and joined the Fordham faculty 10 years later. He taught for three decades before becoming an emeritus professor in 1985. In 1961, Father Clarke helped found the International Philosophy Quarterly (IPQ), a journal promoting theological dialogue between Europe and the Americas. He served as editor until his 1985 retirement. The author of eight books and more than 70 articles, Father Clarke was the recipient of numerous awards. He held honorary doctorates from Villanova University and Wheeling Jesuit College. Viewings will be held from 3 to 5pm and from 7 to 9pm on Sunday, June 15 in the Loyola Hall Chapel on Fordham's Rose Hill campus. Services are set for 10:30am on Monday, June 16 in the University Church. CLARKE--Rev. W. Norris S.J., on June 10, 2008, brother of the late R. Semmes Clarke, beloved uncle of Kate Clarke of San Diego, CA, and brother-in-law of Constance Clarke of Cedar Grove, NJ. Father Clarke is also survived by numerous cousins both near and far. Reposing at the Loyola Hall Chapel, Fordham University, Bronx, NY on Sunday, 3-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday 10:30am at Fordham University Church, Bronx, NY. Interment at Jesuit Martyrs' Shrine, Auriesville, NY. For information contact Farenga Bros., Inc Directors (718) 6540500.

Human rights advocates said the Ethiopian Army had tortured, murdered, raped and evicted civilians in a crackdown on insurgents in the country's isolated Ogaden region. The group Human Rights Watch, in a report released in Nairobi, Kenya, and posted online at hrw.org, said that some villages had been burned, citing independent analysis of satellite photographs by the American Association for the Advancement of Science. The scientists confirmed that dozens of structures had vanished in eight communities identified by witnesses as being attacked, said Lars Bromley, the director of the association's science and human rights program. The Ethiopian government has routinely rejected claims of rights abuses.

For the last three decades, I have photographed abandoned filling stations mostly in American ghettos. For me, they evoked the vision of the end of a gas-based world. In the beginning, this vision was largely confined to disadvantaged neighborhoods. Not anymore. Today, with gasoline prices at record levels, the fragility of a lifestyle, economy and culture dependent on fossil fuel is sensed by everyone, even the most comfortable among us. I have often been amazed by the ways harsh and aggressive forms are taken over by the natural world. The gas stations and pumps that make modern life possible are among our most rationally planned buildings. Their function: get the customers to stop and fill their tanks, fast. And yet, how quickly filling stations disintegrate without constant maintenance. They lose their characteristic smell of oil and exhaust. Scavengers strip the pumps, revealing their hoses, belts, gears and electric motors. In some cases, trees grow out of the concrete; nature sings its song as the loud greens of the ailanthus trees, bushes and white flowers mix with the fading reds of the station walls.

Jane Sherburne has made a career as a legal firefighter, dousing scandal after scandal as a top lawyer in the Clinton Administration and then at Citigroup. Now, as if on cue, she is joining Wachovia Corporation as its general counsel and government relations officer just in time for another round of flare-ups. Her official start date was moved up to Monday, even though it had been scheduled for later this summer. She takes over for Mark Treanor, who is retiring.

Supporters of free trade do not help their case when they accuse those who worry about trade impacts of forgetting about the good stuff, like exports and lower import prices. If there is one event in track and field that the United States has dominated in the Olympics, it is the men's 110-meter high hurdles. In the 14 Summer Games the U.S. has competed in since the end of World War II, American hurdlers have won 10 gold medals in the event, swept it four times and won two of the three medals eight times. For more than 40 years the highs were synonymous with American hurdlers - Willie Davenport, Lee Calhoun, Skeets Nehemiah, Greg Foster, Roger Kingdom and Allen Johnson.

My Sunday column is about the Security Council next week taking up an issue that has never received the attention it deserves: sexual violence in conflicts. It's partly because of the indelicacy of the issue that victims don't talk about it and diplomats don't want to address it either. And that's what makes it such an effective way to terrorize people and depopulate an area.

A coroner ruled that the former Bills lineman Mitch Frerotte died of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, a thickening of the heart muscle. Armstrong County Coroner Robert Bower said Frerotte was 43 when he collapsed at home in Kittanning, Pa., on Wednesday.

The art collector Charles Saatchi was in a generous mood on Wednesday when he bought almost all the works by three young students from their final graduation exhibit at the Royal Academy Schools in London, The Times of London reported. The student artists are Carla Busuttil, 26; Angus Sanders-Dunnachie, 28; and Jill Mason, 33. Mr. Saatchi’s early purchases helped begin the careers of now-famous artists including Damien Hirst, Tracy Emin, Natasha Kissell and Jake and Dinos Chapman.

A special Thursday edition of “Million Dollar Password” gave CBS a ratings lift as 9.4 million viewers tuned in at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen. That tally made it one of the night’s most-watched programs, even with CBS’s repeat of “CSI” at 9 (9.4 million) and ahead of the network’s “Swingtown” at 10 (7 million). CBS earned a second-place finish for the night, trailing only ABC and its live broadcast of Game Four of the N.B.A championship series between the Boston Celtics and the Los Angeles Lakers. On par with earlier games in the series, Thursday’s broadcast averaged 13.8 million viewers. Fox, in third place, edged past CBS for second place among adults 18 to 49, thanks to “So You Think You Can Dance” at 9 (8 million). NBC finished a distant fourth over all, broadcasting a repeat of “My Name Is Earl” at 8 (3.3 million) followed by “Last Comic Standing” from 8:30 to 10 (4.1 million).

In its latest cybercontroversy, the heavy-metal band Metallica apologized for asking several bloggers to remove their online reviews of its untitled coming record, The Guardian of London reported. The band upset fans by suing the file-sharing service Napster in 2000 and by removing its music from iTunes in 2003 — a decision that was reversed in 2006 — but says the removal of the reviews was orchestrated by its management company, Q Prime, without the band’s permission. In a statement on Metallica.com, its Web site, the band described its own reaction to the move. “Our response was ‘WHY?!!!,’ ” the statement said. “Why take down mostly positive reviews of the new material and prevent people from getting psyched about the next record ... that makes no sense to us!” Links to the reviews are now available on the site.

Two Picasso prints were stolen by three armed robbers from a museum in São Paulo, Brazil, on Thursday, The Associated Press reported. Along with the Picasso prints, “Minotaur, Drinker and Women” from 1933 and “The Painter and the Model” from 1963, the thieves took paintings by two Brazilian artists — “Couple” by Lasar Segall and “Women in the Window,” above, by Emiliano Di Cavalcanti — from the Pinacoteca do Estado museum. The works were estimated to be worth a combined $612,000. The robbers paid the museum’s entrance fee of $2.45 and then overpowered guards to take the framed works. In December another Picasso, “Portrait of Suzanne Boch,” and a painting by the Brazilian artist Candido Portinari were stolen from the São Paulo Museum of Art after men used a crowbar and car jack to force open the museum’s doors. The paintings from that robbery were later found leaning against a house on the outskirts of the city.

The musicians union filed a federal lawsuit against the producers of “American Idol” on Thursday, claiming that its members had been underpaid because the show’s live music was rerecorded for reruns, The Associated Press reported. The suit by the American Federation of Musicians contends that American Idol Productions and its subsidiary violated a collective bargaining agreement. According to court papers, the producers used different musicians to record new music for the season highlights show in 2007 and did not inform the union. The damages sought were unspecified.

The writing staff of “Sit Down, Shut Up,” a Fox animated series about a high school scheduled to begin next spring, walked off the job on Wednesday. The writers, who had been working without a contract for weeks, expected to receive the benefits recently negotiated by the Writers Guild of America, but the studio producing the series, Sony Pictures Television, said that another union, the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, would have jurisdiction over the show instead. It was one of the first confrontations between writers and a studio since the crippling three-month writers’ strike was settled in February. “We thought there would be no more shenanigans like this,” said John Aboud, a writer for the series. He noted that the writers union contract had covered every Fox animated series since 1998. Sony said the production of its animated shows has been covered by agreements with the theatrical stage employees union for at least 10 years. The conflict has arisen because this is the first animated series Sony has produced for Fox.

The actor Kevin Spacey, below, has been named Cameron Mackintosh visiting professor of contemporary theater at Oxford’s St. Catherine’s College, The Associated Press reported on Friday. Mr. Spacey, who also serves as the artistic director of the Old Vic in London and has won two Academy Awards, succeeds Patrick Stewart. Rivers showed his three superstar players the parade route used by the Patriots and the Red Sox, preaching sacrifice and team defense along the way.

KAPLAN--Archie , died at his home in Manhattan June 12, 2008. Born in Bridgeport, CT on February 12, 1917, he spent his childhood in Boston, Detroit and New York. He fought in the Battle of Okinawa and every year celebrated the anniversary of his Army discharge. His career was a tribute to his talent and initiative. After leaving college he opened a school and taught surveying and mechanical drawing, then switched to furniture design and industrial design, and then office design, finally opening Environment Planning, Inc. in Manhattan. A faculty member at Parsons, and later FIT, he was the beloved teacher of generations of designers. He was a man of tremendous intellectual curiosity, strong opinions and great wisdom. He loved his family, his work and his life. He was a loving husband to Sylvia until her untimely death in 1983; then a loving husband to his cherished wife Patricia Lutkins, who survives him. He is also survived by his daughters, Jane and Kate, son-in-law Andrew Condey, niece Anita Baskin, and grandchildren, Ted and Abigail Sindzinski and Kira Condey. Service at 11:15am Monday, June 16 at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam. Interment will follow at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI. Contributions may be made to Continuum Hospice Care (Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel), 1775 Broadway, Suite 300, New York, NY 10019.

Last month, he expressed regret for offending Roman Catholics. Now, the Rev. John Hagee is extending his regret to Jews. Mr. Hagee, below, a televangelist and megachurch pastor, publicly endorsed Senator John McCain, the presumptive Republican nominee, but was repudiated last month by Mr. McCain after a Web site posted a 1999 sermon in which Mr. Hagee said God allowed the Holocaust to happen to get the Jewish people to return to Israel to fulfill Biblical prophecy. After the remarks created an uproar, Mr. McCain cut his ties with Mr. Hagee, capping months of escalating outrage about Mr. Hagee's views on the Roman Catholic Church.

PILLSBURY--Donaldson Clark . Michael Sovern, Chairman of The Board of Directors of Sotheby's, Chief Executive Officer Bill Ruprecht and Sotheby's worldwide staff mourn the untimely passing of their colleague and friend, Don Pillsbury, on June 12th. Distinguished by his integrity, grace, wisdom and honor, Don was the epitome of a fine and decent man. He leaves an enormous void at Sotheby's and we will miss him. Our condolences go to his wife, Marnie, and their children Donaldson C. Pillsbury, Jr., Barbara Blair Enders and Wendy Pillsbury Eichmann; to his five grandchildren and to his siblings John S. Pillsbury III, L. Harrison Pillsbury, and Katherine Jose. PILLSBURY--Donaldson C. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc. mourn the passing of Donaldson C. Pillsbury, an indispensable member of the Lincoln Center community. Chairman of the Board of The Chamber Music Society since 1993, his trusteeship and steadfast leadership were exemplary. Don's presence was felt throughout Lincoln Center, and he will be greatly missed. We offer our deepest sympathies to his wife Marnie, and his extended family. Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Chairman Reynold Levy, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc. PILLSBURY--Donaldson C. The family and friends of Don Pillsbury mourn the loss of a beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, and friend. Don died suddenly after a terrific bike ride with good friends along the Connecticut shore in Old Lyme, Connecticut on Thursday, June 12th. He was 67. The cause of death was heart failure. Don was a chairman of Sotheby's North and South America and former worldwide general counsel and executive vice president of Sotheby's. Before that he was a senior partner (1967-1993) at the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell. In addition to his work at Davis Polk and Sotheby's, Don pursued a wide variety of personal business and non - profit interests. He served as chairman of The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in New York-a particular passion--and as a director of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. For 17 years, he was a trustee of the Nightingale Bamford School, also in New York City. More recently, he served as a trustee of Robert College in Istanbul, Turkey, the New York Community Trust, and the Stuart Family Foundation, a private foundation based outside of Chicago. We will remember everything about him. But especially for his utter integrity, his lovely humor, his passion for music, good wine, Cheetos. He loved the outdoors, biking, skiing, hiking, and sailing. We lovingly remember his incredible generosity and joy in simple things, the family, the garden, the silly cards, obscure gifts and collectibles--often acquired on E-Bay. His grandchildren were the light of his life. We will miss him dearly. He is survived by his wife Marnie, his children Donaldson Clark Pillsbury, Jr. and his wife Skye of San Francisco, CA, Blair Pillsbury Enders and her husband Jack of New York, NY, Wendy Pillsbury Eichmann, and her husband Chris of Greenwich, CT and his five grandchildren Tyler and Sam Eichmann, Nicholas and Marian Enders, and Clark Pillsbury. His siblings John S. Pillsbury III, L. Harrison Pillsbury, and Katharine Jose also survive him. A memorial service will be held on Monday, June 23 at 3pm at St. Thomas Church, One W. 53rd St., New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, Robert College in Istanbul, and the New York Community Trust. PILLSBURY--Donaldson C. The Trustees of Robert College of Istanbul deeply mourn the sudden death of a fellow Trustee. We are grateful for his service, wisdom and friendship, and will feel the loss of his presence. We offer our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Marnie and their family. PILLSBURY--Donaldson C. The Board, artists and staff of The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center note with great sadness the loss of our longstanding Board member and cherished friend Don Pillsbury. Don served as Chairman of the Board of Directors from 1993 to 2004 and remained on the Board as Vice Chairman until his sudden death on Thursday. Inspired by a deep love of music, Don was steadfastly devoted to carrying forth and enhancing the mission of the Chamber Music Society. Under his guidance the Society initiated a significant expansion of its Alice Tully Hall season, created new musical programs, and developed a national radio series that successfully drew new and appreciative audiences. He also encouraged the development of the Society's wide-ranging education programs and residency opportunities for young artists. A man of impeccable taste and great integrity, Don was the model of a good and decent man and inspired others through his personal generosity and wise leadership. His immense capacity for friendship was deeply felt and especially appreciated by his colleagues on the Board and by the artists and staff of the Society. We will miss his enthusiasm, commitment, and his reliable presence among us. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Marnie and to his family. Peter Frelinghuysen Chairman Charles Hamilton Vice Chairman David Finckel and Wu Han Artistic Directors Norma Hurlburt Executive Director PILLSBURY--Don. It is with profound sadness that my colleagues and I mourn the untimely passing of Don Pillsbury, devoted husband of our beloved associate, Marnie. Don's remarkable capacity to balance a distinguished career with his total dedication to his family filled us with admiration and awe. We will miss him greatly and send our deepest sympathies to Marnie and her family. David Rockefeller PILLSBURY--Donaldson C. The trustees, faculty, students, and staff of The Rockefeller University community mourn the sudden and untimely passing of our cherished friend, Don Pillsbury, an esteemed member of The Rockefeller University Council and husband of Marnie Pillsbury, our beloved Vice Chairman. Like all who knew him, we loved Don dearly, and we are heartbroken for Marnie and her children. We send them every wish for comfort and strength as they face this devastating loss. Don's friendship with Rockefeller University began as a result of Marnie's involvement; we were the beneficiary of the wonderful partnership that they shared in all aspects of their lives. Along with Marnie, he became a passionate ambassador and advocate for the advancement of biomedical research and for the University. Don was a man of deep integrity, keen intellect, discerning judgment, and immense personal warmth. He gave back to the world through his many pro bono involvements. As Chair of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, he combined a love of music with strong leadership abilities to enrich the culture of our great City. The joy he felt in life, and in his love for Marnie and his children, was palpable. A remarkable couple, Marnie and Don's enduring love and devotion to each other had a way of embracing everyone around them. Gifted at love, their love was a gift to us all. We are so fortunate to have known Don, and we will miss him tremendously. With deepest sorrow, we extend our condolences to Marnie; to their children, Don, Blair, and Wendy; and to the entire Pillsbury family. Paul Nurse, President Russell Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus and the Board of Trustees Torsten Wiesel, President Emeritus Marnie Imhoff, Vice President The Rockefeller University

The Webby Awards, honoring excellence on the Internet, were announced last week. And after I recovered from not being nominated, I spent some time browsing the list of acceptance speeches, which adhered to an interesting format. The winners had to accept their awards using no more than five words. The most successful of these speeches are terrific examples of branding. For example, Stephen Colbert, the winner of the Webby person of the year award, simply accepted with "Me. Me. Me. Me. Me."

I can sigh relief today. The lede of one of my stories about Le Mans came true: The top three finishers at Le Mans were Audis and Peugeots. Furthermore, my decision to go not to Le Mans but to the celebration of the 10th anniversary of the Renault Technocenter paid off. I didn't have to write the story about Jacques Villeneuve winning the Triple Crown - as he finished only second in Le Mans - and I did manage to speak to Fernando Alonso. I have put up a recording of that interview, and I was particularly interested in what he said about why he attacked so hard - and blew it - at the Canadian Grand Prix. I liked that response - it reminded me of the kind of thing you might have heard from...Gilles Villeneuve. But you'll have to listen to the end of my Alonso interview to hear it.

I live in a rent-regulated apartment in Brooklyn, which I rent on a yearly basis. I plan to vacate my apartment one month past the expiration of the lease because I am moving out of state. My landlord tells me to sign a lease for a whole year and to sign a letter saying I am responsible for rent if he is unable to replace me with another tenant. What should I do?
A friend of mine is subletting a co-op apartment. Besides paying her monthly rent, she is responsible for the sublet fee and the maintenance charge. Is this really her responsibility or the owner's?

Barack Obama's bid for the White House has stirred up excitement in Detroit, where residents have waited for the chance to elect a black president. Yet Detroiters also have been waiting nearly a year to see Mr. Obama, who has not appeared in the city since last July, when he received thunderous applause during an N.A.A.C.P. candidate forum despite being considered a long shot to become the Democratic nominee. He did not campaign in the state before the primary and his name did not even appear on Michigan's ballot, after party leaders moved up the date in violation of Democratic National Committee rules.

Mike Day delivered the race of his life, winning the United States BMX trials in Chula Vista, Calif., and securing a spot on the men’s Olympic team. Day set the tone by winning the first race and eventually held such a large points lead that the final heat was canceled because no one could mathematically catch him. Day joins Kyle Bennett, who won USA Cycling’s yearlong qualifying competition. The third spot — a selection by coaches — will almost certainly go to Donny Robinson, the world’s top-ranked BMX racer.

A listing of renovation tips with an article last Sunday about brokers who advise owners to keep resale in mind when renovating their apartments referred incompletely to the life span of prefinished floors. ROGERS--Arthur, husband of Linda and the late Edna, father of Anita, Julie, Ruth and Chris, brother of Joe, Zayde of Melissa and Jim, Aviva and Adam, Rebecca and Cameron, dear uncle, cousin and friend. He was admired and respected by all who passed through his 92 years of wit, wisdom and generosity. His love for life and the positive energy he exuded were incomparable. He touched the lives of so many, so deeply, with so much warmth and grace. His impression will last forever. There isn't a person who will not miss him. There isn't a person who is willing to let him go. He was supposed to live forever --everyone knew that. Contributions may be sent to SHARE, 1501 Broadway, Suite 704A, NY, NY 10036 or Woman to Woman, P.O. Box 10402, Jerusalem, Israel. Memorial service will be announced.

Nowadays, when a politician wants to make a point to the ''folks,'' he goes to the diner to meet and greet and empathize while scarfing a grilled cheese. For all of its hokeyness, it's a safe strategy because, according to health experts, fried foods are what most Americans subsist on, and for some irrational reason, people trust a politician who appears to eat the same foods they do. So I had to laugh -- and feel a little sad too -- when I came across an article in The Times from 1935 in which Huey Long, the colorful Louisiana senator known as the Kingfish, chose not a diner in Peoria but the Hotel New Yorker in New York City as his venue for attacking President Roosevelt's New Deal. In the photo op, Long stood surrounded by journalists and friends, waving a cocktail shaker.

HERD--Pauline Hoffmann, passed on June 13, 2008 at her home in Brooklyn, NY. Survived by her daughters Victoria P. Herd of Doylestown, PA and Pauline M. Herd of Brooklyn, NY. A graduate of Stanford and VSC Law Schools. As an active member of her community, she was a Mentor to many in a caring, gentle, dignified manner. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Brooklyn Botanical Gardens, the Grace Church or any Charity of your choice. A Memorial Service will be held Wednesday June 18, 2008, 4pm at the Grace Church, 254 Hicks Street, Brooklyn Heights, NY.

EIK OTTOSEN, a onetime model turned footwear designer, believes in a thing called company karma: ''If you make a product that makes people smile,'' he said from his home in Copenhagen, ''you'll create a positive energy.'' To that end, he has named his company Rubber Duck (''Who can ever blame a rubber duck for evil?'' he explained) and initiated the Wear and Care Concept, by which 10 percent of the production cost of his Los Drillos espadrilles is given to the workers in China who make them. The money -- last year's bonus added up to nearly two months' pay -- helps feed their families and secure education for their children. And if that doesn't liven the mood, Mr. Ottosen has had the shoes fabricated in funky prints, and the word ''Smile'' embossed on the soles. Rubber Duck espadrilles, $52 at Oak; oaknyc.com.

Funeral Service at St. Matthews Episcopal Church, Bedford, NY Saturday June 21, 2008 11:30am.

BELL--Hilda M. (Folkman), age 95, on June 13th. Beloved mother of Rebecca Folkman, Benjamin Folkman and Jonathan Folkman, grandmother of David Folkman Mazieres and Christopher Folkman. After graduating from Barnard College at age 19, she earned a Master's Degree in music. A social worker during the 1930s, she was also active in Junior Federation, undertaking administrative duties and composing a full-length musical comedy for a Brooklyn Academy of Music benefit performance. In 1940 she married Dr. Nathan Folkman. She later joined the Board of Hamilton-Madison Settlement House. Widowed in 1956, she entered the business world and proved a pioneer. Erecting a new commercial building on Northern Boulevard for her linen supply company, she changed the nature of the supply industry by extending services beyond residences to include smaller hospitals. She soon became a member of the Board of Maimonides Medical Center. In 1974 she married Clarence D. Bell (deceased 2001). Subsequently, she began a five-year tenure as the first woman president of Maimonides. In this post, she devised an ingenious plan to provide an existing building with a major extension. In retirement, she served as a Founding Director of the Palm Beach Festival and gave significant support to the Palm Beach Opera and the Society of the Four Arts. Elected President of the Palm Beach Towers Condominium, she oversaw a major renovation of the building. She also maintained ties to New York, serving as a Trustee of Barnard College, where she recently attended the 75th reunion of the Class of 1932. At Atria Senior Residence in New York, where she relocated in 2006, she founded and became the first President of the Residents' Council. No funeral services will be held. Contributions in her memory may be made to Maimonides Medical Center or Barnard College.

THIS season's boyfriend jackets and grandpa cardigans have given rise to fashion's next big thing: unisex clothing. And Assembly New York, a new clothing and curio shop on Ludlow Street, is one of the more inspired stores catering to it. The owner, Greg Armas (right), has stocked the shop with a tight selection of well-made ''antitrend'' pieces that are drawing male and female shoppers: shrunken jackets and drainpipe trousers from Endovanera, broken-in T-shirts and summer scarves from the Los Angeles newcomer Raquel Allegra and vintage henleys and cardigans from the '40s. Mr. Armas also has antique decorations, Victorian-inspired jewelry and his own collaborative projects including beach towels, audio equipment and Native American quilts. ''I look at every piece in the store as an authentic article,'' said Mr. Armas, who used wood that he pulled from the East River to build the interior. ''It's a different kind of curation. Gender doesn't play into it.''

SPIKING gasoline prices, tighter emissions standards, a grim economic outlook -- does this sound familiar? -- all conspired to doom the original Dodge Challenger to an early expiration date. The Challenger of 1970-74 was Dodge's entry into the ''pony car'' class of sporty coupes spawned by the Ford Mustang in 1964. Alas, it was unfashionably late to a party that had since grown crowded with the introduction of the Chevrolet Camaro in 1967 and competitors from Mercury, Pontiac and even American Motors.
Dance Claudia La Rocco

MICHEELS--Dr. Louis J., died at home in Newton, MA on his 91st birthday on June 6. Dr. Micheels practiced psychiatry and psychoanalysis in Westport, CT, for more than 50 years. He also was an associate clinical professor of psychiatry at Yale University. He was a past president and longterm member of the Western New England Psychoanalytic Institute and Society. He was born in the Netherlands and moved to the United States after surviving World War II. He wrote a book about his Holocaust experience titled Dr.117641, which was published by Yale University Press in three languages. He was an avid sailor competing for many years in Atlantic class sailboats, and an accomplished equestrian and woodworker. He was especially fond of his summer home in West Tisbury, which reminded him of his childhood home near the dunes in Holland. Survivors include his wife of 60 years, Ina; his son Ronald and his daughter Elizabeth, and their spouses, Ann and David; and grandchildren Wyn, Lia, Graham and Erik. Contributions may be made to: Lown Cardiovascular Research Foundation, 21 Longwood Avenue, Brookline, MA 02446.

Last week's high temperatures were greeted with a preview of summer fashion: white dresses, floaty chemise styles and the city's favorite, black. There were a few Mondrian-pattern dresses. Bryant Park installed mist fans, including two huge ones to cool off diners. Saks Fifth Avenue painted flip-flops across six of its 50th Street windows, mirroring the footwear of passers-by. Many pedestrians had to pause to scrape melted chewing gum off their shoes.

PHOTO: Buildings were piled against a railroad bridge in the Cedar River on Saturday, days after the river swamped Cedar Rapids, Iowa, in record flooding. The water, which forced thousands of people from their homes, started to recede, but those who remained were urged to save the last of their unspoiled drinking water. Early property damage estimates exceeded $700 million. (PHOTOGRAPH BY JEFF ROBERSON/ASSOCIATED PRESS)

KAPLAN--Leo, 95, of Flushing, NY, died on June 12, after a life of love, laughter and purpose. Survived by Jewel, his beloved wife of 70 years, daughters and sons-in-law, Carole and Hank Lefcort and Linda and Geoff Councill, and sisters, Rose Bilander and Selma Sacks. Grandfather of Aliza Wolfe and Jessica Merriam, and ''Papa'' to Adam and Victoria, Aidan and Caleb. Leo and Jewel owned Brite Pharmacy in Jackson Heights from 1956 to 1981, after which Leo became a passionate senior activist, teaching a weekly Social Action class for 20 years. NY State Senior Citizen of the Year in 1986. Interment was private. Memorial service will be held at a future date. Donations may be made to Citymeals on Wheels or Channel 13.

FREDERICKS--Phyllis, 85, of Greenwich, died Monday June 9, 2008 at home. Born in New York, NY on July 2, 1922. She was the daughter of the late Max and Gertrude Slaven Marcus, and the wife of the late Frank Fredericks who died on May 14, 2008. She volunteered at Greenwich Hospital. In her younger years she volunteered doing sound recordings for Reading for the Blind. She was a supporter of the Special Olympics and volunteered many hours helping the organization and athletes, she also was very musical, playing the organ and singing with the Silvertones. She also enjoyed tap dancing, and danced late into her 70s. Mrs. Fredericks is survived by two nieces, Irene Baker and Anne Galletta and a nephew, Jeff Baker. Services were held Thursday. Interment took place in Putnam Cemetery. Memorial contributions may be made to Greenwich Hospital Hospice, 5 Perryridge Road, Greenwich, CT 06830.

KUPFERBERG--Paula Rose, died on June 10th after a valiant struggle against lymphoma. She was the adored wife of the late Leonard Kupferberg, loving sister of Doris Goldstein, and dearest companion of Morrie Golick. She was the most beloved mother of Bonnie and Louis, Carol and Bob, Joni and Paolo, and Penny and Steve. Most devoted and cherished grandmother of Cori and Dan, Craig and Andrea, Dana, Michael, Lisa, David, Matthew and Lauren and proudest great-grandmother of Mia and Kyla. She was an extraordinary woman and our hero. Her courage, love, and devotion to her family will keep her forever in our hearts. We love you Mom! Donations in her memory made to SLE Lupus Foundation, NYC or NYU Cancer Institute, NYC.

PILLSBURY--Donaldson Clark. Michael Sovern, Chairman of The Board of Directors of Sotheby's, Chief Executive Officer Bill Ruprecht and Sotheby's worldwide staff mourn the untimely passing of their colleague and friend, Don Pillsbury, on June 12th. Distinguished by his integrity, grace, wisdom and honor, Don was the epitome of a fine and decent man. He leaves an enormous void at Sotheby's and we will miss him. Our condolences go to his wife, Marnie, and their children Donaldson C. Pillsbury, Jr., Barbara Blair Enders and Wendy Pillsbury Eichmann; to his five grandchildren and to his siblings John S. Pillsbury III, L. Harrison Pillsbury, and Katherine Jose. PILLSBURY--Donaldson C. The trustees, faculty, students, and staff of The Rockefeller University community mourn the sudden and untimely passing of our cherished friend, Don Pillsbury, an esteemed member of The Rockefeller University Council and husband of Marnie Pillsbury, our beloved Vice Chairman. Like all who knew him, we loved Don dearly, and we are heartbroken for Marnie and her children. We send them every wish for comfort and strength as they face this devastating loss. Don's friendship with Rockefeller University began as a result of Marnie's involvement; we were the beneficiary of the wonderful partnership that they shared in all aspects of their lives. Along with Marnie, he became a passionate ambassador and advocate for the advancement of biomedical research and for the University. Don was a man of deep integrity, keen intellect, discerning judgment, and immense personal warmth. He gave back to the world through his many pro bono involvements. As Chair of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, he combined a love of music with strong leadership abilities to enrich the culture of our great City. The joy he felt in life, and in his love for Marnie and his children, was palpable. A remarkable couple, Marnie and Don's enduring love and devotion to each other had a way of embracing everyone around them. Gifted at love, their love was a gift to us all. We are so fortunate to have known Don, and we will miss him tremendously. With deepest sorrow, we extend our condolences to Marnie; to their children, Don, Blair, and Wendy; and to the entire Pillsbury family. Paul Nurse, President Russell Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus and the Board of Trustees Torsten Wiesel, President Emeritus Marnie Imhoff, Vice President The Rockefeller University PILLSBURY--Donaldson C. The family and friends of Don Pillsbury mourn the loss of a beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, and friend. Don died suddenly after a terrific bike ride with good friends along the Connecticut shore in Old Lyme, Connecticut on Thursday, June 12th. He was 67. The cause of death was heart failure. Don was a chairman of Sotheby's North and South America and former worldwide general counsel and executive vice president of Sotheby's. Before that he was a senior partner (1967-1993) at the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell. In addition to his work at Davis Polk and Sotheby's, Don pursued a wide variety of personal business and non - profit interests. He served as chairman of The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in New York-a particular passion--and as a director of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. For 17 years, he was a trustee of the Nightingale Bamford School, also in New York City. More recently, he served as a trustee of Robert College in Istanbul, Turkey, the New York Community Trust, and the Stuart Family Foundation, a private foundation based outside of Chicago. We will remember everything about him. But especially for his utter integrity, his lovely humor, his passion for music, good wine, Cheetos. He loved the outdoors, biking, skiing, hiking, and sailing. We lovingly remember his incredible generosity and joy in simple things, the family, the garden, the silly cards, obscure gifts and collectibles--often acquired on E-Bay. His grandchildren were the light of his life. We will miss him dearly. He is survived by his wife Marnie, his children Donaldson Clark Pillsbury, Jr. and his wife Skye of San Francisco, CA, Blair Pillsbury Enders and her husband Jack of New York, NY, Wendy Pillsbury Eichmann, and her husband Chris of Greenwich, CT and his five grandchildren Tyler and Sam Eichmann, Nicholas and Marian Enders, and Clark Pillsbury. His siblings John S. Pillsbury III, L. Harrison Pillsbury, and Katharine Jose also survive him. A memorial service will be held on Monday, June 23 at 3pm at St. Thomas Church, One W. 53rd St., New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, Robert College in Istanbul, and the New York Community Trust. PILLSBURY--Donaldson C. The Trustees of Robert College of Istanbul deeply mourn the sudden death of a fellow Trustee. We are grateful for his service, wisdom and friendship, and will feel the loss of his presence. We offer our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Marnie and their family. PILLSBURY--Donaldson C. The Board, artists and staff of The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center note with great sadness the loss of our longstanding Board member and cherished friend Don Pillsbury. Don served as Chairman of the Board of Directors from 1993 to 2004 and remained on the Board as Vice Chairman until his sudden death on Thursday. Inspired by a deep love of music, Don was steadfastly devoted to carrying forth and enhancing the mission of the Chamber Music Society. Under his guidance the Society initiated a significant expansion of its Alice Tully Hall season, created new musical programs, and developed a national radio series that successfully drew new and appreciative audiences. He also encouraged the development of the Society's wide-ranging education programs and residency opportunities for young artists. A man of impeccable taste and great integrity, Don was the model of a good and decent man and inspired others through his personal generosity and wise leadership. His immense capacity for friendship was deeply felt and especially appreciated by his colleagues on the Board and by the artists and staff of the Society. We will miss his enthusiasm, commitment, and his reliable presence among us. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Marnie and to his family. Peter Frelinghuysen Chairman Charles Hamilton Vice Chairman David Finckel and Wu Han Artistic Directors Norma Hurlburt Executive Director PILLSBURY--Don. It is with profound sadness that my colleagues and I mourn the untimely passing of Don Pillsbury, devoted husband of our beloved associate, Marnie. Don's remarkable capacity to balance a distinguished career with his total dedication to his family filled us with admiration and awe. We will miss him greatly and send our deepest sympathies to Marnie and her family. David Rockefeller PILLSBURY--Donaldson C. The Distribution Committee and staff of The New York Community Trust mourn the sudden death of our esteemed colleague, Don Pillsbury. His passion for the City's nonprofit community and its services to all New Yorkers was an inspiration to those of us who had the pleasure of working with him. Our deepest sympathies to his wife Marnie, their children and grandchildren, and the extended family. Samuel S. Polk, Chairman Lorie A. Slutsky, President PILLSBURY--Donaldson C. ''Our credibility has eroded.'' Richard S. Fuld Jr., chief executive of Lehman Brothers, in a memo to employees. The bank's chief operating officer and president, along with its chief financial officer, were both removed from their posts. ''This is pushing my nerves to the limit.'' Randy Kron, a corn farmer in Griffin, Ind., whose fields are too soggy to plant.

FOR 14 years, the jazz acts at the Caramoor International Music Festival in Katonah, N.Y., have been presented on two consecutive Saturdays at the end of July and the beginning of August. This year, they will be presented on three straight days, Aug. 1 to 3. That coincides precisely with the schedule of the Litchfield Jazz Festival, in Goshen, setting up the first head-to-head three-day competition between two major events on the jazz calendar. Both festivals draw heavily from an upper-middle-class fan base and both are within driving distance of many of the same potential concertgoers.

To the Editor: It was with great interest and nostalgia that I read ''Tree Proud'' and ''Let Them Count the Ways'' (June 1), the articles about New Yorkers' favorite trees. These articles brought back fond memories of my years as a teacher at Public School 9 on the Upper West Side, and more specifically to 1984 and a classroom that my fifth graders and I shared on a second floor on West 84th Street, with a large tree in front of our windows.

SPENCER--Sash. You were a one - of - a - kind person. Whatever you did in your lifetime, you did with the greatest of passion, skill and humor, whether it be involved in business transactions, art, sailing, mountain climbing, hiking or just engaging in dinner conversation with Mary and friends. Sash, we will never forgot and always miss you. We extend heartfelt condolences and love to Mary. Broser Family SPENCER--S.A. (Sash), 76 Sash A. Spencer, a resident of Key Biscayne, Florida passed away on June 10, 2008 in New York following a brief illness. Mr. Spencer was the founder and chairman of Holding Capital Group, a private investment firm specializing in leveraged buyouts, management buyouts, and money management. Born in Zagreb, Yugoslavia on June 22, 1931. He traveled with his parents in Europe during his early years before moving to the Philippines where he lived and was imprisoned during the Japanese occupation. Mr. Spencer graduated from American School in Manila, Philippines in 1948. He received an AA and BS Degree in Commerce, Malayan Colleges in 1946 and 1954 respectively. During this period he also operated his own company, Operated Mercantile, Inc, in the Philippines, which was in the import/export/services industry. Mr. Spencer was an officer in the US Army, OCS Artillery, 101st Airborne Division from 1955-1958. Following his discharge from the army he went on to earn his MBA with distinction from the Wharton School in Accounting at the University of Pennsylvania in 1959. After earning his MBA he was a Principal with McKinsey & Co., Inc., Management Consultants, in Washington, DC and New York from 1959-1966. In 1966 Mr. Spencer became President and CEO at the Briggs Manufacturing Company in Detroit, Michigan. He left in 1970 and was Managing Director of A.P. Moeller (Maersk Line), Copenhagen, Denmark until 1975 when he founded Holding Capital Group. Mr. Spencer was an avid art collector, racer of sailboats and a hiking enthusiast. Surviving are Mary M. Spencer, his beloved wife of 47 years and his sister, Linda Fales of Sunrise, Florida. Mr. Spencer was preceded in death by both of his parents and his brother Henry. A memorial service will be announced at a future date. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made payable to: Columbia University Dr. Schneller Cardiac Research. Checks should be sent to Dr. Schneller's office at: S.J. Schneller, M.D., 161 Fort Washington Avenue, Suite 546, New York, NY 10032.

THE marriage of Louis Vuitton and the Japanese art hero Takashi Murakami has spawned a series of immensely successful designs, beginning with the cartoonish Multicolor Monogram in spring 2003. Now comes their latest collaboration, a camo version of the classic print, called Monogramouflage. The collection, which hits select Louis Vuitton stores today, includes luggage, small leather goods, jewelry, shoes, textiles and ready-to-wear. But, alas, no tote bags. ''I'd love them to make some,'' Mr. Murakami said. ''I'd like to have one.'' Monogramouflage Keepall duffel bag,

SELBY--Dr. Henry M., M.D., F.A.C.R., died peacefully on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89 years old. Dr. Selby is survived by his wife Delia of 25 years. He was the proud father of three sons Norman, Bill and Russell, and grandfather of five, Luke, Thomas, Katie, Ali and Christina. He is also survived by his sister, Mildred York, and his first wife, Dr. Cecily Cannan Selby. Dr. Selby grew up in Brooklyn, and had a long, successful and important career as a diagnostic radiologist in New York City. He began as a resident at Memorial Hospital in 1951, and continued to practice at the Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center for more than 40 years. He was also Clinical Assistant Professor of Medicine at Cornell University Medical College, and Director of the Department of Radiology at the Medical Arts Center Hospital and the Strang Clinic, all in Manhattan. In addition, he founded and led the PMX Medical Group. Dr. Selby received his undergraduate and medical degrees from Louisiana State University. During World War II, Dr. Selby served as a Lieutenant in the Navy Medical Corps and was stationed in the United States and the Azores. Dr. and Mrs. Selby have endowed the Henry and Delia Merit Scholarship Fund at the LSU School of Medicine. The Henry M. Selby, M.D., Young Investigators Lecture Series in Radiology, which is a forum for young radiologists to present their research on cancer, was endowed in his honor by his family at Memorial Sloan-Kettering; his son Norman is a member of the Board of Managers there. Dr. Selby treasured his family, and had a life-long love of New York, New Orleans, good food, good wine and Monte Cristos. In lieu of flowers, Dr. Selby's family is asking that contributions be made to the Henry and Delia Merit Scholarship Fund at the Foundation for the LSU Health Sciences Center in New Orleans, Louisiana, 70112. Services will be private.

KUPFERBERG--Paula. We are heartbroken by the death of this exceptional woman. She had great strength, was wise and innovative, had a great sense of humor and style. She loved and was loved by family and friends alike. She is survived by her loving family as well as her soulmate and devoted companion Morrie Golick. We are deeply grateful for the difference she made in our lives ...and it all started with a blind date. She will be missed but not forgotten. LUSTIG--Harriet, 88, of New York and Florida died of complications after a brief illness on June 9, 2008 at Florida Hospital in Orlando. Devoted wife of Laurence for 69 years and mother of Jonathan of Connecticut. She is survived by her sister Florence and sister-in-law Flora. Harriet and Laurence were snowbirds, spending a few months in their home in New York before returning to their condo in Florida. Harriet will be missed by her many wonderful friends in both the North and the South. Harriet studied art at Marymount College in Tarrytown, NY and became a talented and successful sculptor. Her work was exhibited and sold widely and is probably owned by numerous collectors. She loved flowers, the theater, art and music. A prolific reader, she was an active member of book clubs in Orlando and Winter Park. A talented and creative cook, she delighted friends and family with imaginative dishes. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her and who universally described her as a beautiful human being.

RUSSERT--Tim. The Board of Governors, Trustees, staff and young people of Boys & Girls Clubs of America wish to express our profound sorrow over the sudden passing of Tim Russert. As a longtime advocate for children, Tim cared deeply and gave back generously to children, especially those most in need. He served with distinction as a member of the board of directors of the Boys & Girls Clubs of Greater Washington, and was beloved by all. We were privileged to have counted Tim as a true friend and supporter, and a man of great character and compassion, and our nation will miss him greatly. Boys & Girls Clubs of America Rick Goings, Chairman Roxanne Spillett, President/CEO

THE NEWS With his presidency drawing to a close, President Bush embarked on a farewell tour of Europe that took him to Slovenia, Germany, France, Italy and Britain. BEHIND THE NEWS Though he remains deeply unpopular in Europe, it was clear that he had repaired at least some of the strain over the war in Iraq. European leaders greeted him with evident warmth, and Pope Benedict XVI led a tour of the gardens where he prays each evening -- the first time the pontiff has greeted a world leader there, the White House said -- and offered a gift of four volumes about St. Peter's Basilica. ''Perhaps you'll have some time to read it,'' the pope told him.

WITSELL--Daphne Towne, of Hobe Sound, FL, and Glen Cove, NY, died peacefully at home on June 10, 2008 in Hope Sound, after a five year fight with ovarian cancer. She was a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John D.C. Towne. Daphne was born in New York City on January 14, 1935. She was the loving wife for over 52 years of Frederick C. John Witsell, Jr., and the loving mother of Deborah Witsell Vivian, South Hamilton, MA, and Frederick C. Witsell, III, Pawling, NY. Proud grandmother of: Haley Dolan Witsell; Katharine Towne Witsell; Donald Witsell Vivian; and John Chaplin Vivian. She is survived by her twin sister Mrs. Diana Towne Knox, Greensboro, NC. Daphne was loved and respected by her many friends and admirers. She was a caring, private person; an excellent bridge player; loved to garden; was a good golfer; and enjoyed solving crossword puzzles and double acrostics, on a daily basis. She also was an avid reader. She served on the board of The Hobe Sound Nature Center. Daphne graduated from The New Canaan Country School, The Ethel Walker School in 1952, and attended Finch College. A memorial Service will be held on Thursday, June 26th, at 11am at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church, Lattingtown and Old Tappan Road, Locust Valley, NY 11560. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: Jupiter Medical Center Foundation, Inc., 1210 South Old Dixie Highway, Jupiter, FL 33458-7205 or Hospice Foundation c/o Treasure Coast Hospice 1201 S.E.
