Six of us are interested in traveling to Morocco. What are the best ways to travel among the cities, and are there tour companies that deal with small groups? -- Richard and Bettina Willson, Seattle You can travel between major cities in Morocco by train (www.oncf.ma) or bus (www.supratours.ma). Buses will take you to smaller towns in the south off the train routes. There are companies that offer small-group Morocco tours, like Intrepid Travel (www.intrepidtravel.com), which offers a 15-day ''Colours of Morocco'' tour for up to 12 people.

So far, the harrowing effect of soaring fuel prices has focused mainly on cars, trucks and planes. But boat owners are feeling the pain, too. Commercial fishermen are suffering because of much-higher diesel costs. For salmon fishermen, the fuel burden is adding insult to the injury of a season that was curtailed because of sharply declining stocks. And recreational boaters are finding that their love of the water is having a much more substantial impact on their wallets. When a boater finished filling up his boat's tank earlier this month in Patchogue, N.Y., before a day of fishing off Fire Island, the price tag was an eyepopping $250 for 50 gallons of gas.

SUSKIND--Adeline Magaliff died peacefully at home on June 12, 2008 at the age of 99. She lived at North Shore Towers in Floral Park, NY. She was born in New York City on April 20, 1909, the last surviving of five siblings born to Eva and Harry Magaliff of New York City. Adeline was ahead of her time. She was the first woman to graduate from Hunter College in three years. After graduating she taught grammar school in Harlem and then throughout her 35 year career in schools for underprivileged children. She came from a musical family and was a fine pianist. Independent and adventurous, she traveled all over the world from her early twenties and throughout most of her life. She was the beloved wife of Herman Suskind who died in 1987. She is survived by her daughter Barbara Suskind Goldfarb, an Interior Designer, and her son-in-law Dr. Michael Goldfarb, Chief of Surgery at Monmouth Medical Center. Her two grandsons, Greg and Eric, are technology professionals living in the Bay Area of California with their wives. She is also survived by numerous nieces, nephews, and friends living in the New York and Boston areas. Adeline was entombed on June 13, 2008 at The Sanctuary at Mount Lebanon Cemetery in Glendale, NY. She will always be in our hearts. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in her name to the Jaqueline Wilentz Breast Center at Monmouth Medical Center, Long Branch, NJ.

Jason, Tracy, Rob, Grady, Sullivan Meyer, NJ. Joan Banov, NY; Janet, Leonard Meyer, GA. Beverly B. Brown; Scott, Roger, Richard Meyer. Her zest, humor, wisdom & love illuminate our lives.

PATERSON--James Graham Sr., 89, of Wilmington, NC, died Wednesday, June 11, 2008, at C. N. Davis Health Care Center. He was the C.E.O. of H. A. Astlett & Co., Inc., importers and exporters specializing in the import of natural rubber and burlap and the export of used textile and shoe machinery. After service in World War II, he traveled widely in the Far East and South America seeking reliable suppliers and customers in the newly emerging nations. He was a former member of the India House and the Princeton Club of NY. He leaves his beloved wife of 62 years, Zafero Pappas Paterson, daughter, Page Paterson and husband, Charles Robbins, of Wilmington, NC, two sons, James Graham Paterson, Jr. and wife, Mary, of Wilmington, NC, and David Gregory Paterson and wife, Susan, of Cranbury, NJ; four granddaughters, four grandsons, one great-granddaughter, and a sister, Hilary P. Cleveland of New London, NH. Two sisters, Joan P. Kerr of Hartford, CT, and Marjorie S. Gimber of Montclair, NJ, preceded him in death. A memorial service for friends and family will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made in his name to Lower Cape Fear Hospice, 2222 South 17th Street, Wilmington, NC 28401. Condolences may be sent to the family at: www.andrewsmortuary.com

MICHAEL BARRETT has such an easygoing presence that it's hard to imagine him stirring the pot. But, five years into his tenure as chief executive officer of the Caramoor International Music Festival in Katonah, N.Y., that's precisely what he has done. When Mr. Barrett took the helm in July 2003, standard presentations of the core classical repertory dominated the festival's fare. In its 63rd season, which opens on Saturday, nearly a third of the 38 concerts will deviate in some way from that formula. And the audiences will be about 15 percent larger than they were before he took over, he said.

An article last Sunday about Debbie Capozzi of Bayport, who will compete in sailing in the Olympics this summer, misidentified the location of Old Dominion University, where she was on the sailing team. It is Norfolk, Va., not Richmond.

ENGELKING--Hess, died on Thursday, June 12 in Stamford, CT, two weeks before her 98th birthday. Hess Pringle Houghton Engelking was born on June 27, 1910 in New York, NY. She was the daughter of William Morris Houghton and Mary Motte (Hess) Pringle. The family lived in Plainfield, NJ where Hess attended The Hartridge School. She graduated from Radcliffe College and pursued graduate studies there in Anthropology. In the midst of the Depression, she moved to New York City where she worked at the New York Herald Tribune. There she met the soon-to-be legendary newspaperman, L. L. Engelking and they were married in 1939. The Engelkings, with three children, lived in Forest Hills, Queens and then Plainfield, NJ. In the 1950s, Hess returned to graduate school, earning a Masters in Library Science from Rutgers University. She was a Librarian at the Plainfield and Madison, NJ Libraries for many years. In 1977, the Engelkings retired to Cooperstown where L. L. Engelking died in 1980. Hess worked at the Cooperstown Library, and later volunteered there and at the Bassett Hospital and the New York Historical Association. She was a redoubtable Hiker on the back roads and trails of Cooperstown and all over Europe. In her 80s, she learned how to cross country ski and climbed Mt. Algonquin in the Adirondacks. She was always the consummate reference Librarian, never giving up on an explanation until she had the appropriate source material, and she possessed of an Anthropologists immense insight into human behavior. She was known for her grit and tenacity and realistic approach to life. An admirer said, ''If Hess dies, that means we all have to die.'' She is saluted, loved and missed by her children Elizabeth Mueller, Mary Motte Hall and Peter Engelking; their spouses David Barnes and Connie Engelking; her brother William Houghton and her niece Charlotte Houghton Friedman; her eight grandchildren William Teitler, Joseph Teitler, Sarah Teitler, John Teitler, Timothy Hall, Andrew Hall, Emily Engelking and Joshua Engelking; and by her eight greatgrandchildren. Contributions in her memory would be welcome at the Friends of the Cooperstown Library and the Friends of Bassett Hospital, all in Cooperstown, NY; the Wardlaw-Hartridge School in Edison, NJ; Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study at Harvard University in Cambridge, MA.

ULLMAN--Dr. Montague, of Ardsley, New York, internationally renowned psychoanalyst and pioneer in experiential dream groups for therapists and dreamers, died recently at age 91. He founded one of New York's first sleep laboratories, conducted ground breaking exper iments in dream telepathy and inspired movements in Sweden, Finland and Taiwan with his many professional papers and books. Charter Fellow of the American Academy of Psychoanalysis, past president of the Society of Medical Psychoanalysts, American Society for Psychical Research and the Parapsychological Association, Life Fellow of the American Psychiatric Association. Husband to the late Janet (Simon), father of Susan Ullman, William Ullman and Lucy Bain; grandfather of Annalese McDermott and Jessica Bain, Leif Ullman and Noah Daniel Ullman; great-grandfather of Harris McDermott; brother of Bob Ullman and the late Jean Blake.

THE DeLorean Car Show this weekend in Gettysburg, Pa., will probably bring out many different examples of the much beloved stainless steel car, from pristine restorations to the requisite B.T.T.F. (that's ''Back to the Future'') time machine conversions. But the most interesting car at the biannual event could be an electric DeLorean, built by Dave Delman out of his garage in Jericho, N.Y. A medical doctor by trade with his own physical medicine and rehabilitation practice, Dr. Delman also has degrees in electrical engineering and biomedical engineering. In 2001, he was a semifinalist in the Hammacher Schlemmer catalog's Search for Invention contest. His invention, the TV Pedaler, an exercise device, did not win, but it found its way into the Hammacher Schlemmer summer catalog in 2002.

SPIKING gasoline prices, tighter emissions standards, a grim economic outlook -- does this sound familiar? -- all conspired to doom the original Dodge Challenger to an early expiration date. The Challenger of 1970-74 was Dodge's entry into the ''pony car'' class of sporty coupes spawned by the Ford Mustang in 1964. Alas, it was unfashionably late to a party that had since grown crowded with the introduction of the Chevrolet Camaro in 1967 and competitors from Mercury, Pontiac and even American Motors.

LAUNCHING A KITE AT WHITE SANDS NATIONAL MONUMENT, AUG. 28, 2007 Bruce DeFoor, 53, an art professor from Ruidoso, N.M. ''I actually hadn't been to White Sands since I was a child. I can remember digging my feet down in the sand when I was a kid and feeling that cool sand. It's warm on top, then cool underneath. I was there this time to fly kites under the full moon; because of the white sand, everything just shows up and sort of glows. This kite -- called the Spirit Flier -- was white along with the sand, and there was an eerie glow that happened. The winds were calm, just enough to keep my kites aloft. There's a special feeling about that. You feel the tug on the string, you give it just enough pull to keep it up in the air. I've been a university art professor for 30 years. I love sculpture, I love painting, and I really feel that kites are a flying art form. They're very sculptural, very visual. And when you're flying a kite, you can't help but be connected to that. So it turns into a performance art piece, too.''

MAGGIN--Jane C. Joseph J. Ciancaglini, Head of School, and the trustees, faculty and staff, students, parents and alumnae of Convent of the Sacred Heart, New York City, deeply mourn the passing of an exceptional friend. An inspirational leader and creative problem solver, Jane generously and tirelessly served the school as trustee for over 25 years. Her exemplary loyalty to the school and her dedication to its community were instrumental in cultivating Sacred Heart's excellent academic program, maintaining its landmark home and developing its financial strength. A valiant woman and a devoted Child of the Sacred Heart, Jane will be deeply missed by the 91st Street community. We cherish the memory of Jane's strength and spirit and remember her daughter Alice, class of 1987, and her entire family in prayer.

WITH average gasoline prices hitting $4 a gallon, drivers are increasingly looking for ways to cut fuel costs. Chief among this group are the hypermilers. Hypermilers use a variety of techniques, from the manufacturer-recommended to the illegal, to maximize their mileage. This includes keeping up on vehicle maintenance, especially oil changes and tire pressure; driving at or below the speed limit; and more dangerous tactics like coasting or following closely behind larger vehicles the way Nascar racers draft.

In June 1948, after the Soviet Union blockaded allied deliveries of supplies to the Western sectors of Berlin, the United States and its allies launched what became known as the Berlin Airlift, using transport planes to drop food and supplies to Berliners. The airlift became a turning point in the cold war, when the West pushed back against the Soviet Union's quest for dominance in central Europe. Here is an interview on that historic crisis with Andrei Cherny, the editor of Democracy, a journal, and the author of "The Candy Bombers: The Untold Story of the Berlin Airlift and America's Finest Hour" (2008). Mr. Cherny was a policy adviser and speechwriter in the Clinton White House.

The New Haven Review, a fledging literary journal, has a new issue out. Each Monday the journal publishes a new book review on its Web site - but there's a catch. Before any other readers post another comment about "overpopulation" and doomsday scenarios, I suggest they take a look at my colleague Donald McNeil's excellent article on Malthusian mistakes. As he notes, the current forecasts of energy and food disasters sound just like the ones made during the 1970s. Similar apocalyptic forecasts were made in the 1940s (in books like "Our Plundered Planet") and in other eras by prophets following in Malthus' tradition.

At the beginning of the second full week of the general election contest, Senator Obama delivers a message about competitiveness in Flint, Mich., a city known for economic hardship. Later he'll hold a rally in Detroit.

XM Satellite Radio and Sirius Satellite Radio moved closer to making their proposed $5 billion merger a reality, following reports that the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission would recommend approving the controversial hook-up.

In an open letter to Jerry Yang published Saturday, The New York Times' Joe Nocera lacerates the Yahoo chief to task for his muddled handling of Microsoft's bid to buy the search giant, as well as his decision to throw his company into Google's arms.

Only a year ago, Wall Street reveled in an era of superlatives: record deals, record profit, record pay. But a mere 12 months later, nearly half of the profits that major banks reaped during that age of riches have vanished.
On the first full weekend in June, JPMorgan Chase began phasing out the Bear Stearns name - beginning with the Midtown Manhattan headquarters of the firm it acquired May 31.

SPI Group, the beverage conglomerate, has hired Lehman Brothers to explore a sale of its Stolichnaya vodka unit in what would be the latest sale of a famous beverage brand, according to press reports.

For the second time in three years, the board at American International Group, the giant insurance company, replaced its chief executive Sunday in the wake of its falling stock price and regulatory concerns about its accounting.

The managers of two Bear Stearns hedge funds whose collapse last summer signaled the start the of the credit crisis could get slapped with criminal charges this week, according to a published media report.
InBev, the world's biggest brewer, started to build an argument Sunday for its $65-a-share offer to acquire Anheuser-Busch, saying it was based on the Budweiser maker's current assets and business.

Authorities in the United States on Friday were trying to determine whether Samuel Israel III, a former hedge fund manager who failed to report to prison and is suspected of faking his suicide, will have enough money to sustain life on the run, Reuters reported. The New York Times looked at the many contradictions in the life of Mr. Israel, who managed the now-defunct Bayou Group hedge fund.

It has been almost 10 months since Guy Hands, the private equity financier who had made a fortune sprucing up pubs in England and gas stations on the German autobahn through his firm Terra Firma, bought EMI for about $6.4 billion, and by several accounts, including Mr. Hands's own, it has been a chaotic time.

A group led by NBC Universal is in exclusive negotiations to buy the Weather Channel, NBC confirmed on Friday, hours after Time Warner withdrew its bid. The acquisition may be completed in a matter of days.

Trash company Republic Services is in talks to buy competitor Allied Waste Industries in an all-stock deal worth about $6.77 billion, the companies said on Friday.

Bowing to shareholder pressure, directors at Washington Mutual, the nation's largest savings and loan, stripped Kerry K. Killinger, chairman and chief executive of the company, of his chairmanship on June 2. The board said it would appoint an independent chairman by July 1, and it instituted a majority voting standard for future director elections.

The last time the News Corporation left the German media market in 2002, the exit was costly. The media conglomerate controlled by Rupert Murdoch had been a shareholder in the media group controlled by the Munich entrepreneur Leo Kirch and had to take a $1.93 billion write-off when two Kirch companies filed for bankruptcy.

NYDORF--William S., 97, on June 13, 2008 in Sarasota, FL. Dearly beloved husband of Diane and the late Freda, father of Jane and the late Mark, stepfather to Stephanie and the late Michael Kaufman. After earning his MBA in Finance at NYU he went to Washington, D.C. where his work spanned two decades at several agencies. When he left the SEC he moved to New York and joined American & Foreign Power as Chief Financial Officer. He was an avid concertgoer, voracious reader and accomplished golf and bridge player. His integrity, intellect, kindness and dry wit endeared him to all.

MAGGIN--Jane C. Joseph J. Ciancaglini, Head of School, and the trustees, faculty and staff, students, parents and alumnae of Convent of the Sacred Heart, New York City, deeply mourn the passing of an exceptional friend. An inspirational leader and creative problem solver, Jane generously and tirelessly served the school as trustee for over 25 years. Her exemplary loyalty to the school and her dedication to its community were instrumental in cultivating Sacred Heart's excellent academic program, maintaining its landmark home and developing its financial strength. A valiant woman and a devoted Child of the Sacred Heart, Jane will be deeply missed by the 91st Street community. We cherish the memory of Jane's strength and spirit and remember her daughter Alice, class of 1987, and her entire family in prayer.

The Consumer Price Index, which measures the prices of household products, rose 0.6 percent last month, and consumers paid 5 percent more for food and beverages in May compared with a year ago. More people are clipping coupons online. According to Hitwise, visits to the rewards and directories category, which includes coupon sites, increased 34 percent from May 2007 to May 2008. Web sites like Coupons.com, above, offer searches by ZIP code, by popular brand names, and by categories like beverages and pet care. There is even a way to check for coupons that are about to expire. SHELLY FREIERMAN

BELL--Hilda M. (Folkman), age 95, on June 13th. Beloved mother of Rebecca Folkman, Benjamin Folkman and Jonathan Folkman, grandmother of David Folkman Mazieres and Christopher Folkman. After graduating from Barnard College at age 19, she earned a Master's Degree in music. A social worker during the 1930s, she was also active in Junior Federation, undertaking administrative duties and composing a full-length musical comedy for a Brooklyn Academy of Music benefit performance. In 1940 she married Dr. Nathan Folkman. She later joined the Board of Hamilton-Madison Settlement House. Widowed in 1956, she entered the business world and proved a pioneer. Erecting a new commercial building on Northern Boulevard for her linen supply company, she changed the nature of the supply industry by extending services beyond residences to include smaller hospitals. She soon became a member of the Board of Maimonides Medical Center. In 1974 she married Clarence D. Bell (deceased 2001). Subsequently, she began a five-year tenure as the first woman president of Maimonides. In this post, she devised an ingenious plan to provide an existing building with a major extension. In retirement, she served as a Founding Director of the Palm Beach Festival and gave significant support to the Palm Beach Opera and the Society of the Four Arts. Elected President of the Palm Beach Towers Condominium, she oversaw a major renovation of the building. She also maintained ties to New York, serving as a Trustee of Barnard College, where she recently attended the 75th reunion of the Class of 1932. At Atria Senior Residence in New York, where she relocated in 2006, she founded and became the first President of the Residents' Council. No funeral services will be held. Contributions in her memory may be made to Maimonides Medical Center or Barnard College.

A Twist in ConnectU v. Facebook This spring, Facebook reached a settlement in its long-simmering, often embarrassing lawsuit with ConnectU, a Harvard dating site whose founders claim that their onetime employee, Mark Zuckerberg, then a sophomore, stole their idea to found Facebook.

LEATHERMAN--Sally, 82, of New York, NY, died on June 14, 2008. Beloved wife of her late husband Jack, she will be deeply missed by her family, nieces Lois and Ronnie, nephews Benjamin, Jason, Max and Sam and her dear friends the Warren family. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, June 18 at 3pm at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., NYC.

CUTLER--Dr. Kenneth B., Jr., of Stamford, died June 12, 2008 at age 39. Born September 12, 1968 in New York City to Kenneth and Cecelia (Bilsly) Cutler. Ken graduated from Bronxville High School, Amherst College and Downstate Medical School. He also completed an internal medicine residency at Columbia Presbyterian as well as a dermatology residency at New York Medical College. Ken was a practicing Dermatologist and a diplomat of the AAD and a member of Alpha Omega Alpha. He also was listed in Who's Who, an Eagle Scout and belonged to the Metropolitan Club in NYC. Ken was an Assistant Professor of Dermatology at New York Medical College. Ken was a wonderful husband, devoted son and brother and the best Daddy in the world. His talents were everything and limitless. Survived by his beloved wife Emmy Cutler, cherished children Amanda and William, loving parents Kenneth and Cecelia Cutler and devoted siblings Randy Cutler, Cynthia Cutler, Robert Cutler (wife Dana) and Jeffrey Cutler. Friends are welcome to attend the Funeral Mass Monday 10am at Church of the Holy Spirit in Stamford followed by an interment at Long Ridge Union Cemetery. Services held with dignity by Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home in Stamford.

KAUFMAN--Louis, on June 15, 2008 at the age of 83 of Jericho, NY. Beloved husband of the late Margaret Kaufman. Loving father of Rhonda Grobman and Karen Schwaid. Cherished brother of Akiva Kaufman and brother-in-law of Herbert Gildin. Devoted grandfather of Adam, Peri and Brandon. Louis was the founder and CFO of Satco Products, of Brentwood, NY. CHAMBERLAIN--Rita Mulroy, 92, died peacefully surrounded by her family June 14 at Edgewood Retirement Community in North Andover, MA. DAMAZ--Paul, passed away on June 4th, 2008 at age 90. Architect, he is survived by his wife Solange Damaz, his stepchildren Anne HalberDessaint and Philippe Ganter, and his grandchildren Bart, Clara, Edouard and Marie. A private funeral was held at Green River Cemetery, East Hampton, on June 15th.

SELBY--Dr. Henry M., M.D., F.A.C.R., died peacefully on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89 years old. Dr. Selby is survived by his wife Delia of 25 years. He was the proud father of three sons Norman, Bill and Russell, and grandfather of five, Luke, Thomas, Katie, Ali and Christina. He is also survived by his sister, Mildred York, and his first wife, Dr. Cecily Cannan Selby. Dr. Selby grew up in Brooklyn, and had a long, successful and important career as a diagnostic radiologist in New York City. He began as a resident at Memorial Hospital in 1951, and continued to practice at the Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center for more than 40 years. He was also Clinical Assistant Professor of Medicine at Cornell University Medical College, and Director of the Department of Radiology at the Medical Arts Center Hospital and the Strang Clinic, all in Manhattan. In addition, he founded and led the PMX Medical Group. Dr. Selby received his undergraduate and medical degrees from Louisiana State University. During World War II, Dr. Selby served as a Lieutenant in the Navy Medical Corps and was stationed in the United States and the Azores. Dr. and Mrs. Selby have endowed the Henry and Delia Merit Scholarship Fund at the LSU School of Medicine. The Henry M. Selby, M.D., Young Investigators Lecture Series in Radiology, which is a forum for young radiologists to present their research on cancer, was endowed in his honor by his family at Memorial Sloan-Kettering; his son Norman is a member of the Board of Managers there. Dr. Selby treasured his family, and had a life-long love of New York, New Orleans, good food, good wine and Monte Cristos. In lieu of flowers, Dr. Selby's family is asking that contributions be made to the Henry and Delia Merit Scholarship Fund at the Foundation for the LSU Health Sciences Center in New Orleans, Louisiana, 70112. Services will be private.

PILLSBURY--Donaldson C. The trustees, faculty, students, and staff of The Rockefeller University community mourn the sudden and untimely passing of our cherished friend, Don Pillsbury, an esteemed member of The Rockefeller University Council and husband of Marnie Pillsbury, our beloved Vice Chairman. Like all who knew him, we loved Don dearly, and we are heartbroken for Marnie and her children. We send them every wish for comfort and strength as they face this devastating loss. Don's friendship with Rockefeller University began as a result of Marnie's involvement; we were the beneficiary of the wonderful partnership that they shared in all aspects of their lives. Along with Marnie, he became a passionate ambassador and advocate for the advancement of biomedical research and for the University. Don was a man of deep integrity, keen intellect, discerning judgment, and immense personal warmth. He gave back to the world through his many pro bono involvements. As Chair of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, he combined a love of music with strong leadership abilities to enrich the culture of our great City. The joy he felt in life, and in his love for Marnie and his children, was palpable. A remarkable couple, Marnie and Don's enduring love and devotion to each other had a way of embracing everyone around them. Gifted at love, their love was a gift to us all. We are so fortunate to have known Don, and we will miss him tremendously. With deepest sorrow, we extend our condolences to Marnie; to their children, Don, Blair, and Wendy; and to the entire Pillsbury family. Paul Nurse, President Russell Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus and the Board of Trustees Torsten Wiesel, President Emeritus Marnie Imhoff, Vice President The Rockefeller University PILLSBURY--Don. It is with profound sadness that my colleagues and I mourn the untimely passing of Don Pillsbury, devoted husband of our beloved associate, Marnie. Don's remarkable capacity to balance a distinguished career with his total dedication to his family filled us with admiration and awe. We will miss him greatly and send our deepest sympathies to Marnie and her family. David Rockefeller PILLSBURY--Donaldson C. The Distribution Committee and staff of The New York Community Trust mourn the sudden death of our esteemed colleague, Don Pillsbury. His passion for the City's nonprofit community and its services to all New Yorkers was an inspiration to those of us who had the pleasure of working with him. Our deepest sympathies to his wife Marnie, their children and grandchildren, and the extended family. Samuel S. Polk, Chairman Lorie A. Slutsky, President PILLSBURY--Donaldson C. The Nightingale - Bamford School records with sorrow the passing of our dear friend Don Pillsbury, trustee from 1979-1996. Don's invaluable counsel, wisdom, and kindness helped our school meet many challenges. We have lost a giant of a trustee and offer deepest condolences to his wife Marnie and their children Don, Jr., Blair 1988, and Wendy 1990. Nina J. Koprulu, President of the Board Dorothy A. Hutcheson, Head of School PILLSBURY--Donaldson C. The family and friends of Don Pillsbury mourn the loss of a beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, and friend. Don died suddenly after a terrific bike ride with good friends along the Connecticut shore in Old Lyme, Connecticut on Thursday, June 12th. He was 67. The cause of death was heart failure. Don was a chairman of Sotheby's North and South America and former worldwide general counsel and executive vice president of Sotheby's. Before that he was a senior partner (1967-1993) at the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell. In addition to his work at Davis Polk and Sotheby's, Don pursued a wide variety of personal business and non - profit interests. He served as chairman of The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in New York-a particular passion--and as a director of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. For 17 years, he was a trustee of the Nightingale Bamford School, also in New York City. More recently, he served as a trustee of Robert College in Istanbul, Turkey, the New York Community Trust, and the Stuart Family Foundation, a private foundation based outside of Chicago. We will remember everything about him. But especially for his utter integrity, his lovely humor, his passion for music, good wine, Cheetos. He loved the outdoors, biking, skiing, hiking, and sailing. We lovingly remember his incredible generosity and joy in simple things, the family, the garden, the silly cards, obscure gifts and collectibles--often acquired on E-Bay. His grandchildren were the light of his life. We will miss him dearly. He is survived by his wife Marnie, his children Donaldson Clark Pillsbury, Jr. and his wife Skye of San Francisco, CA, Blair Pillsbury Enders and her husband Jack of New York, NY, Wendy Pillsbury Eichmann, and her husband Chris of Greenwich, CT and his five grandchildren Tyler and Sam Eichmann, Nicholas and Marian Enders, and Clark Pillsbury. His siblings John S. Pillsbury III, L. Harrison Pillsbury, and Katharine Jose also survive him. A memorial service will be held on Monday, June 23 at 3pm at St. Thomas Church, One W. 53rd St., New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, Robert College in Istanbul, and the New York Community Trust. PILLSBURY--Donaldson C. The Board and staff of Rockefeller Philanthropy Advisors extend heartfelt condolences and sympathy to our Board member Marnie Pillsbury and her entire family on the death of her beloved husband Don Pillsbury. Don's commitment to his family, his colleagues, his community and his world leaves a legacy that will endure as a blessing for all who knew him. Kevin P. A. Broderick, Chairman of the Board Melissa A. Berman, President

9 P.M. (HBO) RESOLVED (2008) Until the 1960s high school debate was an art form, a combination of ideas and eloquence. Today debate has evolved into a sport in which students memorize their arguments, employ a specialized jargon and use ''the spread,'' a style of machine-gun delivery at up to 400 words a minute. This documentary from Greg Whiteley follows two socio-economically and stylistically contrasting teams in their quest for the championship at the University of California-Berkeley Invitational Tournament and as their members seek admission to elite universities. The documentary also seeks to illuminate the racial and class divide in American education. Past debaters, including Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. of the Supreme Court, the actor Josh Lucas, the journalists Jane Pauley and Juan Williams, and the political adviser Karl Rove, discuss the value of their oratory skills. 11 A.M. (ABC) THE VIEW Glenn Close discusses politics; Catherine Bell and Kim Delaney talk about their hit series, ''Army Wives''; and Cyndi Lauper performs.

A man. A woman. An empty room that soon will be filled with spilled secrets. And, oh yes, a convenient bottle of liquor to make the spilling easier. Architecture for plays doesn't get much more basic -- or hackneyed -- than this. But Philip Ridley's ''Vincent River,'' which opened Sunday night as part of the Brits Off Broadway festival at the 59E59 Theaters, makes it clear that a fully functioning, top-of-the-line haunted house can be erected from the dustiest blueprint, especially with two nigh-perfect performers like Deborah Findlay and Mark Field on hand to bring it into existence.

McNAMEE--John F., of Eastchester, NY died June 14. He was the son of Patrick and Jennie McNamee, born June 15, 1930. His beloved wife died on August 1, 2005. Surviving him are his devoted children, John F. of Omaha, Nebraska, Ann Marie, Jennifer E. McNamee, Megan M. and five grandchildren. Sisters Martha Gallati, Mary (Dolly) Murphy, Patricia Masio, and brothers Henry, Eugene and Desmond died earlier. Mr. McNamee worked thirty-eight years at The New York Times, retiring in 1994. His career began in their School and College Division in 1965 and later advanced through a number of managerial positions including National Circulation Manager and Director of Single Copy Sales. Friends may call at the Fred H. McGrath and Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY, between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm on June 19 and June 20. LOS ANGELES -- Nine bright gold banners are stretched in three neat rows high above the south end of Staples Center, a reminder of past glory and present goals. On Sunday night, that loose quilt of championship dreams looked like one big security blanket to the Los Angeles Lakers. The Boston Celtics came within inches of claiming the N.B.A. title on the Lakers' home court. But the Lakers leaned hard on their veterans as the evening grew late and pulled out a 103-98 victory that extended the finals for at least another two days and sent the series back to Boston.

Bloomberg remains as popular as ever, despite an overwhelming consensus that his administration should have done more to ensure the safety of construction sites and an overall sense that the city is headed down the wrong path, according to the latest New York Times poll. About 67 percent of city residents approve of the job Mr. Bloomberg is doing, while 28 percent disapprove, according to the poll. (About 5 percent had no opinion.) That matches Mr. Bloomberg’s highest mark in a Times poll, which was in October 2005, shortly before he defeated Fernando Ferrer to win re-election to a second term.

The Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, announced Tuesday that his office was prepared to drop all charges against 28 people who were arrested on May 7 in connection with protests against the acquittals of the officers charged in the shooting of Sean Bell. All 28 people had been charged with disorderly conduct because they had blocked traffic or refused orders to disperse. “Everybody arrested in connection with the demonstrations surrounding the Sean Bell trial will be offered A.C.D.’s (adjournment in contemplation of dismissal), which will result, after six months, in the full dismissal of the charges and sealing of the files,” Mr. Hynes’s office said in a statement.

In the last year, I have moved away a bit from my longtime enjoyment of red wine because of the morning-after effects, and started experimenting with other drinks, most notably whites. Along with this move has come a newfound affection for rosé, which is made not by mixing white and red grapes, as is sometimes thought, but by allowing relatively brief contact between skins and juice, just enough to impart a bit of color and body. The best rosés are much more akin to white than red (this includes the allergic reaction department), copper-colored (though there are a range of enjoyable colors) and, usually, more crisp than fruity. I like them bone dry.

The mortgage crisis claimed another chief executive over the weekend, as Martin J. Sullivan, pictured at left, was removed from his post at A.I.G., the loss-ridden insurance company. And if recent history is any guide, it doesn't bode well for A.I.G.'s share price.

19 Days to L'Étape. On the training schedule: An hour and a half ride in Central Park with four or five "hill spin-ups" on Harlem Hill. My coach describes a hill spin-up as riding on "a hill with a moderate grade (4-6%) in an easy gear and spinning at a high cadence (90+RPM) up the climb, staying in the saddle."I'm attending to last-minute chores and adapting my gearing -- from my old 12-27 Ultegra cassette to the 11-28 SRAM cassette that Gerard Vroomen, the maker of my bike, suggested I use for the Étape. In the continuing battle between Dan Brown and the Roman Catholic Church, this round goes to the church. Two years after Vatican officials urged a boycott of the film “The Da Vinci Code,” based on Mr. Brown’s blockbuster novel, the Rome diocese said Monday that two churches had been declared off limits to film crews for “Angels & Demons,” the “Da Vinci Code” prequel, The Associated Press reported. Msgr. Marco Fibbi, a spokesman for the diocese, said that the film “does not conform to our views” and “treats religious issues in a way that contrasts with common religious sentiment.” Permission to film inside Santa Maria del Popolo, above, and Santa Maria della Vittoria, both in central Rome, was denied in 2007, but the situation did not become crucial until now because production of the movie was delayed by the writers’ strike. “Angels & Demons” reunites the director of “The Da Vinci Code,” Ron Howard, and its star, Tom Hanks, with Mr. Hanks reprising his role as the Harvard symbologist Robert Langdon in a story that involves a papal conclave, the cult of the Illuminati and a high-tech threat to the Vatican. Mr. Brown, an executive producer of both films, published “Angels & Demons” three years before “The Da Vinci Code.” “This is a prequel to ‘The Da Vinci Code,’ and it’s clear that the theme is similar,” Monsignor Fibbi said. The ban will not stop crews from filming the exteriors of the churches.

Gather your Giselles while you may: American Ballet Theater announced Monday that Nina Ananiashvili would retire from the company after its 2009 summer season at the Metropolitan Opera House. Ms. Ananiashvili, right, who has been a principal dancer with the company since 1993, has appeared in “Swan Lake” and “Don Quixote” during its current season and is scheduled to dance in “Giselle” on July 7. Ms. Ananiashvili, who was born in Tbilisi, Georgia, was appointed artistic director of the State Ballet of Georgia in 2004, and in recent years she has led it on international tours, including a visit to the Brooklyn Academy of Music this spring. Her husband, Gregory Vashadze, said in an e-mail message to a Ballet Theater publicist that it had become more difficult for Ms. Ananiashvili to travel overseas with their young daughter for the several months required for her to appear with the American company. The theater’s statement said that she planned to continue performing with the State Ballet of Georgia and to make guest appearances with other companies.

Amy Winehouse was taken to a hospital in London on Monday after she “briefly fainted” and was kept from falling by an assistant, her publicist Tracey Miller said. “She quickly recovered and her father, Mitch, took her to hospital as a precaution,” Ms. Miller said. “Doctors are unsure of the cause of the incident, and Amy is currently undergoing tests.” Ms. Winehouse, the 24-year-old British singer, only recently began performing again after leaving drug rehabilitation.

Officials in Montgomery County, Pa. — home to the Barnes Foundation and its world-class painting collection — decided on Monday not to appeal a judge’s decision to deny new hearings to reconsider a 2004 ruling to move the collection from its home to downtown Philadelphia. Lawyers for the government of Montgomery County, where the Barnes has been since its founding in the late 1920s, appeared before the judge, Stanley R. Ott of the Montgomery County Orphans’ Court, in March to request that he reopen the case. Judge Ott’s 2004 ruling permitted the foundation, which has struggled financially, to bypass the charter and bylaws of its founder, Albert C. Barnes, who stipulated that no picture in his collection could be lent, sold or moved from the walls of the galleries that he built for it in Merion. The judge said at the time that he considered the move to a downtown location “the only viable alternative” to save the Barnes from bankruptcy. But opponents contend that the collection’s financial troubles have been overstated and that new ways to raise money to prevent a move have emerged. James R. Matthews, chairman of the Montgomery County Commissioners, said in a statement that he believed the county had “exhausted any real chance of overturning Judge Ott’s decision.”.

Vin Cipolla will succeed Kent L. Barwick as president of the Municipal Art Society of New York, Philip K. Howard, the society’s chairman, announced on Monday. Mr. Cipolla is currently the president and chief executive of the National Park Foundation and a former executive vice president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation. Mr. Cipolla will assume his position with the society in early 2009, society officials said. He previously served for nine years as chairman of the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston, overseeing the development of the organization’s new waterfront museum. The nonprofit Municipal Art Society strives to promote excellence in urban design and planning, contemporary architecture, historic preservation and public art in New York City. Mr. Barwick, who last year announced his intention to step down, will take a one-year sabbatical before returning to the society as president emeritus. He served as executive director from 1969 to 1975 and president from 1983 to 1995, and returned as president in 1999. He has also served as president of the New York State Historical Association, chairman of New York City’s Landmarks Preservation Commission and director of the New York State Council on the Arts.

One year after earning its smallest television audience on record, the broadcast of the Tony Awards appeared to fare no better in the ratings on Sunday. According to Nielsen’s overnight estimates, CBS’s presentation of the awards show from 8 to 11 p.m. attracted 6.2 million viewers, even with Nielsen’s preliminary estimates a year ago but just slightly more than last year’s final tally, issued a day later, of 5.7 million. CBS ended the night mired in third place. ABC easily finished first as its live coverage of Game 5 of the National Basketball Association championship series averaged well over 13.5 million viewers in preliminary estimates of the 9-to-11 time slots. NBC ranked second, leading early in the night with the conclusion of its all-day coverage of the final round of the U.S. Open golf championship, which averaged just under 14 million viewers from 7 to 9. A “Saturday Night Live” special honoring the work of Mike Myers drew 4.6 million viewers to NBC from 9 to 11. Fox, with a lineup of reruns, finished in fourth place in total viewers but third among adults 18 to 49, ahead of CBS.

TUTERA--Eric John, 1980-2008. Eric John Tutera, 28, a native and long-time resident of New Rochelle, NY, died in a tragic accident on June 8, 2008 in Hong Kong Harbor. Eric had recently moved to Hong Kong in his capacity as a vice president at JPMorgan Chase where he was involved in treasury and securities services. Eric was a loyal, generous and devoted son, brother, grandson, uncle and friend. He lived his shortened life to its fullest, playing and working hard with great passion. Known to those who loved him not only as Eric but as ''ET'', ''Tut'' and ''Rock'', he was a friend to all and touched many lives positively during his time in New Rochelle, Syracuse, New York City and Hong Kong. Eric's generosity and kindness with his family and friends extended to animals. His dog, Guinness, was his beloved companion in the U.S. and in Hong Kong. Eric was an active supporter of animal rescue groups. A member of the class of 1998 at New Rochelle High School, he competed on the Huguenots' varsity football team and the lacrosse team. A lover of the gridiron game, Eric was an avid fan of the New York football Giants. In 2002, he graduated with a BS in business administration from Syracuse University where he was a member of the Pi Kappa Alpha fraternity. Eric joined JPMorgan Chase in 2006 in Manhattan, where he resided for two years. Previously he had served for four years as a financial analyst with Nine West, Inc. in White Plains. Eric is survived by his parents, John and Marlene Tutera, both natives of Portchester and longtime residents of New Rochelle, his grandmother Marge Tutera of Holiday, Florida, his sisters Megan Tutera of Jackson, NJ, Kim Martelli of New Rochelle, and Rachel Tutera of New Rochelle, his brotherin-law Massimo Martelli and nephew Lorenzo Martelli, also of New Rochelle, NY. Visiting hours and a memorial mass will be held at The College of New Rochelle on Castle Place in New Rochelle: visiting hours on Friday, June 20 from 4pm to 7pm and the memorial mass on Saturday, June 21 at 10:30am. The family has requested that donations in celebration of Eric Tuteras life and memory be sent to the following organizations: The Wellness Center Fund, The College of New Rochelle, 29 Castle Place, New Rochelle, NY 10805; Songcatchers, 44 Liberty Avenue, New Rochelle, NY 10801; Pet Rescue, P.O. Box 393, Larchmont, NY 10538; or New Rochelle Fund for Educational Excellence, 265 Clove Road, New Rochelle, NY 10801.

He is survived by his wife, The Honorable Carmen Beauchamp Ciparick of the New York State Court of Appeals, his daughter, Roseanne Ciparick Almanzar of New York City, his sister and brother-inlaw, Louise and David Collins of London, and his son-in-law and step-grandson, Frankie and Jacob Almanzar. He was an extraordinary and loving soul and will be dearly missed. Visitation will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Thursday, June 19th from 25pm and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue at 84th Street, on Friday, June 20th at 10am.

He had recently co-authored ''Include Me Out,'' an autobiography of Farley Granger, his partner of 45 years. A report in the City Room column in some editions on May 16 about the comedian Mort Sahl referred incorrectly to his career as a writer. He contributed jokes used in some of John F. Kennedy's speeches, but did not write the speeches themselves. He wrote screenplays as well, but few if any were produced, so he is not the author of ''many successful'' screenplays. This correction was delayed for research.

The Obama campaign made its first big hire out of the campaign of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Monday. Patti Solis Doyle, below, who was Mrs. Clinton's campaign manager until she was ousted in a staff shake-up in February, will join Senator Barack Obama's campaign as the chief of staff to the vice-presidential candidate -- whoever he (or she) will be. Mr. Obama's campaign also announced the hiring of Stephanie Cutter, a longtime Democratic strategist who was Senator John Kerry's communications director in the 2004 presidential campaign. Ms. Cutter will work as chief of staff to Michelle Obama, a decision reflecting the campaign's expectation that Mrs. Obama will be a target of Republican attacks. Ms. Cutter will also lead a war room to fight attacks against Mrs. Obama.

Australia's track and field authorities announced they will not allow their team to march in the opening ceremony at the Beijing Olympics because of fears the city's smog may harm the athletes. Instead, the team will spend the first week of the Games in Hong Kong because track and field events do not begin until the second week, The Associated Press reported Monday. Australian authorities portrayed the decision as a logistical rather than a health issue, but nevertheless expressed their concerns about the smog.

It's not just battleground states on the itinerary for the presidential candidates. Senator Barack Obama said Monday that he also intended to visit Iraq and Afghanistan before the November election. One day after Senator John McCain met with Iraq's foreign minister, Hoshyar Zebari, Mr. Obama spoke to Mr. Zebari by telephone. Mr. Obama said he was ''encouraged'' by reductions in violence in Iraq, but added that the United States should withdraw troops at a pace of one to two brigades a month, with a goal of removing most combat troops in 16 months.

MAGGIN--Jane C., died at home on June 12th after a valiant six-year battle with cancer. Jane had a remarkably successful career as a leader in education, not-for-profit management, and business. Her charitable efforts were prodigious. She worked tirelessly and brilliantly for the Sacred Heart Schools, serving as Vice-Chairperson of the Convent of the Sacred Heart in New York City for 26 years, as a member of the board of the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Greenwich, Connecticut for 12 years, and as founding board chair of the Network of the 21 Sacred Heart Schools in the U.S. She also served organizations which helped battered women, supported the arts, and provided a variety of educational and other social services. She is survived by her daughter Alice Maggin and Alice's husband Wayne Nelson and their daughter, Lila Nelson, and four brothers and a sister and their families. She is also mourned by Donald Maggin, her ex-husband who remained close to her for decades until her passing. A memorial Mass will be held for Jane at the Convent of the Sacred Heart at 1 East 91st Street in Manhattan at 11am on Friday, June 20th. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, Massachusetts and to The Encore Community Center in Manhattan.

MEIGHAN--Hunter, passed away June 6 at age 94. Born May 8, 1914, Columbia College 1935, NYU Law School 1939. Partner until his death at the law firm of Meighan and Necarsulmer, founded by his father in 1897. Mr. Meighan served as a NY State Senator from 1960 to 1964; he was a Director of Knickerbocker Savings and Loan of NYC, and a trustee of United Hospital of Westchester for 17 years. A passionate sailor until his mid-80s, he leaves behind his wife, the former Miriam Gay, three children, Gay Corning, Lynn Laing, and Marcia Abbott, and seven grandchildren. Services will be held June 24th, 3pm at Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church.

SELBY--Henry M. The Boards of Overseers and Managers and the staff of Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center note with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague Henry M. Selby, who served here for more than 40 years (1951 to 1993) as a diagnostic radiologist. Dr. Selby's contribution to the hospital continues through the Henry M. Selby Young Investigators Lecture Series in Radiology, which was endowed by his family to provide a forum for young radiologists to present their research in cancer. We extend our sincere condolences to his son Norman, a member of MSKCC's Board of Managers, and to his entire family. Douglas A. Warner III, Chairman Harold Varmus, President Robert E. Wittes, Physician-in-Chief and the Boards of Overseers and Managers Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center SELBY--Dr. Henry M., M.D., F.A.C.R., died peacefully on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89 years old. Dr. Selby is survived by his wife Delia of 25 years. He was the proud father of three sons Norman, Bill and Russell, and grandfather of five, Luke, Thomas, Katie, Ali and Christina. He is also survived by his sister, Mildred York, and his first wife, Dr. Cecily Cannan Selby. Dr. Selby grew up in Brooklyn, and had a long, successful and important career as a diagnostic radiologist in New York City. He began as a resident at Memorial Hospital in 1951, and continued to practice at the Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center for more than 40 years. He was also Clinical Assistant Professor of Medicine at Cornell University Medical College, and Director of the Department of Radiology at the Medical Arts Center Hospital and the Strang Clinic, all in Manhattan. In addition, he founded and led the PMX Medical Group. Dr. Selby received his undergraduate and medical degrees from Louisiana State University. During World War II, Dr. Selby served as a Lieutenant in the Navy Medical Corps and was stationed in the United States and the Azores. Dr. and Mrs. Selby have endowed the Henry and Delia Merit Scholarship Fund at the LSU School of Medicine. The Henry M. Selby, M.D., Young Investigators Lecture Series in Radiology, which is a forum for young radiologists to present their research on cancer, was endowed in his honor by his family at Memorial Sloan-Kettering; his son Norman is a member of the Board of Managers there. Dr. Selby treasured his family, and had a life-long love of New York, New Orleans, good food, good wine and Monte Cristos. In lieu of flowers, Dr. Selby's family is asking that contributions be made to the Henry and Delia Merit Scholarship Fund at the Foundation for the LSU Health Sciences Center in New Orleans, Louisiana, 70112. Services will be private.

RUSSERT--Tim. The Board of Governors, Trustees, staff and young people of Boys & Girls Clubs of America wish to express our profound sorrow over the sudden passing of Tim Russert. As a longtime advocate for children, Tim cared deeply and gave back generously to children, especially those most in need. He served with distinction as a member of the board of directors of the Boys & Girls Clubs of Greater Washington, and was beloved by all. We were privileged to have counted Tim as a true friend and supporter, and a man of great character and compassion, and our nation will miss him greatly. Boys & Girls Clubs of America Rick Goings, Chairman Roxanne Spillett, President/CEO RUSSERT--Tim. PBS and its member stations mourn the death of Tim Russert. As an energetic analyst and superb political journalist, Mr. Russert kept all of his competitors on their toes--including those of us who work in public television. We celebrate his extraordinary career and commitment to preserving intelligence and probity in our national discourse. John E. Porter, Chairman of the Board Paula A. Kerger, President and Chief Executive Officer

SOLOMON--Rabbi Victor Martin, Ph.D., Col. (ret'd) USAF. Yeshiva University and its Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS) mourn the passing of a renaissance scholar, author, rabbi, psychologist and psychotherapist, who served as a pulpit rabbi in Philadelphia, PA, and Fairfield, CT, then as the highest ranking Jewish Chaplain in the USAF. He also was Chief of the Jewish Chaplains in the Far East, and associate director of the Jewish Welfare Board in NYC. His distinguished career was recognized by Yeshiva College several years ago. A graduate of YU's High School for Boys and Yeshiva College, he was ordained by RIETS and earned three doctorates from other universities. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his beloved wife, Marcia R. Solomon; to his children: Yeshiva College and Yeshiva University Museum Board member Rabbi Samuel (and Meryl, M.D.) Solomon, who are YU Guardians, Shimon (and Lisa) Solomon, Yitzie (and Yosepha) Solomon, and Avi (and Rebecca) Solomon; to his cherished sister, Rhoda Fefferman, and to his grandchildren. May the entire Solomon family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman, YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman, RIETS Board of Trustees

CHIAROMONTE--Miriam Rosenthal, 96, died at home in Rome, May 19. Wife of the late Nicola Chiaromonte, friend to many near and far, Miriam was part of several extraordinary circles of intellectuals and artists in New York and Europe among whom were such individuals as Dwight Macdonald, Meyer Schapiro, Albert Camus and Tino Nivola. Her friend, a writer, wrote of her: ''It was a joy to see you, positively uplifting... your semi-private or public self is a light house, and I am not the only dark or dubious cranny who responds to its rays.''

WITSELL--Daphne Towne, of Hobe Sound, FL, and Glen Cove, NY, died peacefully at home on June 10, 2008 in Hope Sound, after a five year fight with ovarian cancer. She was a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John D.C. Towne. Daphne was born in New York City on January 14, 1935. She was the loving wife for over 52 years of Frederick C. John Witsell, Jr., and the loving mother of Deborah Witsell Vivian, South Hamilton, MA, and Frederick C. Witsell, III, Pawling, NY. Proud grandmother of: Haley Dolan Witsell; Katharine Towne Witsell; Donald Witsell Vivian; and John Chaplin Vivian. She is survived by her twin sister Mrs. Diana Towne Knox, Greensboro, NC. Daphne was loved and respected by her many friends and admirers. She was a caring, private person; an excellent bridge player; loved to garden; was a good golfer; and enjoyed solving crossword puzzles and double acrostics, on a daily basis. She also was an avid reader. She served on the board of The Hobe Sound Nature Center. Daphne graduated from The New Canaan Country School, The Ethel Walker School in 1952, and attended Finch College. A memorial Service will be held on Thursday, June 26th, at 11am at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church, Lattingtown and Old Tappan Road, Locust Valley, NY 11560. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: Jupiter Medical Center Foundation, Inc., 1210 South Old Dixie Highway, Jupiter, FL 33458-7205 or Hospice Foundation c/o Treasure Coast Hospice 1201 S.E. Indian Street, Stuart, FL 34997.

PLAYER United States defender Christie Rampone, the team captain, was back in the starting lineup Sunday, one month after having her gall bladder removed, when the Americans beat Australia, 2-1, in Suwon, South Korea. The United States played Brazil early Tuesday in the Peace Queen Cup. CLUBS The makeup of the top divisions for next season in Spain and Italy were completed on Sunday. In Italy, Lecce gained promotion to Serie A with a playoff victory over Albinoleffe. In Spain, Málaga and Sporting Gijon were promoted to La Liga after victories on the final day of the second division season.

DEGENSTEIN--Lee. The Trustees and staff of the NYC Police Foundation note with sorrow the passing of our good friend and staunch supporter. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his sons and the entire Degenstein family. May the thoughts and prayers of all those who loved Lee comfort and strengthen you at this difficult time. Valerie Salembier, Chair Pamela D. Delaney, Pres.

ROAMAN--Martin. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University is deeply saddened by the passing of Martin Roaman, beloved husband of Carol Roaman, a longtime member of the National and New York Boards of our National Women's Division. We extend heartfelt sympathy to the entire Roaman family. Allen M. Spiegel, MD The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Bambi Felberbaum President, National Women's Division

POTTER--Irving. The Board of Directors of Progressive Credit Union extends condolences to Loan Officer Edward Potter on the death of his father, Irving Potter: four weeks after a gala celebration of his 95th birthday with family and friends. Beloved father (Barry and Jean, Edward and Reva) a grand and great-grandfather, uncle and friend. He lived his life with humor, good nature and warmth 'til the end. Robert A. Familant Treasurer/CEO

Updated, 6:12 p.m. | An auto salvage company in the Willets Point enclave near Shea Stadium has agreed to sell its property to the city, breaking ranks with other large business owners in the neighborhood that have been fighting plans to raze most of the buildings and replace them with $3 billion worth of development.

The Bush administration’s decision to impose caps on flights at the three major airports in the New York area, and its plans to auction landing slots at the three airports in a first-of-its-kind experiment to handle congestion, are the subject of intense debate at a House subcommittee hearing in Washington.Senator Charles E. Schumer, a New York Democrat who has been a persistent critic of the Department of Transportation and the Federal Aviation Administration, excoriated both agencies on Wednesday morning, saying the Bush administration had resorted to “ideological, market-based theory,” while doing little to fill vacancies among air-traffic controllers.

This week, Sewell Chan, bureau chief of City Room, is answering selected questions from readers about the blog, which began publication a year ago this week. Mr. Chan joined The Times in 2004 and previously covered transportation and City Hall for the Metro staff. Readers were invited to ask about any topic that City Room has covered — or ought to cover — as well as the blog’s practices, philosophy, design and policies. We are no longer taking questions for this feature.
In a new Lens series, the photographer Damon Winter of The Times uses double exposures to capture the endless juxtapositions in New York City. Read about how he creates these photographs.
What we’re looking at on the Web today …

Updated, 9 p.m. | Even as students, parents and teachers continue to protest school budget cuts, there is another debate brewing — just what makes a high-need school? The Campaign for Fiscal Equity, the advocacy group that successfully battled a 13-year lawsuit for billions of dollars more for New York City schools, released a report on Tuesday evening detailing how the city is spending roughly $230 million in new education money from the state.

Conceding the failure of the South Street Seaport pier as a “festival marketplace” — these days, it is not much more than a waterfront mall — its owners plan to replace it with a mixed-use project including a 42-story, 495-foot apartment and hotel tower, wrapped in a terra-cotta exoskeleton and rising from new pilings in the East River, David W. Dunlap of The Times reports.The seaport plan speaks to the undiminished allure of riverfront sites and of developers’ faith that megaprojects can inject new life into, and create profit out of, areas where other visions have failed.

By writing in detail on Tuesday about the tree loss in Central Park from last week’s storm, City Room did not mean to imply that the serious wind damage was in any way limited to that great expanse at the heart of Manhattan. (In fact, I watched a tree out of my own living-room window on West 62nd Street nearly blown over by a punishing and prolonged gust.)

Six new cases of an unusual form of salmonella linked to eating raw tomatoes have been confirmed in New York City, in addition to a previously known case, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene said on Wednesday. In addition, Suffolk County announced that a 26-year-old West Babylon man also contracted the strain of salmonella from eating tomatoes at New York City on May 27.

A significant figure in the review and approval process facing the proposal to redevelop Pier 17 at the South Street Seaport, Councilman Alan J. Gerson, said Wednesday morning that the plan is “certainly not going to pass in its present form.”“I’m not a soothsayer,” he added, “but I’m confident in that.”
So what is our city government’s stance on bottled water?

Waiters and other workers at Shelly’s Prime Steak, Cafe Fiorello, the Redeye Grill and other Manhattan restaurants have accused ownership, the Fireman Hospitality Group, of wage violations, and are hoping that a federal judge will approve a $3.9 million settlement on Wednesday. Two lawsuits against the Fireman Group assert that it systematically ignored federal and state wage and hour laws by often erasing hours that employees worked, not paying minimum wage, giving managers part of the tip pool and docking employees’ paychecks when their customers walked out without paying.

Updated, 6:14 p.m. | An armed robbery suspect running from police officers in Brooklyn on Wednesday afternoon touched off a tense few moments when he fled into an elementary school shortly before dismissal time, the authorities said. Officials evacuated some of the students and staff of the school after the 32-year-old gunman, who was not immediately identified by name, sought cover inside Public School 108, the Sal Abbracciamento Landmark School, at 200 Linwood Street, the authorities said.
by Kimberly Bradley

Two teams -- the Red Bulls (4-4-4, 16 points) and the Eastern Conference-leading New England Revolution (8-3-3, 27) -- heading in opposite directions were on the (plastic) field at Gillette Stadium in Foxborough, Mass., in another midweek game in Major League Soccer. They ended the match -- a 1-1 draw -- in virtually the same place they started.
The cover story of this month's Atlantic Magazine has a provocative piece by Nicholas Carr, called "Is Google Making Us Stupid?" Mr. Carr got my attention with this comment:

Cyd Charisse danced with the Ballet Russe as a teenager but became a movie star after dancing in MGM musicals.
Culver Griffin has been calling the steps at square dances since 1946, and says it's the secret to his longevity.
My Thursday column is about the siege of Gaza, which I argue was both wrong and counter-productive. Before you hit the comment button, however, I have one plea.

As some of you may have heard through the grape vine, the July issue of Italian Vogue will have only black models, and all the features are related to black women in the arts and entertainment. Considering the displays of tokenism on the runways last season-Jourdan Dunn at Prada, and in only one look-an entire issue devoted to black models could be seen as making hay of a controversy. I'll let you be the judge. The issue will be on newsstands in Europe next Thursday, and after in the States. Steven Meisel did the fashion pictures, about 100 in all, and I think they are some of the best he's done. They are crazily, softly beautiful, plainly the work of someone who knows women and fashion, has looked at both a long time, and when I spoke to Meisel the other day-for a piece in the Times tomorrow-I admitted I didn't recognize Tyra Banks in one of the portraits. She's wearing a soft head wrap, and her head is tilted back.
Even the Christian Broadcasting Network can't escape the back-and-forth of the presidential campaign.

Cricket's history dates back to the 16th century, but it was not until last Sunday that the sport had its first switch hitter. In a one day victory over New Zealand, Kevin Pietersen of England hit from both the left and right sides of the wicket. One of the charms of looking at cricket from this side of the Atlantic is the confusing nomenclature of the game and they don't let us down this time, referring to switch hitting as a "reverse slog-sweep".
An American discovers Buenos Aires after much turmoil, including her own.

Joshua Cohen, left, of Stanford University and Brink Lindsey of the Cato Institute look at the parallels between the Iraq and Vietnam wars.

A little more than a week after Tasers suffered a rare loss in a California court and then a strong endorsement in New York city, a government watchdog urged an overhaul to the weapon's use among The Royal Canadian Mounted Police.
Tomorrow is the start of the World Barista Championship, five days of caffeinated competition in Copenhagen, Denmark.

"Two Muslim women at Barack Obama's rally in Detroit on Monday were barred from sitting behind the podium by campaign volunteers seeking to prevent the women's head scarves from appearing in photographs or on television with the candidate," reports Ben Smith of the Politico. "The campaign has apologized to the women, both Obama supporters who said they felt betrayed by their treatment at the rally."

Hexion Specialty Chemicals and its owner, the buyout firm Apollo Management, sued the Huntsman Corporation on Wednesday to end their $10.6 billion merger, dragging yet another deal into a court battle.
Chief Financial Officers are no longer quite so sure the economy will get worse. But they are a long way from optimistic.

Far from the storied hollows of Appalachia, and well before the Rev. Jeremiah Wright lit up the cable news channels or the "elitist" label was fixed to Barack Obama's lapel right where his flag pin ought to have been, a group of older white voters drew a firm line on his candidacy. On Feb. 5, Mr. Obama prevailed by just 10,000 votes in Missouri, a general election swing state. His victory margin was cramped by the fact that he lost white voters over age 60 by nearly 40 percentage points, 67 percent to 28 percent. And it had nothing to do with bowling.
For the July issue of Italian Vogue, Steven Meisel, one of the most influential photographers in fashion, has photographed only black models.

BRIEFS Guess what's been turning up in a "place where you would [not] expect to find a bunch of severed feet"? In today's update, a fifth foot was found on the shore of islands to the south of Vancouver, Canada. By definition, the odd number left something missing in this grisly and mysterious trend. And sure enough, a sixth foot was found by the end of the day.
In today's Dining section Mark Bittman tells you how easy it is to make your own paletas, Mexican popsicles. My suggestion for enjoying them takes more effort.
Scenes from the New Chamber Ballet, choreographed by Miro Magloire.
Decades of declining market share have left the Detroit automakers with too many stores and too few customers to keep all of them open.

My appearance on the "Today" show this morning, making three cold soups, one savory, two sweet: avocado, watermelon-rosemary and rhubarb-orange. --MB

Auto racing's search for fresh talent has expanded in recent years to include women and minorities, as a sport long dominated by white men - at least in the United States - looks to broaden its demographic appeal.

One of the most shameful episodes of the post 9/11 era has been the way the U.S. Government -- particularly the Pentagon under Don Rumsfeld -- oversaw the torture and abuse of supposed terror suspects, even though there often was little or no serious evidence against them. We'll remember Guantanamo the way we remember the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II.

A new survey conducted by Civic Ventures and the MetLife Foundation shows that the idea of reinventing retirement is not just something that people talk about, but is something they are already doing.
Israelis sometimes complain, with some justification, of a double standard: When Israeli troops beat up Arabs, then the world cries foul, but when Arab troops kill Arabs, almost no one notices.

In a publicity stunt in Britain, Burger King's going for the Guinness record for world's most expensive burger. So for 95 pounds (roughly $186) you get flame-grilled wagyu beef topped with white truffles in an Iranian saffron and truffle bun. But some say it won't make their value menu:
Senator Barack Obama's presidential campaign has apologized for keeping Muslim women wearing headscarves out of a key shot at his Detroit event.

Conditions in American prisons are grim, and the inmates are rarely given the help they need to turn their lives around on release. In the correctional world, juvenile facilities are often among the bleakest facilities. And among juvenile facilities, Louisiana's Jetson Center for Youth stands out for its awfulness.

There's been so much written about the crisis in the newspaper industry that it's hard to imagine why anyone would want to read yet another article on it. But Mark Bowden's "Mr. Murdoch Goes to War," in the July/August issue of The Atlantic, has a couple of things in its favor: it's deeper than most takes on the subject - more analysis, less whine - and it provides a layered portrait of Rupert Murdoch.
Anheuser-Busch seems to be brewing up strong resistance to a potential takeover by a foreign suitor.

The two-hour debut of "America's Got Talent" lifted NBC in the ratings on Tuesday as 12.8 million viewers tuned in from 9 to 11 p.m. to watch the show's third season get under way, according to Nielsen's estimates.

The late-night host Jimmy Kimmel will remain at ABC through at least 2010. The network confirmed Wednesday that it had extended his contract by one year. The extension was first reported by DailyVariety.

Morgan Stanley's second-quarter earnings managed to beat Wall Street estimates by a couple of cents per share -- but investors weren't very happy Wednesday. The broker-dealer's stock was down as much as 4 percent in the afternoon, although the loss later narrowed to about 1 percent.

There's been plenty of heated talk lately about MBIA, the big bond insurer that has fallen on hard times. Much of the discussion is about whether or not the company has enough capital to cover its future losses.
Will the need to deal with a growing global oil crunch trump the need to curb greenhouse gases and limit long-term climate risks?.

In 2006, I interviewed dozens of experts on energy, climate, and the economy for a story in our ongoing Energy Challenge series, and more than a few warned then that, in the world of politics and policy, the need to deal with a growing global oil crunch could well trump the need to curb greenhouse gases and limit long-term climate risks.

BRIEFS An elegy of sorts for a crime that is experiencing a restoration in terms of quantity if not quality. These days, "the desperate, the dumb, and more often than not, the drug-addicted" are behind most bank robberies, not celebrity-criminals like Bonnie and Clyde, Mental Floss argues on its excellent blog. The post cites several examples of underwhelming felons of late, but they really need not look further than less-than-glamorous duo Thomas and Rose Marie Uva. The young married couple showed little fear in sticking up New York Mafiosi in the 1990's, but they also showed little savvy as well. Before they were found dead, they earned a nickname on the streets: Bonnie and Clyde. [Mental Floss]
What you eat during pregnancy and nursing may affect the age at which your daughter starts puberty, suggests a new animal study.
Via Tyler Cowen, I learn that there's a paper, regressions and all, evaluating how happy economists look. Yes, I'm in there -- and I cry foul.
My week of blog-based exploration of this subject ends today. It has been a fascinating ride. Thanks to all who have taken time to read and comment and argue.

The evening began like any other in Piazza San Lorenzo in Lucina, an elongated trapezoid of cobblestones in the center of Rome. Nannies and their charges lounged under the 12th-century portico of the piazza's namesake church. An elegant man in a crisp shirt steered his bicycle in lazy figure eights. Well-appointed women emerged from Louis Vuitton and Bottega Veneta to clack their high heels over to the three outdoor bars at the wide end of the piazza.

Israeli TV announcers have coined the American Secretary of State's nickname as a verb -- "to Condi" -- meaning to go endlessly around in circles, accomplishing nothing. She's made 22 largely futile trips to Israel during the Bush Administration's eight years. -- Time's Middle East blog.
Tauk boutique in Montauk, N.Y. (Kathleen Doran)

One line that was (rightly) edited out of this week's Minimalist column was this: "You could probably mix chicken stock and soy sauce, freeze it on a stick, and get a pretty interesting popsicle out of it." That was tongue-in-cheek, but only half so; the point is that savory popsicles can be quite refreshing, and one based on tamarind with very little or no sugar is quite popular in Mexico. I'm wondering what experiences the Bitten community has had with odd-flavored frozen ices, whether on a stick or not.
Tiger Woods will undergo reconstructive knee surgery, according to a statement on his Web site on Wednesday.

Charles O. Prince III just can't seem to escape the real-estate slowdown. The former chief executive of Citigroup, ousted last year amid the troubles emanating from the bursting of the mortgage bubble, is now finding it hard to flush out a buyer for his own home, Bloomberg News reports.
Location: Bloomington, Ind.

Economy | T. Boone Pickens thinks the era of fossil fuels is over. He's into water now, so much so that the oilman and corporate raider is being called the John D. Rockefeller of H2O. He owns more water than anyone else in the country and is looking to control even more. -- Business Week
What a stupid face you have.

A couple of weeks ago, I reviewed free cellphone information services like ChaCha. ChaCha lets you speak a question - and then, a minute later, the answer arrives on your cellphone as a text message, having been researched by a human operator.

I was served this dish at a restaurant in a fishing village in Mexico called Telchac Puerto, where the road ends at a lighthouse, a pier and the Gulf of Mexico. There were good ceviches, and corny, handmade tortillas. Then there was this: fish cooked in what seemed to be a quart of lime juice, with chilies, tomatoes and cilantro, all garnished with toasted garlic.

The Tigers' Marcus Thames has hit some impressive home runs in his career. As a Yankee, in his first major league at-bat in the summer of 2002, he drilled one off of Randy Johnson. And now he's making memories for Detroit.

On Sunday the Twins were trailing the Brewers by 3-2 with Brendan Harris leading off the eighth inning. After falling behind 0-2, Harris asked home plate umpire Brian Runge for time and seemed to think that he got it as he casually began to stride into the batter's box and slowly began to set his feet. Runge, however, had not given him time and Milwaukee reliever Guillermo Mota threw a quick breaking ball for strike three before Harris knew what happened.

In the debate over the future American military role in Iraq, the Bush administration has held firm on one point in particular: there will be no permanent American bases in Iraq. The head of Belgian brewer InBev, on Capitol Hill on Tuesday to promote his company's takeover of Anheuser-Busch to skeptical lawmakers, told reporters the $65 per share offer is the highest it would bid.
Dennis Weatherstone, who helped usher in a new era of banking during the early 1990s as chairman and chief executive at J.P. Morgan, died Friday near his home in Darien, Conn. He was 77.

The risks associated with the vast, unregulated market for credit default swaps played a crucial role in the bailout of Bear Stearns. JPMorgan Chase veteran David Shaheen has been appointed to succeed film-finance icon John Miller as head of the blue-chip firm's entertainment banking group, with Mr. Miller to segue into a consulting role in 2009, according to The Hollywood Reporter.
French drugmaker Sanofi-Aventis plans to make a 40.04 billion Czech crown ($2.57 billion) offer for Czech drugmaker Zentiva, trumping a bid from financial group PPF.
