Some readers of my recent ode to the Beijing taxi wondered why, in the name of efficiency and environmental responsibility, I don't just take the subway. I do, often, but here's one reason I don't enjoy it: To get from my home to just about any place of importance, I must change trains twice. One of those switches is tolerably annoying, but the other involves going outdoors, hiking up and down two escalators and 198 stairs, passing through endless dank and dreary corridors, and adding seven minutes of walking to a journey that can consume an hour. Whoever designed this system did not have convenience in mind.
Russia produced its best performance of Euro 2008 when it was most needed on Wednesday, beating Sweden to snatch second place in Group D.

An unidentified photographer who pressed charges against Britney Spears for running over his foot was found to be at fault himself and prosecutors will not pursue the case, according to The Associated Press. Joseph D. Shidler, a Los Angeles County deputy district attorney, wrote on Friday that based on police records and videotape of the incident last year, the “only way the victim’s foot could have been where the video indicates it to be was by the victim placing it in that location.”.
Senator John McCain said Wednesday that he wanted 45 new nuclear reactors to be built in the United States by 2030, a goal that he called “as difficult as it is necessary.”
After a rare display of enthusiasm to begin the Jerry Manuel era Tuesday, the Mets were sucked back into their season of meek and mediocre baseball.

The United States softball team returned Tuesday to Stevens Point, Wis., for the first time since the wife of its coach, Mike Candrea, collapsed in the airport nearly four years ago and died a few days later. Candrea’s wife of 28 years, Sue, died just days before they were to leave for the Athens Olympics.
Chad Billingsley took a shutout into the seventh inning Tuesday night, and the visiting Dodgers held on for a 3-1 victory over the Cincinnati Reds, ending a five-game losing streak.

Allisen Corpuz, 10, of Kapolei, Hawaii, shot a 15-over-par 88 in the second round of the United States Women’s Amateur Public Links Championship in Erin, Wis. Her two-day total of 169 was nine strokes over the 160 cut for the 64 golfers advancing to match play, but it was pretty good for a fifth-grader who is 5 feet and weighs 111 pounds.
Andy Pettitte won his 171st game as a Yankee Tuesday, moving him into fourth place on the team’s career victory list, as New York blitzed the Padres in the Bronx.
Gay men and lesbians in Norway will be granted the same rights as heterosexuals to marry and to adopt children under a law approved by the upper house of Parliament.
Another human foot has turned up off British Columbia, the police said.
A computer was stolen from the office of the British secretary of state for communities and local government, the second security breach involving a senior government official in a week.
The Austrian authorities have awarded $21.5 million to the families of people caught in a deadly fire in November 2000 at the Kaprun ski resort.
Mexico is adopting a United States-style legal system that will include public trials and a presumption of innocence for criminal defendants.
Cuban television showed the first images of Fidel Castro in six months, a silent video of him chatting in a garden with President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela.
Representatives of about 15 groups focused on the crisis in Darfur met with the United Nations Security Council, urging it to add muscle to its many statements condemning Sudan.
No evidence suggests that Syria has the skilled personnel or the fuel to operate a large-scale nuclear plant, the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency said.

An ethics panel is seeking to settle cases against aides to former Gov. Eliot Spitzer, a year after their alleged involvement in an effort to gather records of Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader.

The former Detroit Red Wings center Igor Larionov and the ex-Edmonton Oilers star Glenn Anderson have been elected to the Hall of Fame. The former linesman Ray Scapinello and the Ed Chynoweth, in the builder category, also made the Hall on Tuesday. The induction ceremony will be held Nov. 10. Larionov won two Olympic gold medals with the Soviet Union and was one of the first Soviet players to play in the N.H.L. He won three Stanley Cups with Detroit and had 644 points in 921 N.H.L. games.

Oakland Raiders receiver Javon Walker remained hospitalized with a concussion and a battered face Tuesday, one day after he was beaten, robbed and left unconscious on a Las Vegas street after a night of partying. The police said a large amount of cash and some jewelry were taken from Walker, 29, who sustained a moderate concussion and significant injuries to his face.

The Atlanta Falcons have released safety Jimmy Williams, two years after trading up 10 spots to pick him in the second round of the draft. Williams started only seven times in 27 games and reported to a voluntary minicamp nearly 20 pounds overweight.

Dino Toso is leaving Renault after five seasons as head of the Formula One team’s aerodynamic technology. Renault has won two F1 constructors’ championships and never finished lower than third since Toso took charge of the department in 2003. Renault won in 2005 and ’06 but has slipped to seventh in the 10-team standings, with only 9 points going into the eighth of 18 grand prix races this season. Dirk de Beer will replace Toso as head of Renault’s aerodynamics department.

Eleven Greek weight lifters have been suspended for two years after testing positive for the banned steroid methyltrienolone. The International Weightlifting Federation said that Greece would still be able to send a team of four weight lifters — three men and a woman — to the Beijing Olympics. Eleven of the team’s 14 lifters tested positive during an out-of-competition test in March in Athens. The athletes have not been named.

The former Detroit Red Wings center Igor Larionov and the ex-Edmonton Oilers star Glenn Anderson have been elected to the Hall of Fame. The former linesman Ray Scapinello and Ed Chynoweth, a longtime president of the Western Hockey League and a founder of the Canadian Hockey League, also made the Hall. The induction ceremony will be held Nov. 10.

Terrell Owens was not on the field for the start of the Dallas Cowboys’ mandatory off-season minicamp and he was not expected to be around the rest of the week. Coach Wade Phillips said Owens was excused from the three-day minicamp to attend to a family matter.
A daylong workshop conducted by the city’s health and emergency management agencies was intended to give businesses tips on how to cope with potential calamities.
Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, the country’s president, said she would ask the Argentine Congress to legitimize the export taxes that have prompted three months of revolt by farmers.
Chien-Ming Wang will miss at least 10 weeks after injuring his foot Sunday, and Dan Giese will take his turn in the rotation Saturday.
Hundreds of gay and lesbian couples in California wed on Tuesday, a steady and decidedly confident celebration that was a marked departure from a mad rush four years ago.
Questions about an athlete’s eligibility for the Paralympics prompted a dedicated effort from his mother.
In a new Lens series, photographer Damon Winter uses double exposures to capture the endless juxtapositions in New York City.
Back at Camden Yards for the first time since being traded to the Houston Astros, Miquel Tejada spoke excitedly Tuesday about seeing his former teammates.

Credit default swaps are taking center stage in another Wall Street drama: whether regulators will let MBIA, the big bond insurance company, renege on a promise to shore up a crucial unit with $900 million in capital.
A former journalist and Congressional aide is accused of working with the Iraqi intelligence services before the United States invasion.
The agreement would allow Japanese investment in Chinese companies that would drill in a contested part of the East China Sea, Japanese media said.
Decades of declining market share have left Detroit automakers with too many stores and too few customers.
The Related Companies announced that it was hiring Jay Cross, who is linked to the ill-fated proposal to build a West Side stadium for the Jets, to run its Hudson Yards development on the same site.
FRONT PAGE.
After reports that some lenders have stopped offering federal loans at community colleges, two senators introduced legislation to forbid lenders from picking and choosing among institutions.

A man convicted of a 1995 murder was put to death by lethal injection as Oklahoma became the sixth state to resume executions since the Supreme Court lifted a moratorium on capital punishment in April. The man, Terry Short, 47, was convicted in the death of Ken Yamamoto, a Japanese exchange student. According to court documents, Mr. Short fire-bombed the apartment of a former girlfriend. She escaped, but the flames spread to Mr. Yamamoto’s apartment and he died from his burns. Since April, executions have been carried out in Georgia, Mississippi, Virginia, South Carolina and Texas. Mr. Short was the seventh convict put to death in the United States in 2008.

A judge in Richmond approved an $11 million state settlement with families of most of the victims in last year’s Virginia Tech slayings that will avoid a court battle over whether anyone but the gunman was to blame. Families of 24 victims — out of 32 killed by Seung-Hui Cho — will be compensated under the settlement approved by Circuit Court Judge Theodore J. Markow. Four families agreed to the settlement, but were not prepared to go before the judge. Four other families did not participate: Two have filed notices of lawsuits, and two did not file claims. Under the settlement, seriously injured victims will have their health care needs covered for life. Representatives of each of those killed will receive $100,000. Money was also set aside for the injured, with individuals eligible to receive up to $100,000 apiece.

Senate Republicans blocked legislation that would have given an extra three months of jobless benefits to all unemployed Americans, but Congressional Democrats plan to bring the bill back by attaching it to an Iraq war financing measure. The majority leader, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, tried to bring the unemployment extension bill up for quick consideration, but was stymied by an objection from Senator Jon Kyl of Arizona, the Senate’s No. 2 Republican. It takes unanimous agreement to fast track a bill in the Senate.

Representative William J. Jefferson, a Democrat facing trial on corruption charges, has announced that he will seek re-election to a 10th term. Mr. Jefferson made his announcement in a news release that emphasized his experience and portrayed him as someone who still wielded power in Congress despite the case against him. The last time he ran for re-election was in 2006. The corruption accusations were a persistent problem for him then, but he overcame the odds and won in a landslide. He has since been indicted, and federal prosecutors have also indicted some of his family members on unrelated charges. Mr. Jefferson has pleaded not guilty to charges of soliciting more than $500,000 in bribes while using his office to broker business deals in Africa.
The Brooklyn district attorney announced that his office was prepared to drop all charges against 28 people arrested on May 7 in connection with protests after the Sean Bell verdict.
The Shoeless Joe Jackson Baseball Museum and Library, Jackson’s tells a story not of shame but instead of civic pride in a local hero who always said he had done nothing to rig the World Series.
Senator Arlen Specter, who has criticized the N.F.L.’s investigation of the New England Patriots, stressed that he did not necessarily consider the matter closed.
U.S. officials warned Chinese leaders not to let American failures in the subprime mortgage crisis become an excuse for not deregulating Chinese markets and opening them to foreign investment.
Friends and family mourned a makeup artist killed on Sunday when a suspicious fire engulfed her Jackson Heights home.
At a fund-raiser, Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton are set to appear together for the first time since the primary battle ended.
Ms. Charisse came of age in a sparkling era of Hollywood musicals, in which she achieved her lasting renown.
Anger in Pakistan over lethal American airstrikes on its soil threatens a joint effort to combat militants.

Criminal prosecutions of immigrants by federal authorities surged to a record high in March, as immigration cases accounted for the majority of all new federal criminal cases brought nationwide that month.
There have been many shortcoming to the process of accounting for the dead and missing in the earthquake that hit Sichuan Province on May 12.
Many New Yorkers who have experienced being fired are offering advice to fired Mets manager Willie Randolph.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut is defending himself against suggestions that he had received preferential treatment from Countrywide Financial Corporation.
Federal regulators said that they would place stricter limits on foreign exchanges that trade American oil as concerns continue to grow about the role of speculation in rising fuel prices.
Some clergy members in California spent Tuesday officiating at same-sex weddings made legal by a State Supreme Court ruling. Others spent the day speaking out against same-sex marriage.

It would be a sad census in any case, but the tally of trees lost in Central Park to high winds during the storm on June 10 comes with particular ill grace in the middle of the Million Trees NYC campaign.
Big brands have been borrowing for their marketing efforts characters from “Family Guy,” which has been criticized for everything from anti-Semitism and sexism to homophobia.
A military judge on Tuesday dismissed the case against the highest-ranking marine charged in the deaths of 24 civilians in Haditha, Iraq, in 2005.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell more than 100 points after a troubling reading on wholesale inflation underscored the drag of high energy prices on the economy.
The e-book may have its place, but for certain kinds of reading there is still nothing like a good old-fashioned hardback.
The French bank Société Générale and Rockefeller Financial Services of New York, which provides financial services for the wealthy, have formed an alliance in private banking.
The minutes of an October 2002 meeting give an extraordinary glimpse of the confusion among government lawyers about both the legal limits and the effectiveness of interrogation methods.
The lack of equipment for a strong Lebanese army is a testament to how shortsighted and contradictory the American approach to Lebanon has been.
A proposed bill that would expand President Bush’s powers to spy on Americans without a court order is a threat to the Bill of Rights.
If bananas reach $1 a pound, the strategy that allowed banana companies to turn an exotic, tropical fruit into an everyday favorite will begin to unravel.
If Gov. David A. Paterson adopts a less rigorous timetable for rebuilding ground zero, it could cause the whole project to take longer and cost more.
A former Mount Kisco police officer was acquitted of all charges in the death of an illegal immigrant from Guatemala.
Robert De Niro asked the city’s Landmarks Preservation Commission to approve a penthouse atop his hotel in TriBeCa that doesn’t match the design the commission approved.
One of Colombia’s most notorious warlords pleaded guilty to drug smuggling charges that could put him in a federal prison for the next three decades.
The American Red Cross and Johnson & Johnson announced that they had settled a longstanding dispute over use of the Red Cross trademark.
Scientists believe the distinctive calls made by female chimpanzees during sex take social factors into account.
The Tigers defeated Rice, 6-5, in an elimination game at the College World Series.
A judge dismissed a suit by a former New York Post gossip writer who accused Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Bill Clinton, The Daily News and others of conspiring to ruin his reputation.
To the Rev. Shannon Rust, a diesel-soaked lot alongside a truck stop in Pennsylvania is a parish ideal for preaching to the traveling masses about life’s ultimate arrival.
While marketers and advertisers have much to cheer in the coming digital revolution, the fastest growth will be in emerging markets, with the United States lagging behind.
Mr. Svensson was a Swedish pianist and leader of the jazz trio E.S.T., one of Europe’s most popular ensembles.
A new television commercial does a good job promoting a major policy difference between Senator John McCain and President Bush.
Mr. Weatherstone helped usher in a new era of banking during the early 1990s as chairman and chief executive at J. P. Morgan.
Commerce, Calif., a working-class industrial city, has developed one of the most prolific and sophisticated youth water polo programs in the United States.
Italy advanced to the quarterfinals of the European Championship on Tuesday with a 2-0 victory over short-handed France in Zurich.

Gov. Charlie Crist announced that 115,232 Florida felons had regained their voting rights since new rules took effect last April, but 80 percent of the state’s disenfranchised ex-offenders remain off the rolls.
A man in Jefferson County, Ala., has sued 12 banks, advisers and insurers, claiming their work on county bond transactions saddled residents with soaring sewer bills.
A handful of developers is transforming an erstwhile manufacturing area into a magnet for budget-minded travelers.
In the midst of Silicon Valley’s recession-proof enthusiasm for community-oriented Web sites, LinkedIn, the most boring of the social networks, is grabbing the spotlight.
Some real estate professionals are sensing a possible resurgence for the office market in New Jersey.
A study argues that the nation’s focus on helping students who are furthest behind may have yielded steady academic gains for low-achieving students in recent years at the expense of top students.
A federal appeals court overturned the conviction of a former Bush administration official caught up in a lobbying scandal.
After waging bitter battles with management at Chrysler and General Motors, the financier Kirk Kerkorian is off to a more peaceful start as a major shareholder in the Ford Motor Company.
The cleric who was known as Osama bin Laden’s spiritual leader in Europe was released under severe restrictions in Britain, after a court decision that blocked his deportation to Jordan.
Australian officials dismissed reports that their athletes would be barred from taking part in the opening ceremony of the Beijing games because of concerns about pollution.
The sense of political, social and economic malaise in Senegal, one of Africa’s most stable and admired countries, is unmistakable.
The revamped SAT, expanded three years ago to include a writing test, predicts college success no better than the old test, according to studies by the College Board, which owns the test.
A total of 11.4 million refugees were under the care of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in 2007, a rise that represented a worrying trend, the agency said.
Relief workers are offering a less pessimistic picture of the human cost of the delay in reaching cyclone survivors.

The second Make Music New York festival, the local counterpart of the worldwide Fête de la Musique, will present more than 800 free outdoor concerts on Saturday. Highlights include a classical, opera and jazz block party on 64th Street near Lincoln Center; a punk concert on Governors Island; and “The Music Man,” by the Village Light Opera Group in TriBeCa. A full schedule is at timeoutnewyork.com/makemusic. ... A ribbon-cutting was scheduled for Tuesday night by the Arts Horizons LeRoy Neiman Art Center, a community arts education center scheduled to open in Harlem next month at Frederick Douglass Boulevard and 148th Street, according to The Associated Press. Mr. Neiman, known for his colorful portraits of celebrities, donated $1 million to create the center.
Northwest said it would eliminate more planes from its fleet by the end of December, its second cut in capacity this year.

The future of the Sundance Channel is being defined this week after Cablevision closed a deal to acquire it. Rainbow Media Holdings, a subsidiary of Cablevision, said on Tuesday that it had completed the acquisition of Sundance from NBC Universal, CBS and Robert Redford for $496 million. On Wednesday, Rainbow executives are scheduled to meet Sundance employees in New York. Rainbow officials plan to announce a new structure for the channel that is meant to unify it with Rainbow’s other cable entities, including IFC, according to two people involved in the negotiations who spoke on condition of anonymity because the announcements had not been made. Sundance and IFC both showcase independent films, and some analysts have speculated that Cablevision may try to merge the two channels, although this week’s announcement is expected to keep the brands separate.

The cranberry harvest is a few months off, so for now it is film festival season on Cape Cod. The Provincetown International Film Festival opens on Wednesday night with the first American screening of Madonna’s directorial debut, “Filth and Wisdom.” The film, about three young people sharing a house in London, received mixed reviews after its premiere at the Berlin Film Festival in February. At the other end of the Massachusetts cape, the Nantucket Film Festival begins on Thursday and features “Elegy,” an adaptation of the Philip Roth story “The Dying Animal” directed by Isabel Coixet.
Neil LaBut’es “Reasons to Be Pretty” will begin previews on Feb. 13 at a Broadway theater to be named.

After losing support from the Swiss bank UBS last fall, the UBS Verbier Festival Orchestra has raised about $1.4 million to continue its operations. Half the money came from public funds and the rest from foundations and private individuals, the festival’s founder and director, Martin Engstrom, said on Tuesday. UBS, which had invested nearly $10 million a year in the orchestra, has transferred its support to a rival Swiss festival in Lucerne. The orchestra still needs to raise about $720,000 to support its orchestra and chamber music activities, Mr. Engstrom said. The Verbier orchestra, a training ensemble based at the Verbier Festival in Switzerland, was founded by the bank and the festival in 2000. After this summer it will stop using UBS in its name. It consists of musicians under 30 who are coached by principal players from the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra.

Reruns ruled the ratings once again on Monday, as Fox and CBS finished first and second for the night over all. According to Nielsen’s estimates, repeats of CBS’s “Two and a Half Men” and Fox’s “House” led the night, with the half-hour CBS sitcom drawing 8.9 million viewers at 9 p.m. and the Fox medical drama averaging 8.6 million viewers over the 9 p.m. hour. Fox edged past CBS for first place by winning the 8 p.m. time slot with a rerun of “Bones” (7 million). CBS led the 10 p.m. hour with a repeat of “CSI: Miami” (8 million). ABC and NBC finished in a virtual tie for third place over all. ABC earned decent ratings for “The Bachelorette” at 9 (6.9 million), but trailed with a “Bachelorette” special at 8 (5.9 million) and especially with “The Mole” at 10 (3.9 million). NBC broadcast “American Gladiators” at 8 (5.1 million), followed by “Nashville Star” from 9 to 10:30 (6.1 million), with a short edition of “Dateline” afterward (4.7 million).

George Carlin, below, the veteran comic whose history in Washington includes the Supreme Court’s consideration of his “Filthy Words” routine, will be the 11th person inducted into the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts’ pantheon of humor. The center announced on Tuesday that Mr. Carlin would receive this year’s Mark Twain Prize for American Humor, an award whose previous winners include Richard Pryor, Whoopi Goldberg, Lily Tomlin and Steve Martin. Mr. Carlin has recorded 18 albums of stand-up comedy and received four Grammy Awards. The award will be presented at the center on Nov. 10. Mr. Carlin thanked the prize’s namesake and instructed Mr. Twain to “have your people call my people.”.

New Yorkers may be blasé or hostile when it comes to film crews in their streets, but other places are willing to pay for the privilege. When Ethan and Joel Coen, coming off their best-picture Oscar for “No Country for Old Men,” were deciding between locations in Wisconsin and Minnesota for their next film, “A Serious Man,” Minnesota lawmakers came up with $500,000 to induce them to shoot in Minneapolis and St. Paul, The Associated Press reported. The Coen brothers — Ethan, above left, and Joel, right — are Minnesota natives.
In a year when album sales have fallen by another 11 percent, the new album by the rapper Lil Wayne looks to be a rare blockbuster hit.
Eager to embrace eggheads and ideas, the Pentagon has started an ambitious program to recruit social scientists and direct the nation’s brainpower to combating security threats.

Of the 19th-century classics that dominate today’s ballet repertory, “The Sleeping Beauty” is the most multilayered, the most abundant in telling detail, the most blessed with a score of miraculous eloquence.

Right away there are gripes to be had with “Black Gold,” a new reality series about oil-rig workers in West Texas that arrives at a moment when their employers are enriching themselves at the spigot of the boom.

As played by Michael Stuhlbarg, Hamlet is unavoidably watchable and on occasion quite entertaining, but never for an instant moving.

South Brooklyn Pizza sells only two menu items: pizza margherita and chocolate chip cookies. At Artisanal, cheese is only the gateway indulgence.

CIPARICK--Joseph Damian, 76, died June 14, 2008 in New York City. He had been a member of the Jesuit community for 22 years, six of which he served in Nigeria as a teacher of chemistry and physics. He continued his teaching career for over 40 years until his retirement from the New York City Public School System in 2000. He is survived by his wife, The Honorable Carmen Beauchamp Ciparick of the New York State Court of Appeals, his daughter, Roseanne Ciparick Almanzar of New York City, his sister and brother-inlaw, Louise and David Collins of London, and his son-in-law and step-grandson, Frankie and Jacob Almanzar. He was an extraordinary and loving soul and will be dearly missed. Visitation will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Thursday, June 19th from 25pm and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue at 84th Street, on Friday, June 20th at 10am.

MILLER--Helen B., passed away on June 14, 2008, at age 90. Beloved mother of Josh, Amy and Gabe; grandmother of Jarrell; sister of James; sister-in-law of Jackie; and aunt of David, Ellen, Emily, Debbie and Brian. She was a longtime creative force in advertising and Lynn Redgrave and Marcel Marceau were among those she worked with. But it was her remarkable capacity for love, her wry sense of humor and her ability to bring a smile to others, sometimes amidst great difficulty, that mark her legacy. ''Grace'' and ''elegant'' were the words most often used to describe her. The family wishes to thank her impossible-to-overestimate and devoted health-care aide, Petronia Atkins, and the Mary Manning Walsh assisted living home.

Kelly's impact on Maxwell-Kates and on our lives will remain with us forever.

An analysis by The New York Times shows that following a new policy last fall establishing a uniform threshold for admission to public school gifted programs, children from the city’s poorest districts were offered a smaller percentage than last year of the entry-grade gifted slots in elementary schools. Children in the city’s wealthiest districts captured a greater share of the slots. The disparity is so stark that some gifted programs opened by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in an effort to increase opportunities in poor and predominantly minority districts will not fill new classes next year. In three districts, there were too few qualifiers to fill a single class.

Pinot noir used to be the proverbial bridge wine. If a couple were at a restaurant and one ordered a delicate dish that called for a white wine and the other ordered more robust fare, a good pinot noir could always bridge that gap, going well with both dishes. I no longer find that to be the case as too many American pinot noirs are simply too big, not so much in alcohol but in body and sweetness.

17 Days to L'Étape. On the training schedule: A second travel day, which started with me being woken up from a deep sleep by a painful cramp in my calf. Since that's about the fifth time I've been woken over the last few weeks by cramps in my legs or feet, I'm starting to think I'm doing something wrong. This cramp was bad enough that more than a day later the calf still feels strained in the same spot. An editor at work suggested that I need to eat more bananas, for the potassium. Anyone else experience this problem and have a different solution?While I'm sorting myself out in a hotel outside Chamonix, France -- I'm about to meet the group I'll be joining for four days of climbing around Mont Blanc in preparation for the Étape -- I recommend everyone check out Le Grimpeur, a fine blog written by Guy Wilson-Roberts "on everything climbing." The post that drew me in was The Original Grimpeurs, which tells the story of how the Tour first came to the mountains, and is illustrated with some great archival photos. Many of the other posts are similarly well illustrated and worth a look. And the author also mentions his own training for his attempt to climb Mont Ventoux this year.

“Most cyclists think that you have to train on hills to be competitive in road races, which typically feature multiple vertiginous, lung-busting climbs. Not Christian Vande Velde, who’s expected to be selected next month for the United States road racing team for the Summer Olympics in Beijing,” Gretchen Reynolds writes in The Times today. Vande Velde and his coaches have developed innovative training techniques, nutritional plans and strategies, and they share with readers with a few clues for riding faster, longer and smarter.

As the cost of gas sinks fishing plans for some power-boaters, paddlers win the spoils: more fishing hot spots unreachable by motorboat and foot. And don’t think the good news extends just to canoers. Kayak fishing — during which one casts, reels and chills from the sea-level cockpit — is on the rise. Joe Cambria, the editor of Kayak Fisherman magazine, says that 1 of every 10 kayaks bought in 1998 was used for fishing; today, half of all purchased kayaks see some angling action. "Kayaks allow you to get to spots you can’t reach by boat or even by foot, and it’s like fishing from a lounge chair," says Cambria. Compared to canoes, kayaks are faster, lighter and less prone to wind effects, and Cambria says that many new kayak designs add stability, reducing the chances of tipping. (Unless you catch the really big one.).

The collective memories that make up Paul Pierce’s Beantown apotheosis are now well documented: The wheelchair exit and the jubilant return. The velcro defense on Kobe Bryant. The dumping of red Gatorade on his bewildered coach. But I choose to recall another moment, when Pierce dunked the ball in Game 5 and the slo-mo replays showed the flab on his arms and shoulder undulating like bread pudding.

It’s one of the enduring institutions in our country, and I think we take some comfort in that.” All due respect to Bob, but the only thing that hasn’t changed about baseball over the last 50 years is the wistful, mythical musings of baby boomers.

As expected, Lil Wayne easily topped the Billboard album chart this week, selling just over one million copies of his new CD, “Tha Carter III” (Cash Money/Universal), according to Nielsen SoundScan. It was the first time an album sold more than a million copies in one week since 50 Cent’s “Massacre” three years ago. (Kanye West came close: His “Graduation” moved 957,000 in its first week last September.) “Definition of Real” (Slip-N-Slide), the new album by the Florida rapper Plies, had a respectable debut, reaching No. 2 with 215,000 in sales. Three more albums opened further down the Top 10: N.E.R.D.’s “Seeing Sounds” (Star Trak/Interscope) was No. 7 with 80,000 in sales; Alanis Morissette’s “Flavours of Entanglement” (Warner Brothers) was No. 8 with 70,000; and My Morning Jacket moved 49,000 copies of “Evil Urges” (ATO) to reach No. 9. Last week’s best seller, Disturbed’s “Indestructible” (Reprise), dropped to No. 4 with 102,000.

The cost of superimposing a nuclear mushroom cloud on a television weather report in the Czech Republic: 50,000 koruna, or about $3,210. That was the fine meted out on Wednesday to each of three artists who hacked into a broadcast of Czech Television’s CT2 channel for 39 seconds last June, Agence France-Presse reported. Seven members of the Ztohoven art collective were acquitted of charges of scaremongering in March, a decision that prosecutors have appealed. The artists have said they were trying to draw attention to the network’s failure to carry out its public broadcasting mission.

Damien Hirst’s latest creation — a bull submerged in formaldehyde, with a head crowned by a solid-gold disc, and hooves and horns cast in 18-karat gold — is expected to fetch $16 million to $24 million when it is sold at a Sotheby’s auction in London on Sept. 15. “The Golden Calf,” above, with the artist, will be part of a two-day auction of works made by Mr. Hirst in the last two years, Sotheby’s announced on Thursday. In addition to the bull, the auctions on Sept. 15 and 16 will include some of his new paintings, drawings and sculptures. This is the second time Sotheby’s has held an all-Hirst auction. In 2004 it sold the contents of the Pharmacy, his defunct Notting Hill restaurant, which included Hirst-designed ashtrays and bar stools, as well as his paintings, for $20 million. Last summer Mr. Hirst’s human skull cast in platinum and covered with 8,601 diamonds was said to have been sold to an investment group for $100 million.

“America’s Got Talent” lifted NBC on Tuesday, as 12.8 million viewers tuned in from 9 to 11 p.m. for that talent show’s third-season premiere, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The show drew 13 million for its 2007 premiere, but faced new competition this time. The final game of the National Basketball Association’s championship series led the night’s ratings with estimates indicating that it earned an audience somewhere between Game 4 on Thursday (13.8 million) and Game 5 on Sunday (17.4 million). At 9 p.m. Fox’s “Hell’s Kitchen” drew a modest 8.2 million total viewers, but was runner-up to basketball for the night’s highest ratings among adults 18 to 49. For the night, Fox tied NBC for second place in that demographic. CBS finished fourth over all with a three-hour special, “AFI’s 10 Top 10” (5.5 million).

New York was the center of the Copernican universe on Tuesday when a first edition of his “De Revolutionibus Orbium Coelestium” (“On the Revolutions of the Celestial Spheres”) sold at auction to a commercial buyer in Britain for more than $2.2 million, nearly double Christie’s high estimate of $1.2 million. The 1543 edition, in which Copernicus put forth his theory that the Earth rotates around the Sun, was among 300 books from the collection of Richard Green, a retired physician and amateur astronomer, which fetched just more than $11 million, a Christie’s spokeswoman said. An 1878 directory for the world’s first commercial telephone system, published in New Haven, sold for $170,500 to a private buyer in the United States.

IUSI--Frederick, 78, of Katonah, died June 17. Survived by wife Mary, six children, five grandchildren. Fordham graduate. Owner, Raymond Appraisals. Past President, American Society of Appraisers. Wake Thursday, CassidyFlynn, Mt. Kisco. Funeral Mass 10am Friday, St. Mary's, Katonah.

The cultivation of coca -- the basis for cocaine -- grew by 27 percent in Colombia last year, the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime reported Wednesday. It called the increase ''a shock'' given eradication efforts financed by the United States. Coca crops also increased slightly in Bolivia and Peru, the report said, but the region's cocaine output remained stable, about 1,000 tons. A vendor, left, packed coca leaves in La Paz, Bolivia, on Wednesday.

Supporters of Senator John McCain have been accusing Senator Barack Obama of having a pre-Sept. 11 mind-set in his approach to national security. On Wednesday, Mr. Obama fired back by linking Mr. McCain and President Bush and calling them weak on terrorism. ''Their approach has failed,'' Mr. Obama said after the first meeting of his newly formed national security working group, according to a pool report. ''Because of their policies, we are less safe, less respected and less able to lead the world. It's time to turn the page.''

REMER--Victor. The Board of Trustees and the staff of The Children's Aid Society mourn the loss of our beloved and esteemed Victor Remer, who served Children's Aid for 20 years as its Executive Director. We express our sympathy to his wife Alma, daughters Sari and Alice and their family. Mr. Remer improved the lives of countless thousands of poor children and families throughout his lifetime of devotion to them. Mr. Remer was a leader in the field and an exemplar of caring and commitment to the poor. For the last 20 years, Mr. Remer devoted himself to preserving and cataloging the case records of 129,000 orphan train riders who were placed in families across the country. This collection, now known as the Victor Remer Memorial Collection, is being archived and is located at the New-York Historical Society. Mr. Remer will be deeply missed by all of us who knew and loved him. Angela Diaz, M.D., M.P.H., President C. Warren Moses, CEO Philip Coltoff, Special Advisor REMER--Victor, on June 17th, 2008 at 88 years old. Beloved husband of Alma, devoted father of Sari and Alice (Brian), cherished grandfather of Grifyn. Retired Executive Director and current Archivist for the Children's Aid Society. Also has room dedicated to him at New York Historical Society. Graveside service will be held today at Mount Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, NY at 1pm. Guttermans Inc. 718-284-1500.

RUSSERT--Tim. The New York State Bar Association mourns the passing of Tim Russert, who was first and foremost a journalist but also a lawyer who did not forget his roots. A Buffalo native and law school graduate, Mr. Russert elevated public discourse in America through his passion for government, the law and the public good. He inspired others and set a standard for excellence that all of us --whether lawyers, politicians or journalists can hold as a model. Our thoughts and prayers go out to his family during this difficult time. He will be missed.

ROBBINS--Herman, M.D., Chairman of the Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases from 1972-1981. His Chairmanship spanned a transforming period in the hospital's history, from that of a general medical center to the mission of a specialty orthopaedic care and research institute. He was one of the pioneers who contributed to the development of pediatrics as an orthopaedic subspecialty. Dr. Robbins was one of the first American orthopaedic surgeons to observe the pioneering technique of low-friction arthroplasty of Sir John Charnley and returned to perform the surgery in the United States. He received his medical degree from the Universite de Lausanne in Switzerland in 1941. Following an internship and surgical training, he entered the Armed Services in WWll, serving as battalion surgeon in Europe, receiving a Purple Heart and the Bronze Star for Heroism. Dr. Robbins served as Editor of the Bulletin of the Hospital for Joint Diseases from 1979-1991, one of the oldest orthopaedic journals in the United States. In 2005, he received the Frauenthal Medal for contributions to the Hospital. He will be remembered with admiration and respect by his patients, colleagues and by the many residents he mentored. Joseph D. Zuckerman, M.D. Chairman NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases Dept. of Orthopaedic Surgery ROBBINS--Herman, M.D., October 16th, 1913-June 15th, 2008. Orthepedic Surgeon and Chairman Emeritus of The Hospital for Joint Diseases (1972-1981) died peacefully at his home in Great Neck, NY, surrounded by his children Karen Robbins and Dr. Philip Robbins. He was passionate about medicine and his family, which included his beloved wife Sylvia, to whom he was married for 64 years, his grandchildren Michael, 18, and Lauren, 16, and daughterin-law Esther. Dr. Robbins attended Anderson Medical College, Scottland and University De Lausanne, Switzerland, graduating in 1941. During World War II he served as captain and battalion surgeon in the European theater, recieving a Purple Heart and Bronze Star for heroism. His distinguished medical career of service, education, and leadership spanned over 65 years. He was devoted to his patients, and to the many young residents he mentored. Tennis, sailing, and his beloved New York Yankees added to his enjoyment in life. He will be missed for his kind heart and warm sense of humor. Services will be held on Friday, June 20th at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY 516-487-9600. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to support the NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases Herman Robbins Medical Library 301 East 17th St., NY, NY 10003 Attn: Francine Mele

With the threat of high water and dangerous E. coli levels having subsided, the final Olympic triathlon qualifying event for the United States team will take place Sunday, albeit at an unfamiliar location. Last week, flooding near downtown Des Moines shifted the Hy-Vee Triathlon, a World Cup race, to a site in suburban West Des Moines, Iowa, but organizers still feared that the water at Blue Heron Lake would be too dangerous to conduct the swim portion of the race. With the full race back in place, the Olympic veterans Hunter Kemper and Andy Potts -- tied in qualifying points -- will engage in a head-to-head contest that will probably determine the third men's slot for Beijing. Jarrod Shoemaker, Matt Reed, Laura Bennett and Julie Swail Ertel have already qualified.

''Eat your heart out, Madonna,'' writes Ben Brantley, who says the pop diva's got nothing on the enduring performance artist/drag queen Joey Arias. ''Arias With a Twist,'' his latest, is a collaboration with the puppeteer Basil Twist, who ''whipped up a vast enchanted troupe of effigies -- from a marionette supper-club combo to a life-size chorus line of plump, plumed dancers -- to back up Mr. Arias's song stylings,'' Mr. Brantley writes. Watch as Mr. Arias, who can sound like Billie Holiday, skips through an Edenic rain forest, eats magic mushrooms, dances with devils, stalks Manhattan as a 50-foot woman, and -- of course -- inhabits a Busby Berkeley number. It's like Vegas crossed with Wigstock, right at Here. ''A Drag Show, Run by a Puppet Master, Set in a Wonderland,'' by Ben Brantley

Data provided by the authority shows that between November 2006 and November 2007, Mr. Mack recorded 585 transactions on his free E-ZPass tags (Mr. Mack was issued six of them).

This week, Sewell Chan, bureau chief of City Room, is answering selected questions from readers about the blog, which began publication a year ago this week. Mr. Chan joined The Times in 2004 and previously covered transportation and City Hall for the Metro staff. Readers are invited to ask about any topic that City Room has covered — or ought to cover — as well as the blog’s practices, philosophy, design and policies. This is the fourth and final set of answers.

The uproar over the noisy comings and goings of sightseeing helicopters along the West Side of Manhattan has finally led to a plan to eliminate them. Air Pegasus, the operator of the heliport at the west end of 30th Street, has agreed to start phasing out tourist flights next year. The number of those flights would be capped at 25,000 for the year by May 31, 2009, then cut to 12,500 over the following 10 months, then halted completely, according to a draft of the agreement made in State Supreme Court.

The first year, it is safe to say, has not passed without its share of problems at the Khalil Gibran International Academy in Brooklyn. The school has gone through multiple principals and lawsuits and even an equal employment opportunity complaint, not to mention a change in location, since opening its doors as the city’s only Arabic-themed school last September. Even the lone science teacher was recently ousted.The biggest problem surrounding the school has no doubt been the removal of its founding principal, Debbie Almontaser, who resigned in August under enormous pressure, much of it from a chorus of critics who said she had a militant Islamic agenda.

Campaigns generate headlines with the tough decisions they make. On Thursday, Barack Obama's campaign made waves with an easy one. My biggest concern about an Obama administration is that, in the end, he won't make universal health care a priority. My second biggest concern is that "Unity" means never having to say you're sorry: that in the name of putting past partisanship behind us, the next administration will sweep the abuses of the past 8 years under the rug, the same way Bill Clinton did in 1993; the result of that decision was that the very same people responsible for Iran-Contra showed up subverting our democracy all over again.

The Associated Press has punted on its commitment to clarify how much text it thinks bloggers and social news sites can reprint from its articles without violating The AP's copyright. Indeed, the giant news organization appears to be insisting that bloggers cannot quote the headline of an A.P. story or its first paragraph. While the law is not settled, many lawyers suggest that such short excerpts are permitted under the "fair use" exception to the copyright laws.

Anthropology | A Cornell researcher suggests that male circumcision and other forms of genital mutilation may originally have been meant to prevent younger men from fathering children with older men's wives. Mutilation reduces fertility, so it's a price you pay to play with the wives of men you cuckold. Ouch. -- Economist

LinkedIn, a Web site that professionals use to make contacts and trade tips, created quite a stir this week. It announced that it raised $53 million in funding, primarily from Bain Capital Ventures, implicitly valuing the four-year-old company at an impressive $1 billion. It was only the latest evidence that social networks for the more-serious set -- think Facebook, as opposed to a more youth-oriented MySpace -- have come into vogue with investors.

BRIEFS Martha Stewart may have moved on to greener pastures since prison, but they weren't in Britain. A spokeswoman revealed today that her visa application had been rejected, and promptly commenced a public campaign. "Martha loves England," she told The Telegraph, "and hopes this can be resolved and that she will be able to visit soon." The border agency refused to comment on the case while tellingly reiterating its opposition to anyone "found guilty of serious criminal offenses abroad." That standard has been applied to many celebrities, The Times of London added, including Snoop Dogg, whose fight to return to Britain continues. In the absence of an official explanation, one theory seemed inevitable: payback for Amy Winehouse?

Kirk Kerkorian is a savvy -- and wealthy -- investor, but lately he has shown an uncanny habit of buying Ford Motor shares just before they take a dive. The stock fell sharply in the weeks after his investment vehicle, Tracinda, made a tender offer for the shares in May. And on Friday, one day after he revealed increasing his stake even more, the stock took another tumble.

Sport | Homer and Virgil were fight fans. The boxer Gene Tunney hung out with George Bernard Shaw, Sherwood Anderson and Thornton Wilder. T.S. Eliot took boxing lessons and Ezra Pound sparred. In a new history, a British academic examines why the intelligentsia has been drawn to pugilism over the ages. -- Economist, London Telegraph

Moody's yesterday became the last of the rating agencies to downgrade MBIA, but it went the other agencies one better: MBIA falls to A, not AA like Ambac. The rating of its insurance subsidiary plunged to a low investment grade.

The French Grand Prix was never supposed to return to Magny-Cours. Somehow it did. Now, plans for the race to return to other parts of France - Paris, Versailles, Rouen, Disneyland - abound. So does a plan that Magny-Cours is offering to update its facilities to tempt Formula One back. While several venues, like Silverstone and Donington Park, are talking about renovations that could cost tens of millions of dollars, Magny-Cours' latest plans also looks fairly costly, with an updating of the pit building, grandstands being fitting with awnings, etc.

As the damage toll rises with the floods in the Midwest, the question is: what happened to the assurances after the Great Flood of 1993 that action would be taken to prevent the next flood from being so devastating. Why were new subdivisions built on floodplains? Why did the levees fail? Why is it so hard to blame plain old bad weather?

The average American mother has 2.1 children. The United States is no Hong Kong, where the average mother has 1, but it's not prolific Somalia, either, where 6.6 is average. Here we just keep procreation moving along.

Education | Four-day school weeks are not a new idea. But will fuel prices bring Mondays off into vogue? Already a sprawling rural parish in Louisiana is introducing them in the fall, in part because the savings in bus fuel alone would likely be $92,000. But there are day-care concerns and other downsides. -- New Star (Monroe, La.). Background: Christian Science Monitor

Watermelon and tomato are two fruits that complement each another in an unusual way. When you cut up and combine them, their distinctions become a little blurry and each masquerades as the other. CLUBBED THUMB SUMMERWORKS 2008 If you thought the playwright Rachel Sheinkin came out of nowhere three years ago with her book for ''The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee,'' or if ''The Thugs'' was the first Adam Bock play you ever saw, you are most likely not familiar with Clubbed Thumb. This small company, which has been producing the work of relatively unknown playwrights for years, presented scripts by both these writers before they had more mainstream successes, and it has produced early works by a number of others who later went on to more well-trafficked places like Playwrights Horizons and Manhattan Theater Club. In order to say someday that you knew the early work of Sally Oswald or Sigrid Gilmer, get to the 13th annual Clubbed Thumb Summerworks festival, continuing through June 28. This weekend will feature the final performances of ''Vendetta Chrome,'' by Ms. Oswald (with Jenny Seastone Stern, above left, and Lisa Rafaela Clair), and the opening of the last show in the series, Ms. Gilmer's ''Slavey.'' (The first production in the short three-show season, ''Gentleman Caller,'' by Ann Marie Healy, closed on June 14.)

This house, built in 1973, has about 8,000 feet of living space and about 100 feet of shore frontage on West Lake Okoboji. The house, like all homes in the area, is priced in accordance with the lake it is on and the amount of shore frontage it has, rather than by the structure itself. Many of the houses in the area are purchased, demolished and replaced with luxury custom homes. This three-level house has a wall of windows overlooking the water. There is a deck on each of the two upper levels and there is a patio at ground level. There is a 100-foot dock and an eight-car attached garage with guest quarters above. On the lower level is a family room with a wet bar. The kitchen has been updated. The house has five bathrooms, a steam bath and hot tub and three fireplaces. It is on one of the best beaches in the Okoboji area. Taxes: $15,540. Broker: Kirk Stauss, Stauss-Terrus Realty, (712) 332-2470; www.okabojihomes.com.

Like many people outside the United States, Canadians have taken an unusually keen interest in this year's presidential election. A memorandum was leaked suggesting that Senator Barack Obama's campaign had privately assured Canadian diplomats not to regard his call to renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement too seriously, for example, and became the subject of intense political debate in Parliament in March. So there is considerable anticipation in Canada's capital as the presidential campaign prepares to move briefly onto foreign soil on Friday. A speech by Senator John McCain at a faux-chateau-style hotel that is an Ottawa landmark is believed to be the first appearance of an American presidential candidate in Canada in an election year.

PERKINS--George W., Jr. died peacefully at his home in Park City, Utah on June 12, 2008. He was born in 1925 at Wave Hill, his grandparent's house in Riverdale, New York. The son of George W. Perkins, the first U.S. Ambassador to N.A.T.O, and Linn Merck Perkins, George grew up in New York City. He graduated from The Hill School early in 1942 so that he could join in the war effort. Because of an eye injury at age 11 he could not enter military service, but instead joined the American Field Service and drove ambulances in Burma throughout the war. He returned afterwards to graduate from the University of Maine in 1949 with a B.S. in Agriculture. In 1950 he married Nancy Foster, whom he met during college, and moved to Millbrook, New York where he raised a grand champion herd of Black Angus cattle until 1979. He was an avid traveler, exploring every continent, and was especially interested in Africa. His travel was curtailed during the last 20 years of his life as his health began to fail, but he never lost his good humor, optimism and love of life. In addition to his wife of 58 years, he is survived by his daughter Jennifer Perkins Speers (and husband Randy), his sisters Penelope P. Wilson and Anne P. Cabot, seven nieces and one nephew. He was predeceased by his son George III. The burial will be held on June 28th at 12:00 noon at Nine Partners Cemetery, Millbrook, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Millbrook Fire Department and/or Rescue Squad. Services by Allen Funeral Home, Millbrook, NY.

FAMILY PUPPET FESTIVAL The Yeshiva University Museum is ordinarily a Jewish institution. But for one afternoon -- this Sunday -- it will be a Chinese, Greek and Czechoslovakian one too. Those cultures will all be represented in the museum's second annual Family Puppet Festival, an international celebration for ages 5 to 12. ''We'll have Chinese hand puppets, Greek shadow puppets and Czech marionettes,'' said Gabriel Goldstein, an associate director for exhibitions and programs at the museum. ''We were eager to show different kinds of puppetry and different regional traditions.''

SAM KIM: 'SELF SURGERY' In recent years all sorts of hole-in-the-wall theaters, casual salons and roving series have popped up outside Manhattan, creating a sprawling, lively performance network. It's a youthful scene, but it's not without some elders, including the Brooklyn Arts Exchange in Park Slope. For 17 years this performing arts center has been quietly providing theater and dance classes, family programs, artist services and performance and rehearsal space; in January the center expanded, taking on an additional floor of space, and has significantly ramped up its offerings in what the organization calls the BAX Building. This weekend the dancer-choreographer Sam Kim, a 2007-8 Brooklyn Arts Exchange artist in residence, will present a work in progress, ''Self Surgery,'' performed with Ryan McNamara, above, with Ms. Kim, and the Other Girls. Ms. Kim is a smart, analytical artist, creating works that challenge personal and cultural assumptions.

LAURIE SIMMONS: 'IN AND AROUND THE HOUSE' Along with Cindy Sherman, Sherrie Levine and Richard Prince, Laurie Simmons is counted as a core member of the Pictures Generation, whose appropriations, manipulations and simulations of various photographic genres profoundly altered the course of late-20th-century art. In the mid-1970s, however, Ms. Simmons was a young art school graduate in New York hoping to support herself as a freelance commercial photographer. Aiming to get a job illustrating a toy company catalog, she photographed dollhouse furniture. She didn't get the assignment, but she found a vision whose resonant possibilities can be seen in this enchanting exhibition of black-and-white images dating mostly from 1976 and '77.

ROBBINS--Herman, M.D., October 16th, 1913-June 15th, 2008 died peacefully at his home in Great Neck, NY, surrounded by his children Karen and Philip. He was an Orthopedic Surgeon, Chairman of The Hospital for Joint Diseases (1972-1981), and Chairman of the Board of Physician's Reciprocal Insurance (1991-2008). He was passionate about medicine and his family, which included his cherished wife Sylvia, to whom he was married for 64 years, his late daughter Judith, his grandchildren Michael and Lauren, and his daughter-in-law Esther. Dr. Robbins attended Anderson Medical College, Scotland and University De Lausanne, Switzerland, graduating in 1941. During World War II he served as captain and battalion surgeon in the European theater, receiving a Purple Heart and Bronze Star for heroism. His distinguished medical career of service, education, and leadership spanned over 65 years. He was devoted to his patients, and to the many young residents he mentored. Tennis, sailing, and his beloved Yankees added to his enjoyment in life. He will be missed for his kind heart, warm sense of humor and sage counsel. Services will be held on Friday, June 20th, 1pm at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY 516-487-9600. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made payable to the NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases Herman Robbins Medical Library Fund, NYUHJD, 301 East 17th St., NY, NY 10003 Attn: Francine Mele ROBBINS--Herman M.D. Orthopaedic Surgeon of world renown. Distinguished teacher, mentor and friend. Sincere and heartfelt condolences to his family. May the Omnipresent console you among the other mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Oskar Weg, M.D. Clinical Assistant Professor of Orthopaedic Surgery NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases

'LETTER TO ANNA' On Oct. 7, 2006, Vladimir Putin's birthday, Anna Politkovskaya was shot and killed in her apartment building in Moscow. A crusading journalist, Ms. Politkovskaya (above) was a dogged critic of Mr. Putin and a tireless reporter of Russian human rights abuses in the Chechen war, which she considered a genocide. ''I understand your question: How come I am still alive?'' she says early in Eric Bergkraut's ''Letter to Anna,'' one of the closing-night movies of the Human Rights Watch International Film Festival at the Walter Reade Theater. ''When I really think about it, it's a miracle.'' Mr. Bergkraut had several hours of footage of Ms. Politkovskaya, filmed in 2003 and 2004 for a documentary about Chechnya, and when she died, he made ''Letter to Anna'': partly a tribute, partly an investigation of her death and partly a consideration and continuation of her work. Her presence gives the film its eerie intensity. Here is the soft-spoken, almost recessive Ms. Politkovskaya talking, wandering, laughing. Here are her eyes, watching, recording, calmly peering through glasses at the world's horrors.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's biggest organized labor supporter, the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, announced on Thursday that its executive board had unanimously voted to endorse Senator Barack Obama for president. The announcement was not unexpected. It means that the union's 1.4 million members and vast political resources will be at Mr. Obama's disposal, Gerald McEntee, the union's president, said in a telephone news conference.

'SUPERHEROES: FASHION AND FANTASY' LECTURE AND PANEL ''Shakespeare is not writing any new plays, but he's taught in classes everywhere. Comics may stop publishing tomorrow, but people can still study comics.'' So says Peter Coogan, the author of ''Superhero: The Secret Origin of a Genre.'' He founded the Institute for Comics Studies to foster a better understanding of the form and to recognize its cultural significance. On Sunday Mr. Coogan will get a chance to do just that at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He, along with Andrew Bolton, curator of the current exhibition ''Superheroes: Fashion and Fantasy,'' will present a daylong series of lectures and panels about comic books. The discussions will revolve around topics from adapting superhero costumes for big-screen films to the use of superheroes as metaphors in modern society. Participants include Paul Levitz, president and publisher of DC Comics; Michael E. Uslan, a film producer whose credits include ''The Dark Knight,'' due in theaters next month; and Alex Ross, a painter, who received critical acclaim for his work on the comic books ''Kingdom Come,'' about a possible dark future for Superman (above) and his DC allies, and ''Marvels,'' which traced the early years of the Avengers and other Marvel heroes.

BRAVERMAN--Dorothy Block, 78, died at home in Montvale, NJ, on June 18th from lung cancer. Born in Brooklyn, she enjoyed many successful years as a clinical psychologist, having received her B.A. from Brooklyn College in 1950 and her Ph.D. from Columbia University in 1958, and running support groups for many years for the ''After Breast Cancer'' organization. She is survived by her husband, Dr. Julius Braverman, her daughters Jill and Nancy, her son Eric, and her grandchildren Rachel, Gabby, and Sam. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Funeral service will be held at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park Avenue, Hackensack, NJ on Friday, June 20th at 1:30pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to: Lung Cancer Alliance, 888 16th St NW, Suite 800, Washington, DC 20006. lungcanceralliance.org

A two-hour installment of the reality series ''So You Think You Can Dance'' led Fox to victory in the ratings on Wednesday as 8.8 million viewers tuned in from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. NBC and CBS shared runner-up status for the night in total viewers, with NBC faring better among adults 18 to 49 thanks to a 90-minute ''Deal or No Deal'' at 8 (8.2 million) followed by ''Celebrity Circus'' from 9:30 to 11 (5.7 million). CBS finished fourth in that demographic, just slightly behind ABC. Both ABC and CBS broadcast lineups of repeats.

FOR CHILDREN 'ADVENTURES WITH DORA AND DIEGO' (Friday through Sunday, and Tuesday through Thursday) The young Latino stars of the Nickelodeon animated television series ''Dora the Explorer'' and ''Go, Diego, Go'' have taken their expeditions into new territory at the Children's Museum of Manhattan. The museum has replaced a ''Dora the Explorer'' exhibition, up for four years, with this show, which has separate Dora and Diego environments, including Diego's Animal Rescue Center and Dora's Fiesta. Intended for ages 2 to 6, the bilingual displays are designed to teach language, science and music skills. From 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., the Tisch Building, 212 West 83rd Street, (212) 721-1223, cmom.org. Free with museum admission: $9; $6 for 65+; free for under 1 and members.

PILLSBURY--Donaldson C. The family and friends of Don Pillsbury mourn the loss of a beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, and friend. Don died suddenly after a terrific bike ride with good friends along the Connecticut shore in Old Lyme, Connecticut on Thursday, June 12th. He was 67. The cause of death was heart failure. He is survived by his wife Marnie, his children Donaldson Clark Pillsbury, Jr. and his wife Skye of San Francisco, CA, Blair Pillsbury Enders and her husband Jack of New York, NY, Wendy Pillsbury Eichmann, and her husband Chris of Greenwich, CT and his five grandchildren Tyler and Sam Eichmann, Nicholas and Marian Enders, and Clark Pillsbury. His siblings John S. Pillsbury III, L. Harrison Pillsbury, and Katharine Jose also survive him. A memorial service will be held on Monday, June 23 at 3pm at St. Thomas Church, One West 53rd Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to: Robert College of Istanbul, 520 8th Ave., North Tower, 20th Floor, New York, NY, 10018; The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, 70 Lincoln Center Plaza, #

BRODWELL--Claude, 55, of Bayside, NY, passed away on June 17th, 2008. As Board President of the Jamaica Center Business Improvement District, his wonderful sense of humor and energetic leadership will be greatly missed. Claude's dedication and commitment to the Center and the Jamaica community was always evident. He is survived by his beloved wife, Katie, his children Adrianne and Eric, his parents, Anne and Bernard and his brother Allan. Shiva will be held at 2361 Woodhull St., The Bronx. Donations in memory of Claude may be made to the American Cancer Society or The Diabetes Action Research Fund. Jamaica Center Improvement Association

My Sunday column is about the West Bank occupation, told largely through Hebron. Now it is clear why the farmer wants a wife: to help fill sandbags. Matt Neustadt, above, the Missouri farmer who is nearing the end of his televised search for a potential mate on the CW reality show “Farmer Wants a Wife,” found himself with bigger priorities this week when a levee near his family’s farm gave way, opening up some 700 of its 2,000 acres to flooding. Mr. Neustadt, of Portage Des Sioux, about 25 miles north of St. Louis, is just one of thousands along the Mississippi and other rivers who are suffering from flooding. The Neustadt family land, near Alton, has flooded at least a half-dozen times in the last 35 years, Mr. Neustadt said in a telephone interview. Even before the levee broke on Thursday, the land had been soaked by seeping groundwater. “We were able to plant about 500 acres of corn,” Mr. Neustadt said. “We might have 300 left.” The flooding, which had Mr. Neustadt shoveling sand into bags for much of Wednesday and Thursday, has left him little time to think about television. The series, which was taped last summer, is scheduled to conclude on Wednesday, when Mr. Neustadt, 30, chooses between Christa, 22, and Brooke, 23. The women have feuded since the opening episode, when Brooke interrupted Christa’s date with Matt by wrapping his truck in toilet paper. The series has respectable ratings, with an average of 2.2 million viewers tuning in each Wednesday at 9 p.m. Eastern time.

On a low-rated Thursday of almost-summer television, Fox came away as the most-watched network, thanks to its game show “Are You Smarter Than a Fifth Grader?” (7.8 million viewers, winning the 8 p.m. time slot, according to Nielsen’s estimates) followed by a results edition of “So You Think You Can Dance” (8.8 million, winning the 9 p.m. slot). CBS finished second for the night, broadcasting comedy repeats during the 8 o’clock hour, a “CSI” rerun at 9 and “Swingtown” at 10, which managed to win its time slot despite an audience of just 6.1 million viewers. Also at 10, NBC’s “Fear Itself” drew only 4.7 million viewers, as did NBC’s 90-minute episode of “Last Comic Standing,” from 8:30 to 10. NBC finished in third place over all. ABC was fourth with a rerun of “Ugly Betty” at 8 (3.1 million) followed by a two-hour “Grey’s Anatomy” repeat from 9 to 11 (3.2 million).

Timothy O’Leary will succeed Charles MacKay as the Opera Theater of Saint Louis’s general director on Oct. 1, when Mr. MacKay becomes the general director of the Santa Fe Opera. Mr. O’Leary, the theater’s executive director since January, most recently directed operations and planning at New York City Opera. He has also served as managing director of the Gotham Chamber Opera in New York and has been a stage director and assistant director for companies including Glimmerglass, New York City Opera and Florida Grand Opera.

Stephenie Meyer, below, the author of the best-selling young-adult “Twilight Saga,” will appear in a four-city tour to promote the fourth and final novel in that vampire love series, “Breaking Dawn.” Little, Brown, hoping to capitalize on the author’s fans — there are 7.7 million “Twilight Saga” books in print in the United States — said she would headline “an evening of story and song.” The Breaking Dawn Concert Series begins on Aug. 1, the eve of the book’s release, at the Nokia Theater in Times Square and makes stops in Chicago on Aug. 5, Los Angeles on Aug. 7 and Seattle on Aug. 12. Tickets cost $20 and will go on sale this Saturday at 10 a.m.; details are available on stepheniemeyer.com and thetwilightsaga.com.

A new TKTS discount tickets booth is opening on July 10 in Brooklyn. The booth, operated by the Theater Development Fund, will be in the MetroTech Center in downtown Brooklyn at the corner of Jay Street and Myrtle Avenue. For the most part, it will operate like the two other TKTS booths in Times Square and at the South Street Seaport, except that it will also sell tickets to Brooklyn arts events, like productions at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The renovated TKTS booth in Times Square is scheduled to open later this summer.

The Smithsonian Institution is restructuring its merchandising unit, its acting chief executive told staff members on Friday in an internal memo. The acting secretary, Cristián Samper, said that effective on July 1, Smithsonian Business Ventures would be renamed Smithsonian Enterprises and would report directly to the Smithsonian’s secretary and Board of Regents, not to the Business Ventures board, which is being disbanded. The move is partly a response to an audit released five months ago that found that the Smithsonian’s revenue-generating arm, established in 1999, was poorly managed and lacked oversight. “What they are trying to do here is make sure the business operations are more closely aligned with the Smithsonian’s mission,” a Smithsonian spokeswoman said. The business unit has been the focus of criticism since 2006, when it signed a contract giving Showtime Networks exclusive access to the Smithsonian archives for documentary purposes.

Mr. Conlon will be the 12th recipient of the prize, which is awarded each year to an artist who has made a significant contribution to music, art and peace. Past winners include Zubin Mehta, Riccardo Muti and Daniel Barenboim.

TOPCHIK--Gary S., on June 19th, after a courageous battle following complications from lymphoma. Creative and inspiring consultant, leading authority and bestselling author on workplace relations. Funeral services on Sunday, June 22nd at 2:00pm, Plaza Community Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, P.O. Box 4072, Pittsfield, MA 01202.

JORQUERA--Mary, a writer, magazine editor and advertising executive died Tuesday evening at her home in Greenwich, CT. A graduate of Framingham (MA) State Teachers' College, she served as Editor in Chief of WEEI Food Fair Magazine and broadcast regularly on WEEI radio. She also wrote for The Boston Globe and The Atlantic Monthly Magazine. In 1955 she married Humberto Jorquera of Santiago, Chile, where she was an account executive with J. Walter Thompson. In more recent years she volunteered her talents as a publicist and writer in the service of community organizations in Greenwich and elsewhere, including the Schlesinger Library for the History of Women at Harvard University. Mrs. Jorquera is survived by her husband, her sister, Helen Brown of Nahant, MA, her daughters, Christine Vickery of New York, NY and Sarah Jorquera of Bedford, NY, and five grandchildren. A funeral mass will be celebrated at St. Mary's Church, Greenwich on Monday, June 23 at 10am. Calling hours will be held at Fred D. Knapp & Son, Greenwich on Sunday, June 22 from 2-5pm.

PERKINS--George W., Jr. died peacefully at his home in Park City, Utah on June 12, 2008. He was born in 1925 at Wave Hill, his grandparent's house in Riverdale, New York. The son of George W. Perkins, the first U.S. Ambassador to N.A.T.O, and Linn Merck Perkins, George grew up in New York City. He graduated from The Hill School early in 1942 so that he could join in the war effort. Because of an eye injury at age 11 he could not enter military service, but instead joined the American Field Service and drove ambulances in Burma throughout the war. He returned afterwards to graduate from the University of Maine in 1949 with a B.S. in Agriculture. In 1950 he married Nancy Foster, whom he met during college, and moved to Millbrook, New York where he raised a grand champion herd of Black Angus cattle until 1979. He was an avid traveler, exploring every continent, and was especially interested in Africa. His travel was curtailed during the last 20 years of his life as his health began to fail, but he never lost his good humor, optimism and love of life. In addition to his wife of 58 years, he is survived by his daughter Jennifer Perkins Speers (and husband Randy), his sisters Penelope P. Wilson and Anne P. Cabot, seven nieces and one nephew. He was predeceased by his son George III. The burial will be held on June 28th at 12:00 noon at Nine Partners Cemetery, Millbrook, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Millbrook Fire Department and/or Rescue Squad. Services by Allen Funeral Home, Millbrook, NY.

Suzann Pettersen shot a five-under 67 in the Wegmans L.P.G.A. in Rochester to open a three-stroke lead over Morgan Pressel, Eun-Hee Ji and Inbee Park. The 28-year-old Pettersen, a five-time tour winner in 2007, is still looking for her first victory this season. Her bogey-free round Saturday got her to 14-under 202.

Asafa Powell of Jamaica, the former record-holder in the 100 meters, ran an impressive 9.96 seconds in Trinidad on his return to competition from a shoulder injury sustained while lifting weights. The race, into a slight headwind with persistent drizzle, was Powell’s first since February. Since then, his countryman Usain Bolt has set the record, with a 9.72 on Randalls Island on May 31.

Roberts, who had three-putted from 30 feet for a double bogey on No. 9, birdied the 18th to move to 10 under par, one stroke ahead of Mark McNulty (70), Jeff Sluman (67) and the first-round leader, Tom Kite (72).

METRO.

Queen Elizabeth II celebrated her first Royal Ascot victory since 1999 when her horse Free Agent won the Chesham Stakes on Saturday. Richard Hughes rode the 7-2 co-favorite from last to a two-and-a-quarter-length victory in Ascot, England.

The Chicago Cubs announced Saturday that Carlos Zambrano has been placed on the 15-day disabled list with a shoulder strain, a move retroactive to June 19. Zambrano, a right-hander, is 8-3 with a 3.13 earned run average in 16 starts this season. Tests show he has a minor strain in his right shoulder. He is expected him to miss two starts.

Boston Red Sox reliever Mike Timlin was placed on the 15-day disabled list because of tendinitis in his left knee. The move allowed Boston to activate the right-hander Daisuke Matsuzaka for Saturday’s game against the St. Louis Cardinals. Timlin, placed on the disabled list retroactive to June 17, is 3-3 with a 7.06 E.R.A. in 24 relief appearances this season.

The Cincinnati Reds placed infielder Jolbert Cabrera on the 15-day disabled list Saturday. Cabrera sustained a compound dislocation of his left index finger sliding into second base in Cincinnati’s 4-2 win over the Yankees on Friday night. He became the fourth Reds shortstop on the disabled list.
Martin Kaymer of Germany closed in on a Ryder Cup berth when he shot a 67 for a six-stroke lead heading into the final day of the BMW International Open in Munich.

The Ottawa Senators signed center Chris Kelly to a four-year, $8.5 million deal. Kelly was eligible to become an unrestricted free agent when his current one-year contract with Ottawa, worth $1.263 million, expired July 1. Kelly has 36 goals and 62 assists in 243 regular-season games.

An article on June 8, about two couples who wrote books about trying to have sex every night, misstated a statistic in the study entitled American Sexual Behavior, by the National Opinion Research Center at the University of Chicago. It found that the frequency of sexual intercourse among married couples 18 to 29 years old was about 109 times a year — not 84 times, which refers to the frequency among all 18- to 29-year-olds.
