Kauff of New York. Justice Harry Lee Anstead of the Florida Supreme Court officiated at the Retreat at Bradley’s Pond, an event space.

Sara Connolly, the daughter of Sally W. Connolly and William F. Connolly Jr. of Milton, Mass., was married on Saturday evening to Matthew DelRosso, a son of Denise A. DelRosso and Robert T. DelRosso of Port Jefferson Station, N.Y. The Rev. Laura Gwen, a minister of the Unity Center of Light, officiated at Rosecliff, a mansion in Newport, R.I.

Juliet Eilperin and Andrew Ronald Light Jr. were married on Saturday in Washington. Stephen F. Eilperin, the bride’s father, a senior judge of the Superior Court of the District of Columbia, officiated at the Swedish Embassy.

Juliana Curran Terian and Bruce Gilbert were married on Saturday in Del Mar, Calif., at the home of the bridegroom’s father, Ross S. Gilbert, and his stepmother, Mary K. Gilbert. Judge Charles G. Rogers of California Superior Court in San Diego officiated.

Katharine Meghan Shaughnessy, the daughter of Judith and Bernard Shaughnessy of Garden City, N.Y., was married on Saturday to Eric Donnelly Southard, the son of Christina and Melville Southard Jr. of Manhasset, N.Y. The Rev. James W. Adelmann, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at Garden City Community Church.

Caroline Anne Morris, the daughter of Mary C. Morris and Thomas V. Morris Jr. of Oradell, N.J., was married in New York on Saturday to Jeffrey Charles Miller, a son of Patricia Miller and James A. Miller of Emerson, N.J. The Rev. Carleton P. Jones, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, where he is pastor.

Alexi Elysia Curlee, a daughter of Pamela A. Curlee of Denver and Dr. Paul G. Curlee of Durango, Colo., was married yesterday evening to Henry Christopher Cashen III, a son of Leslie Cashen Clevenger and Henry C. Cashen II of Washington. The Rev. Declan Jarry, a priest of the Old Catholic Church of America, officiated at the Beaumont Hotel in Ouray, Colo.

Abigail Suzanne Freireich, a daughter of Nancy Freireich and Paul Freireich of New York, is to be married Sunday to Mark Everett Weinsier, the son of Laurie Sherer Weinsier of Marietta, Ga., and Steven Weinsier of Plantation, Fla. Rabbi Jessica Zimmerman will officiate at the Harmonie Club in New York.

Courtland Wallace Wood, the daughter of Cynthia McNair Wood and Stephen W. Wood of West Simsbury, Conn., was married on Saturday to Second Lt. Donald Francis Colantonio III, a son of Paige S. Colantonio and Mr. Colantonio Jr. of Simsbury. The Rev. Joseph L. Pace, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. John’s Church in West Hartford, Conn.
Irena Budimova and Peter Kazumi Shiba were married yesterday evening at the Paauilo Kongoji Mission in Paauilo, Hawaii. Koga Miyazaki, a Buddhist priest, performed the ceremony.

Benee Lisa Frenzel, the daughter of Adria L. Frenzel and Bruce A. Frenzel of St. Albans, Mo., was married on Saturday to Michael Meade, a son of Barbara M. Meade and George J. Meade of Oakland, N.J. The Rev. John J. Cryan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at Congress Hall, a hotel in Cape May, N.J. Rabbi Charles Davidson participated in the ceremony.

A review on June 1 about “American Nerd,” by Benjamin Nugent, misstated the source to which the book traces the word “nerd.” It was a 1950 work of Dr. Seuss, “If I Ran the Zoo,” not mid-1960s issues of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute’s student humor magazine. (The magazine may have been the first to use the word fully in its current sense, the book suggests; in Seuss, it is a nonsense name for a fanciful animal.).

NEIDITCH--Muriel, of Delray Beach, FL and Dumont, NJ, died peacefully at the age of 88 at the Miami Jewish Home and Hospital in Florida on Saturday June 14th. Graduate of Hunter College, Class of 1940, President of her synagogue sisterhood, she was the beloved mother of two sons, Michael and Steven, mother-inlaw of Gaylen Garvett, and proud grandmother of Harris. She was laid to rest next to her husband of 47 years, Harold Neiditch, at the Eternal Light Cemetery in Boynton Beach, FL.

VOGL--Albert J., on June 14 of cancer in Brewster, NY. Al served as editor of magazines including Medical Economics, American Film, and for 18 years, Across the Board and The Conference Board Review. He leaves behind a legacy of dignity and integrity in his work and life, from his interviews with business notables to his community involvement and enthusiasm for jazz piano. Al had a tremendous influence on those who had the privilege to know him, and he will be greatly missed. Survived by wife Linda, son Tim, and daughter Katrina. Donations to the Outreach Ministry of St. Luke's Episcopal Church, PO Box 94, Somers, NY 10589.
UPPER EAST SIDE CO-OP $1,895,000

WITSELL--Daphne Towne, of Hobe Sound, FL, and Glen Cove, NY, died peacefully at home on June 10, 2008 in Hope Sound, after a five year fight with ovarian cancer. She was a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John D.C. Towne. Daphne was born in New York City on January 14, 1935. She was the loving wife for over 52 years of Frederick C. John Witsell, Jr., and the loving mother of Deborah Witsell Vivian, South Hamilton, MA, and Frederick C. Witsell, III, Pawling, NY. Proud grandmother of: Haley Dolan Witsell; Katharine Towne Witsell; Donald Witsell Vivian; and John Chaplin Vivian. She is survived by her twin sister Mrs. Diana Towne Knox, Greensboro, NC. Daphne was loved and respected by her many friends and admirers. She was a caring, private person; an excellent bridge player; loved to garden; was a good golfer; and enjoyed solving crossword puzzles and double acrostics, on a daily basis. She also was an avid reader. She served on the board of The Hobe Sound Nature Center. Daphne graduated from The New Canaan Country School, The Ethel Walker School in 1952, and attended Finch College. A memorial Service will be held on Thursday, June 26th, at 11am at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church, Lattingtown and Old Tappan Road, Locust Valley, NY 11560. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: Jupiter Medical Center Foundation, Inc., 1210 South Old Dixie Highway, Jupiter, FL 33458-7205 or Hospice Foundation c/o Treasure Coast Hospice 1201 S.E. Indian Street, Stuart, FL 34997.

SCHWARTZMAN--Ruth, May 29, 1916 -June 11, 2008. Beloved mother and grandmother, dedicated feminist, socialist and idealist, Ruth came out of the cauldron of the Depression dedicating her life to empowering workers. She will be lovingly remembered by her sons Edward and Victor; her daughter-in-law, Madeline Boscoe; her grandchildren, Cary and Kathryn; and by her extended family, including her former colleagues at the HewlettWoodmere Public Library. A memorial service will be held in Hewlett on June 29, 2pm, at the Boulevard Riverside Chapel. Please consider donations in Ruth's name to The Stephen Lewis Foundation's Grandmothers to Grandmothers campaign (www.groundspring.org)

ORTH--Joan, 76 years old, of NYC, died Wednesday, June 11, 2008. She was the daughter of the late Elizabeth Holden Watlington Bates and the late Colonel Russell Emerson Bates, US Army, Class of 1923, US Military Academy, West Point, NY. She was married to the late Bob Orth. A member of the Episcopal Church, she attended the University of NE, produced a book review radio show for over 20 years, was a public relations specialist and an aide to Mayor John Lindsay, worked for Popular Science Magazine and was a world traveler. She is survived by a sister, Mrs. Elizabeth Bates Smith of Columbia, SC; a brother Melvin Bates of Lincoln, NE; and nieces and nephews; Wayne C. Smith III of Doylestown, PA; Dr. Barbara M. Bates-Jensen of Pasadena, CA; Cecily Ann Smith Lloyd of Minneapolis, MN; Russ Bates of Edgewater, FL; Sandy Lloyd of Kelseyville, CA; and Marty Kenton of Covington, GA. Memorials may be given to the charity of your choice. Private services will be held at the family site in Valleau Cemetery, 660 East Glen Avenue, Ridgewood, NJ.

MEASURE FOR MEASURE We were on the road when ''Luka'' came out and things changed overnight. Literally. One night we were playing the usual half-filled theaters and clubs. The next day, and every day after that, each venue was full. Why? Some of it was the topic; so many people wrote me of their experiences. This has continued right up until this past weekend, when a teenage girl told me she had been a victim of child abuse and that she really identified with the character. This was astonishing to me. I had believed the song was about a small personal issue, but my manager had been correct: it was about a huge social one.

GOLDNER--Jerome, of Boca Raton, FL, following a brief illness on June 13, 2008. Best friend and loving husband of 44 years to Eleanor Goldner. Mourned by children, Leslie Dolan, Denise and Seth Sporn, Ted and Beth Baylis, Karen Harris, and grandchildren Tracy and Rob Dolan, Bill and Craig Baylis, Matt and Jordan Sporn. Donations in memory of Jerry may be made to the American Cancer Society.

HALPERIN--Richard. We will forever miss your enthusiasm, humor, kindness, compassion and wisdom. A finer man there never was. You had the unique ability to make all those around you feel special. Your absence leaves a deep void in so many. Your were not only our ''summer friend'' but truly our friend for all seasons. Our most sincere condolences to Lucy, Ross, Robert, Steven and Kenny. Suzan and Mitchell HALPERIN--Richard E. We hope that Lucy, Ross, Robert, Steven, and Kenny are comforted with all the mourners of Zion. We have all too soon lost a true mensch who always had a moment for anyone. We will miss his friendship, counsel, and love. Steven, Josh, Hope, Debbie, Samantha and Caleigh Perelman HALPERIN--Richard. The most selfless person I've ever known. If you were his ''pal'', you were his pal for life and that was a distinction I cherished and always will. I learned so much from him, and will honor his memory by trying to emulate some of his great qualities. Lucy, Ross, Robbie, Kenny and Stevie, you were his crown jewels his love and devotion to you was endless and pure. Richard, we loved you and will keep you in our hearts and memories forever. Peter, Stacy, Jake, Harrison, Charles and Lily Hochfelder HALPERIN--Richard. There was no truer, more faithful friend than Richard. We were blessed with his love and loyalty for 30 years. His qualities live on in his beloved Lucy, his strong sons, and all who cherished him. Bob Abrams and Jim Conroy HALPERIN--Richard E. Our family is shocked and deeply saddened by Richard's sudden passing. We cannot think of a nicer, warmer, kinder, more generous or caring individual or a more dedicated father. Our love and sincerest condolences go to Lucy and the boys. May Richard's memory be for a blessing. Barbara, Henry, Heather, Samantha, Andrew & Alison Miller HALPERIN--Richard. We mourn the sudden and untimely passing of our partner and great friend, Richard Halperin. Richard will be forever remembered as one of the most giving, genuine, fun-loving, energetic and considerate individuals we have ever encountered. His unbridled energy, optimism and humble nature provided valuable leadership and guidance. He made sure we never forgot our roots or values. His wit, humor and keen business acumen were invaluable in our various endeavors. Throughout everything he did, he made sure that everyone was included and felt special. Richard, we thank you for being you, and extend our deepest sympathy and prayers to your loving family. Quellos Group HALPERIN--Richard. We mourn the loss of our dearest friend, Richard. The word friend doesn't even begin to describe Richard's place in our family. More like a brother, life advisor, confidant; he was our rock. Richard was an example to all of what a loving husband, devoted father and honorable businessman should be. He was truly a man of valor. Our love and thoughts go out to Lucy, Ross, Robert, Stevie and Kenny. May his memory remain as a blessing. Jane, Larry, Greg, Caroline & Philip Scheinfeld HALPERIN--Richard E. The Schleiff family mourns the loss of our dear friend, a man of unusual grace, intelligence and, indeed, humor. Richard was a best friend to all of us, a devoted father to his four sons and a loving husband to his wife, Lucy. Our hearts go out to his family and to all those who were privileged to know him. HALPERIN--Richard. Kind of heart and deeds, and treasured by his parents, the late Anne and Alvin Halperin. Estelle Cohen and Family HALPERIN--Richard, from three hilarious years as roommates at Boston University to someone I could count on anytime as a lifelong friend. From great times at Ken's Pub to long nights of Pick It Up, you were the best. Deepest sympathy to Lucy, Ross, Robert, Kenneth and Steven and sister Marsha. Kevin Goldman HALPERIN--Richard. A sweeter, kinder man never lived. Richard had a sunny disposition and delighted in others' good fortune. He excelled in both the public and private sectors, and was planning the second half of his productive life when he passed away far too soon. He adored his handsome, talented children and his beautiful wife. We will miss him as a neighbor, friend and a force for all that is good in the community. Gina and Cliff Ratner HALPERIN--Richard. Like all who knew him, we loved and admired our friend Richard. Our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Lucy and sons Ross, Robert, Kenneth and Steven and to his devoted mother-in-law, Sally Cory. Teddy, Stephanie, Jodi and Herb Nass HALPERIN--Richard E. The Rye Country Day School Board of Trustees, faculty, staff and administration mourn the loss of Richard E. Halperin, trustee, current parent, friend, and beloved member of the RCDS Community. Richard's invaluable guidance and wisdom, and his dedicated service contributed immensely to the school's success, helping to steer Rye Country Day into the 21st century. Our heartfelt condolences go out to his wife, Lucy, and sons, Ross, Robert, Kenneth and Steven. Marlene G. DiChiacchio President of the Board Scott A. Nelson Headmaster HALPERIN--Richard. With profound sorrow, we mourn the passing of our dear friend, Richard. His loyalty and generosity were beyond measure, as was his devotion to family and friends. Richard, you were father, brother and mentor to me, and I shall endeavor to honor your memory in all that I do. You were deeply loved, pal, and your wit and wisdom, ready grin and bouncing step will be deeply missed. To your Beloved Lucy, and to your sons, Ross, Robert, Kenny and Stevie, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Christina, Kees & Willem van Beelen

DAVIS--Judy Ellen (Rudder), age 64, of Cold Spring, NY, and Sunset Beach, NC, and formerly of Rye, NY passed away peacefully too soon on June 21, 2008. She was the beloved wife of Danny and the cherished mother of Andy Davis and Katy and Paul Cox. Loved and admired by everyone she touched, her energetic spirit will live on through her adored grandchildren, Jacob and Judine Cox. Donations in memory of Judy may be made to the American Cancer Society or Guiding Eyes for the Blind. A memorial service will be held at Round Hill, 110 Round Hill, Washingtonville, NY 10992 on Thursday, June 26th at Noon.
An art entry in the Week Ahead column on Page 4 this weekend misstates the day on which an exhibition of works by Louise Bourgeois opens at the Guggenheim Museum. It opens on Friday, not Wednesday.

LEE--Sidney, four term Virgin Island Senator, philanthropist, businessman, and scientist --died last Friday at the age of 89. He was living at his home in St. Croix until three weeks ago when he became ill. His death at New York Presbyterian Hospital was caused by acute leukemia, said his children Candy and Phillip. Senator Lee served four terms in the Virgin Islands Legislature, becoming Vice President of the Thirteenth Legislature and chairman of the Finance Committee. He subsequently served as chairman of finance on the Virgin Islands Port Authority. His passion was public service, serving many terms on the Board of Education. He was a beloved philanthropist, donating to a variety of causes. He gave a portion of the beach at Sandy Point as a public park for the people of St. Croix, and the rest became a national park. He donated the Sidney Lee Theater at Island Center, and donated to Island Center summer camps for youth. He funded a multitude of charitable, educational and philanthropic activities including a playground at St. Croix Country Day School and a sports facility at In Balance Ranch Academy. His Dream Foundation helped a class of Virgin Islanders attend college. Sidney Lee attended Winona Military Academy where he graduated first in his high school class. Subsequently he also graduated first in his class from the University of Pennsylvania where he majored in chemical engineering. Pursuing his doctorate at Cornell, he was commandeered to leave school to help with the war effort by doing research on jet fuel, which ultimately contributed to American air superiority. After the war he became involved in business in Texas and in the Virgin Islands. He was president of a consulting laboratory which served as the crime lab for the City of Dallas and testified in hundreds of cases. His laboratory also expanded into manufacturing, testing, and certification. He served on the board of directors of American Shipbuilding. He was president of the Junior Chamber of Commerce, and voted one of the five most outstanding young men of Texas. First coming to the Virgin Islands in the 1940s, he served as President of the West Indies Investment Company, involved in land development on all three islands and construction. He helped found and served on the board of the Virgin Islands Bank and Trust whose five branches later became the Chase Manhattan Bank in the Virgin Islands. He also served as president of the Rotary Club of St. Croix, president of Pelican Cove Condominiums, president of the Jewish Community Center, Grand Marshall of the St. Patricks Day Parade, president of the theater group at Island Center, and served on the boards of numerous civic and philanthropic organizations. He served as Democratic National Committeeman, and was a frequent delegate to the Democratic National Convention, and was a delegate to the Virgin Island Constitutional Conventions. He was voted most admired man in the Virgin Islands in the Daily News poll. In later years he published an admired column, Lee Lets Loose, in the St. Croix Avis. He received the Humanist Award from the Virgin Islands Humanities Council, an award which recognizes Virgin Islanders who make an exemplary contribution to the cultural life of the V.I. community through the humanities. Senator Lee is survived by his children Candy Lee and her husband Joseph Ward, Phillip Lee and his wife Diane Rudolph, and his grandchildren Jason, David, and Jennifer. A memorial service which will be held in St. Croix is planned for later in the year. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent to The Sidney Lee Theatre c/o The Island Center for the Performing Arts, Box 5976, Sunny Isle, Virgin Islands 00823.

HERBERT--Raford Watson, 93, diplomat and international business executive died in Jupiter, FL on May 23, 2008 surrounded by his family. Born March 11, 1915 in Lexington, MS to Eloise Watson Herbert and John Garrott Herbert, he graduated from Lexington High School valedictorian in 1932 and played halfback on its undefeated football team that won the Mississippi state championship that year. He graduated with distinction from Southwestern at Memphis (now Rhodes College) in 1936, Omicron Delta Kappa and Sigma Alpha Epsilon, and from Georgetown University Law Center in 1940. Served during WWII in the FBI in Seattle, WA and in South America, under diplomatic cover. He joined the CIA in 1947, serving as Station Chief in Buenos Aires, Montevideo, Rio de Janeiro, and Santiago retiring in 1965 as Deputy Assistant Secretary Western Hemisphere. He was President of Swift-Armour Argentina from 1965 -1970, worked for the King Ranch of Texas in New York in 1971, and was Managing Director of Ethiopian Livestock Development Company in Addis Ababa from 1972-1977. Survived by wife Patricia Thompson Herbert of Jupiter, FL; three children, Lucinda Herbert Flynn of Port Chester, NY, Penelope Herbert of Sleepy Hollow, NY, and Clive Herbert of London, GB, and seven grandchildren. A service was held May 31, 2008 in Florida.
Television Mike Hale

KEEBLER--Stuart E., 83, died on June 14 at his home in Patterson, NY. He was an alumnust of Montclaire Academy, Princeton University and Harvard Law School, and a retired partner of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy LLP. He is survived by his devoted sister, Abby Keebler Ryan.

IF there's a subject that's as contentious as war itself, it might be a video game about war. It's been just over a week since the release of Metal Gear Solid 4: Guns of the Patriots, the latest chapter in the popular video game series about a covert military agent named Solid Snake. And already, fans are exchanging rhetorical fusillades on the Internet, teasing out what the underlying political and philosophical messages of Metal Gear Solid 4 might be.

BAKST--Hyman, M.D., died peacefully on June 9, 2008 at the age of 92 in Poughkeepsie, NY, his daughter Marni Bakst and granddaughter, Sadler Colley Bakst at his side. A lifelong resident of New York, born in the Bronx on February 13, 1916, he earned a B.S. from NYU in 1935, an M.D. from NYU College of Medicine in 1939, and did post-graduate training at Columbia. His internship and residency were at Beth Israel, where he was active in organizing a Physician's Union. Dr. Bakst enlisted in the Army Medical Corps as a Lieutenant on December 8, 1941, participated in the Invasion at Normandy, the Liberation of Paris, the freeing of Buchenwald, and the fall of Berlin. Awarded the Bronze Star and discharged with the rank of Major in 1945, where he returned to NYC and joined Dr. Harry Gold's team developing the 'Double-Blind' protocol in the US, still the 'Gold Standard' for conducting viable scientific studies. A Board Certified Internist, Dr. Bakst's Academic and Hospital Appointments include Assistant Clinical Professorship of Medicine and Psychiatry at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Assistant Clinical Professorship of Medicine at Mount Sinai School of Medicine, Associate Physician at Bronx Municipal Hospital Center, Attending in Medicine at Beth Israel Hospital Associate Medicine Chief of Psychosomatic Service at Montefiore Hospital where he did pioneering work. Dr. Bakst was a Fellow of the American College of Physicians, Fellow of the NY Academy of Medicine, Fellow of the NY Academy of Science, a member of A.A.A.S., and the American Psychosomatic Society. Dr. Bakst published 21 papers in numerous professional medical journals, and made two Educational Films. Dr. Bakst retired at 81. A lifelong student and in turn, a mentor to many. A gifted teacher, he inspired young doctors to treat the whole patient, not just the disease, to cultivate a 'human touch'. Early in offering his service to AIDS patients, he had a deep compassion for all life. Survived by his beloved and loving family, daughter Marni Bakst, granddaughter Sadler Colley Bakst, son-in-law William Sadler, and the incomparable 'Bandito'. Contributions may be made to Doctors Without Borders. For Memorial Celebration info contact mjbakst@aol.com. A lifelong lover of early jazz, we know you've found your way to a swingin' celestial jam with Ella and Louis and all those 'cool cats'. Peace.

To the Editor: Amid all the Father's Day hype, it was a particular pleasure to read ''His Dad, the World's Darling,'' Neal Hirschfeld's moving but bracingly unsentimental memoir last Sunday. It was a beautiful job of communicating the intricacies of family life, and loss, in a particular time and place, when men could be heroes to their co-workers but remain strangers to their own children.

TOMKINS--Lloyd F., known to her friends as Pat, died on June 14. She will be remembered always as the loving mother of Anne, Susan, and Spencer, adoring grandmother of Devon, Barrett, Christopher, Sherrick, and Morgan. A caring friend and a devoted Yankee fan.

ELPHAND--Louis, died June 20, 2008. Beloved husband of Shirley, loving father to Phyllis Van Dyne, Sandy Wolstein and Philip Elphand, father-inlaw to Martin, Lewis, Melanie and Thomas; grandfather to Josh, Matthew, Scott, Michael, Kathy and Maggie; loving uncle to Gary. He is a retired financial advisor for Gary Goldberg & Company, was a WWII veteran and POW, and recipient of a Purple Heart.

NELKIN--Myron. Our 1st anniversary apart, but I can only remember the happy moments we shared together as husband and wife and as a family. Our memories and love will go on and not be forgotten. Hugs and kisses with all my love, Barbara

JORGENSEN--Marion Newbert Marion Newbert Jorgensen, a civic leader and prominent philanthropist in Los Angeles for five decades, died Wednesday at Saint John's Health Center in Santa Monica, CA. She was 96. Marion Newbert was born on March 18, 1912 to Mr. and Mrs. Leroy Newbert of Chicago, Illinois. In 1913 she moved West with her family by private railroad car and later attended Marlborough School, one of the foremost college-preparatory schools in Los Angeles. A licensed aircraft pilot at the age of 17, she attended the noted liberal arts college Finch College in New York City and returned to Los Angeles. In 1930, she married movie producer Milton Harold Bren, who was the Executive Vice President and Producer at MGM Studios and experienced Hollywood during a time of tremendous growth in the entertainment industry. He served in the United States Naval Services during World War II as a Lieutenant Commander. They had two sons, Donald Bren, chairman of The Irvine Company in Newport Beach, CA and Peter Bren, a senior partner with KBS Investors of New York City, NY. While Great Britain was at war in Europe in 1940, Mrs. Jorgensen founded Bundles For Britain, an organization that provided non-military aid to the British people. Women crocheted sweaters and made clothing as Bundles For Britain sent food and clothes overseas from the then-neutral United States. When the United States entered World War II in 1941, Bundles For Britain evolved into the United States Naval Aide Auxiliary. Mrs. Jorgensen was the president of this organization that provided aid to service personnel and United States Navy and Marine dependents. After the conclusion of her first marriage in 1947, she met steel entrepreneur Earle M. Jorgensen while doing volunteer work for the Red Cross. They were married in 1953 and their 47-year wonderful union continued until Mr. Jorgensen's passing in 1999. The Jorgensens were among the social elite of Los Angeles. The couple remained close friends with Ronald and Nancy Reagan for more than 40 years, as Mr. Jorgensen served on Mr. Reagan's ''Kitchen Cabinet'', an informal network of businessmen who advised Mr. Reagan and urged him to run for governor of California in 1966 and later for President. Mr. and Mrs. Reagan celebrated his election to the governorship of California and his election to the presidency of the United States at the Jorgensen's house. ''I was privileged, and blessed, to know Marion Jorgensen as a dear friend for almost fifty years. She was one of the most generous women I have ever known. There isn't a worthwhile cause in this country that hasn't benefited from Marion's generosity. She loved politics, music, education, the arts, and gave liberally to medical research and children's charities in Los Angeles and across the nation,'' said Mrs. Ronald Reagan. ''My love and sympathy goes out to her two children, Don and Peter, and her entire family.'' Mrs. Jorgensen was credited with sparking her husband Earle's interest in philanthropy and they were active in many civic, cultural and charitable causes including the Boy Scouts, the YMCA, several hospitals and the Los Angeles Music Center. ''My mother enjoyed a wonderfully fulfilling life and was a strong inspiration to me,'' said Donald Bren. ''Her commitment to philanthropy and to the communities in which she lived impacted me deeply and formed my passion to give back to the community.'' Mrs. Jorgensen began working with Saint John's in the 1950s and led committees, engaged volunteers and spearheaded legendary evenings such as the Dinner for Prince Charles, the Black and White Ball with Bob Hope, and a series of star-studded evenings, the Bal Rouge and the Crystal Balls, with Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin, Sammy Davis, Jr., and Joey Bishop. After the 1994 Northridge earthquake threatened to close the hospital forever, she agreed to serve on the First Step Committee and co-chaired the Campaign Cabinet to lead the Campaign for Saint John's. She served as a leader on many important Foundation committees including Board Affairs and the Executive Committee and allowed the small community hospital to rebuild from the devastation and attain the flagship status Saint John's enjoys today. Last October, Mrs. Jorgensen was presented with the Spirit of Saint John's Award by the Saint John's Health Center Foundation Board of Trustees in recognition of her many contributions. The award honors an individual whose vision, determination and generosity of spirit have advanced the mission of the Health Center. After serving with distinction on the Los Angeles World Affairs Council, Mrs. Jorgensen was honored by her peers with election to Life Director. She was the first woman to serve as chairman of the board of overseers of the Huntington Library Art Gallery and Botanical Gardens, and for her service in developing the world famous botanical gardens, she was elected Trustee Emeritus. Mrs. Jorgensen was an Honorary Trustee of Childrens Hospital Los Angeles and served on the board of The Colleagues. Included among the other philanthropic endeavors that benefited from Mrs. Jorgensen's support over the years were the Los Angeles Orphanage Guild, the ARCS Foundation, the American Red Cross, Loyola Marymount University and the Prince of Wales Foundation. Additionally, Mrs. Jorgensen served on the President's Blue Ribbon 400 for the Los Angeles Music Center and as director of the Los Angeles Symphony Association, was a Member of the Board of Trustees of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts and was a Founding Member of the James Madison Council of the Library of Congress, the first-ever national advisory and support group in its 205year history. She also served as a member of the board of Continental Airlines and Frontier Airlines. Mrs. Jorgensen is survived by her sons, Donald and Peter Bren, four Jorgensen children and many grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

Many young men continue to wear their pants ever lower, but the ongoing battle with gravity doesn't mean that they don't tweak the style from season to season. Lately, there's the addition of a glittering belt or belts. Some belts have a sparkly skull motif. And when the temperature hit 90, T-shirts and tank tops came off to display sculptured torsos, a contrast with the oversize pants. The look is a good example of fashion born on the street: it has nothing to do with designer influences. If anything, it defies the runway, especially in a season when some designers showed shrunken, tight suits. But just as graffiti made its way from the streets to the galleries, it may one day appear there.

PERKINS--George W., Jr. died peacefully at his home in Park City, Utah on June 12, 2008. He was born in 1925 at Wave Hill, his grandparent's house in Riverdale, New York. The son of George W. Perkins, the first U.S. Ambassador to N.A.T.O, and Linn Merck Perkins, George grew up in New York City. He graduated from The Hill School early in 1942 so that he could join in the war effort. Because of an eye injury at age 11 he could not enter military service, but instead joined the American Field Service and drove ambulances in Burma throughout the war. He returned afterwards to graduate from the University of Maine in 1949 with a B.S. in Agriculture. In 1950 he married Nancy Foster, whom he met during college, and moved to Millbrook, New York where he raised a grand champion herd of Black Angus cattle until 1979. He was an avid traveler, exploring every continent, and was especially interested in Africa. His travel was curtailed during the last 20 years of his life as his health began to fail, but he never lost his good humor, optimism and love of life. In addition to his wife of 58 years, he is survived by his daughter Jennifer Perkins Speers (and husband Randy), his sisters Penelope P. Wilson and Anne P. Cabot, seven nieces and one nephew. He was predeceased by his son George III. The burial will be held on June 28th at 12:00 noon at Nine Partners Cemetery, Millbrook, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Millbrook Fire Department and/or Rescue Squad. Services by Allen Funeral Home, Millbrook, NY.

The diversity situation in Nascar compared to other forms of motorsports sums up nicely why Nascar is a circus sideshow and not the real thing. Bernie Ecclestone didn't run an incentive program to get McLaren to hire Lewis Hamilton. The circumstances that produced the Danica Patrick phenomenon weren't manufactured (at least at first). Even the National Hot Rod Association, which gives Nascar a run for its money in terms of the least common denominator, found some driver diversity naturally.

LAST week, Leslie Wayne reported on our sister blog, The Caucus, that all official vehicles at the Democratic National Convention in Denver in August will be fueled by ethanol derived from beer, of all things. The Molson Coors Brewing Company has been converting beer into ethanol since 1996. The company generates about 3 million gallons of ethanol a year from waste beer, i.e., beer that's below quality standards or lost during packaging.

THE NEWS Israel offered to conduct direct peace talks with Lebanon on all issues, including a disputed patch of occupied land called Shebaa Farms. BEHIND THE NEWS Israel had previously said that the land, which its forces retained while withdrawing from Lebanon after the 2006 war, was actually part of the adjacent Golan Heights, Syrian territory that Israel has held since 1967. But Syria has not disputed Lebanon's claim to the land. Israel also agreed to a truce with the militant Hamas group that dominates Gaza after months of clashes, held a round of talks with Syria that both sides said were productive, and was said to be near a prisoner-exchange deal with Hezbollah.

TRAVELING THROUGH MALI BY BOAT, JAN 6. 2008 Robyn Paiba, 35, a London art director for film and television, rests against the gunwale of a 50-foot pinasse while traveling from Mopti to Timbuktu on the Niger River. ''I went because a friend of mine had sent this big e-mail around to all his friends last year, saying he wanted to spend New Year's in Timbuktu and then go to a music festival in the desert. And I was the only person that replied 'yes.' So the main aim was to get to the festival in Essakane, about 40 kilometers north of Timbuktu, and travel through Mali for a few weeks to get there. It was amazing. We were there for just under three weeks, and those three days on the boat were the holiday of the trip. It's quite hard work traveling across Africa -- it's pretty basic country. It's all very exciting and you're completely overstimulated everywhere you look, but to sit on a boat for three days and not really have to think about anything or worry about getting on a bus -- it was lovely.''

TILGHMAN--Henry Ashe, 87, died Saturday June 14. Hal was born May 27, 1921 in Morristown, NJ, son of George Hammond and Ruth (Slocum) Tilghman. Hal graduated from Kent School in 1939 and Harvard College in 1943. After Pearl Harbor, Hal enlisted in the Navy. In the summer of 1941, Hal went to Chappaquiddick Island to visit his Kent and Harvard classmate, Bill Pinney. Bill introduced him to his sister Olive, who for 65 years was the love of Hal's life. They were married on December 2, 1942, the same day he received his naval commission. He served as a Lieutenant on the USS Chauncey from 1942 until 1946 and remained in the Naval Reserves until 1963, retiring as a Commander. After the war, Hal had several careers: shell fisherman, law student, lawyer, divinity student, Episcopal priest and headmaster. Hal and Olive spent every summer on Chappy. They built a summer house, which became their retirement home in 1989. Hal and Olive enjoyed life on Chappy until declining health required them to move to an assisted living facility in Vermont where Olive died from complications of Alzheimer's in 2007. Hal is survived by five children, Ruth, Thomas, Peter, Frank and Lois; 12 grandchildren, five great-grandchildren; two brothers, George and Richard Tilghman, and two sisters, Sally Wardwell and Anne Lyman. A memorial service will be held at St. Andrew's Church in Edgartown, MA on July 25th.

IN our house, the tenuous relationship between word and deed begins at the top of the cellar stairs. That's because there's a list there, tacked to the wall years ago when we took up residence. Replace basement windows. Pour concrete floor. Repair rotten step. Install shelving. Though nothing but a few words on a scrap of paper, that inventory is a place where an idea became an intention and the intention, a word. And when the word was written down, I was sure it would be the first step toward materiality. But this is the way it tends to go at our house, a place where compulsive list making is given due respect. Whether the issue is how to overhaul the basement or what to buy for dinner, there is a general understanding that enterprise begins on paper, something scribbled on a napkin or the back of an envelope. A grocery list, a to-do list -- any household list is the first thing that gives expression to what you need, and maybe more important, what you want. And while a quick glance into our basement makes it clear that a list is often nothing more than a vague statement of purpose, those assorted scraps of paper still remain a place where it is possible for intent to be introduced to action.

GREENSPAN--Leon. The man many called ''Dr. Bubala'' passed away at his California home June 15th, at 96. Leon Greenspan, M.D. headed the Children's Division of the Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine at NYU Medical Center after having a pediatric practice in the Bronx. As a professor at the Medical School until his retirement in 1987, Dad was a teacher of science and the qualities that make a doctor a person, a friend, a bubala. Our Dad was one of the first to be board certified in pediatrics and pediatric physical medicine. He set a loving example of hard work, dedication and decency for us as we grew up in New Rochelle. He was the Medical Director at the Human Resources School for Handicapped Children in Albertson, Long Island. He was a national vice president of the Muscular Dystrophy Association of America from 1978-1988, treasurer, then president of the American Academy for Cerebral Palsy and Developmental Medicine 1973-1976 and 1977-1978, respectively, and was appointed to several NYC and State committees where he strove to improve the understanding of the needs of disabled children. He worked with the disabled in India and Venezuela. He has a long list of awards, but the satisfaction he got from helping people was his greatest reward. He graduated from the University of Michigan Medical School in 1937. Dad's beloved wife, Jeanette, our mother, predeceased him in 1984 as have his younger sister and brother, Ruth Hacker and Morton Greenspan. His daughters, Leslie Korngold (Aaron Korngold) of Larchmont, NY, Alison Greenspan (Stanley Mainzer) of Burlingame, CA, and son Avram Greenspan (Sheryl) of San Carlos, CA, and his six grandchildren and grandsonin-law will miss the benefit of his thinking and his love. Donations to Doctors Without Borders and Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem would be appreciated.

The steps of City Hall — once the scene of loud, colorful protests and even a few violent riots — are now available only by appointment and must be booked much like a Saturday morning golf tee time, Fernanda Santos reports. Competition for them is intense.

This is a city where there seems to be no end of the humble foods that can be transformed into a luxury. Joining the $60-plus hamburger and the $95 beer is the $30 TV dinner, courtesy of Loews Regency Hotel and the childhood nostalgia of its executive chef, Andrew Rubin.

The death of television commentator Tim Russert at age 58 has raised many questions about how cardiologists assess a patient's condition, as Denise Grady reports in Science Times. Among other confusions, many are wondering how Mr. Russert could have passed a recent stress test, as well as other evaluations, and still have succumbed to sudden cardiac death.

Bill Keller, an evangelist based in Florida, runs "Liveprayer.com," an Internet call-in program. Because he receives a government tax exemption, he is prohibited by law from endorsing or opposing candidates for public office.

There were no climate-science bombshells from James E. Hansen on Monday on his trip to Capitol Hill at the invitation of some House Democrats, who wanted to commemorate his momentous global warming testimony 20 years earlier. On that front, he said everything he has been saying for years: unabated warming would erode the ice sheets, flood coastal cities and drive many species into extinction.

"While this year's presidential campaign has been marked by historic firsts, the nominations of senators McCain and Obama will renew one surprising trend: For the fifth time in the last 35 years, America will have a lefty in the White House," notes The New York Sun's Russell Berman. "Both major party candidates are southpaws, contributing to a largely unexplained phenomenon that has vexed researchers and historians - and drawn notice from a federal judge destined for the Supreme Court. Though left-handers comprise just 10 percent of the population, they are dominating presidential politics."
Facing campaign debt in excess of $22 million, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton sent a video message to supporters on Monday telling them, "I still need your help."

The 2008 World Barista champion was crowned on Sunday in Copenhagen -- and the winner was Stephen Morrissey of Ireland. His professional coffee connection is London's Square Mile Coffee Roasters.

Tighter visa restrictions imposed by the Chinese government are putting a serious damper on the tourism windfall originally expected for the Beijing Olympics, David Barboza writes in the Times Business section. The tighter restrictions are resulting in more visa denials, which has meant a drop in overseas visitors -- 14 percent fewer in May, according to Beijing city government statistics.

NBC's coverage of the "U.S. Olympic Trials" gave the network a boost in the ratings on Sunday, making it No. 1 for the night among adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsen's estimates, the women's gymnastics contenders put NBC in the lead in that demographic during the 7 and 8 p.m. hours despite averaging only a modest audience of 6.2 million total viewers.

Well, the search for a good cheap rosé continues, and this Portuguese baby, Casal Mendes, meets the cheap requirement (under $4; you can't get cheaper than that) but not the requirement that it be good; this one is way too sweet, and in a sugary way, not a shout-out-the-fruit manner.

Did anyone else (besides Phil Gordos of the BBC) catch Zinedine Zidane sitting with fellow Frenchman Arsene Wenger, the Arsenal boss, in the stands at Sunday's quarterfinal match between Italy and Spain? Based on the brief TV cutaway of the two, it wasn't exactly clear who they were supporting. Zidane has former teammates on both sides from his days at Real Madrid and Juventus, but I find it unlikely he was pulling for the azzuri.

FRESNO, Calif. - In the 18th century the British parliament offered a £20,000 prize to anyone who figured how to solve the problem of calculating longitude. More recently, Netflix offered a million-dollar prize for improving its movie recommendation software. And now Senator John McCain is suggesting a new, national prize: $300 million for anyone who can develop a better, more efficient car battery.

If any Democrats are worried whether there will be natural unity between Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton on Friday when they make their first on-the-road appearance since the primary battle ended, they can rest easy.

Don't forget your customers. That's the moral of a new report conducted by Accenture, the consulting firm, examining the problems sales organizations encounter after corporate mergers and acquisitions.

In today's Arts section, Charles Isherwood reviews a new Polish production of "Macbeth 2008," presented by the St. Ann's Warehouse in a stunning outdoor stage on the waterfront in Dumbo. Having seen the production last week, I wholeheartedly second Isherwood's take.

As states assess the damage of the recent floods in the Midwest, they are faced with the same questions that were raised after the flood of 1993: Why were new subdivisions built on floodplains? Why did the levees fail? Why are "great floods" occurring not every 150 years but every 15?

The week between the NHL Entry Draft and the July 1 onslaught of free agency is a time of furtive activity. There's tons of contract negotiating (you can't say any longer that GMs and agents "burn up the phone lines;" can anyone out there suggest some decent hyperbolic nomenclature for heavy cellphone use?) and some teams -- Buffalo and St. Louis are two we know -- are conducting lightly publicized development camps.

Global warming has felt like breaking news a few times in recent years. But the first big pulse of coverage and public attention came in 1988, when the Amazon rain forest and Yellowstone were ablaze, a searing drought had farmers kicking dusty fields in frustration, and global temperatures had seen enough of a rise that a NASA climate expert, James Hansen, asserted before a Senate panel that statistics showed "the greenhouse effect has been detected and is changing our climate now."

Huntsman made the logical counter-attack in its fight with Apollo Management. It sued Leon Black, Joshua J. Harris and over a dozen other Apollo affiliated funds and entities in Texas for more than $3 billion.
"ABC, the stingiest of the major television networks when it comes to syndicating its programs across the Web, is loosening up a little," Brad Stone reports.
The Philadelphia Phillies learned what American League teams have known for months now: the Los Angeles Angels have one of the most successful rotations in baseball this season.
There's a whole lot of backseat thieving going on today in Britain. Is James Milsom the country's "dumbest criminal" or are the courts far too soft?

ITALY Evidently, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi has sat out one too many communions. Under church law, the Italian leader is forbidden from the rite along with most other Catholics who have divorced and remarried. But his patience ended -- if only for a moment -- in Sardinia on Saturday, when he surprised a bishop performing Mass. "When are you going to change this rule that stops me taking communion?" he blurted out, according to The Guardian. The bishop wisely sidestepped the issue, advising him to appeal to a higher authority.
N.H.R.A.: The Funny Car driver Scott Kalitta died Saturday as a result of a crash during a qualifying attempt at the Lucas Oil SuperNationals at Old Bridge Township Raceway Park in New Jersey.

Angelo Vignara, a 63-year-old Vietnam veteran, sunbathes on a blanket in the middle of the sidewalk at Broadway and 109th Street.
Deutsche Bank announced Monday that it has hired two investment bankers to help bolster its Midwestern region operations.

This is a popular pre-meal dish made at Cookshop, the Manhattan restaurant at 10th Avenue and 20th Street. It was an easy order for me the first time around, because I'm a huge fan of all forms of dried corn.

BRIEFS New city of superlatives, meet the man who has always gloried in building the biggest and the best, or at least most expensive: "Trump penthouse breaks Dubai records." If you are on the fence about paying $3,000 per square foot, take this note of reassurance from Donald Trump: "I have created some of the world's most spectacular buildings and hotels," he told told The National of the United Arab Emirates, "but my project with [Dubai developer] Nakheel will be one of the most impressive undertakings."

"The novelist Ian McEwan has launched an astonishingly strong attack on Islamism, saying that he 'despises' it and accusing it of 'wanting to create a society that I detest,' " reports The Independent of London. "His words, in an interview with an Italian newspaper, could, in today's febrile legalistic climate, lay him open to being investigated for a 'hate crime.' " McEwan was speaking out in defense of his friend and fellow novelist Martin Amis, who has come under attack for expressing anti-Islamist views.

BlackBerrys blur the lines between work and play. A recent dispute at ABC News asked: at what point does checking e-mail after hours constitute working overtime?

Banc of America Securities expects Merrill Lynch and UBS to write down $3.5 billion and $7 billion respectively in the second quarter and forecast a quarterly loss for the investment banks, Reuters reported.

Workplace | Multitasking used to be the wave of the future. Now it's in disrepute. It's not only unsafe in some cases (cell phones and cars) but "infomania" is being called a serious threat to worker productivity. Besides, flitting from one activity to another may be an outmoded throwback to nomads who led a peripatetic life. It's ill-suited to the demands of modern society. -- The New Atlantis, Economist

The founder of founder of The Children's Investment Fund, Chris Hohn, gave 324 million pounds ($648 million) to his charitable foundation last year, making the activist hedge fund manager among the most generous of the current wave of super-rich British philanthropists, The Financial Times reported.
The Federal Reserve and Securities Exchange Commission are finalizing an agreement to start the process of redrawing how Wall Street is regulated, The Wall Street Journal reported.

Nearly three dozen former federal prosecutors have thrown their weight behind a Congressional bill intended to safeguard confidential communications between lawyers and their clients, a legal bedrock that has come under attack amid corporate fraud scandals.

German conglomerate MAN asked Goldman Sachs to sound out interest in its plant engineering and industrial services unit MAN Ferrostaal, Financial Times Deutschland reported.

Former Bear Stearns hedge-fund manager Ralph Cioffi, who was indicted Thursday, has used his homes in New Jersey and Naples, Fla. to secure a $4 million bond, but did not use his toniest address in Southampton to gain his freedom pending trial, The New York Post reported.
While Comcast didn't succeed in buying Walt Disney a few years ago, it has now succeeded in buying a part of it, PaidContent.org reports.
Hellman & Friedman is part of a private equity group that is considering a joint bid for British media company Informa, fellow members Providence Equity Partners and The Carlyle Group said.
Shareholders say Getty Images can go ahead with its plan to sell itself to the private equity group Hellman & Friedman of San Francisco.
Neocleus, a company that provides "endpoint virtualization," has raised $11.4 million in a second round of funding.
Kaltura, a video company that is considered a blend of YouTube and Wikipedia, has closed a second round of funding.
Fortress Investment Group is considering adding another $1 billion to the war chest it has amassed to take advantage of the pain being felt on Wall Street, The New York Post reported.

In another sign that trading on the floor of the nation's stock exchanges isn't what it used to be, futures-brokerage giant R.J. O'Brien & Associates is exiting the floor-trading business on New York's commodities exchanges, The New York Post reported.
Bunge said Monday that it would buy Corn Products International for $4.4 billion in stock, as the fertilizer and oilseed processor seeks to better compete against other American agricultural giants.

These days, it's hard to find much love on the Street for General Electric, once the bluest of blue chips. Shares of the company, which makes everything from light bulbs to jet engines to movies, sank to a five-year low last week after one of the few remaining bulls on the stock finally threw in the towel.
Morgan Stanley said it had appointed Yoshihiko Shigenari head of its private equity unit in Japan as the investment bank strengthens its business in the world's second-largest economy.
William Ackman's grim view of bond insurer Financial Security Assurance is costing its European parent a pretty penny.
Senator Kent Conrad never asked for or expected discounted mortgages or a "sweetheart deal" from Countrywide Financial, he wrote in a letter appearing in Monday's edition of The Wall Street Journal.
Nokia said Monday that it has inked a deal to buy Plazes, a German social network, as part of the mobile phone giant's push to transform itself into a next-generation entertainment company.

SJM Holdings, Macau's largest casino operator, may raise as much as 5.1 billion Hong Kong dollars ($653 million) from a share sale repeatedly delayed by a dispute between billionaire Stanley Ho and his sister Winnie, according to press reports.
British bank Lloyds TSB would consider a significant acquisition and is looking at a possible deal in Germany, according to Reuters.

This presidential election year may prove better than most at allowing a candidate to survive charges of flip-flopping. And Senators Barack Obama and John McCain seem to have set out to test their luck.
Sometimes, as in the case of ABC Family’s new comic-based series “The Middleman,” evil is downright funny.
“Hard Times at Douglass High: A No Child Left Behind Report Card” is, despite that subtitle, a draw-your-own-conclusions sort of documentary.
This documentary about the tribulations of a middle-aged British garage-punk cover band succeeds, thanks to the resilient dignity of its subjects.
Richard W. Stevenson, political editor, answered questions.

If you spend two hours interviewing the Hall of Fame pitcher Bob Feller, you are bound to get some terrific stories and some saucy opinions. When I spoke with Feller last week for a story about the 1939 All-Star Game in today's paper, he delivered. He gave me priceless anecdotes and blunt comments.
Bill Pennington meets the club's starter and learns the etiquette of beginning a round.

[UPDATED 6/23, 9:30 a.m.] Twenty years ago today, James E. Hansen testified before the Senate Energy Committee -- in a room kept intentionally warm by committee staff -- that the atmospheric buildup of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases from burning fossil fuels and forests was already perceptibly influencing Earth's climate.
Headlines from the world of property:
As the floodwaters slowly recede, residents find that going home is only one step toward recovery.
Jim James, the lead singer of My Morning Jacket, couldn’t decide whether Radio City Music Hall was a cathedral or a playground.
Some young players may decide that it makes more sense to play professional basketball in Europe than to play semipro, N.C.A.A. basketball for free.
The blast in Baquba underscored the growing security problem of female suicide bombers able to conceal bombs beneath head-to-toe robes.
Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno, New York State’s highest-ranking Republican, will step down at the end of this term in December.
Q & A With Stuart Elliott.
Webdenda.
Timex, the watchmaker, targets its new campaign to devotees of outdoor sports like hiking, skiing and rock climbing and to efforts to protect the places these sports are pursued.
Accounts.
Oil prices rose after the Saudis pledged only a slight increase in production during an energy summit.
The Bulldogs defeated North Carolina, 6-1, to win their bracket in the College World Series on Sunday night and advance to the championship round for the first time.
Gov. David A. Paterson and lawmakers are close to agreement on a series of changes aimed at preventing abuses of the state pension system.

The United States men’s team lost to Serbia, 7-3, in the FINA World League Super Final in Genoa, Italy. But the silver-medal performance bolsters the team’s budding chances of contending for a medal in the Beijing Olympics in August. Once considered something of a long shot, the team upset Croatia, ranked No. 1 in the world, this month.

Roman Kreuziger held off Andreas Klöden and won the Tour de Suisse in Bern. Kreuziger, from the Czech Republic, held a 49-second lead over Klöden going into the final stage and was never threatened during the 104-mile ride from Altdorf to the Swiss capital, winning by the same margin.

Laura Wilkinson earned her third trip to the Olympics, holding off 15-year-old Haley Ishimatsu on the 10-meter platform Sunday at the United States diving trials in Indianapolis. Wilkinson, 30, who won the gold medal on platform at the 2000 Sydney Olympics, botched her second dive, but her next one produced all 10s.

Todd Wells and Georgia Gould were the first two racers to clinch spots on the United States Olympic mountain biking team, after no Americans secured an automatic bid in the world championships in Trentino, Italy. Each made the Olympic team based on having the best cumulative placing in international races this year.

Eun-Hee Ji earned her first victory on the L.P.G.A. Tour, rallying for a two-stroke win over Suzann Pettersen at the Wegmans L.P.G.A. in Pittsford, N.Y. Ji, a 22-year-old from South Korea, shot a five-under 67, and Pettersen shot a 72 and surrendered a three-stroke lead.

Titans defensive end Jevon Kearse was arrested and charged with driving under the influence after a traffic stop near the Vanderbilt campus in Nashville. The Vanderbilt spokesman Jim Patterson said Kearse was stopped early Sunday morning after the campus police reported seeing the S.U.V. that Kearse was driving weaving across the road. Patterson says Kearse took a field sobriety test, but refused a breathalyzer. He was arrested and charged with D.U.I. and a violation of Tennessee’s implied consent law for failing to take the breathalyzer test.

Jeff Sluman birdied three of the last four holes and won the Champions Tour Bank of America Championship in Concord, Mass., by two strokes. He birdied the 15th to break a tie with Loren Roberts, then made putts of more than 30 feet on the 17th and 18th. Roberts was the second-round leader.

The Pittsburgh Penguins star Evgeni Malkin has no intention of returning home to play in Russia, his agent said. The Toronto Star reported last week that several teams from the newly formed Continental Hockey League in Russia intended to offer Malkin a multiyear contract worth at least $12.5 million a season. The agent, J. P. Barry, confirmed that Malkin received a lucrative “back channel” offer to play in Russia, but stressed it was a deal Malkin had no intention of accepting.

Pacman Jones, the suspended Dallas Cowboys cornerback, said he would like to be called by his given name, Adam, and make his nickname a thing of the past. “There’s really just a lot of negativity behind it,” Jones said. “It’s just time for a change, man.”.

A pop music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about the songwriter-singer Tony Joe White, who will perform at Joe’s Pub on Wednesday, misidentified an artist who recorded his “Rainy Night in Georgia.” It was Brook Benton, not Gladys Knight. (She recorded “Midnight Train to Georgia,” by Jim Weatherly.).

An article Saturday about Steven, Mark and Diana Lopez, siblings who qualified for the Olympics in tae kwon do, misstated the origins of karate. It is a Japanese martial art, not a Korean martial art like tae kwon do.

An article on Tuesday about business deals announced on the eve of trade talks between the United States and China misstated the name of the school where the top Chinese delegate to the talks, Vice Premier Wang Qishan, was educated. It is Northwest University, in his native Shanxi Province — not Northwestern University.
METRO.

An art review on June 13 about “Heavy Light: Recent Photography and Video From Japan,” at the International Center of Photography in Manhattan, misidentified the source of comments by the photographer Makato Aida in the exhibition’s catalog. They are from a condensed interview with Masayuki Yoshinaga, another photographer in the exhibition; Mr. Aida did not forgo the catalog interview.

A report in some editions of the Sports Briefing column on Friday about the United States Olympic men’s basketball team misspelled the surname of a player who withdrew from consideration for the team and misspelled the surname of the managing director of USA Basketball. The player is Amare Stoudemire, not Stoudamire, and the managing director is Jerry Colangelo, not Colangleo.

An article in some editions on Friday about pitcher Kei Igawa’s toiling in the Yankees’ minor league system misstated his career statistics with the Yankees. His record is 2-4, not 3-3, and his earned run average is 6.75, not 4.46.

An article in some editions on Sunday about the first round of the N.H.L. draft misidentified the teams that drafted Alex Pietrangelo and Luke Schenn. Pietrangelo was selected fourth by the St. Louis Blues, not the Toronto Maple Leafs. Schenn was selected next by Toronto, not by the Columbus Blue Jackets. The article also misstated the outcome of a trade between the Maple Leafs and the Islanders. The Maple Leafs gained the fifth pick of the first round from the Islanders, not the fourth pick.
Many low-income tenants in rent-stabilized homes are likely to be hit with a higher-than-expected increase.
Anthony Como’s razor-thin victory in a special election for a City Council seat is a victory that brings bragging rights for the Queens County Republican Party’s leadership.
The flooding that has claimed 24 lives and forced thousands to evacuate across six states continued Sunday, as the Mississippi crested in northern Missouri.
Border Patrol officials acknowledge that black recruits have often been overlooked or been difficult to attract.
The people at MoveOn.org have moved on to express contempt for all who might choose to serve their country in uniform.
Hunter Kemper out-ran Andy Potts in the race’s final leg to make the Olympic team for the third time.
A full schedule of drag races was completed on Sunday amid the shock and sadness caused by the death of the driver Scott Kalitta one day before.
Big Brown’s owners announced Sunday that they would immediately begin withdrawing all steroids and any unnecessary medications from their horses.
Despite recent disappointments on clay, the Williams sisters have rarely experienced disappointments on grass, especially not at Wimbledon.
The Bronx Zoo has opened a spectacular new series of living dioramas devoted to the distinctive ecosystems of Madagascar.
Senator Barack Obama proposed ending a legal provision that exempts crucial energy commodities from government oversight.

GONZALEZ--Joseph A., of Somers, NY, passed away Friday, June 20th, 2008 at Mount Sinai Hospital. Born on February 27th, 1926 in Buenos Aires, he was married to Nella Zorzut for 55 years until her passing in July 2007. He emigrated to the United States in 1959, received a BS from Queens College in 1968 and retired in 1989 from IBM Americas/Far East Corporation. He served as Treasurer of Council 6205 of the Knights of Columbus, in Somers, NY. He is survived by two daughters, Rosana Agostini and Liliana Gonzalez Sarro; two sons, Joseph Jr., and Daniel and six grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10:00am on Tuesday at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Croton Falls, NY.

The most popular song excerpts that people download to use as ring tones on their cellphones roughly align with top songs purchased complete for digital playlists. ''Lollipop'' by Lil Wayne, above, is No. 1 on the ring tones list, and it has risen as high as No. 2 on the digital songs ranking. ''I Kissed a Girl'' by Katy Perry has risen to No. 2 on this week's downloads chart (at right). Some ring tones remain popular. ''Low'' by Flo Rida has been on the list for 39 weeks and is currently No. 11. ''Sweet Home Alabama'' by Lynyrd Skynyrd has been on the list for 93 weeks. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Our heartfelt condolences go out to his wife, Lucy, and sons, Ross, Robert, Kenneth and Steven. Marlene G. DiChiacchio President of the Board Scott A. Nelson Headmaster HALPERIN--Richard. Our love and thoughts go out to Lucy, Ross, Robert, Stevie and Kenny. May his memory remain as a blessing. Jane, Larry, Greg, Caroline & Philip Scheinfeld HALPERIN--Richard. You were a joy to everyone who knew you and your passing is way too soon. All our love to you and your family. The Aronson's HALPERIN--Richard. We mourn the loss of our beloved friend, Richard Halperin. Always there, always ready to share and give a part of himself with complete sincerity. He was a treasure, a rare gift. We were blessed to have him in our lives. We will sorely miss our friend but gain a comfort in the knowledge that his spirit, his humor, and life lessons live on in our hearts and in our memories. Our deepest sympathies and love to Lucy, Ross, Robert, Kenneth and Steven as well as the extended Halperin and Landsman families. Philip, Gail, Jaime and Gregg Cohenca HALPERIN--Richard. To my dear friend, with great admiration, affection, and appreciation for all you have done. Maxine Bendheim HALPERIN--Richard, our heartfelt condolences to Lucy, Ross, Robbie, Kenny and Stevie on this terrible loss. Our thoughts, prayers and love are with you at this very difficult time. We will miss Richard and will hold him in our hearts forever. Lois and Andrew Zaro and Family

8 P.M. (TCM) 75TH ANNIVERSARY OF THE SCREEN ACTORS GUILDTurner Classic Movies salutes the birth of the labor union that brought stability to the lives of actors and the performers who conceived of it. This two-part tribute begins with ''Movie Crazy'' (1932), starring Harold Lloyd as a Kansas boy bamboozling his way into Hollywood. The evening continues with ''The Kennel Murder Case'' (1933), which introduced William Powell as the society sleuth Philo Vance, at 9:45; ''The Kid From Spain'' (1932), with Eddie Cantor as a Brooklyn artist who becomes one of the world's great bullfighters, at 11:15; ''The Mask of Fu Manchu'' (1932), starring SAG member No. 9, Boris Karloff, above, at 1 a.m.; ''The Last of Mrs. Cheyney'' (1937), the film that set Joan Crawford on a downward career spiral, at 2:15; and ''For Me and My Gal'' (1942), the overlooked Judy Garland classic that brought in $4.8 million on an $800,000 investment. It was also Gene Kelly's film debut. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOWMary Jo Buttafuoco talks about life after the tabloids.

BETTS--Glynne Robinson, 74, died peacefully on June 21st in New York City. She was the beloved mother of Elizabeth, William and Katherine and adored grandmother of Oliver and India Brown. An accomplished photographer and author, she published ''Writers In Residence: American Authors at Home'' in 1981. She was the co-publisher and co-owner of the Lakeville Journal of Connecticut and the Millerton News of New York from 1986-1991. We will remember and celebrate her wonderful generosity and spirit everyday. She is in our hearts forever. Donations in memory of Glynne may be made to The Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation (multiplemyeloma.org). BETTS--Glynne Robinson. For our wonderful and courageous mother, a Celtic prayer: Deep peace of the running wave to you. Deep peace of the flowing air to you. Deep peace of the great earth to you. Deep peace of the shining stars to you. Deep peace of the watching shepherds to you. Deep peace of the Son of Peace to you. Love always, Liz, Will and Kate

MacNEIL--Gail. With grace and dignity, Gail C. MacNeil, 65, of Chatham died at her home on June 21st, after a ten year battle with ovarian cancer. A Funeral Service to celebrate her life will be held at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 200 Main St., Chatham, on Wednesday, June 25th at 10:30am. Relatives and friends are invited to visit at Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main St., Chatham, on Tuesday from 2-4 and 79pm. In lieu of flowers, donations in Gail's memory may be made to Kaleidoscope of Hope Foundation, P.O. Box 1124, Madison, NJ 07940 or at www.kohnj.org. For further information or to send a condolence, go to bradleyfuneralhomes.com Born in Derby, and raised in Canterbury, England, Gail came to the U.S. in 1965 and moved to Chatham in 1971. She met her husband, David, in the fall of 1964 in Lugano, Switzerland where she was the secretary to the director of the post graduate program of the American School in Switzerland and he was a teacher in the same program. Gail was a co-founder of Kaleidoscope of Hope Foundation, a non-profit organization whose goals are to raise funds for ovarian cancer research and awareness of the disease. It was also Gail who created the ''Turn The Towns Teal'' campaign of tying teal ribbons in towns throughout the state. The purpose of the ribbons is to create awareness of ovarian cancer, and the campaign is on its way to becoming national. She was a top producing sales associate/broker for Coldwell Banker in Madison where she was the recipient of the ''Realtor of the Year'' award 2003 and the ''Humanitarian of the Year'' award in 2004 for her efforts as co-founder of the Kaleidoscope of Hope Foundation. Gail had served on the Chatham Township's Enviornmental Commission and Advisory Committee on Affordable Housing. She was a past director of the Chatham Chamber of Commerce and past director of Chatham Township League of Women Voters as well as a member of the Vestry of St. Paul's Church. Gail is survived by her husband of 42 years, David; her daughters Jocelyn McCarthy and her husband Brian, and Karen Nordmeyer and son-in-law Seth; her grandchildren Skyler, Alicia, and Mia; her sisters Jacky Wilkes and her husband Steve, and Pippa Cacciato and her husband Richie and her sister-n-law, Jane MacNeil.

The newly launched TimesPeople Beta is where The New York Times meets the social Web - think of it as all the news that's fit to share. But it's not a Timesian Facebook or MySpace: there's no fretting over "friends" to accept or reject, no navigation of the foggy realm of online etiquette. Instead, you can choose the TimesPeople members whose activity you'd like to follow: the content they recommend, the comments and reviews they post, and the ratings they give to movies, restaurants and hotels. And those interested in your recommendations can see your activity too. It's New York Times content brought to your fingertips (or rather, browser toolbar) by the readers you know.

In my recent post on the Eyrie Vineyards I complained that too many American pinot noirs are no longer versatile enough to serve as bridge wines, as they are too big and often too sweet to go with more delicate foods. Naturally, I hedged by saying exceptions abound, and of course they do. So I thought I would talk about some of the other American pinot noirs that I enjoy and that I think still strive for the classic pinot noir characteristics of finesse and elegance.

[There's a lot of interest in climate right now, but other predicted risks still loom, as well, so back we go to earthquakes.] Some of you may recall the image above, which I included with a recent post on efforts to make schools less likely to fall down in earthquakes like the one that shattered so many communities in China's Sichuan province. It is the product of research by Santiago Pujol, a structural engineer at Purdue who is focused on cutting losses from predicted earthquakes, particularly in schools. After a question from a Dot Earth reader, Dr. Pujol drew a more brightly lit variant, which you can see below.
Charter Communications, the big cable company, said Tuesday that it is suspending its plan to sell data about its customers' Web surfing to an advertising company.

As TV Decoder noted yesterday, George Carlin hosted the inaugural edition of "Saturday Night Live" in 1975. This weekend the late-night landmark will pay tribute to the comedian, who died Sunday, by broadcasting that premiere episode.
"I Survived a Japanese Game Show" premieres tonight on ABC. What's so hard about a Japanese game show, you ask?
The most popular of the Japanese game shows on YouTube is a stunt called "Human Tetris." It comes from Fuji TV's "Tunnels No Minnasan No Okage Deshita," or "Tunnels Thanks to Everybody."

As Michael Brick reports in The Times, the Austin Ice Bats of the Central Hockey League, formerly of the Western Professional Hockey League, are almost certainly dead and buried. If they do indeed pass into the icy great beyond, they will be yet another minor league team among the hundreds to have come and gone over the years. (Here is the list of defunct hockey leagues, never mind teams.)

When the new models arrive in showrooms this fall, 50 years will have passed since the apogee of the tailfin. Most automotive historians agree that the 1959 model year marked the extreme reach of the tailfin craze, which was born on the 1948 Cadillac as the fishtail.In a brief time, the tailfin became a symbol of the space age and an icon of prosperity - and excess. To mark the anniversary, the Antique Automobile Club of America Museum in Hershey, Pa., is offering the show "Fins: The Rise and Fall of the Tail Fin in American Automotive Design" through Oct. 12.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif. -- The McCain campaign sometimes makes a virtue of Senator John McCain's propensity for telling people not only what they want to hear, but also what they don't. As the cable channels that populate the television dial conclude their advance advertising sales, they have something to celebrate: they made much greater gains than the broadcast networks.

BRIEFS It's been a tough few days for Mike Myers. His movie, "The Love Guru," was skewered by this paper's movie critic and many others late last week. Over the weekend, it bombed at the box office as well. And then the criticism grew even sharper, somehow, and closer to home. On Monday, a newspaper columnist in Canada, his birthplace, decided to disown Mr. Myers on behalf of the country. The article, "Mention Mike Myers and few of us smile anymore," leads the most popular list on the National Post's Web site.

Nanotechnology holds vast potential for producing energy efficient products and processes -- from purifying water to making better solar cells. In my Business of Green column this week, I write about how the market for such products could be worth trillions of dollars in coming years.

Yahoo 's shares surged Tuesday afternoon after TechCrunch reported that Microsoft is back in talks to buy the company. Yahoo's stock was up more than 2 percent on the news.
Hillary Rodham Clinton emerged today to claim her well-paid, perk-laden consolation prize -- a return to the United States Senate, a place she has barely seen for the last 16 months.

Bloomsbury has just published "Dirty Words: A Literary Encyclopedia of Sex," edited by Ellen Sussman. We can't mention quite a few of the subjects discussed (or even show you the cover), but there are plenty we can. The book features more than 90 writers, including Stephen McCauley on "anal sex," Bliss Broyard on "one-night stand," Phillip Lopate on "duration" and Danielle Trussoni on "striptease."

Zoglin adds, "And he helped bring stand-up comedy to the very center of American culture. It has never left."

Austin Ventures, a venture capital firm managing around $3 billion across nine funds, has invested $50 million to try and create a new media franchise called Atcor Holdings.

The Massachusetts Economic Assistance Coordinating Council, which oversees government incentives for development, is expected to give its approval to a $3.5 million tax break for banking behemoth JPMorgan Chase on Wednesday, The Boston Herald reported.

Hedge funds around the world became more cautious, reducing the amount of debt they took on to buy assets by the end of last year as returns took a beating from turmoil in global credit markets, according to a study released on Monday by Greenwich Associates.

What is planned to be the final report from a watchdog group that monitors alcohol advertising concludes that progress still lags in curbing the access of young viewers to television commercials selling liquor, beer and wine.
Goldman Sachs strategists urged stock investors on Monday to "underweight" U.S. financial and consumer shares, admitting it was wrong when it upgraded both sectors just seven weeks ago.
