When the Blackstone Group went public about a year ago, Tom Wolfe, the author of "The Bonfire of the Vanities," on hand on the trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange, delivered this prophecy: "We may be witnessing the end of capitalism as we know it."
Fisher Communications shares rose 10.4 percent, to $35.17, on Monday after the company rejected an unsolicited offer to buy the television and radio station owner for about $384 million.
British gas producer BG Group launched a hostile $13.1 billion bid for Australia's Origin Energy, as it seeks to boost its position in Asia-Pacific's fast-growing gas market.

In his more than three decades on Wall Street, Leon D. Black has played many roles, including wunderkind investment banker and private equity mogul. On Monday, however, he assumed an altogether different one: defendant in a civil lawsuit.
Based on the annual report it released on Monday, The Carlyle Group is preparing for a rougher year ahead.

In the 18th century the British offered a 20,000 pound prize to anyone who figured out how to calculate longitude. More recently, Netflix offered a million dollars for improving movie recommendations on its Web site. Now Senator John McCain is suggesting a new national prize: He said Monday that if elected president he would offer $300 million to anyone who could build a better car battery.

Ticketmaster is expected to be spun off from IAC/InterActiveCorp by late July or early August and will borrow $750 million to pay a dividend to its former parent, IAC Chief Financial Officer Tom McInerney said Monday.
Tommy Hilfiger has taken its plans for a possible initial public offering off the table, and instead plans to focus on expansion after turning around its U.S. business.
AGA Medical has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of stock to raise up to $200 million.

Nokia, the world's biggest maker of mobile phones, offered to buy the 52 percent of Symbian that it doesn't own for about 264 million euros ($410 million) to gain control in the maker of operating systems for handsets.

The food company Dongwon said on Tuesday that it would buy the canned tuna company StarKist from the Del Monte Foods Company for about $300 million in the latest push by South Korean food makers for global expansion.

The European Commission on Monday opened its voluntary registry for the thousands of lobbyists and special interest organizations operating in Brussels, aiming to shed more light on a group that seeks to influence regulations on everything from computer software to greenhouse gas emissions.
American corporations reaped a $265 billion windfall thanks to a one-time tax break aimed at bringing home profits stashed overseas, according to recent government data.

A judge has dismissed several claims made by American International Group in its three-year battle to regain control of a block of its shares held by an investment fund once used mainly to compensate A.I.G. executives.

Technology billionaire and philanthropist Henry Samueli pleaded guilty Monday to a felony charge of lying to regulators about his role in an alleged plot to secretly reward his Broadcom employees by manipulating stock options.
In a tribute to George Carlin on today's Op-Ed Page, Jerry Seinfeld recalls the bane of his generation of comedians -- "Carlin already did it":
Trans-Atlantic stock market operator NYSE Euronext said it would buy a 25 percent stake in the Doha Securities Market for $250 million, boosting its access to the fast-growing Middle East economy.
A South Korean high court on Tuesday cleared U.S. private equity house Lone Star of manipulating the stock price of a former credit card unit of Korea Exchange Bank, rejecting an earlier ruling.

Small-business owners explore the possibilities of variable pay for employees. Should workers take some of the risks in return for sharing in a company’s success?

The acquisition of the canned tuna company StarKist from the Del Monte Foods Company for about $300 million in the latest push by South Korean food makers for global expansion.

BOSTON (AP) — Red Sox pitcher Curt Schilling could be throwing off a mound by January after having surgery on his shoulder Monday. That keeps him on target to pitch by the middle of next season if he decides to return.
Georgia came from three runs behind to defeat Fresno State, 7-6, on Monday night in Game 1 of the College World Series finals.
Miss Goodman combined a dancer’s grace, a strawberry blond mane and exquisitely timed scatter-brained humor to create television legends.
In manager Jerry Manuel’s first home game the dreadful Mariners cruised past the Mets thanks to an unlikely grand slam by Seattle pitcher Felix Hernandez who previously had only one career hit.
One week after Mets’ manager Willie Randolph’s dismissal, Fred Wilpon, the team’s owner, finally spoke about the decision.
The 12-man squad could raise some questions about its lack of balance, with only one true center in Dwight Howard and two power forwards in Carlos Boozer and Chris Bosh.
Dan Haren was dominant over seven shutout innings, limiting Boston to two hits and outpitching Josh Beckett in the Arizona Diamondbacks’ 2-1 victory over the host Red Sox on Monday night.

Carolina Panthers receiver Dwayne Jarrett pleaded guilty to driving while impaired, minutes before he was scheduled to go on trial. Jarrett surrendered his driver’s license and was ordered to pay $420 in court costs and perform 24 hours of community service. Jarrett will enter the first stage of the N.F.L.’s substance-abuse program, meaning he will be subject to more frequent tests for drugs and alcohol.

Two former Duquesne basketball players have sued the university over a 2006 shooting that injured them and three teammates. Kojo Mensah and Shawn James accuse the university of not providing adequate security at an on-campus dance after which they and three teammates were shot, according to federal lawsuits filed in United States District Court in Pittsburgh. Mensah and James also accused Coach Ron Everhart of forcing them to practice, work out and play before they had recovered.

Candace Parker received the Honda-Broderick Cup as the nation’s top female college athlete. Parker led Tennessee to its second consecutive N.C.A.A. title in April, then was drafted No. 1 by the Los Angeles Sparks.

The Giants waived the backup quarterback Jared Lorenzen, a little more than a month before the opening of training camp. Lorenzen’s status has been a question mark since the Giants signed the veteran David Carr as a free agent and drafted Andre Woodson, who, like Lorenzen, played at Kentucky. With Eli Manning and Anthony Wright also on the roster, the move left the Giants with five quarterbacks.

The International Olympic Committee said the barred sprinter Justin Gatlin, whose four-year doping ban was recently upheld by the Court of Arbitration for Sport, was not eligible to compete in the Beijing Olympics regardless of a ruling by a federal court judge in Florida.

New Orleans guard Rasual Butler faces charges after reportedly flashing a loaded gun near a Miami area nightclub. A witness told investigators that Butler pulled out a gun near a South Beach club early Monday, according to a Miami Beach police report. He was sitting in an S.U.V. when officers arrived and found a loaded gun in the vehicle. Butler faces charges of carrying a concealed firearm and improperly displaying a firearm.

The Denver Nuggets will suspend forward Carmelo Anthony for the first two games of the 2008-9 season because of his arrest on suspicion of driving under the influence of alcohol. Anthony was arrested on April 14 and is scheduled to appear in court in Denver on Tuesday. The suspension came the day Anthony was named to the United States men’s basketball team for the Beijing Games.
The European Union approved new sanctions against Iran, imposing additional financial and travel restrictions on a list of Iranian individuals and companies.
Momin Khawaja also used computers at Canada’s Department of Foreign Affairs to exchange messages about the detonators with fellow conspirators in Britain.
President Nicolas Sarkozy also tempered his address by assuring Israel that it could count on France’s support in halting Iran’s nuclear program.
Stojan Zupljanin, who is accused of atrocities against Bosnian Muslims and Croats, made his first appearance in The Hague before the United Nations tribunal that will try him.
Heavy sectarian fighting between groups supporting and opposing the government in the northern Lebanese city of Tripoli continued for a second day.
Militants ambushed troops patrolling in the mountains of eastern Afghanistan, prompting a gun battle and airstrikes that left about 55 insurgents dead.
Social Democrats, who share in Germany’s governing coalition, and opposition parties called on the U.S. to remove all nuclear weapons stored in military bases in the country.
A Greek industrialist who was kidnapped two weeks ago was freed unharmed after his family paid an unspecified sum in ransom.
New York City’s recreational experiment that will convert 6.9 miles of Manhattan into a car-free park during parts of three Saturdays in August originated in the Andes.
Charles E. Schumer is leading a group of Democratic senators to block a set of contentious no-bid oil contracts that Iraq has decided to award to the Western oil giants.
Lai Ho, 57, of Brooklyn, was killed and four people were injured after a commercial dump truck rammed a parked bus on Canal Street.
Peyton and Archie Manning spoke on Monday to a crowd of about 400 MasterCard employees that included everyone from a mailroom clerk to the chief executive.
The N.B.A.’s attempt to recoup nearly $1.4 million in restitution from the disgraced referee Tim Donaghy is “a transparent attempt at witness intimidation,” his lawyer said Monday.
NATIONAL.
Big Brown’s co-owner rejected the notion that steroid withdrawal played a role in the colt’s last-place finish in the Belmont Stakes, saying a dislodged shoe on his right hind hoof was a factor.
Nawaz Sharif had been barred from running in the February parliamentary elections because of a conviction on charges of hijacking.

The death of the man selected by Republican leaders on Staten Island as their candidate for a vacated Congressional seat has once again plunged party leaders into uncertainty.
The 19-hole playoff in San Diego between Tiger Woods and Rocco Mediate cast the sport’s giant against one of its jolly journeymen.

The transfer of Myanmar’s junta to Naypyidaw, a relatively remote location, has drained the country’s finances and widened the gulf between the rulers and the ruled.
Huntsman Corporation accuses Apollo Management and two of the private equity firm’s founders of interfering in its $10.6 billion merger with an Apollo company chemical maker.

Tina Ramirez, the founder of Ballet Hispanico, announced Monday that she was hanging up her shoes after 38 years as artistic director. “I am planning to continue as a roving ambassador and spokesperson for the company and school and to carry forward my work as an advocate for dance education,” she said in a news release. Ms. Ramirez, above right, was awarded the National Medal of Arts for in 2005 for her work over the years. She has said that her father, a bullfighter, first taught her to dance. The unifying element, to her, has always been the music. “I wanted to show who Hispanics are,” she once told The New York Times. “Our culture. Why we move the way we do. Our music. There is so much that unites us, like language and love of home and family. Yet there’s so much variety within the given.”.

In the wave of buyouts and layoffs hitting newspapers this season, The Kansas City Star has decided it can no longer afford a classical music critic. Paul Horsley, who took the critic’s job eight years ago, was quoted on the Web site MusicalAmerica.com as saying, “I think it was a very ‘corporate’ decision.” He added, “I think they eliminated the beat they thought they could most easily farm out.” Kansas City’s orchestra, opera and ballet companies are said to be organizing a formal protest. The newspaper’s owner, the McClatchy Company, cut 1,400 people from its workforce last week because of declining revenues. Howard C. Weaver, vice president for news, sent a memo to the staff saying that across the company, 310 to 320 newsroom positions would be cut.

Regional theaters aren’t the only cultural places falling on hard times. Cody’s Bookstore in Berkeley, Calif., a literary lighthouse for more than 50 years, closed for good on Friday. Yohan Inc., a Japanese distributor and retailer, bought the store in 2005, and Hirosho Kagawa, Yohan’s president, said in a statement posted on the bookstore’s Web site, codysbooks.com: “Unfortunately, my current business is not strong enough or rich enough to support Cody’s. Of course, the store has been suffering from low sales and the deficit exceeds our ability to service it.” During the 1960s the bookstore was an outpost of the Free Speech Movement. Mr. Kagawa was one of the many writers and readers who fell in love with the store. This is a “heartbreaking moment,” he said, adding, “It means so much to me and I apologize to the people who have supported Cody’s for not being able to keep this landmark independent bookstore open.”.

Sacha Baron Cohen, below, the irreverent creator of “Borat,” was one of 105 people asked to join the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Monday, Agence France-Presse reported. Also on the list was Marion Cotillard, who won an Oscar this year for her portrayal of Édith Piaf in “La Vie en Rose”; Josh Brolin, who starred in “No Country for Old Men” and is playing President Bush in Oliver Stone’s forthcoming film “W”; the martial arts master Jet Li; the director Jason Reitman; and Diablo Cody, the screenwriter of the Oscar-winning comedy “Juno.”.

NBC’s coverage of the United States Olympic Trials gave the network a boost in the ratings on Sunday, making it No. 1 for the night among adults 18 to 49. But that was not enough to pull NBC ahead among total viewers. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the women’s gymnastics contenders put NBC in the lead in the 18-to-49 demographic during the 7 and 8 p.m. hours despite averaging only a modest total audience of 6.2 million. That tally fell short of CBS’s programming in those time slots: “60 Minutes” (8.9 million) followed by “Million Dollar Password” (8.3 million), helped CBS edge past NBC for the night in total viewers. NBC’s “Dateline” ranked first during the 9 and 10 p.m. time slots with 8.2 million viewers, outpacing CBS’s repeats of “Criminal Minds” (7.3 million) and “The Unit” (6.9 million). ABC finished third for the night with a lineup of all repeats. Fox was fourth, although it fared particularly well with the 18-to-49 set. Fox’s “Family Guy” rerun at 9 earned the night’s highest ratings in that age group but just 5.5 million total viewers.

The prizewinning British author Ian McEwan has caused a minor uproar by saying that he despised “Islamism” because of its intolerance of homosexuality and its limits on women’s freedom, The Telegraph of London reported. Mr. McEwan, right, known for his many novels including “Enduring Love” and “Atonement,” made the comments to the Italian newspaper Corriere Della Sera while defending his friend the writer Martin Amis from charges of racism. Mr. Amis has written that people who look as though they are from the Middle East should be strip-searched and possibly deported. Mr. McEwan said, “As soon as a writer expresses an opinion against Islamism, immediately someone on the left leaps to his feet and claims that because the majority of Muslims are dark skinned, he who criticizes it is racist.” He added: “This is logically absurd and morally unacceptable. Martin is not a racist. And I myself despise Islamism, because it wants to create a society that I detest, based on religious belief, on a text, on lack of freedom for women, intolerance towards homosexuality and so on — we know it well.” He called fundamentalist Christians with similar views “equally absurd,” though at least they are not trying to kill people. Mr. McEwan’s words drew criticism from the Muslim Council of Britain.

Bill Keller, an evangelist based in Florida, runs ''Liveprayer.com,'' an Internet call-in program. BIRNBAUM--Leonard, died suddenly on June 21, 2008 at the age of 90. He lived in New York City and Hillsdale, NY. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania, Class of 1939 and then served as a Lieutenant Commander for the United States Navy in the Pacific during WWII. He was a pioneer in the wine and spirits industry along with his wife Bonny, who he was married to for 47 years until her death on February 20, 2004. He was the father of Richard, of New York City, Jane of Norwalk, CT and Peter of Bernardsville, NJ and grandfather to Kate, Tim, Liz, Sam and Anna. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the University of Pennsylvania Athletic Department.

HALPERIN--Richard. To my dear friend, with great admiration, affection, and appreciation for all you have done. Maxine Bendheim HALPERIN--Richard, was oneof the pillars of Westchester County, a place he truly loved. He grew up here with his beloved sister Marcia, he lived here with his caring, sensitive and soulful wife, Lucy and he and Lucy raised their four adored boys, Ross, Robert, Steve and Kenneth, here in Westchester. Richard was a person who gave a lot to his friends and took very little in return. He always seemed to be happiest making others smile. Filled with common sense, a great passion for work, a twinkle in his eye, a willingness to laugh at himself and a big bounce in his step, he was truly one of a kind. Richard left everything he touched better than he found it, including friends like us. Jon and Barbara Landau HALPERIN--Richard. Boston University, its College of Communication, and College of General Studies share in the heavy grief of this sudden and tragic loss, and our prayers and heartfelt sympathies are with Lucy, Ross, Robert, Stevie, Kenny and Marsha. Richard's leadership infused us with optimism, energy, and bold ideas. It was impossible to know Richard and not be permanently and positively touched; his legacy will endure in all of us.

PRITZ--Florence. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our devoted longtime Women's Auxillary Board member and cherished congregant, Florence Pritz. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Dr. David M. Posner, Senior Rabbi Dr. Ronald B. Sobel, Senior Rabbi Emeritus Marcia Waxman, President Frances A. Hess, President, Women's Auxillary

GROSSMAN--Sylvia. Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn Heights, NY mourns the passing of our beloved member, Sylvia. Our heartfelt condolences to her husband and family. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas Susan Zelman, President GROSSMAN--Sylvia, on June 22, in her 90th year, beloved wife of Irwin; devoted mother of William, Edward (Rochelle), and Richard; loving grandmother of David, and dear sister of Dorothy Margolin. Attorney, former county official, and tireless volunteer, her community activities were as extensive as her years. She served Nassau County as Deputy County Attorney and Executive Assistant to County Executive Eugene Nickerson. She was President of the Roslyn Board of Education; member of the Town of North Hempstead Board of Ethics; a founder of Temples Sinai and Beth Sholom in Roslyn, Roslyn Chapter of Hadassah, Roslyn section National Council of Jewish Women, Roslyn Glen Cove League of Women Voters, Better Roslyn Association, and Community Advocates; director of the Visiting Nurse Association of Long Island, president of the Roslyn Visiting Nurse Association, and beloved ''Cake Lady'' of Ronald McDonald House. Among her many awards and honors: Women's Roll of Honor, Town of North Hempstead, and Junior League of Long Island's Volunteer Merit Award. She was truly a ''Woman of Valor''. Service on June 24, at noon, at Temple Beth Sholom, 401 Roslyn Road, Roslyn Heights, NY 11577. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Temple Beth Sholom. GROSSMAN--Sylvia. Shelter Rock Tennis Club mourns her loss and extends sympathy to her husband Irwin and family.

Elizabeth Edwards, the wife of John Edwards, the former presidential candidate, on Monday questioned whether Senator Barack Obama should have opted out of the public campaign financing system, but she stopped short of saying that he should not have done so. Mrs. Edwards said that she thought voters did not care about the money but that they would care if he appeared to have said one thing earlier and was saying something else now (as Mr. Obama had done). She then quickly noted that Senator John McCain was in no position to question any change of heart by Mr. Obama because he himself had switched positions on several issues.

A senior adviser to Senator John McCain apologized on Monday after he was quoted as saying in a magazine interview that another terrorist attack in the United States would ''be a big advantage'' for Mr. McCain in the coming election. The adviser, Charlie Black, was quoted in an interview with Fortune magazine describing the assassination of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan in December as an ''unfortunate event,'' but adding that it highlighted Mr. McCain's knowledge and ability to talk about it.

The Service Employees International Union has been very successful in unionizing tens of thousands of janitors and doormen in New York City, and now it has set its sights on unionizing — and winning improved wages and benefits for — tens of thousands of security guards in the city. That bill empowering the New York State Dental Association to oust any chapter that violates certain undefined standards passed the State Legislature on Tuesday. And none too soon. So confident was the state association of its clout in Albany that, before the bill even got to the floor, the executive committee of the board of governors scheduled a special meeting last Friday to do just that — remove the Manhattan group originally chartered in the 19th century and replace it with a new association incorporated this year.

My Thursday column, the last from my Middle East swing, is about Iraqi refugees and their destabilizing influence in Jordan in particular. The number of Americans with diabetes increased by 15 percent in two years to 24 million, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. About 8 percent of the population now has the disease, mainly Type 2 diabetes, which is linked to obesity and sedentary living, the agency said in a report using data from 2007. A quarter of people ages 60 and older had diabetes, the agency said. The number of people worldwide with diabetes will double to 366 million by 2030, according to the World Health Organization, which calls the disease an epidemic. Most people with diabetes have resistance to insulin, which the body uses to convert blood sugar to energy. The C.D.C. report was its first update of the prevalence of diabetes since 2005, when it reported that about 21 million Americans had the disease.

Five sex offenders filed a lawsuit claiming that a tough new state law that bans them from volunteering at churches also robs them of their right to participate in religious worship. The lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court in Rome, says the law effectively “criminalizes fundamental religious activities” for sex offenders and bars them from serving as a choir member, a secretary, an accountant or in any other role with a religious organization. It is the latest of a growing list of legal challenges to Georgia’s sex offender statute, which was hailed by supporters in 2006 as one of the toughest in the nation but has since been the focus of lawsuits contending that it is far too restrictive. The main part of the measure bans sex offenders from living, working or loitering within 1,000 feet of just about anywhere children gather. The original version of the law banned sex offenders from working at churches, but when it was retooled this year supporters added a provision also banning them from volunteering at houses of worship. Doing so could risk a penalty of 10 to 30 years in prison.

A wrecking ball slammed into one of three towering sugar silos as Imperial Sugar cleared the site of an explosion at its refinery in Port Wentworth that killed 13 workers and injured dozens more. Imperial Sugar began demolition over the weekend and plans to rebuild the silos and adjacent sugar packaging building that were destroyed in the Feb. 7 explosion and fire. Demolition was expected to continue until next week. An initial investigation traced the explosion to sugar dust that ignited like gunpowder in a basement area beneath the silos, where sugar was loaded onto conveyor belts and transported to the packaging area. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration and the Chemical Safety Board are still investigating.

Fire crews joined aircraft from neighboring states to battle hundreds of lightning-caused wildfires across Northern California. The blazes have scorched tens of thousands of acres and forced hundreds of residents to flee, though few buildings have been destroyed, said Daniel Berlant, a spokesman for the state’s Department of Forestry and Fire Protection. A blaze that had charred nearly six square miles in the Shasta-Trinity National Forest about 160 miles north of Sacramento was a threat to about 1,200 homes and several youth camps. Mendocino County alone had 110 fires, with just 17 contained. In Monterey County, a fire near the coast south of Big Sur was only 3 percent contained.

Expanding its drive to preserve Modernist landmarks, the World Monuments Fund has awarded a prize to two German architects who restored a Bauhaus-era school, above, for the German trade union confederation. Winfried Brenne and Franz Jaschke, both of Berlin, are the first recipients of the Knoll Modernism Prize, established to recognize architects and designers who rejuvenate Modern structures. The pair re-exposed elements of the 1928-30 ADGB Trade Union School in Bernau, Germany, that were hidden or removed during the East German era, like glass brick, stainless steel and the original bright red color of the steel framing. The jury was led by Barry Bergdoll, chief curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, and included the architectural historians Kenneth Frampton, Jean-Louis Cohen and Dietrich Neumann. The prize consists of a $10,000 honorarium and a limited-edition chair made by Knoll.

In a low-rated Monday night of network television, filled mostly with summer repeats and reality fare, CBS, ABC and Fox finished in a virtual dead heat for first place in the prime-time ratings. CBS eked out a victory as the most-watched network, according to Nielsen’s estimates, earning the night’s top ratings at 9 with a rerun of “Two and a Half Men,” which attracted nine million viewers. CBS also led during the 10 o’clock hour with a repeat of “CSI: Miami” (8.2 million), which easily outpaced ABC’s struggling reality show “The Mole” (4.1 million). During the 8 and 9 o’clock hours, ABC’s two-hour installment of “The Bachelorette” averaged a competitive 7.5 million viewers, leading during both time slots among adults 18 to 49. ABC and CBS tied for first place for the night in that demographic, just slightly ahead of Fox, which broadcast repeats of “Bones” (6.4 million) at 8 and “House” (7.4 million) at 9. NBC was a distant fourth for the night, drawing 4.9 million viewers for “American Gladiators” at 8, followed by “Nashville Star” (6.1 million) from 9 to 11.

Boy George, below, has canceled his American summer tour after being denied a visa by the United States because he is facing trial in London in the fall, his management said in a statement. He had been scheduled to show up in New York in August for the Department of Sanitation’s annual family day. (Boy George cleaned the streets for five days in 2006 as court-ordered community service after falsely reporting a break-in to his New York home. He wanted to give a concert for department workers.) The statement said that Boy George was “devastated” and that “George is astounded at the decision and is having lawyers here in the States look at it in the hope that someone will change their mind.” Boy George, whose real name is George O’Dowd, is facing trial in November on a charge of falsely imprisoning a man. The statement said, “George has not been convicted of anything in London, and there is a presumption in the Western world of innocence until proven guilty.”.

After more than three decades as the editor of Art in America magazine, Elizabeth C. Baker, a powerful voice in the contemporary-art world, is stepping down, the magazine said on Tuesday. The change comes shortly after a shake-up in the magazine’s ownership. Peter M. Brant, a newsprint magnate and art collector, took over Brant Publications, the magazine’s publisher, in January after buying out the 50 percent stake owned by his former wife, Sandra Brant. Mr. Brant appointed Fabien Baron and Glenn O’Brien as joint editorial directors of Art in America and the company’s two other publications, Interview and The Magazine Antiques. Ms. Baker, known as Betsy, took over the magazine in 1974. Under her leadership Art in America grew from a bimonthly publication with a circulation of around 45,000 to a monthly with a circulation of more than 75,000, featuring the writing of many influential critics. Marcia E. Vetrocq, who joined Art in America in 1998 as a senior editor, will take over as editor. Ms. Baker will become editor at large in charge of special projects, which will include book publishing and Web site development.

Charles Wadsworth, the director of Spoleto Festival USA’s chamber music series for more than 30 years, has announced that he will retire in 2009, ArtsJournal reported. Mr. Wadsworth, who turns 80 this year, has organized music for the festival for 50 consecutive seasons, beginning with Gian Carlo Menotti’s Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy. “We will miss Charles and look forward to celebrating his birthday and his tremendous artistic contributions,” said Paula Edwards, a spokeswoman for the American festival.

For fans of “The Sopranos” who can’t get enough, HBO Video is releasing “The Sopranos: The Complete Series” on Nov. 11. The limited-edition DVD set — weighing in at 10 pounds — will cost $399.99. The 30-disc collection includes an interview between Alec Baldwin and the show’s creator, David Chase; a roundtable with cast members titled “Supper With the Sopranos”; and 16 scenes that did not appear on television. Also included are three soundtracks.

HALPERIN--Richard, was one of the pillars of Westchester County, a place he truly loved. He grew up here with his beloved sister Marcia, he lived here with his caring, sensitive and soulful wife, Lucy and he and Lucy raised their four adored boys, Ross, Robert, Steve and Kenneth, here in Westchester. Richard was a person who gave a lot to his friends and took very little in return. He always seemed to be happiest making others smile. Filled with common sense, a great passion for work, a twinkle in his eye, a willingness to laugh at himself and a big bounce in his step, he was truly one of a kind. Richard left everything he touched better than he found it, including friends like us. Jon and Barbara Landau

Since he became the all-but-certain Republican nominee this year, Senator John McCain has traveled to Iraq, Jordan, Israel, Britain and France (on the taxpayer's dime) and to Canada (on his campaign's). Next week, Mr. McCain will travel to two more places without Electoral College votes: Colombia and Mexico. ''I want to go to Colombia as it is a vital ally in our struggle against the scourge of drugs,'' Mr. McCain said Tuesday at a campaign stop in Riverside, Calif., praising Plan Colombia, the American antidrug program that has sent more than $5 billion in aid since the 1990s. He also affirmed his support for a free trade agreement with Colombia.

Here is something you might not know about Senator Barack Obama: His musical tastes are pretty mainstream. His reading list is, well, a little dark. In an interview with Rolling Stone magazine to be published on Wednesday, Mr. Obama revealed that his iPod was full of dozens of selections from, top to bottom, Bob Dylan, Sheryl Crow, Jay-Z and Yo-Yo Ma. (Joining perhaps every other Democratic politician alive, he also confessed a deep love for Bruce Springsteen.)

PORK on Fire. This contender for spiciest dish in the city should draw heat-seeking chowhounds to Rhong-Tiam, a restaurant that opened in Greenwich Village in March. But the timid shouldn't be turned off: Rhong-Tiam also explores the complexities of Thai dishes that have nothing to do with heat. But first, Pork on Fire ($13). It's not so much a dish as a session: an hour spent suspended exquisitely between pleasure and pain, craving and fear. Lemon grass, ginger, kaffir lime leaves and whole basil are fried into a powerfully fragrant carpet of crisp, aromatic leaves over bits of ginger, garlic and pork. Lashings of seared green chilies give it heat. But there are also floral, herbal and sweet flavors.

The New York City health department plans to announce today an ambitious three-year effort to give an H.I.V. test to every adult living in the Bronx, which has a far higher death rate from AIDS than any other borough. As Anemona Hartocollis reports in a front-page article, the campaign will begin with a push to make the voluntary testing routine in emergency rooms and storefront clinics, where city officials say that cumbersome consent procedures required by state law have deterred doctors from offering the tests.

Updated, 2:45 p.m. | “New York City Waterfalls,” Olafur Eliasson‘s $15.5 million quartet of temporary cascades dotting the New York Harbor, formally opened on Thursday morning with a ceremony at South Street Seaport and a publicity blitz by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who criss-crossed four morning television programs to tout the installation.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, whose advocacy against illegal gun trafficking has been a centerpiece of his political identity, responded cautiously to the Supreme Court’s ruling this morning that the United States Constitution protects an individual’s right to have a gun, not just the right of the states to maintain militias.Trying to portray the ruling as largely theoretical, the mayor said the ruling would not jeopardize the work of his coalition, Mayors Against Illegal Guns, to advocate for stricter gun-control laws.

As if there weren’t enough distractions for taxi riders in New York, VeriFone Holdings, whose screens are in half of the city’s 13,000 cabs, says that programming from People.com and others will be added for the enjoyment of back seat jockeys trying to get from Point A to Point B. In addition to People.com, the celebrity news site, passengers will be able to see content from PMbuzz.com, which provides information on New York night life, and Disney Broadway, which brings Disney classics to the stage. Riders can already watch news from WABC-TV (Channel 7), and scan information from AccuWeather, Reuters and the Zagat Survey on the 10.4-inch touch-screen monitors.

In comparison with all American women, women in New York State are worse off financially than two decades ago, with more of them below the poverty line, according to a new report [pdf]. More than one of every seven women in the state was poor in 2005, compared with about one in eight nationwide, the report said. Among the states, New York ranked 40th in the share of women living above the poverty line, a decline from its 30th place spot in 1989, according to the study released on Thursday by the Institute for Women’s Policy Research.

EUGENE, Ore. -- The U.S. Olympic track and field trials (and the U.S. Olympic swimming trials, too) are the most cutthroat in the world. No track and field athlete gets a free pass to the United States Olympic team. Every runner, jumper and thrower must finish in the top three here or sit at home and watch on television what might have been.

EUGENE, Ore. -- The United States Olympic track and field trials will begin Friday in the city that grandly calls itself Track Town, USA. In truth, it is entitled to that title because no other site in the nation treats the sport with so much reverence and enthusiasm.

Jose Reyes mentioned the World Series in the Mets' clubhouse on Wednesday night. Really, he did. But he wasn't talking about the mediocre Mets regrouping and getting there this season. Reyes was discussing this weekend's series with the Yankees.

I once exited a creative meeting in Paris with Hermès' in-house perfumer, Jean-Claude Ellena, and heard him make a simple comment. Ellena had presented an iteration of the perfume he was working on to the creative team. The perfume was "not there yet," but, they all agreed, "Ça sent bon." It smells good. In the hallway, Ellena repeated it with evident relief. As long as he could get them to "Ça sent bon," he said, he knew he was going in the right direction.

The annual event at which privileged young ladies were presented to the Queen, kicking off "coming out" season, stopped 50 years ago, in 1958. But, this year, you can relive those last gasps of the debutante era, at a fascinating exhibit at Kensington Palace in London.

Medicine | The story of a woman who "scratched through her skull during the night-and all the way into her brain" lends urgency to this puzzle: What is an itch and why do we scratch the darn thing so much? Plenty of non-skin conditions can cause itching. The latest understanding of sensation suggests new treatments based on the careful manipulation of our perceptions. -- New Yorker

"After a regular season eviscerated by a writers' strike and with a potential actors' strike looming, the broadcast networks don't need another summer of dissed content while cable channels make further advances (and money) with fresh scripted shows," Bill Carter reports in today's New York Times.

There is a basic aspect of cooking that makes it one of the most enjoyable experiences in life; that's the process itself. (Which is why I firmly believe that "Joy of Cooking" is the best possible cookbook title, even though it's the darned competition.) And though I experience this almost daily, it occurs to me that I don't write about it enough here: it's too obvious to me (maybe it's too obvious to you), but I hope it's evident. (I know Ed does a good job of showing his joy.)

Sam Bowie. Darko Milicic. The names strike fear into the hearts of N.B.A. general managers everywhere. Both have become shorthand for colossal missteps on draft night.

The report today is that Anheuser Busch is going to reject the InBev offer. InBev will now have to decide whether it will launch a consent solicitation to remove all of the Anheuser directors. This can be done at any time. Alternatively, at the request of 25% of Anheuser's shareholders a special meeting of Anheuser shareholders can be held. So, InBev can also go this route and remove the Anheuser directors at the special meeting if they can get enough shareholder support for it to be called. I suspect that if InBev does attempt to remove and replace the Anheuser directors, InBev will arrange a consent solicitation rather than attempting to call a special meeting: it is quicker.

It is nothing more than shrimp in tomato sauce, a combination that is served over pasta all the time. But by varying the spices, using seasonings are from the other side of the Mediterranean, you can transform the common into the exotic.

Marshall Faulk hasn’t let retirement stop him from playing with his hometown New Orleans Saints. And free agent quarterback Daunte Culpepper says he’s throwing long with the Dallas Cowboys. Something tells me that’s not exactly what Wade Philips and Tony Romo have in mind for next season.

It’ll be years before we can declare with full-throated authority the winners and losers of tonight’s draft, yet one thing is already certain: the lives of the lottery picks will change fully and immediately. Basketball executives can only hope that their draft pick manages the transition as well as Amare Stoudemire, whose background didn’t exactly portend smooth sailing. Stoudemire entered the 2002 draft straight out of a high school (he attended six of them) and with a single mom who had been in and out of jail. Even after the Suns drafted him, the team “behaved as if Stoudemire might surface on the police blotter without full-time baby-sitting and remedial input,” Peter de Jonge wrote in “The Leap of His Life” for The Times Magazine. “Seemingly oblivious to all this attention, Stoudemire came in and took care of business, dunking as mercilessly on the heads of N.B.A. All-Stars as he had on overmatched schoolboys... He organized his life around simple routines, chilling on his couch after practice, napping before game and limiting his night life to trips to the mall for ’something to chew on’ at the Cheesecake Factory.”.

PORTLAND — Twenty-eight years ago, when the United States Olympic track and field trials were last held at Hayward Field on the University of Oregon campus in Eugene, earning one of the three slots on the American team was a validation in itself -- the equivalent of a mayoral candidate in Baltimore winning the Democratic primary. Just as the victorious politician was a shoo-in in the general election, the winning athlete had already proved herself among the best in the world. Now that the trials have returned to Eugene, by contrast, America has long since ceded domination of distance running to the Africans. And in events where American athletes still flourish -- the sprints and jumps -- doping has all but destroyed public confidence. In 2008, most elite American track-and-field performers are thrilled to get to the point where they’re suspected of juicing.

Central Park’s 843 acres provide runners with nearly limitless options. “So why in the name of Frederick Law Olmsted do so many choose to run in circles on the 6.1-mile asphalt road looping the park?” Liz Robbins writes in The Times today. “Because runners are creatures of habit. The workout is the thing, peace often found in the rhythm of repetition and the exploration of personal limits, rather than the surrounding natural space. Efficiency is of utmost concern.”.
Astros pitcher Shawn Chacon was suspended after reportedly grabbing General Manager Ed Wade by the neck and throwing him to the ground.
An apartment fire in Midtown Manhattan left an 83-year-old man dead on Wednesday evening, officials said.
This year Saudi authorities have arrested and detained 520 people suspected of having ties to Al Qaeda, the Interior Ministry said.
Omar Minaya’s decision to give a four-year contract to a 32-year-old whose legs have deteriorated does not seem shrewd these days.
Joba Chamberlain overwhelmed the Pittsburgh Pirates for six and two-thirds innings Wednesday in a victory at PNC Park.
The Mets rebounded from two losses to the worst team in baseball, the Seattle Mariners, with a pair of home runs by David Wright.

Mayor Sheila Dixon of Baltimore criticized state prosecutors and the news media in her first comments since acknowledging she had been in a relationship with a major developer whose projects she supported as City Council president. The news media have acted as “judge and jury,” even though she has not been charged, and the Office of the State Prosecutor has leaked information, Ms. Dixon said, but she is forbidden to respond publicly because of the two-year investigation into city spending practices. Ms. Dixon, a Democrat, issued a statement Monday confirming that she had been in a “personal relationship” in late 2003 and early 2004 with Ronald H. Lipscomb, a developer who owns Doracon Contracting. Prosecutors said they were investigating possible bribery, perjury and misconduct in office. The authorities raided Ms. Dixon’s home last week and seized numerous boxes, and a grand jury began hearing testimony this week.

A federal judge refused to order an overhaul of the Department of Veterans Affairs’ health care system, saying veterans groups who had sued for the changes should take their case elsewhere. The judge, Samuel Conti of Federal District Court, ruled that the lawsuit was “misdirected” and that the veterans should instead ask Congress, the head of the Veterans Administration and the federal court in Washington, D.C., to improve the system. Veterans groups had sued Veterans Affairs, alleging that its mental health care and benefits award system were flawed. A spokesman for Veterans Affairs, Phil Budahn, said the agency was “pleased” with the ruling. Gordon Erspamer, a lawyer for the veterans group, said he would appeal the decision.

A grand jury in Eldorado opened its investigation into a polygamist sect accused of forcing under-age girls into marriage and motherhood. One witness subpoenaed to testify is a 16-year-old girl who denies state claims that she was married at 15 and had a child soon after. She has asked for a new lawyer, saying her court-appointed lawyer is lying about her. Grand jury proceedings are supposed to be secret, but news of the meeting and the girl’s subpoena have been disclosed in other proceedings. The girl is a daughter of Warren Jeffs, considered a prophet by members of the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

A million acres of public land near Grand Canyon would be off limits to new uranium mining under a declaration adopted by a House committee. Tapping a rarely used provision, the panel, the House Natural Resources Committee, voted 20 to 2 to stop any new claims to uranium on lands adjacent to Grand Canyon National Park for up to three years. Supporters of the measure, which was advanced by Representative Raúl M. Grijalva, Democrat of Arizona, said a rush of claims to mine for uranium for proposed nuclear power plants threatened the landscape. A spokesman for the Interior Department said the department would weigh its next steps, given that a 1983 Justice Department opinion found similar resolutions unconstitutional.
Tribune Company is exploring the possible sale of its headquarters on the Magnificent Mile in Chicago and buildings in Los Angeles.
An Internet oversight agency is considering the first sweeping changes in the network’s addressing system since its creation 25 years ago.
A wildfire swept through the outskirts of Athens, burning one of the city’s last forests.
One in five adults in Europe have used marijuana or related drugs like hashish, and 13 million Europeans had used cannabis in the past month, the European Union’s drug agency said.
A Spanish parliamentary committee opened the door for Spain’s legislature to become the first national one to call for such rights for nonhumans.
The lower house of Parliament approved a bill that would take a key step in the government’s efforts to avoid a collapse of a pension system strained by an aging population.
Seven Maori tribes signed New Zealand’s largest-ever settlement over grievances arising from the loss of lands and fisheries during European settlement in the 19th century.
Tuareg-led rebels in Niger said they had released four French hostages unharmed to the Red Cross, three days after the rebels seized them in the northern part of the country.
Nike reported a 12 percent rise in quarterly profit, helped by international growth, but weakness in the United States sent its shares down about 5 percent.
The home-goods retailer Bed Bath & Beyond posted a better-than-expected quarterly profit as sales rose 6 percent.
After early speculation that the Knicks might move up in Thursday’s draft, the latest indications are that the team is in discussions to move down.
Hoboken, N.J., is an economic success but its governance is an unholy mess.
Jerry Manuel said he is not carrying a grudge against the umpire who ejected him in Tuesday’s game.
A Virginia Beach hairdresser has auctioned off the chance to be a bridesmaid in her April 2009 wedding on eBay. The winning bid was $5,700.
Officials are planning an ambitious effort to give an H.I.V. test to every adult living in the Bronx.

Jockey Jeremy Rose apologized Wednesday for striking his mount in the head with a whip, a day after he was given a six-month suspension at Delaware Park. Rose, who won the 2005 Preakness and Belmont Stakes aboard Afleet Alex, was suspended for striking Appeal to the City in a race Monday. The horse had some hemorrhaging around one eye. “I want everyone to know that this was an accident and not an intentional act on my part,” Rose said in a statement.

The Giants guaranteed that their offensive line will stay together for the foreseeable future, signing right guard Chris Snee on Wednesday to a six-year, $43.5 million contract extension. Snee, 26, will earn nearly $24 million in the first three years of the deal, the agent Tony Agnone said. The extension will keep Snee under contract with the Giants through 2014. Since beating the New England Patriots in the Super Bowl, the Giants have locked up three starters on the offensive line — Snee, left tackle David Diehl and left guard Rich Seubert. Right tackle Kareem McKenzie and center Shaun O’Hara are under contract through 2012.
Geno Auriemma has signed a contract that would keep him as the women’s basketball coach at Connecticut through 2013, the university announced Wednesday. The five-year, $8 million deal begins July 1.

The banned sprinter Justin Gatlin took his doping appeal to the next level Wednesday, hoping he can compete at United States Track and Field’s Olympic trials this weekend. Gatlin’s lawyers sent a motion to the 11th United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta, asking that he be allowed to compete in the 100-meter races that begin Saturday in Eugene, Ore. A similar motion was filed with United States District Judge Lacey Collier in Pensacola, Fla., who ruled Tuesday that he did not have jurisdiction in a case stemming from Gatlin’s doping suspension.

Shaquille O’Neal’s raunchy rap in which he mocked former teammate Kobe Bryant is costing him another of his lawman badges. Bedford County Sheriff Mike Brown said Wednesday that he has asked O’Neal, a center for Phoenix, to return a badge he was given for his work with the Virginia county’s Internet Crimes Against Children Task Force. A sheriff in Arizona has also asked O’Neal to return a special deputy’s badge.
Mr. Tucker as lead singer of the Dixie Hummingbirds helped propel gospel music toward a harder-edged, more emotive style.
Following the death of their candidate for Congress, Republican leaders on Staten Island and in Brooklyn are seeking potential candidates to run for the seat.
Of course Baron Davis had played soccer before — he was in seventh grade at the time. And of course he had a game plan for Wednesday night’s pickup soccer match.

Athletes who inject themselves with a performance- enhancing drug that boosts their blood cell count can do so with little risk of getting caught, a new study indicates.
An unseeded player, Nathalie Dechy, came within an inch of ruining Ana Ivanovic’s Wimbledon on Wednesday before Ivanovic prevailed.
Voters must demand that both Barack Obama and John McCain explain how they plan to reform the campaign-finance system.

Philipp Lahm scored a 90th minute-winner to give Germany a thrilling 3-2 victory over Turkey on Wednesday and a place in the Euro 2008 final.
Representative Chris Cannon lost his bid for a seventh term, defeated in a Republican primary that focused on whether he was conservative enough for Utah’s Third District.

Jim Lehrer plans to return to the anchor desk at “The NewsHour” on PBS on Thursday, after being absent since late April while recuperating from aortic valve replacement surgery. “The NewsHour” said Mr. Lehrer, 74, planned to anchor the nightly newscast two or three evenings a week before eventually returning to a full-time schedule. He is also planning to anchor PBS’s live coverage of the Democratic and Republican conventions later in the summer. Mr. Lehrer has been an anchor on “NewsHour” and its predecessor, “The MacNeil/Lehrer Report,” since 1975.

One of the largest museums dedicated to Abraham Lincoln is closing its doors on Monday and giving away its $20 million collection, The Civil War News reported. The Lincoln Museum collection in Fort Wayne, Ind., includes more than 18,000 books and pamphlets; 7,000 prints; 5,000 photographs; 350 documents signed by Lincoln, including one of 13 copies of the 13th Amendment he signed; and thousands of newspaper clippings and Lincoln-related items. The Lincoln Financial Foundation, which runs the museums, intends to donate the collection “to one or more of the nation’s major nonprofit institutions specializing in Abraham Lincoln and the Civil War,” and to digitize documents to make them more accessible for next year’s Lincoln Bicentennial, a spokesman said. The Library of Congress, the National Museum of American History, Ford’s Theater and President Lincoln’s Cottage have formed a partnership to try to buy the collection, The Washington Post reported.

MSNBC is creating MSNBC Films, which will finance feature-length documentaries, The Hollywood Reporter said. The move is part of an effort to turn the cable news channel into more of a player in the feature world. While each deal will be structured differently, MSNBC intends to contribute to several elements of a film’s development, from production to marketing for theatrical release.

Six months ago KYW-TV, the CBS affiliate in Philadelphia, fired its newscaster Alycia Lane, above with her former co-anchor, Larry Mendte, after she was arrested for reportedly hitting a New York City police officer. Now the station has dismissed Mr. Mendte, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported. The F.B.I. has been investigating Mr. Mendte, seizing his computer to determine if he illegally broke into Ms. Lane’s e-mail account and forwarded its contents to news organizations. A statement from KYW said that Mr. Mendte’s termination “was based on an independent investigation conducted by CBS.”.

When the Impressionist and modern art auctions continued in London on Wednesday night at Sotheby’s, it was a far more modest affair than Christie’s blockbuster auction the previous evening, which saw a record price of $80.4 million for one of Monet’s late waterlilies. Of the 55 works offered Wednesday, the standout was probably “Dancer,” right, a 1915 painting by Gino Severini. Four telephone bidders vied for the painting, and it ended up selling to one for $29.6 million, far above the high estimate of $19.8 million and a record at auction for the artist. The previous record for a Severini, $3.6 million, was set in 1990 at Sotheby’s in New York for “Sea=Dancer.” The painting sold Wednesday dates from the end of Mr. Severini’s Futurist period and was later acquired by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, where it hung from 1944 until 1988, when it was deaccessioned. An unidentified collector who had owned the painting ever since was the seller.

Blake Fielder-Civil, the husband of the singer Amy Winehouse, got into a barroom fight in 2006 and beat up a pub manager, James King. Though he has admitted he offered Mr. King $400,000 to keep quiet about the incident, a British court acquitted Mr. King on Wednesday of obstructing justice by taking a bribe, The Associated Press reported. Mr. King, who ended up with a broken cheekbone, said he had been intimidated into dropping assault charges. Mr. Fielder-Civil and three others face jail terms when they are sentenced.

Derek Keeling and Ashley Spencer, finalists on the NBC audition series “You’re the One That I Want,” are joining the cast of “Grease” on Broadway in the lead roles of Danny and Sandy. Max Crumm and Laura Osnes, who won the competition, will play their final performances on July 20.

When Kanye West, right, decided to move his 8:15 p.m. appearance to 4:30 the following morning at the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival in Manchester, Tenn., last week because he wanted it dark enough for his light show, audience members were understandably upset, and they let him know it by booing, waving makeshift signs (“Kanye hates hippies!”) and scrawling anti-West graffiti. The criticism continued on the Internet. Now Mr. West has hit back on his own blog. “This Bonnaroo thing is the worst insult I’ve ever had in my life,” he wrote on his Web site, kanyeuniversecity.com. “This is the most offended I’ve ever been ... this is the maddest I ever will be.” He continued, “Call me any name you want ... arrogant, conceited, narcissistic, racist,” adding, “BUT NEVER SAY I DIDN’T GIVE MY ALL!”.

Ears aren’t the only items that may suffer from blaring rock music. The preliminary results of a Russian study by scientists at the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg found that rock concerts by the Rolling Stones, Paul McCartney and others in the adjacent Winter Square have affected their collections over the past three years, The Independent of London reported. The research, now being examined by the Grabar Art Restoration Institute in Moscow, showed that every 10 concerts above 82 decibels added an extra year to the age of a work because of vibrations. After a 2004 McCartney concert shook the windows of the Hermitage, the museum asked the Stones last year to keep the sound level below 85 decibels to protect works by the likes of Cézanne and Matisse in the palace’s nearby wings.

John Derian, the designer who made découpage stylish, didn’t plan to open a store in Provincetown, Mass. “I hadn’t been here in years, came to visit a friend, happened upon the house and fell in love,” he explained. The object of Mr. Derian’s affection was a 1789 sea captain’s house, bottom left, at center. He bought it last year and put a smaller version of his East Village shop in the gray-shingled carriage house just behind it. Stylishly crammed into just 360 square feet, below, is everything one might need to spruce up a summer rental: pieces from Mr. Derian’s popular découpage line, sheets by Matteo and John Robshaw, brightly colored lanterns from Turkey, votive candle holders from Paris, poufs and vintage trays from Morocco, pottery by Astier de Villatte and linoleum cuts by Hugo Guinness, bottom right. (Clint Craig, the store manager, stands in front of the wall of framed linoleum cuts, below.) Open weekends in June, and every day starting July 1, at 396 Commercial Street (Law Street), Provincetown, Mass., (508) 487-1362.RIMA SUQI.

SEGAL--Pauline , at age 96, on June 24, 2008. Beloved mother of Miriam Segal and George (and Joan) Segal. Adored grandmother of Jessica Fox and Elizabeth Segal. Sister of Jules Chorna. Graveside services Thursday, June 26, 2008, 11am at Mt. Hebron Cemetery entrusted to Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, NY.

REES--John S. , passed away June 25, 2008 of lung cancer. He was born in Manhattan on June 12, 1937 and went to the Bronx High School of Science. A graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, he served for five years in the U.S. Air Force as a pilot, achieved the rank of Captain, and then spent his career in Financial Sales before retiring. He is survived by his devoted wife of 41 years, Elaine, his loving son, Jim, and sister Helen, nieces Kathy and Joanne and cousin Frolly. We, as well as all who knew him, will miss his intelligence, his keen sense of humor and fine wit. Services will be held Friday at 11:30am at the Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the American Cancer Society.

LOVE--Kermit . Sesame Workshop mourns the passing of Kermit Love, puppet builder and master artist, whose work will live on through the world of Sesame Street for many years to come. Our deepest sympathies to Christopher, his family and friends.

It's summer, so why shouldn't one's laptop match one's hot-pink bikini? Dell's Studio line comes in seven colors and offers some impressive computing power inside. The laptops, which start at $799, use Intel Core 2 Duo processors and have up to 320 gigabytes of hard drive space. Optional Blu-ray or DVD recording drives ensure you can watch a movie under your beach umbrella, while built-in Wi-Fi, cellular broadband and Bluetooth keep things connected.

POWERS--Francis H., ''Frank'' , of Staten Island, on June 22nd, 2008. Adoring husband of Dianne. Proud father of John ''JC'', Douglas, Brian Devlin, Kathleen, Kelly Ann, Robert John and Francis Michael. Cherished grandfather of Angelina, Eamonn, Anthony, Rory, Annie, Alex, Abby, John Sebastian and Maria Isabel. Fond brother of Betty Susino, Margie Hall, Bobby Powers and Lillian Calcaterra. Also survived and loved by many nieces and nephews. Funeral from the Hanley Funeral Home, 60 New Dorp Lane, Friday, June 27th at 9:30am. Mass of Christian Burial, Our Lady Queen of Peace Church, 10:30am. Entombment Moravian Cemetery, Staten Island. Friends will be received Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Francis H. Powers Charitable Fund c/o the Powers Family, 29 Annfield Court, Staten Island, NY 10304 would be greatly appreciated.

KIEL--Rose (Grund) , died on Sunday, June 22, 2008, at the Sarah Neuman Nursing Home in Mamaroneck, NY at the age of 101. Rose spent most of her life in Brooklyn and Manhattan. She was an accountant who worked for the New York City Planning Commission for a number of years. She was married to William Kiel who passed away in 1993. She is survived by her children, Doreen Gertner and Gerald Kiel, her five grandchildren and eight great - grandchildren. The funeral was held on Tuesday at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Manhattan.

CAHILL--Mary E. (Nee Mossein) , 81, of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Brooklyn and Pound Ridge, NY, passed away peacefully at her home on Tuesday, June 24, 2008. Mary is the daughter of the late Edward and Eleanor Mossein. She is survived by her beloved husband of 59 years John J. ''Jack'' Cahill, adored daughter Marianne Cahill Platt (Douglas J.) and her cherished grandchildren Allison and Jennifer. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated at Mary Mother of the Redeemer Catholic Church, Montgomery Township, PA at a time to be announced. The family requests donations in lieu of flowers to St. Josephs High School, 80 Willoughby St., Brooklyn, NY 11201 (718-624-3618).

A Bluetooth phone headset frees up your hands -- if you remember to bring it along. The LG Decoy may appeal to people who like to travel light, because the phone's designers have built a detachable Bluetooth headset into the back of the phone so the earpiece is there when you need to make a hands-free call. The headset is not the only feature tucked away on the LG Decoy. The keypad slides out from below when it's time to dial. The phone costs $180 with a $50 rebate and a two-year contract with Verizon Wireless (verizonwireless.com).

HOROWITZ--Paul , 1924-2008. Beloved husband, father, and brother. Husband of Gladys, father of Maxine Willett (Ken), Michael (Susan), Marvin (Lenore), grandfather of Scott, Shari, Jeffrey, Joseph, Jeffrey, Philip, and Carolyn. Great-grandfather to Rebekah, Gabrielle, Jacob, Nicholas, and Isabella. Paul was a decorated WWII Veteran and a Mason. He loved ballet, golfing with his friends, and a good walk. A kind and gentle man who will be missed by all who knew him. Graveside services will be at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY, 1pm, Thursday, June 26. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Schuyler Ridge Residential Care Facility (1 Abele Blvd. Clifton Park, NY 12065) or The National Stroke Association (800-STROKES, Extention 0917, or www.stroke.org).

KLEPPEL--Nathaniel H. , suddenly on June 24, 2008 at age 86. Beloved husband of Shirley Kalb and the late Nettie Kleppel. Devoted father of Rise Stern (Alan) and Sharon Rebell (Michael). Loving grandfather of Jonathan Tannenhauser, Seth Stern and Sarah Rebell. Devoted stepfather of Amy (Albert) and Rebecca and stepgrandfather and step-great-grandfather. He was a man of high principles and high standards whose integrity and values defined him. He will be missed.

GREEF--Ernest Twyford , of Quogue, NY, Palm Beach, FL, and New York City, died suddenly in London, England, on June 23, 2008 at the age of 84. He is survived by his wife Olive Rousseau Greeff, sons Douglas Haven Greeff and David Chapin Greeff, sister and brother-in-law Nancy and Nelson Dane, granddaughters Hilary and Eugenie Greeff. A graduate of the Hill School and Williams College Class of 1948, he served as a 1st Lieutenant in the United Sates Navy from 1944 to 1946. A Funeral Service will be held on Thursday, July 3rd at 4pm at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Main Street, Westhampton Beach, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in Ernest's memory may be directed to the Ernest Greeff Memorial Fund at Williams College, 75 Park Street, Williamstown, MA 02167.

FRIEDMAN--Sherry J . The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the passing of Sherry J. Friedman, beloved mother of Ira Friedman, an esteemed leader of the New York Jewish community whose commitment to philanthropy strengthens our ability to serve those in need. We extend our deepest sympathies to her husband, George; her son, Ira; her daughter, Meryl Berger, and her husband, Jason; her daughter, Jodi Ehren, and her husband, Todd; and the entire Friedman family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO FRIEDMAN--Sherry J., 70, of New York City on June 23rd, 2008. Loving Wife of George M. Friedman for 48 years, daughter of Betty and Irving Grossman, founders of IG Federal Electrical Supply Corp. and sister of Judith Malz. Beloved mother of Ira Friedman, Meryl Berger, and Jodi Ehren. Mother-in-law of Jason Berger and Todd Ehren. Bubbe of Julie and Josh Friedman, Rae and Gabrielle Berger, and Amanda and Noah Ehren. Sherry was an admired and selfless friend to many, her spirits and love of life will carry on in all who she touched. She will be deeply missed. Funeral Services will be held on Wednesday June 25th at 11am at RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY 11021. WHEN Spike Gjerde started to build a new restaurant in an old mill in Baltimore, he did not want a slick menu with crisp, perfect letters. ''We're all totally about salvage and reuse,'' he said. The menu had to reflect the restaurant's goal: presenting local ingredients in a rough-hewn complex that once cast the 36-inch-wide columns that support the dome of the United States Capitol. So he turned to Mary Mashburn, a designer with an office filled with old type just a few blocks away. Ms. Mashburn set the restaurant's name, Woodberry Kitchen, with scratched and nicked wooden type from her collection of antique block types and then printed a copy on her old letterpress. She then scanned the result into her computer, where she tweaked a few letters and adjusted some spacing. A new version of an old font was born.

AS the ice caps melt, surfers may be closer to an endless summer than they ever expected. To help stem the tide, some surfers are choosing trunks built with eco-friendly fabrics. Recycled polyester began showing up in surf shorts two years ago, hemp blends appeared the following year, and this season bamboo blends as well as a pair of breeches that can be recycled are available.

WALDMAN--Stanley . Born January 1, 1933. Passed away on June 24, 2008. Loving husband of 45 years to Barbara. Beloved father of Dara and Philip. Proprietor for 20 years of the Manhattan Galleries, founded by his father, Lewis Waldman. Funeral service Friday, June 27, Forest Park Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills.

BISHOP--Adelaide . New York City Opera mourns the passing of our dear friend and colleague Adelaide Bishop, a leading soprano of our company from 1948-1960 and a loyal friend and frequent visitor until her death. Beginning with her 1948 City Opera debut as Gilda in Rigoletto, she brought her lyric voice, keen musicianship, and sprightly stage presence to our stage in roles including Susanna in Figaro, Sophie in Rosenkavalier, Olympia in Tales of Hoffmann, Gretel in Hansel and Gretel, and Norina in the company premiere of Don Pasquale. A staunch advocate of new American music, Adi was very proud of, and will be especially remembered for, her City Opera performances as Laetitia in Menotti's ''Old Maid and the Thief'' (1952), Mary Stone in Moore's ''The Devil and Daniel Webster'' (1959), and the Stepdaughter in the world premiere of Weisgall's ''Six Characters in Search of an Author'' (1959). Becoming an opera director and administrator after retiring from singing, she served as opera department chair at Boston University and artistic director of both the Wolf Trap Opera Training Program and the Opera Theater at Hartford's Hartt College of Music. We will sorely miss her and her enthusiastic support for our company, and we offer our sincere condolences to her family and her vast extended family of friends, colleagues, and former students, many of whom are company members. Susan L. Baker Chairman

Ralph Nader on Wednesday defended the comments he had made to a newspaper suggesting that Senator Barack Obama has not devoted enough time to poverty in inner cities and rural areas and ''wants to talk white.'' In an interview with The Rocky Mountain News in Denver, Mr. Nader, who is running as an independent for president, said of Mr. Obama: ''There's only one thing different about Barack Obama when it comes to being a Democratic presidential candidate. He's half African-American. Whether that will make any difference, I don't know. I haven't heard him have a strong crackdown on economic exploitation in the ghettos. Payday loans, predatory lending, asbestos, lead. What's keeping him from doing that? Is it because he wants to talk white? He doesn't want to appear like Jesse Jackson?''

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the Pentagon's loss of engineering-management expertise overstated the percentage increase in projected cost overruns for 95 major weapons programs in 2007 and 75 projects in 2000. A $295 billion overrun projected for 2007 was 26 percent above initial estimates, not 40 percent. And a $42 billion estimated overrun in 2000 was 6 percent over budget, not 27 percent. (The 40 percent and 27 percent increases were for cost overruns in the projects' research and development in 2007 and 2000, respectively.) The incorrect percentages also appeared in an article on June 4 about a senator's criticism of the cost overruns.

WOLF--Stephen L. , who conflated his towering intelligence with military intelligence and to whom so many owe so much. Clarence S. Barasch WOLF--Stephen. The Officers and Clergy of Temple Israel of the City of New York mourn the passing of longtime congregant Stephen Wolf, husband of our congregant, Mary Wolf, father of Matthew. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Beth Lee, President David J. Gelfand, Rabbi WOLF--Stephen L., businessman, civic leader, and bibliophile, after a short illness, June 24, age 91. Steve was a true New Yorker who gave so much to the city and family he loved so well. Born in New York on January 26, 1917 the only child of Selma and Isaac Wolf, he graduated Phi Beta Kappa from New York University in 1937. During World War II, Steve enrolled in the signal intelligence corps, for which he was honored in 1946 with a Legion of Merit for his cryptoanalytic work. Following the war, he turned down a job in Washington with the State Department in order to enter the family firm, S. Wolf's Sons, that had been founded by his grandfather, Simon, in 1869. The business was the oldest paint and wallcovering store in the city, and Steve was named its president in 1953, remaining so until 1987, when he sold the firm. Steve made a passion out of his vocation, amassing one of the leading collections of books on paint and color theory in the country, with volumes dating to the 1600s. Always involved in the world at large, Steve was at various times president of the Ninth Avenue Association, president of the board of directors of the Metropolitan Historic Structures Association, chairman of the West Side Highway committee, twice chairman of Community Planning Board number 4 on Manhattan's West Side, vice-chairman of the board of managers of the McBurney School, and a board member of the Hartley House community center, from whom he received a founder's award in 2004. He is survived by Mary, his devoted wife of 53 years, and his infinitely proud son, Matt, a journalist based in London, Stephen's second-favorite city. Funeral service Friday June 27, 11am, at the chapel at Temple Israel. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Hartley House

Government officials have given further details of the kinds of high-emission vehicles that will be banned from the streets of Beijing in an effort to curb pollution during the Summer Olympics, according to state news media. The ban will take place from July 1 to Sept. 20 and will apply to vehicles that do not meet the lowest of the European emissions standards. Those vehicles, mostly freight trucks, have yellow labels on their windshields, and there are more than 300,000 of them. With six weeks to go before the Games, the air in Beijing is still a dense, soupy haze. Last Friday, officials announced their initial plans to limit vehicle usage around the Olympics.

Even with Independence Day and then Election Day fast approaching, the most presidential place in New York City at the moment just might be an unexpected one: the work space of the design and fabrication company StudioEIS on the fourth floor of an anonymous-looking building in Dumbo, Brooklyn.There, in one corner, is a nearly completed new sculpture of Abraham Lincoln standing with a horse. In another, a Thomas Jefferson statue bound for Monticello. And down a hallway, an early version of a sitting James Madison that will one day join a statue of his wife, Dolley Madison, and take up residence outside their historic home at Montpelier.

A New Jersey dentist, Michael Mastromarino, 44, was sentenced to 18 to 54 years in prison on Friday after pleading guilty to being the mastermind behind a multimillion-dollar enterprise that harvested tissue and body parts from funeral homes and sold them for use in transplants and medical research. Among the bodies plundered was that of Alistair Cooke, the British journalist and former host of “Masterpiece Theater.” Mr. Mastromarino, 44, had pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on March 18 to numerous charges of enterprise corruption, reckless endangerment and body stealing. He admitted leading a harvesting operation that sold hundreds, perhaps thousands, of bone fragments and bits of flesh from people who had never given their consent to being donors. The body parts were sold to tissue processors around the country, and eventually to medical companies for use in surgical transplants like bone and skin grafts.

The French are feeling as economically pinched as Americans, but I get the sense they are busting to look fashionable. I've noticed it all day as I go around to shows and look at people on the streets. Heading to Montmartre, I saw a young woman-20s, thin, medium height-in a pair of slim gray shorts that ended mid-thigh, a loose navy popover top, and a classic pair of black stilettos. Super chic. I've seen slim-fitting shorts with a sailor front, worn with chunky black sandals and a cream silk blouse. The look is tailored and sexy. And there are lots of women in mini skirts; this afternoon I saw a woman in a flaring navy cotton skirt with a red and white striped polo shirt. The best-looking dress at the moment seems to be a dark tunic. I've noticed a lot of the guys in the front row also wearing shorts, especially as a kind of nerd school-boy uniform with knee socks and maybe a pastel vest and a tie. And it's a little surprising how many shows have hats-the porkpie, the scarecrow, the snap-brim. Shades of next summer

Ryan Church could rejoin the Mets as soon as Saturday if he felt well after playing the outfield Friday night in Class A Brooklyn's game against Aberdeen. He went 0 for 3 and played seven innings in right field. But Manager Jerry Manuel said Church, on the disabled list since June 6 because of post-concussion symptoms, would have only "an outside chance" of playing this weekend. "If he's not quite ready, Sunday could be a good day for him, could be," Manuel said. "That would be kind of pushing it anyway." Manuel said Church would definitely not start Saturday, when Andy Pettitte, a left-hander, is scheduled to pitch. Church went 3 for 3 and played right field Thursday for Brooklyn but the Mets recommended he play another game before evaluating him.

London is the night-life capital of the world; so if you can't beat them, why not invite them? That's what the Italians did last week for an all-night rave hosted by the designer Carri Mundane (aka Casette Playa) in honor of the annual Pitti Immagine Uomo men's-wear trade show in Florence. Mundane, who is also a stylist for the likes of the recently "retired" singer M.I.A, trucked into town with her 50-strong crew of friends, muses and post-ironic ravers, setting up in an old gymnasium for a "live video jumpdance installation." (Read: ecstacy.) Mundane makes clothes that are a bit like an enlightened version of B.A.P.E, was recently nominated for best men's-wear designer at the British Fashion Awards and will be showing off her glow-stick-friendly uniforms as part of the "Fashion V Sport" exhibition at London's Victoria & Albert Museum in August. For those of you not too hung over to remember, several seasons ago Milan Fashion Week hosted the club kids behind the BoomBox, then the "It" British dance haven. (Note to self: raving is the new clubbing.) Italy's shameless co-opting of London's nightclub culture is not only endearing, but it looks kind of fun. New York would be smart to take a lesson.

The Paris men's shows have started. Last evening, a beautiful Paris sort of evening, Mr. Alloux and I were on our way to Dries Van Noten's show in the 15th, at the site of a former slaughter house for horses. Our destination prompted a culinary discussion (in my limited French) about the differences between horse and beef. Mr. Alloux said that horse meat was once a commonplace in France and that, in terms of taste, you could barely distinguish it from beef. He asked me if horse was ever popular in the States, and I replied that it may have been at one time in some places but that we Americans tended to keep Nelly in the barn.

July 1, as every hockey fan knows, is a special day. It's Canada Day! (Quick translation here for Americans: It's sorta Canada's Fourth of July, but it's three days earlier and it also doesn't celebrate Canada's complete independence from Great Britain the way July 4 does -- because that didn't happen on July 1, 1867, but rather in 1982 when the final constitutional link was broken, but it was the start of the process.)

The guidebook, part of a longstanding campaign by the group on human rights issues at the Beijing Olympics, is free and available for download by anyone (via pdf file, link here).
