In a back page essay for this Sunday's Book Review, I write about a boutique Jerusalem-based publisher, Ibis Editions, which is devoted to publishing books from the Levant. It was founded in 1998 by the biographer and critic Adina Hoffman and the poet and translator Peter Cole, whose book of Medieval Hebrew poetry we reviewed here. Ibis recently issued the first English translation of a controversial Hebrew novella, "Khirbet Khizeh," by the Israeli author S. Yizhar, which tells of the violent evacuation of a Palestinian village by a Jewish unit in the 1948 war of independence. (In recent years, Toby Press has released English translations of two other books by Yizhar, "Midnight Convoy and Other Stories" and "Preliminaries.")

The Yankees began ambling into the clubhouse Friday around noon for the 2:05 p.m. game. "Business as usual," Manager Joe Girardi called it. Eleven hours earlier, they were just getting off their flight from Pittsburgh, putting an end to a frustrating night that saw them sit at PNC Park in a two-and-a-half-hour rain delay until the game was called off. Not the ideal way to prepare for a day-night, two-stadium doubleheader against the Mets.

Re "Pantsuits and the Presidency" (June 22): We seem to carry the concept of political correctness to absurdity while avoiding the larger, substantially more important issues. Your column is a case in point. Is it worth asking whether The Times has been biased in its reporting, or whether it has been prejudiced? Certainly! And that is an area to be followed with some vigor.
[UPDATE, 7/14: A remarkable animation depicting the pulsing flow of Arctic sea ice over a stretch of years moved to the "jump" page because it was slowing the loading of Dot Earth for some users.]

Re "Culling the Anonymous Sources" (June 8 ) : I believe the problem with accountability of anonymous statements can be solved with a simple baseball-like statistic. Reporters and their editors should carry a "believability average" - some ratio of "proved true," "still unknown truth," "proved false" - whereby anonymous statements are reviewed multiple times after those statements were published.If individual writers and editors had individual ratings attached to them, the public would be better informed about anonymous sources while those reporters and editors would have to think harder about what to publish because their entire decision-making history would be on the line.Scott KaczmarekSeattle, June 8, 2008

They seemed to go out of their way to acknowledge the widely understood reality -- that it had been a hard-fought primary, to say the least. But now, they are clearly on the same side. The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here, the photographer, curator and publisher Tim Barber shares a few of his stylish essentials. Barber, who runs the online art gallery Tiny Vices and the newly launched print-on-demand publishing house TV Books, is hosting a special two-day exhibition/catalog viewing this weekend (see the invitation after the jump). But Barber doesn't keep his curatorial sixth sense strictly digital. He has brought his hyperlinking vision to a range of international exhibitions and gallery spaces, most recently as a co-curator of the 2008 New York Photo Festival.

The Bulgarians' withdrawal bears an eerie resemblance to last month's revelation that 11 members of the Greek weightlifting team had tested positive for banned substances.

No one is dusting off those valiant titles once bestowed on Eliot Spitzer, honorifics like "The Enforcer" and "Sheriff of Wall Street." But slowly, even a bit gently, Mr. Spitzer's successor as the attorney general of New York, Andrew M. Cuomo, is shaking up the financial industry, according to The New York Times.

The lobbying arm of the Family Research Council, the conservative Christian organization, is going on the air in several cities on Friday with a television ad featuring a personal note from the group's president, Tony Perkins, to Senator Barack Obama. The message: Mr. Obama's abortion rights stance is hypocritical.
At the time he agreed to sell the Huntsman Corporation for $10.6 billion last year, the chemical maker's chief executive thought he had a solid deal. But now Peter Huntsman is steaming mad.
A spokesman for Chrysler said on Thursday that market rumors of a bankruptcy filing by the privately held automaker were "without merit," saying the company had ample liquidity.

The top securities regulator in Massachusetts has sued UBS on the grounds of fraud, saying that the firm misled clients when it sold them auction-rate securities and that it pushed the increasingly risky instruments on individual investors to reduce its own potential losses.

The $8.9 billion that Barclays plans to raise will be backed by several of London's largest hedge funds, The Financial Times reported citing a prospectus issued by the bank on Thursday. But an analyst said that fundraising round may not be enough.

JPMorgan Chase vice chairman James B. Lee Jr. was honored last night at The New York Public Library. Under pressure from many shareholders for its poor performance and for its failure to complete a deal with Microsoft, Yahoo is doing something it has done several times before: reorganizing itself.

CINCINNATI - You are a (comparatively) young Republican making a name for yourself, and your name keeps cropping up on media lists of potential running mates for Senator John McCain. But with the McCain campaign playing its cards so close to the vest, it can be maddeningly hard to figure out where you stand.
Social-network-turned-gaming-site I'm In Like With You has raised $1.5 million of venture funding led by Spark Capital, CNet News reported.
Gloom has descended over Wall Street once again. While the price of oil is rising, the health of the financial sector is flagging, taking yet another heavy toll on the markets.

The majority of U.S. banks would have the option to adopt alternative risk-based capital adequacy rules based on the Basel II accords, under a proposal agreed to by a top U.S. banking regulator, Reuters reported.

Earlier this month, Mentor Graphics rejected an unsolicited $1.6 billion takeover bid from Cadence Design Systems Inc. Analysts now say Cadence will have to up the ante in order to succeed in buying the rival chip design software maker, The Daily Deal reported.

Suadad al-Salhy is an Iraqi reporter who recently joined The New York Times in Iraq. In May she was one of five Iraqi journalists who visited the United States on a reporting tour organized by the State Department to learn about 'How America's Middle East Policy is Formulated.'

Bradford & Bingley investors are clamoring for an urgent clarification of the agreement between the lender and Texas Pacific Group because of growing fears that the private equity firm's deal would make it almost impossible for the company to negotiate with other bidders.
Apollo Management has slashed more than 1,500 jobs at Countrywide since buying the British company at last year's market peak, Bloomberg News reported.
Bank of America on Thursday said it expects to eliminate about 7,500 jobs over the next two years after it completes its acquisition of Countrywide Financial, the largest U.S. mortgage lender.
Mary Jo Salter is the author of "A Phone Call to the Future: New and Selected Poems." She is a professor in the writing seminars at Johns Hopkins University.

GMR Infrastructure has bought 50 percent of InterGen from AIG Highstar for an equity value of $1.1 billion. The deal marks the largest ever acquisition of a global energy utility by an Indian company, Finance Asia reported.
Britain's High Court has rejected a last-gasp effort mounted by a group of hedge funds to block Candover's 1.8 billion pound bid for oil services group Expro, The Telegraph reported.

China South Locomotive & Rolling Stock may sell a 30 percent stake in a Shanghai initial public offering to help fund nearly 9 billion yuan ($1.3 billion) of projects, Bloomberg reported citing a company filing.

Everbright Securities is gearing up for an initial public offering to sell as many as 520 million shares in Shanghai.

Microsoft has agreed to buy Silicon Valley semantic search engine Powerset, Venture Beat reported. The acquisition price is rumored to be slightly more than $100 million with an announcement expected in July.
Virgin Group's first green investment fund has attracted the interest of such maiden investors Wolverhampton City Council and Calpers, The Financial Times reported.

Mergers and acquisitions across Asia are headed to mark an 8.7 percent rise to $362 billion in volume for the first half of 2008, after accelerating in the second quarter, according to preliminary data from Thomson Reuters.

The News Corporation may bid for two major pay-TV players, Germany's Premiere and Spain's Digital+, in a move that could give more responsibility to James Murdoch, son of News Corp. chief Rupert Murdoch, The Wall Street Journal reported on Thursday.

In a privately negotiated deal, Diamond Castle Holdings has sold Catamount Energy to Duke Energy for $320 million including debt.

The drawing comes fairly close to what my blurry work-life looks like most weeks, though I still aim for at least a day or two a week that look like the Sunday on Mr. Rao's "then" drawing (though not necessarily on a weekend).

It was a warm holiday afternoon nearly 25 years ago, a perfect day for July 4th baseball. For the Yankees' Dave Righetti, it was also a perfect day to pitch a no-hitter against the Boston Red Sox. On that afternoon, Righetti whiffed Wade Boggs, flung his arms in the air and celebrated his doodle of a day at Yankee Stadium.
“Wanted” shows life in the killing lane with lots of zippy effects, action and exploding heads.
“Wall-E” breaks new ground in giving us a G-rated, computer-generated cartoon vision of our own potential extinction.
Peter Askin’s stirring documentary “Trumbo” gives you reasons to cheer but also to weep.

Officials of Guerrero State have agreed to pay $3,400 each to 14 indigenous men who were coerced into having vasectomies a decade ago. The men will also get water storage tanks and cement to build new homes, Luis Barrera Rios, the state health secretary, told The Associated Press. During a visit to the village of El Camalote in 1998, health workers demanded that men with more than four children be sterilized, the National Human Rights Commission said last year in a report. The men said state workers had promised them new homes and scholarships for their children if they underwent the procedure.

A federal appeals court unanimously rejected the petition by a group of states and environmental organizations to force a speedy decision on whether and how to regulate heat-trapping gases like carbon dioxide.
The police in Niger arrested Hama Amadou, a former prime minister and governing party chief, on corruption charges, a judicial source said.
Diagnoses of H.I.V. and AIDS in men who have sex with men rose significantly from 2001 to 2006, while declining in other demographic groups, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported.
Neil Entwistle, 29, was sentenced on Thursday to two life terms without the chance for parole and ordered by the judge never to profit from the story.
Hawaii has become the first state to require solar water heaters in new homes.

A Mississippi businessman born in India was convicted of plotting to have his black daughter-in-law killed weeks after she married his son because, prosecutors said, he believed she would bring down the family stock.
The death toll from Typhoon Fengshen could reach more than 1,300, including the passengers and the crew of a ferry that capsized Saturday in the storm, officials said.
A surgeon charged with killing three patients in Australia, signed papers in Federal District Court in Portland agreeing to be sent to Australia.

Salvatore Battaglia was sentenced on Thursday to four years and nine months in federal prison after pleading guilty to extortion and receiving bribes in a Mafia-controlled racketeering conspiracy.

BUSINESS DAY.
An Indian fabric maker paid nearly $250,000, a record price, for a 200-pound bale of exceptionally high grade wool at an auction Thursday in Australia.

A federal court has denied the sprinter Justin Gatlin’s appeal to run in the United States Olympic track trials this weekend. The United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit said Thursday that Gatlin had not shown he met the “applicable standard for such an injunction.” Earlier this month, the Court of Arbitration for Sport upheld a four-year ban against Gatlin, the defending Olympic champion in the 100 meters, for doping violations, but he went to federal court seeking to run in trials starting Saturday.

Corey Pavin, Bo Van Pelt and Dudley Hart shot eight-under-par 64s to share the first-round lead Thursday at the Buick Open in Grand Blanc, Mich. Briny Baird and Daniel Chopra were a stroke back, and Woody Austin, Shigeki Maruyama, Kenneth Ferrie and Jon Mills shot 66s on the Warwick Hills course. Rocco Mediate, making his first start since pushing Tiger Woods at the United States Open, opened with a 71.

A federal judge has given a Jets season-ticket holder more time to amend a lawsuit seeking millions from the New England Patriots and Coach Bill Belichick for “deceiving customers” by videotaping opponents’ signals. The lawsuit by Carl J. Mayer, filed in September, was scheduled to be dismissed June 30 because of a lack of activity. Mayer and his co-counsel, Bruce I. Afran, this week asked United States District Judge Garrett E. Brown Jr. for more time because Afran had been ill and because of “revelations” developed by an investigation launched by Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, after the lawsuit was filed. They asked permission to serve notice on the defendants by Aug. 30.
BP’s Russian partners said that a general shareholders’ meeting for a joint venture had been held in violation of Russian law.

The deadline has been extended for Oscar Pistorius, the South African double-amputee runner, to qualify for the Beijing Olympics. Pistorius’s manager, Peet van Zyl, said that the South African athletics federation moved its deadline from July 11 to July 17, giving Pistorius time to compete in four European races as he tries to meet the 400-meter qualifying time of 45.55. Pistorius won a ruling from the Court of Arbitration for Sport in May allowing him to compete.

Martin Straka has decided to leave the N.H.L. and return to his former Czech club. Straka, who played for the Rangers the last three seasons after joining the N.H.L. in 1992, will be a player and sports director for HC Lasselsberger Plzen, the club said on its Web site Thursday. Straka, a 35-year-old forward, scored 257 goals and had 460 assists in 954 N.H.L. regular-season games, and had 26 goals and 44 assists in the playoffs. He joined the Pittsburgh Penguins in 1992, and also played for the Ottawa Senators, the Islanders, the Florida Panthers and the Los Angeles Kings. He had 14 goals and 27 assists last season.
With all sides recognizing that there is virtually nothing Congress can do to lower fuel prices any time soon, Democrats and Republicans focused as much on finger-pointing as on policy making.

The N.H.L.’s salary cap is on the rise again. The league and the players association announced Thursday that each team will have a maximum of $56.7 million to spend for the 2008-9 season — up $6.4 million from last season. The most money a player can earn in a new contract next season is $11.34 million a year.

‘BRIGADOON’ To find Brigadoon, it seems, you must move backward. That’s what the director Vincente Minnelli and the cinematographer Joseph Ruttenberg did for MGM’s “Brigadoon.” First they shot the discovery scene as a clear view of a village nestled in a valley and then pumped in fog to cover it over. Finally they projected the sequence in reverse, and Brigadoon emerged magically from the Highland mists for its one day every 100 years.

SCAPULA--Pierre . We mourn the death of our beloved friend, Pierre Scapula, on June 21st in Paris, France at the age of 92. We were honored to know Pierre as our friend for over 45 years. Connoisseur of French and European antique furniture, silver and decorative arts, collector of fine art and automobiles, leader in home, automotive, jewelry and personal accessory design -Pierre's zest for life encompassed many disciplines. Pierre's elegance and refinement lent an air of grace to every event. He could regale partygoers with tales of worldwide travels while charming his partners on the dance floor. Pierre was always a gentleman without ceasing to be a gentle man, one whose kindness will be fondly remembered. His many friends will forever miss his presence. We will not cite all of Pierre's international renown and universal respect in the fields of art, fashion and design or list the array of prominent leaders in the political, business and social spheres who availed themselves of Pierre's many talents. Namedropping would have been abhorrent to a man who valued his friendship with everyone. We do not know what epitaphs will mark Pierre's interment in the family plot outside of Paris where he will be laid to rest. The true testament to Pierre is the warmth and love which he inspired in the hearts of the many fortunate enough to have known him throughout his rich and rewarding life. Joy and Walter Samuels Rest in Peace Beloved Friend

Calling its claims ''overly speculative and not credible'' and saying it is too late anyway, lawyers for the federal government argued this week that a so-called doomsday suit intended to prevent the startup of the world's most powerful particle accelerator should be thrown out. In the lawsuit filed in March in Federal District Court in Honolulu, Walter L. Wagner, a retired radiation safety expert, and Luis Sancho, a Spanish science writer, contended that the Large Hadron Collider could create microscopic black holes that could wind up eating Earth, or other dangerous particles known as strangelets -- a sort of contagious dead matter -- or so-called magnetic monopoles that could catalyze the destruction of ordinary matter.

PECHTER--Morton H. , November, 13, 1922-June 24, 2008, a business tycoon and later Hall of Fame, Underwater Photographer, adventure sports photojournalist, writer and book author passed away peacefully from respiratory failure on June 24, 2008. Pechter was the last remaining member of the original Pechter Baking Company and Harrison Baking Company, well-known for its Jewish Rye Bread and other baked goods products. In later years, when the Pechter Baking Company had been sold, Pechter turned to SCUBA diving and underwater photography, first as a hobby and later as a profession. His professional life as a photographer grew and he wrote and photographed for hundreds of magazines, joining the masthead designation on many. He became the ''official photographer'' for the Chris Event Tennis Charities Event: for eight years for the Delray International Tennis Championships: for four years for the Air & Sea Show in Fort Lauderdale, Florida: and was the photographer for ''Raffi on Broadway'' and several other Broadway productions. He authored and photographed an award winning book, ''What's In The Deep?'' that was selected as a ''Reading Rainbow'' designated book. His many awards include: the 2003 NOGI for Distinguished Service from AUAS. (The Academy of Underwater Arts & Sciences); the 2008 Diver of the Year from Beneath the Sea; Director's award from the Balloon Federation of America and honored with election to the SSI Platinum Pro 5000 group in recognition of making over 5000 SCUBA dives and his work within the industry. He was elected a Fellow National member in the prestigious Explorers Club for his contribution to scientific knowledge in the field of geographical exploration. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Alese and his children: Dr. Stuart and Madeline Pechter; Dr. Richard and Robin Pechter; Dr. Jay and Roxanne Pechter,Todd and Christine Pechter and his grandchildren, Nelson, Wyatt, Joseph, William, Patricia and Diana.

'ADVENTURES WITH DORA & DIEGO' Visit a rain forest, go spelunking, rescue an armadillo, guide sea turtles to their nests and listen to a jaguar's heartbeat: somehow that doesn't sound like a typical New York afternoon. But these days children can get a taste of all those experiences in our own urban jungle. They're part of ''Adventures With Dora & Diego,'' an exhibition at the Children's Museum of Manhattan whose Latino title characters come from hit Nickelodeon animated series. Dora, the feisty 7-year-old of ''Dora the Explorer,'' was the subject of a show the museum opened in 2004, which this new installation replaces. ''Adventures'' gives equal time to her cousin Diego, the 8-year-old conservationist in ''Go, Diego, Go!'' But while these cheerful cartoon figures appear in the exhibition, they are more hosts than heroes. The real star is Latin American wildlife.

FIGMENT For the second year, a bit of Burning Man will come east when Figment, a free arts festival, inhabits Governors Island this weekend. Like that annual event in the Nevada desert, Figment is equal parts installation and performance piece, and heavy on the interactivity and good vibes. More than 200 arts groups and individuals are participating, said David Koren, the executive producer. Last year it drew 2,800 visitors in one day, the maximum allowed on the island. (Figment was so successful that the organizers were able to expand it to three days this year; the name comes from an Andy Warhol quotation describing his preferred tombstone: ''No epitaph, and no name. Well, actually, I'd like it to say 'Figment.' '') Among the spectacles planned for the park, which is accessible through a free ferry, is ''Limbonade,'' a contest in which good limbo dancers win lemonade; ''Creamcycle,'' in which visitors design and build a bicycle-powered ice cream churner; and a gnome adoption agency, in which qualified parents are matched with orphaned lawn gnomes -- and a disposable camera, to document the adventures of their new charges.

'COMPLICATED STORIES: SCULPTURES AND WRITTEN TESTIMONIES, 1998-2008' ''Complicated Stories'' indeed. If Charles Juhasz-Alvarado were a less inventive and industrious sculptor, you might think he missed his calling as a magic-realist novelist. Born in 1965 and based in San Juan, P.R., Mr. Juhasz-Alvarado has been included in international biennial exhibitions in Brazil, Cuba, the Czech Republic, Russia and Singapore. This entertaining, intermittently inspired 10-year survey is his first solo show in New York.

WORLD CULTURE MUSIC WEEKEND In the era of the imploding record label, a sizable number of jazz musicians have adapted, releasing albums themselves; through organizations like ArtistShare; or through one of the handful of indies typically based in Europe or Canada. A smaller contingent has gone further, establishing coherent imprints with multiple groups on the roster. Among the recent success stories in this vein is World Culture Music, founded by the drummer Kendrick Scott about a year and a half ago. Mr. Scott, now 27, inaugurated the label in standard fashion, with a release under his own name. ''The Source,'' issued early last year, was his auspicious debut as a leader, with a group that included the pianist Aaron Parks and the guitarist Mike Moreno. Later came ''Between the Lines,'' an excellent first outing by Mr. Moreno. With those two releases, World Culture Music began to form a public identity and receive some modest recognition.

So the E-ZPass is even easier than anyone thought -- good for a lifetime and free, as long as you are, or ever were, a board member of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. But if you're shocked -- shocked! -- at that perk, which was scaled back on Wednesday by the embarrassed authority, consider the freebie-travel scandal that shamed the agency's more imperious cousin, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, some 30 years ago. What is it, anyway, about public transportation officials and their travel perks?

The government halted the search for hundreds of bodies feared trapped on a capsized ferry after salvage divers discovered the boat was carrying tons of endosulfan, a restricted pesticide, Reuters reported. Efforts to salvage the ferry are on hold until a way is found to remove the pesticide safely, Elena Bautista, a disaster recovery official, told Reuters. As many as 809 people on the ferry are thought to have died when it capsized after a typhoon Saturday, and officials say the death toll from the storm is expected to exceed 1,300. Divers continued to search the boat, where hundreds of bodies are believed to be trapped, as villagers, above, prayed for the victims during a Mass on Sibuyan Island. Apart from the ferry disaster, officials raised the death toll to 498.

FRELINGHUYSEN--Marian Kingsland , of Oldwick, NJ and West Stockbridge, MA, died peacefully at home on June 26. She is survived by Henry W. SeherrThoss and his wife Elizabeth and George L. K. Frelinghuysen and his wife, Alice, of New York, and her eight grandchildren, Christopher, Alexandra, Virginia, Marian, Henry and Hans SeherrThoss, and Henry and Russell Frelinghuysen. WOLF--Stephen L. , businessman, civic leader, and bibliophile, after a short illness, June 24, age 91. Steve was a true New Yorker who gave so much to the city and family he loved so well. Born in New York on January 26, 1917 the only child of Selma and Isaac Wolf, he graduated Phi Beta Kappa from New York University in 1937. During World War II, Steve enrolled in the signal intelligence corps, for which he was honored in 1946 with a Legion of Merit for his cryptoanalytic work. Following the war, he turned down a job in Washington with the State Department in order to enter the family firm, S. Wolf's Sons, that had been founded by his grandfather, Simon, in 1869. The business was the oldest paint and wallcovering store in the city, and Steve was named its president in 1953, remaining so until 1987, when he sold the firm. Steve made a passion out of his vocation, amassing one of the leading collections of books on paint and color theory in the country, with volumes dating to the 1600s. Always involved in the world at large, Steve was at various times president of the Ninth Avenue Association, president of the board of directors of the Metropolitan Historic Structures Association, chairman of the West Side Highway committee, twice chairman of Community Planning Board number 4 on Manhattan's West Side, vice-chairman of the board of managers of the McBurney School, and a board member of the Hartley House community center, from whom he received a founder's award in 2004. He is survived by Mary, his devoted wife of 53 years, and his infinitely proud son, Matt, a journalist based in London, Stephen's second-favorite city. Funeral service Friday June 27, 11am, at the chapel at Temple Israel. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Hartley House. WOLF--Steve. The Trustees and Staff of Hartley House are profoundly saddened by the death of our esteemed Board Member, Steve Wolf. Deepest sympathies to his beloved wife Mary and son Matthew. Steve will be greatly missed. Eleanor Mascheroni and Alice Truax, Co-Presidents and Members of the Board of Trustees, Hartley House

SKLAR--Alan L. , of Boynton Beach, Florida, Eternal Rest on June 25, 2008. Beloved husband of Susan and the late Arlene. Devoted father to Jonathan, Lizzie and the late Connie. Doting grandfather to Zachary and Emily. Led the J. Sklar Manufacturing Company of New York with distinction. He will always be in our hearts.

REES--John S. , passed away June 25, 2008 of lung cancer. He was born in Manhattan on June 12, 1937 and went to the Bronx High School of Science. A graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, he served for five years in the U.S. Air Force as a pilot, achieved the rank of Captain, and then spent his career in Financial Sales before retiring. He is survived by his devoted wife of 41 years, Elaine, his loving son, Jim, and sister Helen Lessner, nieces Kathy and Joanne and cousin Frolly. We, as well as all who knew him, will miss his intelligence, his keen sense of humor and fine wit. Services will be held today at 11:30am at the Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the American Cancer Society.

CSX's announcement this week that it will take a month to determine the outcome of its board election is a bit cheeky to say the least. CSX is incorporated in Virginia, where an aggrieved shareholder can take a claim that a board election was mishandled to court. But it is hard for the Children's Investment Fund, one of the hedge funds that has claimed several CSX board seats, to sue on that ground. For one thing, the statute comes into play only once the results of the election are announced. And any ruling in a lawsuit would be unlikely to come in four weeks.

FOR CHILDREN 'CINDERELLA' (Saturday) Forget about a wicked stepmother and a pumpkin-turned-coach. This new production by Youth on Target Theater Company presents a version drawn from the Italian tradition, in which Cinderella's mother is very much alive, and Cinderella is not so much persecuted as immobilized by grief. (Her father has died.) For ages 7 and older, this retelling will run through July 27 in different Brooklyn locations. At 2 p.m., Chez Bushwick, 304 Boerum Street, (212) 352-3101, youthontarget.org; $15; $10 for 12 and under.

Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California opposes ending the federal ban on offshore oil drilling, which puts him at odds with a fellow Republican, Senator John McCain, the party's presumed nominee for president. On Thursday, Mr. Schwarzenegger, lower right, criticized politicians who suggested that expanded oil exploration off the coast of the United States would lower gas prices. Speaking in Miami at a meeting on climate change, he said politicians were ''throwing around all kinds of ideas in response to the skyrocketing energy crisis and energy prices.''
Chrysler's Credit Chrysler has tapped a $2 billion credit line that was a condition of its sale last year from Daimler to Cerberus Capital Management, Daimler said this week.

The Fund for America, which had been expected to be a major Democratic vehicle in the presidential campaign for unregulated contributions known as soft money, is disbanding. It is the latest sign that the landscape may be changing for such groups. The group was created to be a clearinghouse for large donations that could then be funneled to various organizations on the left. It had distributed about $20 million since its founding last year.

While there may be no YouTube snowmen, rifle-toting questioners or lightning rounds with buzzers and lights, the official presidential debates this fall may offer a few new twists to the standard format. The co-chairmen of the Commission on Presidential Debates outlined several changes on Thursday they wanted to institute this year, including plans for a single moderator for each debate and for two of the forums to be divided into eight issue-based segments to generate lengthy discussions between the candidates.

Bo Van Pelt shot a six-under-par 66 at the Buick Open in Grand Blanc, Mich., giving him a two-shot lead after two rounds and a career-best 14-under 130 through 36 holes. Daniel Chopra (67) and Dudley Hart (68) are at 12 under. Rocco Mediate (69) made the cut at four under in his first tournament since losing to Tiger Woods in a playoff at the United States Open.

Floyd Landis will find out if he can reclaim his 2006 Tour de France title on Monday, when the Court of Arbitration for Sport said it would announce the result of a five-day hearing held in March. Landis appealed to the court after an arbitration panel in the United States ruled in September that he used performance-enhancing substances during his victory. He was stripped of his title and Oscar Pereiro was declared the winner.

Bills running back Marshawn Lynch had his driver’s license revoked in traffic court after saying he did not know he had hit someone May 31 while driving in Buffalo. Lynch pleaded guilty on a charge of failure to exercise due care; he also received the maximum $100 fine and $50 surcharge. A plea deal allowed him to avoid a hit-and-run charge.

Musicians, singers and record companies seeking more radio royalties won an initial victory in Congress on Thursday. The House Subcommittee on Courts, the Internet and Intellectual Property passed the Performance Rights Act, which would reverse terrestrial radio’s exemption from paying royalties to the performers of sound recordings, which satellite and Internet radio stations are required to pay. The measure still faces opposition in the House and in the Senate, which is considering its own version.

The closing credits of “The Dark Knight,” the highly anticipated sequel to “Batman Begins,” include a tribute to Heath Ledger, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Ledger, who plays the Joker in the film, directed by Christopher Nolan, died of an accidental overdose of prescription drugs in January. The tribute, which also acknowledges the death of Conway Wickliffe, a special-effects technician who was killed in September in an accident, reads, “In memory of our friends Heath Ledger & Conway Wickliffe.” The film opens July 18.

Nelson Mandela, below, celebrated his 90th birthday on Friday in London with a concert in Hyde Park to support his global campaign to fight AIDS. Proceeds from the show will go to 46664, the charity named after Mr. Mandela’s prison number and dedicated to raising awareness of the H.I.V./AIDS epidemic. Mr. Mandela turns 90 on July 18. Video of the concert, which was scheduled to include performances by Amy Winehouse, Josh Groban and the Soweto Gospel Choir among others, is available at 46664.com. ... New York Theater Workshop has announced its 2008-9 season, which will include new works by Peter Brook, Michael Weller and Naomi Wallace. The company also announced the inaugural season of Off Again, a series of concert versions of revivals of Off Broadway musicals. Proposed shows include “Iphigenia in Concert,” by Peter Link; “Promenade,” written by Maria Irene Fornes, with music by Al Carmines; and “The Waves,” written by Lisa Peterson, with music by David Bucknam.

The Swiss architecture firm Herzog & de Meuron has been enlisted to design a new residential tower in TriBeCa that will incorporate a monumental public sculpture at ground level by the artist Anish Kapoor, the project’s developer said. The real estate company Alexico Group, which also developed the Mark Hotel, said a design would be released in the fall. The tower is to rise at the intersection of Leonard and Church Streets, and the sculpture will be fully integrated into the architecture. Mr. Kapoor, who was born in India and lives in London, is known for vast public sculptures like “Sky Mirror,” a convex stainless steel reflecting sculpture that was installed at Rockefeller Center two years ago. Herzog & de Meuron’s many projects include the new national stadium for the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing, the Tate Modern museum complex in a former power station at Bankside in London, and an expansion of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis.

Members of Ailey II, below, the junior troupe of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, will perform in Berlin on July 5 to mark the reopening of the United States Embassy in the onetime capital of East Germany. The official opening of the embassy will be celebrated with a public open-air festival and stage program titled Amerikafest on the historic Pariser Platz, near the Brandenburg Gate. The official opening of the embassy will be on Friday, with President Bush and Chancellor Angela Merkel scheduled to appear. In addition to Ailey II, the soul singer Jocelyn B. Smith is scheduled to perform.

The Prado Museum in Madrid said on Thursday that “El Coloso,” right, the oil painting of a looming giant long attributed to Francisco de Goya, was probably painted by an assistant. The authenticity of the painting, which was created during Napoleon’s occupation of Spain, had been disputed by a Goya specialist at the museum, Manuela Mena, The Independent of London reported. “Stylistically, it is completely alien to Goya,” said Ms. Mena. “The person who painted the bulls in ‘El Coloso’ knew nothing about the anatomy of a bull, which Goya knew everything about.” José Luis Díez, a curator at the Prado, also claims that initials at the bottom corner of the work belong to Asensio Juliá, Goya’s assistant, The Telegraph reported. The painting has been omitted from “Goya in Times of War,” a special exhibition commemorating the bicentennial of the start of the Spanish War of Independence, which runs through July 13.

The movie version of “Frost/Nixon,” the acclaimed play by Peter Morgan, will open the London Film Festival in October, BBC News reported. The movie, directed by Ron Howard, reconstructs interviews between former President Richard Nixon, played by Frank Langella, and the British journalist David Frost, played by Michael Sheen, that were shown on television in 1977. Both actors are reprising their stage roles for the film. The annual film festival, now in its 52nd year, runs from Oct. 15 through Oct. 30. The movie also stars Kevin Bacon, Oliver Platt and Sam Rockwell. The play, which opened in London in 2006, later came to Broadway and earned three Tony nominations in 2007.

Fox ranked No. 1 in the ratings on a slow summer Thursday of network television, as “So You Think You Can Dance” led the night over all with 8.6 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The 9 p.m. dance competition followed Fox’s 8 p.m. game show, “Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?” (6.9 million), which edged past CBS’s rerun of “Million Dollar Password” (6.8 million) to win its time slot. CBS finished second for the night, attracting 7.2 million viewers at 9 for a “CSI” repeat and 5.7 million for “Swingtown” at 10. NBC was third, with “Last Comic Standing” from 8 to 10 (5.3 million) followed by “Fear Itself” (4.5 million). ABC earned a fourth-place finish with reruns of “Ugly Betty” at 8 (3.5 million) and “Grey’s Anatomy” at 9 (3.4 million). At 10, the first part of “Hopkins,” ABC’s six-part documentary filmed inside the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, led its time slot by a slim margin with 5.8 million viewers.

HALPER--Louise A., age sixty-three, passed away on Saturday, June 21 at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, NJ. Louise, born August 2, 1944, in Columbia, SC, was the beloved wife of Fred, and the mother of Jacob Halper of New York City and Reuben Halper of San Francisco. Louise was a Professor of Law, and Director of the Frances Lewis Law Center at Washington and Lee University in Lexington, VA. Louise'slong career as an activist for social justice began when she was a teenager in Tulsa, Oklahoma, where she participated in sit-ins protesting segregation. She continued her activism while pursuing her B.A. at Brandeis University. From there, she went on to earn her M.A. from RutgersNew Brunswick, and in 1973, her J.D. from Rutgers-Newark Law School. What followed was a distinguished 15year career in public interest law, during which she argued in state and federal courts, and in the United States Supreme Court. Louise worked closely with Morton Stavis, a founder of the Center for Constitutional Rights, and as Assistant Attorney General of New York, focused her energies on environmental justice. Following her years of legal practice, and while earning her L.L.M. from New York University, Louise began teaching, a field in which she earned the respect and admiration of colleagues and students alike. She began her teaching career at NYU Law School, moving from there to Washington & Lee University, where she taught property, jurisprudence, critical legal theory, and environmental law. During her 17-year academic career, she published and traveled widely and held many distinguished visiting positions at institutions in the U.S. and worldwide. She was a visiting Professor at Seton Hall University. As a Fulbright Fellow, she taught at Marmara University in Istanbul. Years later, she was a visiting scholar at Koc University, also in Istanbul. She taught at The American University in Cairo, and spent a year as a visiting Professor at Harvard Law School. In 2005, she spent part of her sabbatical in Iran, speaking on law and gender in Islamic societies. As a deeply loved wife, mother, sister, friend and mentor, Louise touched the lives of so many. She was an insightful observer of people who displayed an extraordinary curiosity and interest in the world. Her expansive intellect was matched only by her unbounded consideration and love for her family and friends. They, her colleagues and students, will remember her not just for her considerable academic and professional triumphs, but also for her warmth, kindness, wit, and humor. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, June 29 (1-5pm) at NYU School Of Law, Vanderbilt Hall, Greenberg Lounge, 40 Washington Square South, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Louise's name to the Center for Constitutional Rights (ccrjustice.org) or the Montclair, NJ chapter of the NAACP: P.O. Box 353, Montclair, NJ 07042.

BORUT--Helen, 94, born September 1, 1913 in New York City, died June, 24, 2008 in Washington, DC. Longtime resident of the Bronx and Putnam Valley and matriarch of an extended family spanning four generations. Helen was a constant and reliable presence in the lives of each of her family members and friends, whatever their age. Her table was a refuge for conversation and comfort food. A child of the depression, Helen lived a full life without wasting. She embraced art and music and all things relevant to the human condition. She demonstrated her love for people through the constant and steady application of compassionate acts. She is survived by her sons, Allan and Donald of Washington, DC, her two grandsons and her four greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Riverdale Temple, 4545 Independence Avenue at 246th Street on Monday, June 30, 2008 at 3:00pm.

ACHENBAUM--Leila (nee Auerbach) died, age 77, in NYC, June 26, 2008. Born in Montreal on September 4, 1930, daughter of Hyman and Sybil Auerbach. Married 1948 to Irvin Goldberg of Altoona, PA, they had four children, Mark, Kathy, Tina, Amy. Second husband Robert Lebendig (d.). Survived by husband Alvin Achenbaum, son Mark and partner David Lugowski of NYC; daughter Kathy and fiance Kevin Fitzgerald of Doylestown, PA; daughter Tina of Palm Desert, CA; and daughter Amy of Hilton Head, SC. Predeceased by sister Marjorie Lebovitz, survived by sister Judith Stolovitsky. Stepmother of John and Barbara Achenbaum, Marty and Lisa (Achenbaum) Kounitz, and Mark and Martha (Achenbaum) Bratt, and step-grandmother to Julie, Amy, Ann, Ben, Jake, Alex, and Tori. She scored highest marks of any female in Quebec upon graduation from high school, and attended McGill University. Extremely generous, engaging and artistic. Avid and skillful tennis player, also accomplished at bridge and painting. Volunteered at victim crisis centers and consumer hotlines. She loved New York, theatre, ballet, concerts, films, good books, museums, and traveling. She cherished friends and family, and mastered the arts of giving and living. Services: Riverside Memorial Chapel, Sunday, June 29, 11:15am. In lieu of flowers, send donations to Central Park Conservancy, UJA-Federation or the American Friends of the Weizmann Institute of Science, Israel.

EUGENE, Ore. -- For many of the men and women of the 1980 Olympic track and field team, the frustrations have mellowed, but the perspective remains. They still feel President Jimmy Carter should not have forced the United States to boycott the Moscow Olympics that year to punish the Soviets for their invasion of Afghanistan.

When Jason Giambi was hitting .150 in early May, the lowest average in the major leagues, he said Yankees Manager Joe Girardi and Kevin Long, the batting coach, kept him from plummeting into a mental funk. "Those were the two guys that really kept my head on straight and didn't let the human emotion get in the way where you look up at the board and you go, 'I'm hitting .150,'" Giambi recalled. Since then, Giambi is hitting .322 and seems look a good bet to be picked for the All-Star team and perhaps compete in the Home Run Derby. I asked Giambi about those possibilities for Sunday's Times and he used words like "cool" and "awesome" to describe how he would feel if he was selected. As Giambi's average deteriorated, he said that Long had told him to stop worrying about statistics. Instead, Long told Giambi to analyze each individual at-bat. "At the end of the game, we'd go in there and we'd line them up," Giambi said. "He would be like, 'Awesome, three out of four at-bats, a line drive or a hard-hit ball.' That's how we were breaking it down. He was like: 'Look at it, you're doing great. I know the numbers don't show it, but you are.' He told me to just keep doing the same things and I'd start to get out of this." Long was right. Giambi, who seemed lost in May, is a productive hitter again.

An article on June 8 about problems with New York City’s new policy of moving troubled teenagers out of group homes and into foster care misstated the reason that two teenage boys left the home of one foster mother, Mary Chancie, after six months and misstated the age of the older one during that time. The boys both left to live with relatives, as planned; neither “lasted only six months” because of behavioral problems. The older boy was 17 at the time, not 19. (He stayed with Ms. Chancie again for four months when he was 19; that departure was prompted by behavioral problems, Ms. Chancie said. Since the article was published, he has returned to her home.).

An article last Sunday about the TV series "Mad Men" referred incorrectly to the history of original series on its network, AMC. “Mad Men” is AMC’s first scripted drama series; the show is not AMC’s maiden voyage in original programming. (That occurred with "Remember WENN," a comedy about a radio station that ran on the network from 1996 to 1998 when it was known as American Movie Classics.).

Larrazabal is tied with Colin Montgomerie and Soren Hansen, and Lee Westwood is another stroke back.

To the Editor: The exorbitant fees charged by airlines for “extra” baggage (“Checking Baggage. Not at These Prices, ” June 15), pale in comparison with JetBlue’s recent doubling of fees to carry a pet in the flight cabin. My seat on a September trip to Tampa costs $94; to take my 12-pound miniature schnauzer in a carry-on bag, crammed under the seat in front of me, I must forgo the legroom, forgo carrying another carry-on bag, and pay $100. I could, of course, pay an extra $20 to recoup part of the lost legroom by purchasing a seat in the “extra legroom” bulkhead seats or I could find another airline for future trips. I am choosing the latter.

The 36 Hours column on June 15, about Vienna, misspelled the German for “Vienna” in a reference to a concert hall. And an accompanying map repeated the error and also misspelled the German for “Vienna” in reference to a club. The concert hall is Wiener Konzerthaus and the club is Badeschiff Wien — not Weiner and Wein.

Don't write off the tailfin yet. Car design, like fashion, runs in cycles, and there's been a noticeable stiffening of design since the aero gumdrop look of the '90s typified by Ford's Taurus. Look at the lumps, bumps, and appendages growing on the backs of Cadillacs and BMWs. Unless I miss my bet, right now, in the design studios, fins are growing again. And you'll see them on concepts, then high-end cars, then on everything, in 2-3 years. -- JAYBIRD248

VISITING THE RUSSIAN ORTHODOX CATHEDRAL, CHISINAU, April 26, 2008 Vicki Smith, 56, a homemaker from Thomaston, Georgia, pictured with her husband, Dannie, 54, a physical therapist. ''This was a Christian mission trip, sponsored by the Christian Medical and Dental Association. We traveled to several poor villages, and we saw so much hopelessness because there are no jobs and the fathers or mothers have to go to another country to work for a few months at a time. We listened to them and prayed with each one, and they seemed to be comforted that someone cared. When the picture was taken, we were on a tour of Chisinau, and we were in a very old Russian Orthodox church. I remember thinking that all the beautiful icons, paintings and other antique things in the church were beautiful and old, but also that it all seemed a waste of money. I thought of all the 'stuff' we were looking at and thought that really, God is simple and seen in creation, not in what our hands can make. We plan to go back, hopefully next year, because we love the people of Moldova and realize that we can offer them hope.''

WHEN does a merger mean more choice for consumers? When it's a satellite radio merger -- at least according to XM and Sirius, which have been trying to complete their merger plans for more than a year. Now, indications are that the deal may be consummated this summer. The final stumbling block has been securing approval by the Federal Communications Commission. But last week two developments appeared to push it toward a conclusion. First, the companies filed a letter with the F.C.C. outlining voluntary commitments the operators would agree to should the merger be approved. Then the F.C.C. chairman, Kevin J. Martin, issued a statement that the conditions outlined by the companies would, in his opinion, satisfy the requirement of being in the public interest. And he would put his support behind the merger.

When Mom and Dad Share It All I find it disheartening that in 2008 couples who share parenting duties equally have such an unusual arrangement that it merits a cover article in your magazine (June 15) and that much of Lisa Belkin's focus was on organizations that assist parents who may strive to achieve such equality. My husband and I equally divide parenting tasks in much the same manner as the schedule set forth on your cover, but not because we discuss divisions of labor ad nauseam or take classes to learn how to split the work -- it simply never occurred to either of us that we're not equally responsible.

Now you can travel comfortably between New York City and Toronto without spending your entire budget en route. Neon, a new low-fare bus service from Greyhound Canada and Adirondack Trailways, offers two daily departures from both cities for as little as $1 (there is at least one $1 seat on every bus) -- although a $25-to-$75 price range is more likely -- one way. Buses have video screens, Wi-Fi service and power outlets. Customers board in New York outside Penn Station and in Toronto at the Royal York Hotel. Walk-up tickets cost $85 (one way), and the better deals (the earlier the reservation, the lower the price) are available at www.greyhound.com.

WITH a collection of some 5,000 vintage sunglasses, Benjamin Montoya has become the go-to guy in Los Angeles for exceptional eyewear. He has frames bequeathed to him by Dennis Roberts, who designed sunglasses for Elvis Presley and Elton John. And, from the 1960s, folding Persols like those Steve McQueen wore in ''The Thomas Crown Affair.'' Mr. Montoya, who owns several dozen of those, considers them the Rolex Daytona of sunglasses. ''They're rare and timeless,'' he said. Now the eyewear connoisseur has introduced a line inspired by such classics but redesigned to look bolder and fit better. Best sellers include Kayne, a take on a vintage Persol pair, punched up with clear frames and gradient lenses; and Nicole, based on a preppy '80s version of those worn in ''Breakfast at Tiffany's.'' Ewan McGregor recently bought two pairs, both with black frames and green lenses.

I fell for choux paste, a k a cream-puff dough, early in my cooking career. At one of my first restaurant jobs, creating pretty slices for our cheese-plate service left the kitchen with countless dismal little ends of cheese. (We cooks called them cheese butts.) Choux (pronounced SHOO) paste proved the perfect home for the orphaned bits of Boucheron, Roquefort and cheddar. The cheeses would be stirred into the paste, which then was shaped into neat quenelles and fried into beignets; crisp on the exterior, oozy and fragrant on the interior. From near garbage came near perfection, all thanks to a strange, decidedly old-fashioned dough. There's something about choux paste that is both gleefully absurd and a little bit miraculous. First, there's its preparation, which seems to defy pastry logic. You cook a paste of water, butter and flour over the stove and then furiously beat eggs into the still-steaming ball of dough. At various moments, the choux looks like an unredeemable mess, but with continued stirring, it comes together into a glossy, golden paste. When baked, it inflates into gloriously hollow little balls, perfect for filling. It's no wonder choux paste inspires goofy desserts like the towering, pyramidal croquembouche, the bicycle-tire-shaped Paris-Brest and that banquet standby, choux-paste swans.

HAREM pants, or ''dropped crotch'' trousers, as fashion editors have democratically termed them, are having a tough time winning over the crowds. Straight men find them abominable, and the fashion blogs are having a field day: ''My eyes! My eyes!'' screamed the British site The Fashion Police. ''Show me the person that wouldn't look like a giant toddler in them.'' Even Harper's Bazaar is having trouble swallowing the saggy-pants pill. In this month's issue it reported that pants for fall were an odd-looking lot but that the ''clear-cut winner for weirdness was the drop-crotch trouser.'' So why are chic women like Diane Kruger, Naomi Campbell and Emmanuelle Alt of French Vogue wearing them? And why are they all over the fall runways, not to mention the winter resort collections? ''Because it's fresh,'' said Nevena Borissova, the owner of the SoHo boutique Curve, where a healthy stock of Isabel Marant dropped-crotch pants (the originator of the trend, some say) have nearly sold out. ''In Paris last fashion season, all the French women were wearing them, while all the Americans were in tight jeans.''

A FUR hammock, leather knit boots, a cashmere sweater with crystal elbow patches -- for over a decade, Bless, a design label operating in Paris and Berlin, has been turning out imaginative clothing and objects, and presenting them in stylized guerrilla stores around the globe. In Mexico City, it furnished an abandoned house, dangling clothes from the door frames. In Werkleitz, Germany, it planted its wares in specialty shops: bedsheets printed with a sleeping couple were put in a linen store; a hairbrush that sprouted blond tresses was displayed at a cosmetics shop. ''It made everything look especially cuckoo,'' recalled Desiree Heiss, who, along with Ines Kaag, are the Bless masterminds. Now, for the first time in eight years, the two have returned to New York to present an exhibition and pop-up shop at the new art space Ludlow 38. Inspired by its architecture, they created 10 steplike boxes, each packed according to a different theme. One is filled with their favorite designs, another with found items. Each box will be sold as a whole. ''The point is not to create a sale situation,'' Ms. Heiss said, ''but to show our whole universe and the things we believe in.''

WHEN the new models arrive in showrooms this fall, 50 years will have passed since the apogee of the tailfin. Most automotive historians agree that the 1959 model year marked the extreme reach of the tailfin craze, which was born on the 1948 Cadillac as the fishtail. In a brief time, the tailfin became a symbol of the space age and of prosperity -- and excess. To mark the anniversary, the Antique Automobile Club of America Museum in Hershey, Pa., is offering the show ''Fins: The Rise and Fall of the Tailfin in American Automotive Design'' through Oct. 12.

''IT'S only a two-minute ride to school,'' said Adam. ''Calm down, Dad.'' He had his final final exam of high school, in economics, at 10:15 on June 17, and it was now 10:03, and how was he preparing? Reviewing his notes? No. (That's what his older brother, Ben, would do.) Sharpening those No. 2 pencils? No. (That's what his younger sister, Annie, had done that morning, before the eighth-grade state math test.) A half-hour before the final, Adam had strolled around the corner to the deli to get himself a bacon, egg and cheese sandwich. As much as I urged him to get to school early so he'd be in the right frame of mind for the test, so he would graduate and go away to college in the fall (please, dear Lord), he would not accelerate his pace by one newton.

AFTER releasing scores of albums, winning 12 Grammys and gaining a place in the Country Music Hall of Fame, Emmylou Harris still has one goal that she hasn't accomplished: playing the accordion. ''I thought I'd be able to learn it, but I've given up,'' Ms. Harris, 61, said. No matter. On ''All I Intended to Be'' (Nonesuch) she sings the type of dazzling harmonies and arrangements that won her all those awards, accompanied by a new quintet that includes someone who plays the instrument that has so far eluded her grasp. Apparently the sound has taken root. Released on June 10, ''Intended'' is her highest ranking album, reaching No. 4 on Billboard's country charts and No. 22 on the main chart. As she took in the hackberry, maple, magnolia and oak trees near her Nashville home during a break from her tour, Ms. Harris spoke with Winter Miller about what she's listening to now. Porter Wagoner

HUNTER S. THOMPSON, who has been lionized in two feature films, served as the model for a running character in ''Doonesbury'' and is the subject of enough doctoral dissertations to build a bonfire, now has a documentary devoted to him, ''Gonzo: The Life and Work of Dr. Hunter S. Thompson,'' by Alex Gibney. Thompson, who always seemed to keep one drug-crazed eye on posterity behind his ever-present shades, would surely be pleased but not surprised. But how to freshly document the life of a man who was his own Boswell, whose books and articles slavishly documented his own every tic, whoop and hallucination? A journalist who announced his arrival in American letters by riding with the Hells Angels and in the end choreographed a memorial from the grave that made the Burning Man bacchanal seem chaste?

THE NEWSBarack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton appeared together at a political rally, putting aside their primary rivalry to set a fresh tone for the Democrats in the fall campaign. BEHIND THE NEWS Hundreds of people turned out for the rally on Friday in Unity, N.H. (where else?), part of a day of choreographed harmony. Although a litany of issues remain between the two former adversaries, Mrs. Clinton used the occasion, three weeks after suspending her campaign, to renew her endorsement of Mr. Obama and pledge to do all she could to help the Democrats take the White House. ''Unity is not only a beautiful place,'' she told the crowd, ''it's a wonderful feeling, isn't it?''

SET in the summer of 1994, ''The Wackness,'' a Sundance favorite that hits theaters on Thursday, couldn't be more timely. Just think of the current flannel shirt and floppy knit-hat trends, the revival of Doc Martens, the impending spinoff of ''Beverly Hills, 90210'' and the reunion tours of Stone Temple Pilots and New Kids on the Block. Premature as it may be, the '90s are having a comeback. ''We're in a transitional period,'' said Greg Krelenstein, the former MisShape, who now is the host of Loser, a weekly '90s-themed party. ''So people go back to the things they loved.''

Because the archetypal women in Daphne Guinness's short film, ''The Phenomenology of Body,'' revolve on turntables, it is somehow easier to think of her as a D.J. than as a director. Because the chic images she assembled appear in some sense random, it seems appropriate to think of her as more a sampler than any kind of auteur. And because the story depicting women through the ages is, as its creator points out, not exactly linear and only accidentally feminist, it is easy to see in it hints of autobiography, the personal history of a slightly anachronistic sort of being, less actor than spectator, a woman upon whom the events of life impress themselves. While few outside the style world are likely to have heard of Guinness, she exercises considerable fascination in fashionable circles and the tabloid press. The daughter of the Guinness brewery heir Jonathan Guinness, formally known as Lord Moyne, Guinness is also the step-granddaughter of Sir Oswald Mosley, the British fascist; the ex-wife of Spyros Niarchos, of Greek shipping fame (she married him at 19; he settled a reputed $40 million dollars on her when they divorced in 1999); and lately the subject of tabloid rumors related to her friendship with Bernard-Henri Lévy, the wealthy, and married, French writer whose intellect is almost as celebrated as his luxuriant head of hair.

Mayors Michael R. Bloomberg of New York and Thomas M. Menino of Boston — the co-founders of the Mayors Against Illegal Guns coalition — wrote an opinion essay in The Wall Street Journal today arguing that last week’s Supreme Court decision is not bad news for gun-control advocates. (The court found that the Second Amendment guarantees an individual right to own a gun for self-defense.)The essay, “Some Gun Rules We Can All Agree On,” elaborates on opinions Mr. Bloomberg advanced on Thursday, following the court’s landmark decision. The two mayors argued that the ruling does not affect most existing state and local restrictions on gun ownership and argued, “For years, shouting matches over the Second Amendment drowned out reasoned discussion of any middle ground.”

At the Urban Assembly School for Law and Justice in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, 93 percent of the senior class — nearly all college-bound — collected their diplomas on Thursday, far higher than the city’s graduation rate of roughly 50 percent. Many in the first graduating class of 79 seniors were from the city’s poorest neighborhoods, and have struggled academically for years, but they received the kind of personal attention more commonly associated with the priciest prep schools.

So who is the world's worst dictator? I was thinking about that after seeing Slate's article suggesting that Africa's worst dictator isn't Robert Mugabe but Teodoro Obiang of Equatorial Guinea. It's true that Obiang fritters away his country's money on fast cars and other toys, but he's nothing like his uncle, the previous dictator. One of the legends in the State Department is of the American diplomat who killed another during their posting in Equatorial Guinea; his defense was that he had gone mad listening to the screams of men being tortured in the nearby police post.

In February, I wrote about researchers at Los Alamos National Laboratory who proposed sucking carbon dioxide out of the air and turning it into gasoline as one way to battle global warming and find a new energy source. That prompted vehement e-mail messages from some readers who felt that I was being irresponsible in suggesting that gasoline could have a long-term future, and that to raise that possibility drew attention from electric cars, which they said was the real solution.

A beekeeper never really knows what's going on inside a hive until she takes a look. You can see bees coming and going, and you can observe a funnel of activity at the entrance and assume the worst (bees have a natural swarming instinct, often expressed as a small tornado of swirling bees at the front of the hive, which can presage a mass exodus). Are they ready to swarm because of cramped quarters from bulging frames of honey? No way to know until you take a look.

The Obama campaign is hitting the airwaves with its second general election advertisement. This one is meant to highlight Senator Barack Obama's commitment to the American worker, the campaign says.
Randy Credico is a standup comedian and opponent of severe drug laws. Video by Corey Kilgannon.

As the Paris men's shows wind down to a close, it's time for a men's wear video retrospective courtesy of Suzy Menkes, a T columnist and one of our favorite colleagues over at the International Herald Tribune. The clips feature candid interviews with style guydols like Tom Ford (he confirms he is dressing Daniel Craig in the next James Bond installment!), Paul Smith (he plays peek-a-boo behind a pair of bright green shoes!), Stefano Gabbana and Domenico Dolce (they describe Naomi Campbell as being like a little sister!), Bottega Veneta's Tomas Maier (he says the key look in a men's wardrobe is the jacket!), and, er, Fergie? Check out that clip, if for nothing else, to see Fergie call Menkes a "goddess" and confess to always loving the fetching IHT fashion editor. Suzylicious!

Psychology | Haven't much of a clue? Guess again. Researchers have found that the average of first and second guesses is more accurate than either guess on its own. But it's best to solicit other views, a la "The Wisdom of Crowds": more heads are far better than one. -- Economist

"Ten Scariest Escapes from Death" lifted NBC's "Dateline" to No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday among adults 18 to 49, though the network finished second in total viewers. [A promo for the show promised, "People trapped in burning planes, sinking ships, a roaring avalanche, skydiving accidents ­ and each one is caught on tape. EUGENE, Ore. -- The 800 meters is one of the beautiful races in track and field. In the shorter races (100, 200 and 400), one mistake usually means defeat. In the next-longest Olympic race, the 1,500, there is enough time and distance to overcome some mistakes.
Television and radio station operator CBS Corporation said Monday that it completed its acquisition of CNet Networks, the Associated Press reports.

OMAHA -- In 1992, Roque Santos made the Olympic team as a decided underdog, handing the world-record holder Mike Barrowman his first defeat in the 200-meter breaststroke in three and a half years at the United States Swimming trials. Sixteen years later, he is at these trials, reprising his role as the earnest long shot.

OMAHA - For about two minutes, Hayley McGregory was on the top of the world. Swimming in the second-to-last heat of the preliminaries for the 100-meter backstroke at the United States Olympic Trials, McGregory, a 22-year-old from Texas, clocked a 59.15 to break the world record by .06 seconds.

At the very least, U.K. home builder Taylor Wimpey's announcement today that it will write down about £660 million (or about $1.3 billion) is confirmation that the slump in Britain is no mirage or the creation of negative media reports. As part of its announcement Taylor Wimpey says the U.K. market has entered a "significant downturn," according to Reuters coverage.

"This is a sad, sad day," John R. Bolton said last week as the Bush administration prepared to take North Korea off the U.S. terror list. Today, the longtime Bush loyalist and former top State Department official on arms control had a few more words on the decision -- 955 of them in fact. It seems as though the only time you hear about car companies fudging horsepower numbers, it's when they're busted advertising more beans than are actually present in the under-hood burrito. Mazda got in trouble for exaggerating the 2001 Miata's power output. Ford had to recall the 1999 SVT Mustang Cobra when owners realized its motor fell about 20 horsepower short of its official numbers. In the early 2000's, Hyundai offered its customers extended roadside assistance and warranties after several models suffered double-digit horsepower deficits.

"The contract covering 120,000 members of the Screen Actors Guild expires on Monday night at midnight, and that date was widely seen as likely to pass without a settlement or work stoppage, plunging the world's entertainment capital into labor limbo," Reuters reports.
The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee is setting its sights on unseating 13 House Republicans with a new radio ad featuring a faux President Bush.

Astronomy | Score one for the amateurs: A Dutch science teacher has made a major discovery participating as one of the armchair astronomers helping out the pros at the Sloan Digital Sky Survey. "Hanny's Voorverp" (Hanny's object) is a weird blob that appears to be a light echo of a long-ago galaxy. As a result of this find, look for more attempts to harness the power of many. -- Science News, Economist

Business | Jacob "Kobi" Alexander, an Israeli-born tycoon now on the lam in Namibia, seems to have bought himself status there as a modern-day "Lord Jim." He flew in 200 friends for a swanky bar mitzvah for his son, and has endowed a $20,000 scholarship. But unlike the Joseph Conrad character, Alexander exhibits little of the "acute consciousness of lost honor." Rather, he's into "effective bribery and ostentatious display." -- Wall Street Journal

Even in the dog days of summer, student loans are generating some news. Thanks to Congressional action, the interest rates charged on some federal student loans are set to drop as of July 1. Here is a complete update on the new rates, from the Web site of the federal Education Department. Rates charged on new subsidized Stafford loans, on which the government pays interest while students are enrolled, will fall to 6 percent from 6.8 percent; rates on unsubsidized Stafford loans will remain 6.8 percent.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo. - As the nation prepares to celebrate the Fourth of July, Senator Barack Obama opened a weeklong patriotism tour here on Monday, hoping to explain and define his American ideals to ward off skepticism and answer questions from his critics.

Two other experiences with the less-is-more style of cooking. The first involved large beans (you could call them gigantes, but maybe they were limas; once the beans are out of the bag and into the jar, I forget what I bought), a sausage, a meatball, a strip of bacon. It's cassoulet, or fabada, or franks 'n' beans, or whatever you want to call it. In any case, a quarter pound of meat (really: two ounces of sausage, one of ground lamb/beef, maybe one of bacon) fed four. With salad.

Lazard said Monday that it has hired three investment bankers for its middle-market unit, as it seeks to expand upon the business it created by buying Goldsmith Agio Helms last year.
UBS, responding to a Reuters report that it might consider putting its Paine Webber business on the block, said "no major business is for sale."

A few minutes after Manager Jerry Manuel called his Mets "kind of the second team" in New York on Sunday, I saw David Cone drinking a cup of coffee in the Yankees' clubhouse. Cone, who pitched for the Mets and the Yankees, is now announcing for the YES Network.
As Citigroup tries to rebuild itself from the wreckage of the credit crunch, it is rethinking how it rewards its executives.
A Chinese investment fund manager became the latest person to win a lunch with billionaire Warren Buffett.
A young man convicted of running a hedge fund scam in Connecticut has filed a federal lawsuit against New York University, claiming the school owes him a diploma, The Associated Press reported.

Carl C. Icahn is expected to file his definitive proxy by July 4 in the fight over Yahoo, CNet News reported. Last Thursday, the activist investor filed a preliminary proxy form. The definitive version will signal whether he will run a dissident slate of directors to unseat a majority of Yahoo's board members, or look to get rid of just a few.

So far this has been a challenging year for companies hoping to go public. But it has been even rougher on venture capitalists who were hoping to get a big payday from such an offering.
The steel magnate Lakshmi N. Mittal joined the board of Goldman Sachs as an independent director, a move that underscores the growing importance of the developing world for Wall Street's behemoths.
Lakshmi Mittal is looking at entering the takeover battle for the Rio Tinto mining group, The Financial Times reported on Monday, quoting people familiar with the situation.
France Telecom, in a surprise move, has dropped its $42 billion bid for TeliaSonera, the Swedish-Finnish telephone company whose board had rejected the unsolicited offer as too low.

Looking to profit from the breakup of Russia's national power monopoly and the demise of regulated electricity prices, Dubai World and Roskommunenergo have offered to buy Russian utility OGK-1 for 125 billion rubles ($5.34 billion).

Expected further write-downs by Merrill Lynch and worry that it may have limited options for raising capital have renewed speculation that it may sell its stake in financial information provider Bloomberg LP, MarketWatch reported.

Barclays Chief Executive John Varley is disputing an analysts' report last week suggesting that the 4.5 billion pounds ($9 billion) his firm is raising may not be enough for it to ride out the credit crunch.
Wachovia could be forced to buy Prudential Financial out of a retail brokerage joint venture the duo share, according to The New York Post.

6 Days to L'Étape. Training update: Monday off, blogging by the pool near Avignon, on my way to the Pyrenees from the Alps. Last Friday, when I was unable to post due to a problem with the "WeeFee" at the gorgeous hotel in Hautluce we stayed at on our way south from the Chamonix valley, I did an hour-long endurance ride down to the village of Beaufort and back up to the hotel, which is halfway up the climb to the Col des Saisies.

Every few years, the conflicts of interest so deeply embedded in the Wall Street business model emerge from the shadows for all to see. Coming to light last week, courtesy of Massachusetts regulators, was UBS's dual roles in the auction-rate securities market, which have had devastating effects on the people and institutions that invested in them, The New York Times's Gretchen Morgenson wrote in her latest Sunday column.

Shareholders of Australia-based Herald Resources must decide between identically priced takeover offers, one from Bumi of Indonesia and the other from an acquisition vehicle formed by Indonesia's Antam and China's Zhongjin Lingnan.
Citigroup will restructure its distressed debt unit following the departure of top traders Jeff Jacob and John Humphrey to start a hedge fund, MarketWatch reported.

Britain's Prince Charles has coordinated a team of property executives to run a 1 billion pound ($1.99 billion) fund to invest in sustainable developments across the nation's urban areas, The Telegraph reported.

When Rob Williams, the senior vice president for music at Real Networks, came by last week to talk about a bunch of announcements by Rhapsody, the music service jointly owned by Real and Viacom, I have to confess that I felt a bit sorry for him. As I've written, I have a soft spot for the idea of listen-to-anything subscription music services. But they have essentially failed in the market.

The South Korean steel firm Posco agreed to buy a stake in Macarthur Coal for $404 million a day after top steel maker ArcelorMittal raised its holding, potentially blocking any takeover of the Australian miner, Reuters reported.
Immofinanz and Immoeast will acquire Constantia Privatbank's real-estate unit for $695 million, Bloomberg reported.
Britain's Taylor Wimpey has confirmed that it is in talks with its largest institutional shareholders for a cash injection, The Telegraph reported.

Clive Cowdery has thrown in the towel on a planned 400 million pound ($797 million) injection into the British lender Bradford & Bingley. On Friday, Mr. Cowdery's Resolution group said a deal had been made impossible by the bank's refusal to open its books.

OpenTable.com, the Internet's dominant restaurant reservations site, does a good job of telling people where they can dine. It does a poor job of telling people where they should dine -- the best restaurants in a certain region, within a certain cuisine category or for a certain occasion. For that, newer foodie community sites like Yelp and ChowHound do a much better job.
Vodafone Group's mobile phone unit in Qatar is planning an initial public offering in Septemer, The Peninsula newspaper reported.

Belgian-Dutch financial services group Fortis received $630 million in capital from Russian billionaire Suleiman Kerimov as part of its recent share issue, The Wall Street Journal said, citing people familiar with the matter.

Monday marks the 100th anniversary of the moment when something roared through the empty skies over Siberia and exploded, blasting forests for hundreds of square miles. More such incoming space rocks are inevitable. Are we ready? No.

The Yankees will have a new player when they oppose the Texas Rangers at Yankee Stadium on Monday night. Brett Gardner, a speedy outfielder, told The Times and Democrat of Orangeburg, S.C., his hometown newspaper, that the Yankees had summoned him to the Bronx.
