Queen Quedith Earth Harrison, 19, became one of the youngest members of the United States team for the Beijing Games on Sunday.

Joseph S. Blatter, the president of soccer’s world governing body, FIFA, said for the first time that a contingency plan existed to move the 2010 World Cup from South Africa in the event of a natural disaster. The 2010 tournament has been plagued by stadium construction delays, security fears, transportation problems and the possibility of power outages, leading to concerns that the first World Cup staged in Africa may have to be shifted to another country.

Steffen Peters won the national Grand Prix dressage championship and earned one of four Olympic berths by winning the freestyle event at the Olympic dressage trials in San Juan Capistrano, Calif. Debbie McDonald, Courtney King and Leslie Morse also qualified for the United States team for the Beijing Games.

Kenny Perry shot a six-under-par 66 on Sunday to finish at 19-under 269, one shot better than Woody Austin and Bubba Watson, to join a short list of multiple champions at the Buick Open in Grand Blanc, Mich. Perry, who won this event in 2001 at Warwick Hills, has 11 victories on the PGA Tour, including the Memorial earlier this month.

The Spanish rookie Pablo Larrazabal won the French Open for his first European Tour victory, closing with a four-under 67 to beat Colin Montgomerie by four strokes at Versailles. Larrazabal, who had to play two qualifying rounds, finished at 15-under 269.

Loren Roberts made a 29-foot double-breaking birdie putt on the par-5 17th hole in the Commerce Bank Championship in East Meadow, N.Y., and he went on to win his first Champions Tour event this year. Roberts bogeyed the closing hole, but his three-under 68 gave him a 12-under 201 total and a one-stroke victory over Nick Price and Lonnie Nielsen. Roberts won his eighth event on the Champions Tour, the same total he had in his PGA Tour career. He has three second-place finishes on the Champions Tour this year, including last week, when he finished behind Jeff Sluman.

The Advertising column on June 12, about two television shows in which the sponsors are integral to the show’s content, misspelled the given name of a host of one program and misstated her background. She is Shanon Cook, not Shannon. And she is a host and contributing reporter on CNN; she is not an actress.

A chart on June 6 with an article about the rising rate of foreclosures and overdue mortgage payments had incorrect rates for some states in some editions. Seven states — Arizona, California, Georgia, Illinois, Louisiana, Mississippi and Rhode Island — had delinquency rates of 4 to 5 percent, not 5 to 6 percent. Two states, Indiana and Ohio, had delinquency rates of 5 to 6 percent, not over 6 percent. A corrected version can be found at nytimes.com/business.

A picture in some editions on Wednesday with the continuation of an article about a review by New York City suggesting that many ground zero workers who are suing over their injuries are not as sick as their lawyers have claimed carried an erroneous credit in some copies. The photograph of workers searching the rubble of the twin towers was by Ruth Fremson of The New York Times, not by Tyler Hicks of The Times.

An article on Thursday about career academies, which combine job placement, college preparation and classes beyond the vocational trades, misidentified a high school in southern California that has such a program, called the Global Academy of Finance. It is Valley High School, not Santa Ana High School.

An Associated Press picture in some editions on Wednesday with an article about the federal government’s consent to release most of the grand jury testimony in the 1950s atomic espionage case against Julius and Ethel Rosenberg was published in mirror image. Julius should have been on the right and Ethel on the left.

An article on Thursday about a speech by President Bush at a fund-raising event for the Michigan Republican Party misspelled the surname of the cleric who delivered the invocation at the event. He is Rabbi E. B. Freedman, not Friedman.

HOWARD--Alice, 79, my wife of 57 years, died on Memorial Day. If there were ever two people made for each other, it was Alice and me. We were true soul-mates, passionately devoted to each other; Alice introduced me to great paintings, and I introduced her to great music. We were both deeply concerned about the human condition, and proud that our son, Henry, inherited that trait. Alice will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her: friends and family in California, New York, Oregon, Florida, Georgia, Oklahoma, New Jersey, and England. She came up a few months short: we would have loved to see Barack Obama become the next President of the United States, with his wife, Michelle, by his side. For further information please contact Pierce Brothers, Westwood Village, CA. (310)474-1579. Al Howard

VANESSA HUDGENS ''Identified'' (Hollywood) ''Gone With the Wind'' is the sort of song you would expect from someone who lives a very public life in the tabloids but still plays a wide-eyed high school student on the Disney Channel. A gently aching piano-soul number with echoes of Alicia Keys, it's the best vocal performance on ''Identified,'' the second album from Vanessa Hudgens, a star of the ''High School Musical'' franchise. ''I don't care what anybody thinks/I've released that fear,'' Ms. Hudgens sings about the end of a traumatic relationship or, lyrical ambiguity being a coming-of-age hallmark, the transition from child star to adult maybe-star. ''I don't have to be what you want me to be/Because every time I try to fit in/It feels like I'm in a prison.''

HOLLAND--Lila (Inkeles), she passed away peacefully on June 27, 2008. She was the adored wife for 51 years of Richard, the much beloved mother of Leslie and Adam, the cherished and devoted grandmother of Zoe and dear sister of David Myron Inkeles. She was a generous, caring and loving friend to all her large family and many friends. Lila was active in many civic and philanthropic organizations. She was a past president of the Five Towns Community Chest as well as holding many other positions. She served on the Board of the South Shore Executive Committee of the UJA-Federation of NY. She recently co-chaired the Rosenwald Mission to Israel and is a Lion of Judah. She was a volunteer in the Literacy Program mentoring at-risk Students. Lila was the consummate New Yorker and enjoyed participating in many cultural events offered in the City of New York. Lila truly loved her time spent in the Berkshires. Her home was her haven, which she shared with her family and friends. Her great pleasure was the enjoyment she received from the peace and tranquility of her surroundings at Goose Pond. Words cannot express how much she will be missed -Her kindness and spirit. -Her dignity and elegance. -Her inner beauty. -Her light and love. Services Monday 12 noon at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. Shiva will be observed a the Holland's residence.

Joseph O'Neill's novel ''Netherland,'' set in post-9/11 New York, earned a comparison to Fitzgerald and Gatsby from Michiko Kakutani, who called it ''a resonant meditation on the American Dream.'' The story of a transplanted Dutchman who takes up with a multiculti cricket team on Staten Island, it ''captures the city's myriad moods, its anomalous neighborhoods jostling up against one another, its cacophony and stillness, its strivers, seekers, scam artists and scoundrels,'' she wrote. ''Most memorably, he gives us New York as a place where the unlikeliest of people can become friends and change one another's lives.'' Tonight the author, himself a transplanted Irishman/Dutchman and enthusiastic cricket player, reads at the Half-King. ''Post 9/11, a New York of Gatsby-Size Dreams and Loss,'' by Michiko Kakutani

BOEHLY--Lawrence William passed away in Wilton, CT on June 27, 2008. Larry was born on October 5, 1937 in New York City. He was the proud son of Erna and Henry Boehly who both emigrated from Germany in the 1920s. Early in his life, Larry moved to Northern Virginia and stayed in that area until early 2008. Larry graduated from George Washington University with a degree in Mechanical Engineering and thereafter spent his professional life as a home builder and an engineer, finding solutions to complex engineering problems. Larry had passion for life. He loved spring skiing in the West and he loved cars. For Larry, a car could never be too fast or a road too sinuous. Larry married Carol Bartz, from Mount Holly, NJ in 1971 and they had two children. Larry's strongest passion was his family. Larry was a dedicated husband to Carol and a loving and caring father to Todd and Mandi. In his later life, Larry found more love to give Todd's wife, Katie and Mandis husband, Bill Schmauch who provided him with four treasured grandsons; Nicholas (6), Zachary (4) and Clay Boehly (2) and Tanner Schmauch (9 months). A celebration of Larry's life will be held Tuesday, July 1, 2008 at one o'clock at the home of Todd and Katie. Larry is loved and remembered by his wife Carol, son Todd of Darien, CT and daughter Mandi of Wilton, CT and their families as well as his two brothers Bill of McLean, Virginia and Erhardt (Bo) of Arlington, Virginia and loving mother-in-law, Nellie Bartz Caldwell. The family wishes that expressions of sympathy and love for Larry go to the Boehly Family Foundation.

SOULJA BOY ''The Teen of the South'' (mixtape) The new Soulja Boy mixtape begins with a debate: an audio clip lifted from MTV of talking heads discussing whether this 17-year-old Atlanta rapper deserves to be labeled one of the ''hottest M.C.'s in the game'' over more established candidates like T. I. and Young Jeezy. Last year he released the single ''Crank That (Soulja Boy),'' which has sold more than three million digital copies and another three million ringtones. Though his exuberant debut album ''Souljaboytellem.com'' (ColliPark/Interscope) didn't fare quite as well, selling just under a million copies, he has been one of the most important hip-hop innovators of the last 12 months, and one of the few bright spots in a dismal retail landscape.

ALKALINE TRIO ''Agony & Irony'' (Epic) Ten years ago the Chicago punk band Alkaline Trio released its debut, a minor classic with a mildly blasphemous title. Since then, there have been personnel changes (confined to the drum chair) and musical add-ons (a curtain of strings), along with a regional shift: no one in the band lives in Chicago anymore. But Alkaline Trio's pugnacious irreverence hasn't wavered, and neither has its near-gothic fixation on darkness and death.

O'CONNELL--Francis (Frank) A., died in Grass Valley, CA on June 29, 2008, at age 94. Born on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and raised in the Bronx, he remained a New Yorker at heart despite spending his final thirty-five years in northern California. He graduated from St. Nicholas of Tolentine in the Bronx and Fordham Law before WWII and practiced labor law at Cravath, Swain and Moore. He enlisted during WWII and served in Australia as a cryptographer. After the war he returned to Cravath, and then worked as a labor relations attorney in private industry. He went back in the Army for the Korean war, as a Captain in Anna Rosenbergs labor office in the Department of Defense. Afterwards, he returned to corporate labor law, retiring from Olin in 1977 as V.P. of Industrial Relations. He was widely recognized as a proponent of employer prerogatives in labor relations, building on the thinking of Boulware and other corporate employee relations leaders before him. Before retiring, he worked with John M. Olin to transform the Olin Foundation into a powerful and well-endowed underwriter of ideas. O'Connell then ran the Foundation before again retiring in 1982. He was an ardent free market conservative who served on the board of National Review with his friend William F. Buckley. His first wife, Alice (Costuma), daughter of a New York City Deputy Police Chief, died a few years after their marriage. He was then married to Mary (Reinhart) who lives in California. His third wife, Marjorie (Furry), with whom he had a daughter, Anne, is deceased. His fourth wife, Kathryn (Beitsch Grant), who he married in 1964, passed away in 1969. He has been a loving parent to her sons Arthur Grant, William Grant and Anthony Grant for 44 years. He married Eleanor (Tremoreux) in 1971 and she survives him, as does Anne, Arthur, William and Anthony and their families.

HAUSDORFF--Joyce Kogan, 83, of NYC on June 22nd, peacefully at her son's home. Beloved wife of Don, devoted mother of John, Bill, Rich, generous mother-in-law of Goska, Wendell, Sue, loving grandmother of Kate, Ben, Becky, Max. Graduate of Hunter and Columbia with an Education Doctorate. She had a long, fulfilling career in nursing and teaching, retiring as Associate Dean from Downstate Medical Center. With Don she traveled around the globe, and was an avid and voracious consumer of the ballet, opera, theater, museums, and concerts. No memorial service. Donations to American Cancer Society.

WOLF PARADE ''At Mount Zoomer'' (Sub Pop) ''Strike up the band as the ship goes down,'' Dan Boeckner sings in ''The Grey Estates'' on ''At Mount Zoomer,'' the second album by the Montreal band Wolf Parade. ''Strike up the band, we have survived,'' sings its other songwriter, Spencer Krug, in ''Bang Your Drum.'' There's always something major at stake in the songs of Wolf Parade, which harnesses perky pop drive to existential reflections. The lyrics are the thoughts of a jittery urbanite pondering destruction, renewal, love, art and the meaning of home. The songs don't hide their seriousness. But they don't let it slow them down either.

The summer blockbuster season opens with the long Fourth of July holiday weekend. Among past top weekend openers, ''The Perfect Storm'' was unusual in that it did not involve some blend of superheroes or aliens. Most summer hits do, and several of the top 15 films have also starred Will Smith. They include ''Independence Day''; ''Men in Black,'' above, and its sequel; and ''Wild, Wild West,'' the 1999 remake of the TV series, which ranks No. 13 on the list of Fourth of July openers. Representatives from Consolidated Edison and the union that covers nearly 9,000 workers at the utility returned to the bargaining table on Tuesday morning after a three-day cooling-off period. City officials reminded the construction and real estate industries on Tuesday that the city’s new Construction Codes — the first modernization of the Building Code since 1968 — formally took effect today. The codes, based on international models, expand requirements for fire protection, structural integrity and work-site accountability and are intended to focus the Buildings Department’s enforcement work on the buildings and job sites that “pose the most serious safety hazards to construction workers and the public,” the Bloomberg administration said in a statement.

For Beijing, 1949 was a big year. That's when the People's Republic was founded, right here in the capital. It was also the year that the Beijing Machinery and Electric Institute opened a factory in the Sanlitun neighborhood. Nearly 60 years later, that long-idle industrial ruin has become the centerpiece of one of the most unusual drinking and dining complexes in town. 1949-The Hidden City opened a few weeks ago, and it's drawing praise from diners, architecture fans, preservationists and my out-of-town visitors, who get dragged there whether they want to or not.

The National Rifle Association will pour $40 million into an advertising campaign timed to the fall presidential election, with more than a third of the money devoted to attacking Senator Barack Obama on the issue of gun rights.

5 Days to L'Étape. Today's training: a look at the course for the Étape. After arriving in Pau, where the course starts, late on Monday, I drove part of the course and rode up to the Col du Tourmalet under my own power. Despite accidentally starting in the village of Campan, rather than Sainte-Marie-de-Campan, where the first road signs announce the start of the ascent, I managed to make it to the pass over 14 miles away slightly ahead of my goal of 2 hours: arriving 1 hour 46 minutes later and getting a high five from another cyclist who had just made the climb and was standing right at the top urging on total strangers.
After losing his leg in an accident, Van Phillips created a new prosthetic device. The result? Speed.

Denver has promised to make its nearly 4,000 homeless people comfortable during the Democratic National Convention in August, enlisting private donations for extra hours at local shelters, flat-screen televisions tuned to cable news and bingo games in the evenings.

Alex Rodriguez left his hotel room Tuesday with a special guest. It's not who you may think, considering the gossipy whirlwind surrounding him now. It was John Challis, a teenager with liver cancer whose story is beautifully told here.

Film | Is the tide turning against special effects? In the new Batman flick "Dark Knight," the director, Christopher Nolan, favors real physical stunts over computer-generated imagery. One explanation: "Movie fans have gorged on digital eye candy-and, perhaps fearing retinal diabetes, now they're cutting back." But is this stuff more suitable to the art house than the multiplex? -- Wired

Bush's "considerable legacy": An article on the op-ed page of The Boston Globe by Andrew J. Bacevich, a professor of history and international relations at Boston University, is bouncing around blogland. Bacevich says that "in crucial respects, the Bush era will not end Jan. 20, 2009. The administration's many failures, especially those related to Iraq, mask a considerable legacy." He continues:

Metabolomics is the study of metabolites, "the by-products of the hundreds of thousands of chemical reactions that continuously go on in every cell of the human body." It's the key to personalized medicine (which, by the way, might imperil the traditional meal, making it "more like a course of medical treatment than a pleasure"). -- Economist

[Update, 9:35 p.m.: Dana Vollmer advanced to Wednesday night's 200 free final by going 1:58.58 in her semifinal, the sixth-fastest qualifying time. In the 200 IM semis, Kaitlin Sandeno qualified seventh for Wednesday night's final at 2:13.64. Amanda Beard did not qualify; she was 10th (2:13.94).]

Last night was a scrambled eggs kind of night. I'm sure you've had one or two of those yourself. You know, when you get home and it's a little too late for serious cooking, and maybe a little too hot as well.

There was an eruption of assertions in recent days that the increasing summer retreats and thinning of Arctic Ocean sea ice might be a result not of atmospheric warming but instead all the heat from the recent discovered volcanoes peppering the Gakkel Ridge, one of the seams in the deep seabed at the top of the world.

Media | Newspapers doomed? So what? Richard Posner writes that "long after newspapers like the New York Times and the Washington Post have ceased print publication, their Web sites may be among the leading Internet news services." He reasons that aggregation sites like Google News are "parasitic on print newspapers' large staffs of reporters." Something has to fill the void of print, or the Internet will kill "the goose that lays the golden egg." -- Becker-Posner Blog

MOSCOW -- Skinhead violence against foreigners and non-Slavic Russians has been steadily growing in Russia for years, but reached a new level of grotesque last fall when video surfaced on the internet of the grisly double murder of two bound, dark-skinned men.

Management is not participating in the offer nor is directors and according to the last United Rentals proxy they own 2.1 percent of the company.

Updated | 4:20 p.m. The Obama campaign's willingness to have supporters communicate and strategize with each other online, rather than wait for commands from on high, has been credited with giving him a crucial advantage over opponents who favor more traditional political tools. Nothing better typifies this strategy of letting the grass-roots grow on the campaign headquarters' front lawn than its popular Web portal, my.barackobama.com, where supporters can form groups and create blogs.

When you cover the Yankees, you get to have an easy, friendly relationship with Derek Jeter. He is the most accessible superstar around, never afraid to spend time around his locker, making small talk, answering questions.

Kudos to the Baltimore Orioles for an inventive promotion. Six days out of seven, the Orioles are one of the best teams in baseball. It's that seventh day that's the problem. The Orioles are 1-12 on Sundays, 40-27 on the other six days of the week.

Heading to the Democratic National Convention in August and want to ensure that you will rub shoulders with governors, senators and other movers and shakers? Nancy Jacobson, a Democratic fund-raiser and wife of Democratic pollster Mark Penn, is organizing a "by invitation only" event with candidates, policy makers and others. The price tag: $10,000.

"It's not 'Soylent Green' again, but the old Hollywood sense of lawless New York is rearing its ugly head," writes Julia Vitullo-Martin of the Manhattan Institute. Nearly two months have passed since Microsoft pulled the plug on its bid for Yahoo. It now looks as if the deal has little hope of being resurrected, even with Carl Icahn threatening to oust Yahoo's board.
India's climate plan will cheer champions of solar power who say the technology could be a cheap and easy solution for sunny nations seeking to replace coal-fired power plants with clean electricity.

But then Mr. McCain got to the point and darkly warned that similar decisions might be forthcoming if Mr. Obama wins the White House.

It's official: Bank of America has acquired Countrywide Financial, marking the completion of an audacious rescue of one of the most troubled lenders in the United States. The deal will expand Bank of America's reach in the mortgage business -- but, in the current environment of rising defaults and delinquencies among American homeowners, the expansion obviously comes with serious risks.

The consortium of Hollywood producers that is negotiating a new contract with the Screen Actors' Guild gave the union a "last, best, final" offer on Monday night, shortly before the midnight deadline for the old contract expired.

Retailer Steve & Barry's is readying plans to close more than 100 of its stores, and is contemplating a full liquidation should it not find emergency financing, The Wall Street Journal reported on Monday.
General Electric's property investment arm said on Tuesdy that it has bought a portfolio of loans from Credit Suisse for 642 million euros ($1.01 billion).
It's understandable if morale at UBS is a little low right now. The Swiss bank has been battered by the markets lately, and is under pressure from investors to break itself up.

The pace of initial public offerings in the first half of the year was the slowest since 2003, as investors shunned risk amid fears of a stalling economy, Bloomberg News reported. There were 333 initial offerings through the end of June, compared with 702 in the comparable period a year ago.
As of Tuesday, Google has the option to sell its 5 percent stake in Time Warner's AOL division. Google acquired the stake via a 2005 deal with Time Warner under which it invested $1 billion.
InBev stuck to its proposal to take over reluctant bid target Anheuser-Busch and said it would seek to give the latter's shareholders a direct voice if the U.S. brewer still refused to talk.

Wall Street was abuzz on Monday with speculation that a rival firm was going to make a bid for Lehman Brothers at a substantial discount to its current price. The chatter sent shares of the embattled investment bank plummeting by 11 percent.
Anheuser-Busch is gearing up to reduce the size of its work force as much 15 percent to cut costs. At least one in every 10 jobs will be eliminated, Bloomberg News reported.
JPMorgan Chase reigned supreme across global debt and equity underwriting for the last quarter.

D.E. Shaw & Company said Monday it would take steps to help broker a resolution to the dispute between Huntsman and Hexion Specialty Chemicals, including possibly providing debt or equity to foster a merger.

Federal authorities asked a federal court on Monday to force UBS, the Swiss banking giant, to turn over the names of wealthy American clients suspected of evading taxes through secret offshore accounts.
The venture capital industry's trade association said Tuesday that for the first time since 1978, not a single venture-backed company went public in the second quarter.

CIT Group, which has reported four consecutive quarterly losses, said Tuesday it will sell its home-lending businesses to Lone Star Funds for $1.5 billion in cash and the assumption of $4.4 billion in debt.
Qantas Airways may sell part of its frequent flyer business in an initial share sale, Bloomberg News reported. The news sent the airline's stock to its biggest gain in more than a year.

BCE will defer its 294 million Canadian dollar ($290 million) second-quarter payout to investors as it attempts to make its $52 billion takeover more palatable to a group of lenders that are seeking more favorable terms on the deal's financing, The Globe and Mail reported.
Lakshmi Mittal did indeed consider buying a stake in bid target Rio Tinto to expand his interests in iron ore but has decided against it for now, sources familiar with the matter told Reuters.
MBIA attempted to allay investor fears on Monday saying it has sufficient cash and collateral to cover additional requirements on certain contracts that were triggered by a recent Moody's downgrade.
Jefferies has hired former Barclays Capital director Andrew Bracey to lead the group's consumer and retail investment banking division in Europe and the Far East, The Telegraph reported.
Having walked away from Bradford & Bingley, Clive Cowdery has other fish to fry.

The takeover battle for Enodis has ended with Manitowoc the victor over Illinois Tool Works . The two companies went head-to-head in a blind auction, The Telegraph reported, with Manitowoc making the winning bid at 1.2 billion pounds ($2.4 billion).

Mark Schwarz of Newcastle Partners on Monday filed a lawsuit against Royal Philips Electronics, saying that the company's plan to sell its 69.5 percent stake in MedQuist for $285 million undervalues the company and violates its fiduciary duty to MedQuist's minority investors, The Daily Deal reported.

Faced with the worst market for first-time share sales in five years, Hong Kong's stock exchange has begun accepting applications from companies in countries such as Russia and Mongolia to sell depositary receipts, Bloomberg News reported.
Florida sued Countrywide Financial and its chief executive, Angelo R. Mozilo, on Monday, accusing it of engaging in unfair and deceptive trade practices in mortgage lending, Reuters reported.
San Francisco's Agiliance has raised a $10 million round of funding, Venture Beat reported. The startup offers IT tools to help companies comply with regulations and manage risk.
Dubai International Capital has hired David Smoot as managing director of private equity, Bloomberg News reported. Mr. Smoot is an 11-year veteran of Morgan Stanley and will be based in Dubai.
A judicial official says French police have detained a former Airbus president in an insider trading investigation at its parent company EADS.

In its first deal since launching last October, Talon Merchant Capital has gone retro. The private equity startup has acquired Lava World International, maker of 1960s teenager bedroom staple, the lava lamp.
(Update below) Huntsman appears to be taking a novel approach to Hexion's Delaware suit: Go slow.
Properties on the market in North Carolina, Tennessee and Maryland.
Photos of a four-bedroom villa in Montego Bay, Jamaica.
In a concert by the NeoLit Ensemble at Bargemusic on Friday night, it was refreshing to encounter a slate of works by seven female composers, presented without any hint of corrective polemic.

This cautionary series, which begins Tuesday on ABC Family, woodenly follows the trials of a 15-year-old named Amy, a good student and dutiful daughter who becomes pregnant the first time she has sex.
“Election Day” is a ground-level look at the Bush-Kerry election on Tuesday on PBS’s “P.O.V.” series.
Photos of a 16th-century farmhouse in the Aquitaine region of southwest France.

As I reported Saturday, venture capitalists experienced a very poor second quarter. The industry's trade association said Tuesday that for the first time since 1978, not a single venture-backed company went public in the quarter.
Location: Oxford, Ohio
The new system of paying fares involves dipping MetroCards into a machine at the bus stop before the bus arrives.
A decision to relax Georgia’s gun laws has led to a clash over whether people can legally carry concealed firearms in Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport.
At New York magazine, Mr. Felker was credited with inventing a widely imitated formula for glossy weeklies.
A 25-year-old cheerleading instructor from the Bronx gathered with friends to watch her performance as a contestant on “American Gladiator.”
Although Erison Hurtault did not qualify at the United States Olympic track and field trials, he will still compete in Beijing, for his parents’ country of birth, Dominica.
Mike Mussina got virtually no support from the Yankees’ offense, leading to an unlikely 2-1 victory for the Texas Rangers.

The Tampa Bay Lightning signed left wing Ryan Malone to a seven-year contract. Malone was acquired from Pittsburgh last weekend along with Gary Roberts for a conditional draft pick in 2009. Malone played in 77 games with the Penguins last season, scoring 27 goals and finishing with 51 points. Roberts signed a one-year deal with Tampa Bay.

Bobby Murcer has had to curtail his work for the YES Network as a Yankees analyst and cut short the book tour for his autobiography to deal with the effects of brain cancer and shingles, his family said Monday in a statement.

Following is a transcript of audio responses to questions from The New York Times for Abdelmalek Droukdal, the leader of Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb. The responses were in Arabic and were translated by The New York Times:.
Shoddy fielding, a slumbering offense and poor pitching, stalwarts of the first 81 games, reappeared as the Mets opened the second half of their season with a 7-1 loss.
Ken Griffey Jr.’s two-run homer helped the Reds defeat the Pirates and the Astros released Shawn Chacon following a scuffle with the team’s general manager.
The offer for Russia’s biggest wholesale power producer comes from Dubai World and OAO Roskommunenergo, an energy trading company headed by the son of the Kremlin’s top real estate official.

Lawyers for the Bank of New York Mellon were in a Russian court to defend the bank against a $22.5 billion claim filed by the Russian customs service relating to a money laundering scandal in the late 1990s.
A rebound by the manufacturing sector helped the economy of Canada grow by a stronger-than-expected 0.4 percent in April after two months of contraction.
KANSAS CITY, Mo. (AP) — They opened the season by sweeping the Tigers in Detroit, and their long-suffering fans sat slack-jawed, wondering if the Kansas City Royals had finally turned the corner.
Nikon’s D700, priced at $2,995, packs the considerable abilities of the company’s hefty $5,000 flagship, the D3, into a more svelte 2.2-pound device.
Monday was June 30, a momentous day: The last day of the first six months of the year. It was also the perfect time to ask: How’s it going?
A Chilean judge sentenced the former secret intelligence chief for Gen. Augusto Pinochet to two life terms for a 1974 murder case.
A prosecutor said that a French soldier did not act deliberately when he used live ammunition during a mock antiterrorist exercise.
The Taiwanese government announced that it was relaxing rules limiting the access of journalists from mainland China to Taiwan.
Geert Wilders, a Dutch legislator, will not be prosecuted on charges of inciting hatred of Muslims for his film and comments written for a Dutch newspaper, prosecutors announced.
Russian prosecutors said they had charged a gang led by two teenagers with murdering 20 people in a series of racist killings over the last year.
Jason Kidd is the only member of the United States Olympic basketball team who already has an Olympic gold medal, which he won in 2000 in Sydney, Australia.

A film review on Friday about “Trumbo,” a portrait of the blacklisted Hollywood screenwriter Dalton Trumbo, misspelled the surname of one of the actors who reads from his letters in the movie. He is David Strathairn, not Straithairn.

A theater review on Friday about “A Brush With Georgia O’Keeffe,” at St. Luke’s Theater on West 46th Street, misspelled her husband’s surname at several points. As noted elsewhere in the review, he was Alfred Stieglitz, not Steiglitz. A picture caption with the review carried an erroneous credit. The picture, showing Natalie Mosco as O’Keeffe and David Lloyd Walters as Stieglitz, was by Richard Kent Green/Workshop Theater, not by Katvan Studios.

A picture caption in some editions on Monday with an article about efforts by some Swift boat veterans who object to the term’s political connotation misspelled the surname of a man who served with John Kerry in Vietnam and who helped start the Swift Boat Veterans for Truth group in 2004. He is Roy F. Hoffmann, not Hoffman.

A theater entry in the Listings pages on Friday about “Forbidden Broadway,” at the 47th Street Theater, included an outdated title and description. The show is “Forbidden Broadway: Dances With the Stars!” — not “Forbidden Broadway: Rude Awakening,” which ran earlier this year. That show, not the new one, was the 25th-anniversary version.
FRONT PAGE.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the Libertarian presidential candidate Bob Barr misidentified the political office Mr. Barr was seeking in 2002 when he accidentally fired an antique pistol at a fund-raising event. He was running for a seat in the House, not the Senate.

The two-time Masters champion José María Olazábal failed to qualify for the British Open when he bogeyed the third hole of a playoff in Sunningdale, England. Darren Clarke also failed to qualify at the 36-hole qualifier for European Tour players.

The cyclist Jeannie Longo of France, a five-time world champion, has clinched a berth in her seventh Olympics at the age of 49. Longo staked her claim last week with wins in the road race and the time trial at the French national championships.

New England Patriots defensive back Willie Andrews was held without bail after being accused of pointing a handgun at his girlfriend’s head. Andrews, 24, was arrested after an incident that occurred about 1 a.m. Monday, after he returned home and had an argument with his girlfriend, according to Gregg Miliote, director of communications for the Bristol County (Mass.) district attorney’s office. Andrews is being held pending a hearing on Thursday.

Indiana University’s president told the N.C.A.A. infractions committee that the hiring of the former Hoosiers coach Kelvin Sampson was “a risk that should not have been taken.” The president, Michael McRobbie, said during a private session on June 14 that Sampson had betrayed the university’s trust by violating N.C.A.A. recruiting regulations.

Nicolás Massú of Chile, who won gold medals in singles and doubles in tennis at the 2004 Olympics, was among 12 players given special places in singles at the 2008 Games in Beijing. The places are awarded by the International Tennis Federation to players who did not meet requirements for direct acceptance. Massú’s ranking of 131 was too low to qualify.

Brenda Villa and Heather Petri will lead the United States women’s water polo team and Tony Azevedo and Ryan Bailey will head the men’s squad at the Beijing Olympics. Those four, all three-time Olympians, were on the 13-player teams announced Monday.
Gov. Matt Blunt signed a bill outlawing cyberbullying in a ceremony miles from where a 13-year-old girl committed suicide after being harassed on the Internet.
Representative Vic Snyder, a Democrat, announced that he and his wife, the Rev. Betsy Singleton, pastor at a United Methodist church in Little Rock, are expecting triplets.
Two of more than 1,400 wildfires in Northern California choked parts of the Sierra Nevada foothills, darkening a 100-mile stretch of Interstate 80 with clouds of smoke.
Medicare will delay processing doctors’ claims to give Congress time to pass legislation that would block a scheduled 10 percent cut in payments.
The death of a 22-year-old man who had been taken into custody on the night the Boston Celtics won the N.B.A. championship has prompted an official investigation.
For Stephen A. Schwarzman, the co-founder of the Blackstone Group, an accounting rule partly explains why the American financial system looks so wobbly these days.
The Rays have scuffled with the Red Sox a half dozen times since 2000, including a June 5 brawl in Boston that resulted in eight players being suspended.
Ryan Ludwick, the Cardinal’s terrific outfielder, has become a symbol of a team that has surprised everyone this year.
The retailer Toys “R” Us is counting down to July 26, when it begins selling toys from the latest “Star Wars” film, “The Clone Wars,” an animated movie that opens in August.
Tiger Woods will not be able to host his AT&T National event this week due to major reconstructive surgery on his left knee.
In Staten Island, party leaders have been in a frenzied effort to find a candidate to succeed Francis H. Powers, who died on June 22, on the ballot for Congress.
The co-owner of Big Brown is apparently starting to lose patience with the horse’s outspoken trainer, Rick Dutrow.
Both opponents of coal use and the company that wants to build the plant said it was the first time a court decision had linked carbon dioxide to an air pollution permit.
A grand jury refused to indict a 62-year-old man who fatally shot two burglars last November as they fled his neighbor’s house.
The World Health Organization said that the new test promises to help significantly improve treatment and prevent the spread of the airborne infection.
The United States shooting team is encountering a complication because of government controls against exporting firearms and weapons technology to China.

Exactly 10 years ago, with a surprise hit album of obscure, prerevolutionary Cuban pop songs, the Buena Vista Social Club played a sold-out concert at Carnegie Hall. Wim Wenders filmed the show for a documentary released a year later. Now the Carnegie concert (which featured, above from left, Eliades Ochoa, Ibrahim Ferrer and Compay Segundo) is finally being released as a double CD by World Circuit/Nonesuch. The album, “Buena Vista Social Club at Carnegie Hall,” is not expected to be released until the fall, but on Tuesday iTunes will start selling a live version of Segundo’s song “Chan Chan.”.

Survivors of the “10 Scariest Escapes From Death” lifted NBC’s “Dateline” to No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday among adults 18 to 49, as the network led the night in that demographic but finished second in total viewers. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 7.5 million viewers tuned in to ‘Dateline’ from 9 to 1, building on the 5.5 million who watched the Olympic Trials on NBC from 7 to 9. But CBS edged past NBC in total viewers, thanks to the strength of “60 Minutes” at 7 (9.3 million) and “Million Dollar Password” at 8 (8.5 million). Two reruns of CBS’s “Cold Case” garnered 6.7 million viewers, at 9, and 6.4 million, at 10. ABC finished third with a lineup of all repeats, while Fox was fourth, averaging 4.2 million viewers for its broadcast of the 1997 movie “The Lost World: Jurassic Park.”.

A runner will speed through Tate Britain’s neo-Classical sculpture galleries every day for the next four months. The tightly choreographed live performance, called “Work No. 850,” has been created by the artist Martin Creed for the Tate Britain Duveens Commission 2008, sponsored by Sotheby’s. A runner will sprint as fast as he or she can every 30 seconds through the gallery. A statement from museum officials said: “Work No. 850 is about the purest expression of human vitality. This investigation into the body celebrates physicality and the human spirit, the constant ebb and flow of nature.” Mr. Creed, who won the 2001 Turner Prize, advertised in running magazines to recruit semiprofessionals, who are being were paid $19.95 an hour, Bloomberg News reported.

George Carlin, famous for listing the seven words that he said you can never say on television, was remembered at a private memorial service on Sunday as always having a kind word for everyone, The Associated Press reported. At the service attended by about 150 people, the 71-year-old comedian, who died of heart failure on June 22, was memorialized by the comedians Bill Maher, Garry Shandling and others as a kind man without enemies. “What everyone said tonight is if you spent time with my father, whether it was five seconds or five hours, he was kind, attentive, connected to you, compassionate,” said Kelly Carlin McCall, the comedian’s daughter.

Luciano Pavarotti’s estate has been settled “fairly,” a lawyer for Pavarotti’s second wife, Nicoletta Mantovani (above, with Pavarotti), said in statements published on Monday after reports of a dispute between Ms. Mantovani and three of his daughters from his first marriage. In a report from Agence France-Presse, Ms. Mantovani’s lawyer, Anna Maria Bernini, told the daily newspaper Il Resto Del Carlino: “Nicoletta and the three daughters are friends. It was this affection that made it possible to reach the best conclusion to the negotiations on the estate.” The Italian news media have published a number of reports that the last will of Pavarotti excluded his daughters from a trust fund worth more than $15 million. Pavarotti died of pancreatic cancer in September.

The philanthropic group ArtVenture is establishing an annual award, the Freedom to Create Prize, for three categories of artists whose work promotes human rights. The winner of the main prize, open to artists in the visual, performing or literary arts, will receive $50,000, half to be donated to a group that furthers the artist’s cause. A $25,000 prize will be given to an artist younger than 18, with $10,000 for a scholarship and $15,000 to be donated to a cause. A final $25,000 will be awarded to an artist who is imprisoned for his or her work. The deadline for entries is Oct. 31, and the winners are to be announced on Dec. 1.

The music download service Rhapsody has stepped up competition against Apple’s iTunes by making its catalog of five million songs available without electronic restrictions on playback or duplication and allowing free previews of complete songs. With its announcement on Monday, Rhapsody, a joint venture by RealNetworks and MTV Networks, became the latest digital music service to do away with digital rights management, or D.R.M., which prevents users from making unauthorized copies of songs and can also determine which electronic devices can be used to listen to the songs. Apple has used D.R.M. since it began selling music on iTunes five years ago — and offers song previews at 30 seconds — but the other major download services, Amazon.com, Napster, Wal-Mart and eMusic, all sell music without restrictions. Rhapsody will restrict full-song previews to 25 a month, and the company also announced that users of Verizon’s V Cast service can listen to songs from Rhapsody through their cellphones.

LANG--Theresa. Marymount Manhattan College mourns the loss of Theresa Lang, an alumna, former trustee and longtime friend. The Theresa Lang Theatre, the Theresa Lang Center for Producing and the Theresa Lang Scholarship Fund have all been made possible by her generosity to the College. Mrs. Lang served on the Board of Trustees of MMC for nearly ten years. The College awarded Mrs. Lang an Honorary Doctorate of Fine Arts at the 2008 Commencement in honor of her commitment to the College. Our deepest sympathies go out to Mrs. Lang's husband Eugene Lang and her family. Judson R. Shaver, Ph.D. President Anne C. Flannery, Esq. Board Chair

VINCENT--Edgar. A true gentleman whose knowledge, integrity and sparkle have enriched our industry for decades. You shall always be remembered with deep affection, mio caro Edgardo. Mirella Freni VINCENT--Edgar. Such a gentleman, I loved him very much and will miss him terribly. He represented me magnificently. Love, Roberta Peters VINCENT--Edgar. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Edgar Vincent, one of opera's most distinguished citizens. For more than half a century, he guided and publicized the careers of many of our greatest stars, including Ezio Pinza, Rise Stevens, Birgit Nilsson, Beverly Sills, Mirella Freni, and Placido Domingo. We will miss his wise counsel, warm friendship, and devotion to the art form he loved so much. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director VINCENT--Edgar. The board of the George London Foundation is deeply saddened by the passing of fellow trustee Edgar Vincent, a brilliant mind and a devoted friend of Nora London, and longtime publicist of George London. He will always be remembered. Nora London, President VINCENT--Edgar. Edgar was a devoted friend and treasured colleague of my mother, Beverly Sills. We shall miss him. Meredith H. Greenough VINCENT--Edgar. A quiet giant and wise mentor. He was the last of a breed and beloved by his artists. Arrivederci, Edgardo. Salvatore Licitra VINCENT--Edgar. New York City Opera mourns the passing of our esteemed and cherished friend, the irreplaceable Edgar Vincent. Long in our midst as trusted adviser and press representative of such eminent City Opera artists as Beverly Sills, Placido Domingo, and Samuel Ramey, Edgar blessed our company and the entire classical music community with his encyclopedic knowledge, wise counsel, loyal friendship, and passion for music. Edgar's passing marks the end of an era. We will sorely miss his gentlemanly Old World charm and manners, and his modest, practical, and rock-solid presence. Susan Baker Chairman of the Board

HERGUTH--Edward E., died suddenly on June 26, 2008. Beloved husband of Candace and devoted father of Andrew and Alexander, son of Henry and the late Katherine Herguth, brother of William and Sally Herguth all of Terrytown, NY and loving uncle to seven nieces and nephews. A kind and gentle man, loved by everyone who knew him. A funeral mass will be held on Wednesday, July 2nd at 1pm at Grace Church, Franklin Avenue, Millbrook, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Grace Church, P.O. Box 366, Millbrook, NY 12545.

HOWARD--Alice, 79, my wife of 57 years, died on Memorial Day. If there were ever two people made for each other, it was Alice and me. We were true soul-mates, passionately devoted to each other; Alice introduced me to great paintings, and I introduced her to great music. We were both deeply concerned about the human condition, and proud that our son, Henry, inherited that trait. Alice will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her: friends and family in California, New York, Oregon, Florida, Georgia, Oklahoma, New Jersey, and England. She came up a few months short: we would have loved to see Barack Obama become the next President of the United States, with his wife, Michelle, by his side. For further information please contact Pierce Brothers, Westwood Village, CA. (310)474-1579. Al Howard

Washington THE interim between the primaries and the parties' nominating conventions is, according to ancient writ, a fertile period for presidential campaigns to talk about how they plan to expand the political map in the fall. This year is no different. Barack Obama's strategists are suggesting that the first African-American presidential nominee of a major political party can parlay increased turnout among black voters into a string of victories in the South.

BRENNAN--Mary McMorrow, passed away at her home in Bronxville, NY on Saturday, June 28th following a five month illness. She was the daughter of the late Michael and Catherine McMorrow and the adored and beloved wife for 59 years of the late Vincent P. Brennan. She was the treasured mother of Mary Gerster (Alec) of Rowayton, CT, Vincent Jr. (Pat) of Abbottsford, B.C., Joan Hearst (William) of Montclair, NJ and David (Dierdre) of New York City. She was Nan Honey to Eileen Lane (John), Brennan Gerster (Molly), Elvira, Liam and Eli Brennan, Billy, Mary and Andrew Hearst. She was YaYa to great - grandchildren Grace, Kate and Isabella Lane, Mackenzie and Joey Brennan and Laley Gerster. She is also survived by her devoted sister Toddy Savarese (Louis) of Saddle River, New Jersey and was predeceased by her sister Peggy McMorrow. She graduated from St. Sebastian School, Bishop MacDonald High School and Manhattanville College and received a design degree from the New York School of Interior Design. The family will receive friends at McGrath and Son at 20 Cedar Street in Bronxville, NY from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 on Monday, June 30th. There will be a Mass at St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville on Tuesday, July 1 at 10am. Donations may be made in her name to the Jansen Hospice Group, 69 Main Street, Tuckahoe, NY 10707 and the Irish Repertory Theater, 132 West 22nd Street, NY, NY 10011.

RUBIN--Walter, passed away June 30 in Brunswick, ME, at the age of 77. Beloved husband of Rita, loving father of Seth and Rachel, adoring grandfather of Sam and Aidan. Graveside service Thursday July 3, 11am at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

ATTOLICO di ADELFIA-Lorenzo, passed away at his home in Paris on June 23rd 2008. He is survived by his brother Gian Giacomo Attolico, his sister Maria Carmela Hambleden, his son Gian Giacomo Attolico Trivulzio and his grandchildren Polimnia and Clemente Attolico Trivulzio. Lorenzo lived in Europe and in the US working for NATO and the United Nations. A true Renaissance man, unwavering in his beliefs, he bravely struggled against an unbeatable illness. He rests in peace in his native Italy, at Adelfia (Bari). A memorial service will be held in New York City in September. A more precise time and place will be announced at a later date.

HAUSDORFF--Joyce Kogan, 83, of NYC on June 22nd, peacefully at her son's home. Beloved wife of Don, devoted mother of John, Bill, Rich, generous mother-in-law of Goska, Wendell, Sue, loving grandmother of Kate, Ben, Becky, Max. Graduate of Hunter and Columbia with an Education Doctorate. She had a long, fulfilling career in nursing and teaching, retiring as Associate Dean from Downstate Medical Center. With Don she traveled around the globe, and was an avid and voracious consumer of the ballet, opera, theater, museums, and concerts. No memorial service. Donations to American Cancer Society.

LIPTON--Esther Bashevkin, 98, passed away on Sunday, June 29th. She was married to the late William L. Lipton of Pittsfield in 1934 and he predeceased her in 1993. She had three children: Claire Lipton Zimmers of Boca Raton, FL, Mark Lipton of New York City and Middlefield, MA, and Alan Lipton, who predeceased her last year. She also leaves four grandchildren and ten great-grandchildren. Funeral services are scheduled for Wednesday, July 2nd in Pittsfield, MA.

(49) HEART OF DARFUR ''Wide Angle'' begins a new season with an examination of what the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, has called ''the largest humanitarian crisis in the world.'' Reporting from El Fasher, the capital city of North Darfur in Sudan, this episode ventures into the sprawling Abu Shouk refugee camp and beyond the city borders into the rebel-held areas of Sudan, where violence is reported to be escalating again (above, a group of rebels). The episode ends with a discussion between Nicholas D. Kristof, an Op-Ed columnist for The New York Times, and Aaron Brown, the series's anchor. 8 P.M. Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY, July 3, 11am.

MONTAG--Ann. Peacefully, and with the grace and dignity befitting a grand, proud and elegant lady, the 91 year old matriarch of our family left us to join Popa Jack on Sunday, June 29. She will be honored and remembered with tears of joy forever by daughters Toba and Jill, sonsin-law Mickey and Elliot, grandchildren and grandchildren-in-law Cathy, Merrie and Andy, Liz and Mike, Becky and Alon, Ben and Allysa, Marc and Laurie and great-grandchildren Jason, Jake, Justin, Dylan, Aron, Dani, Gaby, Sophie, Olivia, Jack and her sister Joan. She cannot be replaced. Graveside service will be held on Wednesday, July 2 at 11am at Sharon Gardens Valhalla, NY.

MILTON--Edgar G. Wall Street Bull with a Heart of Gold, born January 23, 1916 in NY, died in Pompano Beach, FL June 27, 2008. Educated in Europe and worked for NBC in New York. Was drafted into the U.S. Army in 1940. Landed in Omaha Beach, participated in the liberation of France. Chief de-nazification Officer Civil Administrator in Bonn, Germany. Awarded multiple bronze star medals and Croix De Guerre. Member French Olympic Swim Team 1932. Member, Harlequin Rugby, NYAC, Racing Club of France. Joined Merrill Lynch in 1953 as a broker and retired as V.P. Survived by wife, Denyse, His children, Patricia, Audrey, Sandy, Jeffrey, nine grandchildren, 10 great grandchildren, nephew and nieces. Private Memorial Service. Memorials to Parkinson's Foundation

FINK--Raymond. It is with the deepest regret that we inform you of the death of Ray Fink on June 28, 2008. Born April 4, 1924, lived since childhood in Larchmont, NY, former officer in the US Navy, served honorably in WWII. Loving husband to Carole, (recently departed), successful businessman, founding member of the Beach Point Club, excellent all-around athlete, traveler and adventurer, having once hiked the Milford Track in New Zealand. Passionate sailor, Ray was past commodore and 15 time champion of Ensign Fleet 1. He leaves many dear, close friends and relatives and will be warmly remembered by them. Funeral -Wednesday, July 2, 1pm, Ballard Durand, 2 Maple Ave., White Plains, NY. FINK--Raymond. The Board of Governors, the Yacht Club Board and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Raymond Fink, and extend sincere condolences to his family. Abraham B. Stenberg, President Mark Ellman, Commodore

GOLDSTEIN--Wallace, at home on June 29, 2008. Beloved husband of Helen for 50 years. Adoring partner of Jessica Gray. Loving father of Melanie and Hal, and spouses Michael and Susie. Devoted brother of Beulah and brother-in-law of Elinor, Alan and Esther. Cherished grandfather of Jessi, Kimi, Joey, Tori, Samantha, and Reed. Dear cousin and uncle. Special member of Jessica's family. Close and loyal friend to many, and loved by all. Funeral at Congregation Kol Ami, White Plains, NY on Wednesday, July 2nd at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The American Cancer Society.

MINDLING--Ruth. Ruth, born in New York City, resided in Santa Monica, CA and Bennington, VT, died peacefully at 90 great years old. She had a wonderful full life and is survived by her beloved sister, Evelyn Dilloff of Boca Raton, FL, her loving son, Jim Mindling of Weston, CT, her beloved daughter, Toni M. Schulman of Los Angeles, CA, her beloved son-in-law, John A. Schulman, her three magnificent granddaughters Abby, Jessie and Natasha plus her two loved nieces, Leni and Nancy. She will be missed by all of them.

PECHTER--Morton H., November, 13, 1922-June 24, 2008, a business tycoon and later Hall of Fame, Underwater Photographer, adventure sports photojournalist, writer and book author passed away peacefully from respiratory failure on June 24, 2008. Pechter was the last remaining member of the original Pechter Baking Company and Harrison Baking Company, well-known for its Jewish Rye Bread and other baked goods products. In later years, when the Pechter Baking Company had been sold, Pechter turned to SCUBA diving and underwater photography, first as a hobby and later as a profession. His professional life as a photographer grew and he wrote and photographed for hundreds of magazines, joining the masthead designation on many. He became the ''official photographer'' for the Chris Evert Tennis Charities Event: for eight years for the Delray International Tennis Championships: for four years for the Air & Sea Show in Fort Lauderdale, Florida: and was the photographer for ''Raffi on Broadway'' and several other Broadway productions. He authored and photographed an award winning book, ''What's In The Deep?'' that was selected as a ''Reading Rainbow'' designated book. His many awards include: the 2003 NOGI for Distinguished Service from AUAS. (The Academy of Underwater Arts & Sciences); the 2008 Diver of the Year from Beneath the Sea; Director's award from the Balloon Federation of America and honored with election to the SSI Platinum Pro 5000 group in recognition of making over 5000 SCUBA dives and his work within the industry. He was elected a Fellow National member in the prestigious Explorers Club for his contribution to scientific knowledge in the field of geographical exploration. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Alese and his children: Dr. Stuart and Madeline Pechter; Dr. Richard and Robin Pechter; Dr. Jay and Roxanne Pechter, Juris Dr. Todd and Christine Pechter and his grandchildren, Nelson, Wyatt, Joseph, William, Patricia and Diana.

DRUSS--Ruth. NCJW New York Section mourns the passing of Ruth Druss, an esteemed Honorary Vice President who served many productive years and provided wise counsel to the Section. She will be missed. Sincerest condolences to her son Dr. Richard Druss and family. Beatrice Kahn, Co-Pres. Beth Mitchell, Co-Pres. Joan Shapiro-Green, Executive Director DRUSS--Ruth. Her colleagues at the Practising Law Institute (PLI) mourn the passing of Ruth L. Druss and send our condolences to her family. Ruth was a Program Attorney at PLI for more than 50 years, starting in 1947 until her retirement at the age of 92. She had many achievements over the years, but her singular achievement was helping to found and then shepherding PLI's Patent Bar Review Course which continues until this day. She was a consummate professional but had a New York insouciance which endeared her to her colleagues and the volunteer faculty with whom she worked. She was an inspiration to us all and she will be missed. Victor J. Rubino, President Practising Law Institute

BOLE--Theodore J., Jr., a highly respected expert in Expatriate Tax Administration and Planning, age 58, passed away peacefully June 23, 2008 at his home in Brooklyn. Born January 21, 1950, Ted received a BA from NYU and an MBA from Pace. Ted's service with PriceWaterhouseCoopers, Arthur Andersen and Ernst & Young included many overseas assignments. Ted's expertise was also valued as a Vice President at Chase Manhattan Bank. Ted served his clients with great dedication and was always caring and nurturing of his staff and friends. He will be greatly missed. He is survived by partner, Aaron Morishita, parents Theodore and Alma Bole, sisters, Alma Schmidt, Jane Briggs, Elizabeth Boaman, Elaine Bole-Baierlein and brothers, Robert J. Bole, Thomas W. Bole and David F. Bole.

Barbara and Marty Dymonds, Franks and Millers
STUCHINER--Leonard J. Beloved husband of Beverly, dear father of Richard (Patricia), Robert and Michael. Services today 10am at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd., Manhasset.

HOLLAND--Lila. We are heartbroken at the tragic and untimely passing of our dear friend Lila. So many good times are just a memory now. Rest peacefully sweet Lila. NIERENBERG--David Eli, age 90, on June 17, 2008 in Saratoga, CA after suffering from Alzheimer's and heart failure. Graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and Yale Law School. Served in the Navy in the Pacific theater. Practiced law with Bondy & Schloss in New York City and then also Chappaqua, where he resided for many years, co-founding the Chappaqua Orchestral Association and serving as elected New Castle Justice of the Peace. Named New Castle Citizen of the Year in 1962. Married to Joan Livingston Werblin (d. 2000), former Life Magazine Copy Chief. Survived by wife Joan Vinton Nierenberg of Saratoga; brother Theodore Nierenberg of Teaneck, NJ; daughters Wendy Nierenberg Gibney (and husband Robert) of Berkeley, CA, and Lorie Nierenberg of McLean, VA; son David W. Nierenberg (and wife Joan) of Lebanon, NH; stepsons Lewin, John, and Henry Vinton (and their families); six grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren (who knew him as ''Pops''), and many other loving family members. His passion for life, commitment to service, and love of family will be remembered always. Memorial services are being planned.

KASSAP--David, 80, passed away on June 29, 2008 after a brief battle with lung cancer. Mr. Kassap was a graduate of The City College of New York with a B.S. in Civil Engineering. He worked in the Marine and Heavy Construction Industry during his career which spanned 60 years, the last 18 years with The Parsons Group. Mr. Kassap was born on May 28, 1928 in NYC. He was married to Grace Davis Kassap for 46 years who passed away on February 17th, 2008. He is survived by his brother Burton, his three children Susanne, Grant and Jonathan, and his grandchildren Peter, Samantha and Elaina. Visitation Wednesday 5 - 9pm. Funeral Service Thursday 11am at ''Gutterman's Inc'', 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, L.I., NY.

GARDNER--Rhona. The members of Congregation B'nai Yisrael are saddened by the death of our friend, Rhona Gardner. We share our sadness with her devoted sons Matthew and Alexander. We will miss her resilient spirit, dignity and strength. Frederic J. Siegel, President Rabbi Douglas E. Krantz Rabbi Seth M. Limmer Cantor Hayley Kobilinsky

HAMMELBURGER--Ludwig. Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn Heights, NY mourns the passing of our beloved member, Ludwig Hammelburger. Our heartfelt condolences to his family. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas Susan Zelman, President

PILCH--Todd David 7/1/61--1/15/99. Happy Birthday in Heaven. I will never stop thinking about you and wondering if you are okay--that's what big sisters are for. We all missed you at both graduations. With all my love, Sue

PRITZ--Samuel P., D.D.S., Associate in Clinical Dental Medicine at the Columbia University College of Dental Medicine, passed away on June 28, 2008. Dr. Pritz received his D.D.S. from Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery (now the College of Dental Medicine) in 1933, and had a long career in general dentistry with a reputation of providing outstanding care to his many patients. He was a member of various dental organizations, including the American Dental Association and the First District Dental Society. A devoted alumnus and generous benefactor, Dr. Pritz served the College of Dental Medicine in many ways, and was most recently a member of the Admissions Committee. He was a friend and mentor to generations of dental students at Columbia. Our thoughts and prayers are extended to his daughter, Amy Pritz Kulick, son-in-law Roy Kulick, and grandson Richard Kulick. Ira B. Lamster, D.D.S., M.M.Sc., Dean Columbia University College of Dental Medicine

Childhood lead poisoning declined by 15 percent last year, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene reported on Wednesday, reaching the lowest rate ever recorded in New York City. The 2007 figure — 1,970 poisonings among children from 6 months to 6 years of age — marks a 90 percent decline since 1995, when nearly 20,000 children were identified with lead poisoning. Even low levels of lead poisoning can cause learning and behavior problems.

Brother Jay McGowan always found it hard to explain to New Yorkers just exactly what he did as a member of the Little Brothers of the Gospel. Other religious groups run schools, hospitals or parishes, managing staffs and budgets. The brothers in his tiny order — there are now only 71 members in the world — work with their hands and live among the poor in Brooklyn, bearing witness as Christians and neighbors.

A woman on the Lower East Side was struck and killed by a bus that kept on driving after the accident, according to witnesses at the scene, the police said. The woman was not immediately identified by name.

After eight months, the first of two 200-ton tunnel-boring machines has reached Grand Central Terminal, completing a journey that began more than a mile away, in the bedrock below 63rd Street and Second Avenue, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced on Wednesday.

Consolidated Edison and the union that represents nearly two-thirds of its workers agreed to a tentative four-year contract about 4:30 a.m. on Wednesday, ending a tense fight over wages, health care benefits and pensions, Ken Belson reports. The agreement helped avert what would have been the first strike in a quarter-century at Con Edison. But the path to the accord was contentious. Managers had been girding for duty in the event of a strike.

Ten or 11 months ago, I was stopped at a light in Prospect Heights in Brooklyn near a bunch of hole-in-the-wall-looking auto garages when I did a double-take at the vehicle that passed me by: a candy-apple red pedicab. A muscular, middle-aged man huffed away at the pedals and a thin woman with a floral headscarf sat in the back like some visiting dignitary, but with what looked like a sack of groceries beside her. It looked nothing at all like an official pedicab you’d see in Manhattan, and the woman was no tourist.I cranked the wheel around like the star of some cop movie and gave chase, losing him on a one-way street, finding him later parked outside a building. Maybe it was too much like a movie. I hopped out of the company Grand Am, and you could tell the pedicab driver was thinking: cop.

A 90-year-old Staten Island man was critically injured after two pit bulls attacked him. Adam Goldfarb is answering questions from City Room readers this week about dangerous dogs. Mr. Goldfarb is an issues specialist for companion-care animals at the Humane Society of the United States, the nation’s largest animal protection organization. The organization urges approaches that “look beyond a dog’s particular breed or bloodline into behavior and responsible pet ownership.” Mr. Goldfarb’s research has focused on the often dangerous practice of long-term chaining or tethering of dogs. He has testified at the state and community levels on this issue and advocated for chaining and tethering ordinances. A graduate of Tufts University, he joined the Humane Society in 2004. He previously was a volunteer at Lollypop Farm in Rochester.

A Brooklyn judge has ordered the removal of an 18-foot-tall, 200-foot-long metal fence that separates the Red Hook Recreation Area from the Henry Street Basin. City lawyers had argued that the fence was built illegally and impeded access to the Red Hook waterfront.

Much attention was given last week to an offer you can afford to refuse: a "free" digital TV converter box from an Ohio-based company called Universal TechTronics. As many writers pointed out, this supposedly free box, which will convert broadcast television signals from digital to analog for those with older TVs, actually costs close to $100. The gimmick: the box is free, as long as you pay $88 for a five-year warranty, plus $9.30 shipping.

Atul Malhotra joined Hewlett-Packard as a vice president in its printing division in May 2006. His employment ended four months later. In between he got himself into hot water with H.P., and, now, the federal government.

My Thursday column is about foreign aid, through the prism of Beatrice Biira, a Ugandan girl who was able to go to school because of a goat given to her family through Heifer International. For readers who want to help their own Beatrice, you can go to Heifer's on-line catalog and buy anything from honeybees to heifers for impoverished families abroad. Every Christmas, my parents buy my three children flocks of geese or chickens or ducks; the animals are donated in their name to needy families abroad. Sure my kids might prefer an I-Pod, but they recognize that geese are probably a better use of the cash.

MEXICO CITY - Senator John McCain Tuesday denied a recollection from Senator Thad Cochran, Republican of Mississippi, that he had roughly grabbed an associate of President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua and lifted him out of his chair during a trip to Central America in 1987."McCain was down at the end of the table and we were talking to the head of the guerrilla group here at this end of the table and I don't know what attracted my attention,'' Mr. Cochran said in an interview with the Sun Herald in Biloxi, Miss."But I saw some kind of quick movement at the bottom of the table and I looked down there and John had reached over and grabbed this guy by the shirt collar and had snatched him up like he was throwing him up out of the chair to tell him what he thought about him or whatever.''

4 Days to L'Étape. Today's training: a recovery ride of about an hour around the streets of Pau, the city where the Étape will begin on Sunday morning. It was my first ride in two weeks on really flat ground, and with great relief I discovered that I'm not as totally fried as I thought I'd be during the first miles I rode yesterday from Campan up toward the Col du Tourmalet. Riding the city streets today I realized that I've been doing so much climbing that I'd nearly forgotten how it feels to ride a bike on a flat stretch of road.

Alessandra Facchinetti showed her first haute couture collection tonight for Valentino. It was held in the Place Vendôme showroom of Valentino, a little more intimate than most places here. She did a great job. This collection was so much more interesting than her ready-to-wear show, and, of course, you might expect something a little higher up for couture. UPDATED 1:35 P.M.It's no big secret that the big tech news next week will be the July 11 release of the new iPhone. But it strikes me that the really big news is the App Store, which opens the same day. The van Meegeren case will never cease to fascinate people because it raises so many strange aesthetic issues. Han van Meegeren was a mediocre Dutch painter but a brilliant forger who, in the 1930s and early 1940s, painted six "Vermeers" that fooled practically everyone. One of his paintings, "Christ at Emmaus," became the most famous and admired "Vermeer" of its day. The hoax was revealed only when van Meegeren was thrown into prison for collaborating with the Germans during the occupation and confessed to the crime of forgery to avoid a charge of treason. Some experts never did accept the fact that he had forged the paintings they had endorsed.

The Kosk Pansiyon, a traditional guesthouse on the east coast of Cyprus, is the second-worst hotel I've ever stayed in. Dark and depressing, four creaky beds to a room, and an open-window "air-conditioning" system that wouldn't have been so bad if there had been a breeze - or, for that matter, a screen to keep the mosquitoes out. And let's not even discuss the toilets.

When I prepared 10 of today's 101 picnic items (which included a simple edamame salad -- see the video here) on this morning's "Today" show -- all in one place at one time -- I realized the value (for me, along with, I hope, for others), of really stretching things out, of trying to see what the experiences of years of cooking could come to when all applied to one exercise. In this case, how many good, fast, non-clichéd, transportable food items can you write down on a single page?

Our reporters know a lot about a lot, but the goal we've set for our Times Topic pages-to offer our readers the best about everything-is a pretty steep one, so we're experimenting with bringing in experts to help out. Take the Berlin airlift, for instance. On its 60th anniversary, we published a Times Topic page devoted to the historical event, which includes a Q&A with Andrei Cherny, who wrote "The Candy Bombers: The Untold Story of the Berlin Airlift and America's Finest Hour." There's a selection of recommended articles and books, as chosen by Cherny, not to mention a resource listing compiled by New York Times staff. Experts are also helping to build lists of resources, like on dark energy. On other pages, outsiders are offering background and analysis, as on Tibet, floods and even surfing, among others.

Syracuse University has acquired a major collection of 78 r.p.m. records from the family of a Manhattan dealer, giving the university what it says is the second-largest collection of 78s in the United States, after the Library of Congress’s. Doubling the holdings of 78s at the university’s Belfer Audio Laboratory and Archive, the collection of more than 200,000 records was donated by the family of Morton J. Savada, who ran the Records Revisited store on West 33rd Street in Manhattan for 29 years and died in February. Particularly strong in jazz and big bands, the Savada collection contains a wide swath of popular music from the first half of the 20th century, with country, blues, gospel, polka, folk, Broadway and Hawaiian music. It also has a strong selection of V-Disc records, which were produced for American military personnel overseas in the 1940s. Now in transit in 1,300 boxes, the collection will be cataloged once it reaches Syracuse, said Suzanne Thorin, the dean of libraries.

With its presentation of “Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg” this month, the annual Bayreuth festival in Germany, which celebrates the music of its founder, Richard Wagner, will offer streaming video and audio live on the Internet for $77, The Associated Press reported. Organizers said they hoped the online broadcast would draw new audiences to the festival, where tickets are so scarce that fans can wait seven years or more for the chance to buy them. “Those are complicated hoops,” said Katharina Wagner, a great-granddaughter of the composer, whose new staging of “Die Meistersinger,” above, had its premiere last summer. “But for those who only know Bayreuth by name, maybe they will say, ‘O.K., I’ll check it out if I can watch it at home on my laptop.’ ” The Metropolitan Opera in New York and La Scala in Milan have offered high-definition video at movie theaters, but at prices closer to $24. Alexander Busche, Bayreuth’s spokesman, said the price would offset the cost of filming and purchasing media rights. The premiere is on July 27; the video will be available for paid download at bayreuther-festspiele.de through Aug. 2.

With reruns on CBS and Fox leading the ratings on Monday, ABC’s reality dating series “The Bachelorette” kept that network in close contention. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 7.3 million viewers tuned in to “The Bachelorette,” putting ABC in the lead at 8 p.m. ahead of Fox’s “Bones” (6.7 million). At 9 p.m., a special “Men Tell All” episode of the dating show also fared well, winning its time slot among adults 18 to 49 despite trailing in total viewers (7.5 million) behind Fox’s “House” (8.1 million) and CBS’s sitcom reruns, including “Two and a Half Men” from 9 to 9:30 (8.4 million). Fox won the night in total viewers, and ABC and CBS tied for the lead among the 18-to-49 set. ABC might have won the night outright had it not lagged far behind with “The Mole” (3.9 million) at 10 p.m., a time slot CBS dominated with a repeat of “CSI: Miami” (8.1 million).

A nine-minute interview with Paul McCartney and John Lennon that languished in a damp London garage for 44 years was played on BBC Radio in Britain on Tuesday. The interview took place in London at the studios of Scottish Television on April 30, 1964, two months after the Beatles, right, returned from their first American tour. It was discovered among 64 unmarked, rusting cans by a film enthusiast, Richard Jeffs. The writing on the label was faint, but Mr. Jeffs was able to decipher the names of the two people who conducted the interview, the BBC reported. In the interview the two Beatles discuss their success, how they write songs and how they met as teenagers. “I was playing at a garden fete in the village where I lived just outside Liverpool playing with a skiffle group,” Lennon says. “And he came along, and that’s how we met.”.

Two Brooklyn arts organizations, BRIC Arts Media Brooklyn and Urban Glass, will be gaining space in the building they share in the BAM Cultural District thanks to a $17.3 million makeover, the groups announced. With the renovation of the basement and first floor of the Strand Theater on Fulton Street in Fort Greene, BRIC Arts, which presents visual and performing arts programs, including the Celebrate Brooklyn concert series, will gain 20,000 square feet for a gallery and performance space; Urban Glass, a glassmaking studio and school, will get gallery and retail space as well as a walk-in workshop. “It’s the first project that is really advancing the goals of indigenous arts groups that are already in the BAM Cultural District,” said Leslie Schultz, executive director of BRIC Arts. The center, designed by Leeser Architecture, , will be paid for by the mayor’s office, the city council and the office of the Brooklyn borough president.
A 1967 portrait by Francis Bacon fetched $27.4 million at Sotheby’s in London on Tuesday, becoming the 10th work by this artist to bring more than $25 million at auction in the last year and a half.

An Indonesian court has sentenced a museum curator and his accomplices to up to 18 months in jail for stealing and selling six ninth-century Hindu statues, Agence France-Presse reported. In November a routine inspection of the Radya Pustaka Museum in Solo on Java Island found that the stone statues had been stolen and replaced with fakes two years earlier. The museum curator, K. R. H. Dharmodipuro, was convicted of violating the Cultural Heritage Act and of embezzling state funds raised from the illegal sale of the pieces, the Antara news agency reported. Mr. Dharmodipuro said he would appeal the sentence, handed down Monday. Two other former museum workers received 14-month sentences for assisting the curator, and another man was given 18 months for buying stolen property and fraud. The statues were found in the Jakarta home of the businessman Hashim Djojohadikusumo, who has not been charged with any crime.
