LANG--Theresa. The trustees, faculty, students, and staff of The Rockefeller University community deeply mourn the loss of our cherished friend Theresa Lang, an esteemed member of the Board of Trustees for more than two decades. Terry Lang joined The Rockefeller University Council in 1984 and was elected to the Board in 1986. She was named an honorary member of the staff of The Rockefeller University Hospital, in recognition of her leadership as chairman of the Board's Hospital Committee. The Theresa and Eugene M. Lang Professorship, which Terry's beloved husband established in her honor, reflects their shared passion for scientific inquiry and belief that basic research can provide answers to the unsolved questions of human health and disease. Terry will be remembered for her numerous philanthropic and pro bono activities, including her service to hospital patients and their families as a volunteer in several New York medical institutions. She put into action her conviction that there is a natural kinship between biomedical science and medical care, and that each has much to learn from the other. As a philanthropist, as a knowledgeable advocate for physicians and their patients, as a dedicated trustee, and as an exemplary wife and mother, Terry made the world a better place. She will be greatly missed. Our deepest condolences are sent to Gene; their children, Jane, David, and Stephen; and her entire family. Paul Nurse, President Russell Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus Torsten Wiesel, President Emeritus Barry Coller, Physician-in-Chief Jules Hirsch and Attallah Kappas, Physicians-in-Chief Emeriti Jeffrey Ravetch, Theresa and Eugene M. Lang Professor LANG--Theresa. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the passing of Theresa Lang, beloved wife of Eugene Lang, whose commitment and generosity strengthens our ability to serve those in need. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Eugene, to the couple's children, to their grandchildren, and to the entire Lang family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO LANG--Theresa. The Board of Directors and share holders of Fifth 912 Corp., 912 Fifth Avenue, mourn the passing of Theresa Lang, beloved wife of fellow board member Eugene Lang and wish to express their condolences to the family. Board of Directors LANG--Theresa. The trustees, faculty and staff of The New School are deeply saddened by the death of Theresa Lang, beloved wife of our dear Trustee Eugene Lang. Together with Gene, Terry brought passionate devotion and a zealous commitment to our students and university. Her warmth and affectionate style will remain in our hearts and halls forever. We extend our deepest condolences to Gene and their children Jane, Stephen and David, and their families. Bob Kerrey, President, The New School Julien J. Studley, Chair, Board of Trustees Neil Gordon, Dean, Eugene Lang College The New School for Liberal Arts LANG--Theresa, died peacefully in her sleep on June 30, 2008 in her New York home. Beloved wife for more than 62 years of Eugene M. Lang, she was the adored mother of and survived by, her children Jane, David and Stephen, their spouses Paul, Belinda (former) and Kristina; by her grandchildren Lucy, Daniel, Noah, Grace, Jessica, Benjamin, Joanna and Jacob; by her great - grandchildren Maitlynne, Alexander, Teddy, Thomas and Erin; by her great-nieces Charlotte, Lily and Daisy; by her sister-inlaw Barbara; and by many dear friends. Theresa-Terry as she was known-was a rare human being. Kind, sincere and generous, she represented the nobility of compassionate service, the sterling qualities of friendship and the profound meaning of family. Daughter of Albert and Lucy Volmar, she was born in 1918 in Greenpoint, NYC. She graduated from Jamaica High School in 1936 and, in 1997, at the age of 79, she graduated from Marymount-Manhattan College with a B.A. to which, as a Trustee of the college, she added an honorary L.H.D. degree early this year. The Theresa Lang Theater and the Theresa Lang Scholarship fund at MarymountManhattan will continue to recognize her cherished college relationship. Terry's lifelong commitment to volunteer service began in 1942, when employed as an executive secretary in a Long Island aircraft parts factory, she volunteered to serve as a nurse's aid on evenings and weekends at the Queens General Hospital, After the war, she transferred her voluntarism to the New York Hospital-Queens (then the Booth Memorial Hospital) and continued her service, uninterrupted by her marriage to Eugene in early 1946, throughout her life. She joined the hospital's Women's Auxiliary, became its president and since 1975, a hospital Trustee. This lifetime relationship is memorialized by the NYH-Q's Theresa Lang Emergency Pediatric Clinic, Ambulatory Pediatric Clinic, Auditorium and Center for Research and Education. In 1975, Terry joined the New York City Visiting Committee of the United Hospital fund, became its chair and, in 2008, was named Hospital Trustee of the Year. In 1986, she became a Trustee of Rockefeller University and chaired its Hospital Committee. She also served on the Boards of he New York City Opera, Roundabout Theater, and the Hunter College Foundation. She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club. Family will receive friends on Wednesday 6:30-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday at 10am at St. Jean Baptiste Catholic Church, Lexington Ave. at E. 76th St. Interment will follow at Kensico Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Theresa and Eugene M. Lang Center for Research and Education at the New York Hospital-Queens or the Theresa Lang Scholarship Fund at MarymountManhattan College.

DRIX--Samuel, Dr., 96, Holocaust survivor and author of ''Witness to Annihilation'' (Brassey's 1994), passed away from pneumonia on May 22, 2008 in Ithaca, NY. He is survived by his son Severin in Valois, New York. A full obit can be viewed at IthacaJournal.com.

A capsule summary on June 20 about a slide show on Mumbai, India, at nytimes.com/travel, misidentified an accompanying picture. It was the Gateway of India, which extends into Mumbai harbor -- not India Gate, which is in New Delhi.

Heading to the Democratic National Convention in Denver in August and want to ensure that you will rub shoulders with governors, senators and other movers and shakers? Nancy Jacobson, a Democratic fund-raiser and the wife of the Democratic pollster Mark Penn, is organizing a ''by invitation only'' event with candidates, policy makers and others. The price tag is $10,000. That amount will allow access to a four-day conference at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel that will run concurrent with the convention. Designed to mix policy and politics, the conference will also offer a little star power, with Kevin Spacey and Laura Dern, who starred in the HBO film ''Recount,'' about the 2000 presidential vote in Florida, scheduled to appear.

KRAYTON--Lillian, of Yorktown Heights, NY left us all too soon on Tuesday July 1, 2008. She was born on September 7, 1923 in New York City and spent her almost 85 years in the New York area-58 of those years with the love of her life, her husband, Jack Krayton, who passed away in 2004. Lillian is survived by her daughters Sheri Saidel (Marc) and Marcia Goldstein (Ron), her grandchildren, Jenna Lebowich (Michael), Daria Prusky (Andrew), Eric Saidel, and Jesse Goldstein, and her five greatgrandchildren--the lights of her life--Eliana Saidel, Marina Lebowich, Alex Prusky, Sara Saidel, and Olivia Prusky. Throughout her long career as a New York City public school teacher, Lillian touched the lives of many children in the South Bronx and Co-op City. She was loved and respected by her students and teachers alike. Her life was enriched by her love of learning, travel, the arts, her devotion to the New York Times crossword puzzles, and by any other intellectual challenges she met. Her generosity and concern for social issues, both large and small, left an indelible mark on all who knew her. A funeral service will be held on Thursday, July 3, 2008 at 12 noon at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, NY, followed by burial at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. If she were asked, Lillian would welcome contributions in her memory to the Susan B. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation, Public Radio or Television, Brandeis Women, the Barack Obama campaign, or any charity of your choice.

The National Rifle Association will pour $40 million into an advertising campaign timed to the fall presidential election, with more than a third of the money devoted to attacking Senator Barack Obama on the issue of gun rights. The group plans to run advertisements on television and radio and in print in closely contested states throughout the Midwest and the Mountain West, and focus on its four million members with telephone calls and direct mailings. News of the association's campaign was first reported by Politico.com.

Denver has promised to make its nearly 4,000 homeless people comfortable during the Democratic National Convention in August, enlisting private donations for extra hours at local shelters, flat-screen televisions tuned to cable news and bingo games in the evenings. Such accommodations will not be offered to the dozens of groups planning to protest the convention, who have complained that they are being forced to protest from fenced enclosures -- ''freedom cages,'' they call them -- well out of earshot of the convention site.

An editorial on June 20 about the Honda FCX Clarity, a new hydrogen-powered fuel-cell car, stated incorrectly that it has a bigger carbon footprint than the Toyota Prius. The Clarity's greenhouse gas emissions, including those from making and transporting the fuel, are about 9 percent to 17 percent lower than the Prius's.

The Red Sox face the Yankees in a four-game series starting tonight, but in an odd twist it turns out to be Boston’s second-most important series of the week. The Red Sox just finished three games with the Tampa Bay Rays, the team with the best record in baseball and one they’ve been chasing in the standings for most of the season. Does Tampa’s ascendancy steal any of the luster of the Boston-New York rivalry?

Steel is at the heart of any romantic view of construction in New York (at least before the recent crane accidents): slender columns and beams rising from the ground at improbable speed to scrape the sky and delineate a building’s future form. But the widespread disruption caused by the unexpected strike of concrete-truck drivers is a reminder of the critical — if less romantic — role of concrete.

Today's training: a light ride of less than an hour on flat ground, mainly circuits along both sides of a wide boulevard in Pau with little traffic, a wide bike lane and men playing boules on the "boulodrome" in the center strip of park between the two sides of the road. After a protest group gained prominence on Senator Barack Obama's own campaign Web site, the candidate has written a response to those who object to his support for the current compromise legislation in the Senate on immunity for telecoms. The long note explaining his position appeared on his campaign Web site this afternoon, and several of his policy staff members answered questions in the comments section for about 90 minutes. Though Mr. Obama did not change his position in response to supporters' objections, the mere fact of his response, as well as the choice to put it on his own site, is a remarkable illustration of the power of online organizing.

The case against organic perfumes is vast and twofold. The first objection involves art. Perfume as an art form (and as a commercial concern) is built on synthetic raw materials. Of course, so are architecture (wood and adobe are nice, but Renzo Piano's work, for example, relies on advanced polymers and metal alloys), painting (most pigments these days are born in the laboratory, and colors that are unnatural, in all senses, are crucial to painting today), and music (the electronic manipulation of voices etc).

[UPDATE, 7/7: Tropical Storm Bertha became Hurricane Bertha on Monday. The latest model runs have it rumbling toward Bermuda but possibly then curving north away from coasts. Image will be updated periodically.] The first Atlantic Ocean tropical storm of the season is on the march, but does not appear likely to pose a coastal threat, forecasters say. This Atlantic hurricane season is projected by government and private forecasters to be around normal or a bit above, largely because of persistent warmth in tropical seas, and with a lack of the wind patterns in El Niño years that can cut off the tops of forming hurricanes.

Some members of Congress are rightly agitated about Mississippi's shameful attempt to hijack Hurricane Katrina aid -- which should have been spent on affordable housing for the poor -- for a $600 million expansion of the Port at Gulfport. The Port expansion short changes the neediest Mississippians and has nothing to do with storm damage. It's actually a pet development project, conceived well before the storm, that should have been paid for through bonds and other means.

The Red Sox face the Yankees in a four-game series starting tonight, but in an odd twist it turns out to be Boston's second-most important series of the week. The Red Sox just finished three games with the Tampa Bay Rays, the team with the best record in baseball and one they've been chasing in the standings for most of the season. Does Tampa's ascendancy steal any of the luster of the Boston-New York rivalry?

This holiday weekend, many travelers will get a first-hand look at the extreme measures that airlines are taking to raise revenue, cut costs and just remain in the air in these times of mind-bogglingly high jet fuel prices. They are charging passengers for bags, grounding inefficient aircraft and reducing their work force, all in an effort to find crumbs of hidden value.

France's Euro 2008 postmortem is over.
